It's good to talk. But it's much better to sling abuse. That's the maxim the Fiver has followed since it ruled the playground with an iron fist (in a velvet glove, mind). Martin O'Neill shares a similar belief, manfully labelling Ken Bates a "footballing cretin" after his Foxy Foxes had been knocked out of the Cup by Chelsea yesterday. But respectable chairman Kuddly Ken wouldn't stoop to such levels himself. Would he?

"It takes one to know one," was Bates's response today, observing a philosophical truth that underpins much of what we call Western civilisation. Having started the whole affair by accusing Leicester of playing kick and rush, the much-loved Chelsea chairman didn't want to continue this name-calling any further. So he went on: "It seems to me that O'Neill is losing his Mr Clean image." If all that takes is the use of the word cretin, then God help Martin Bell.

What happens next in this increasingly vicious exchange of words remains to be seen. Perhaps the pair will sort things out maturely. Perhaps the FA and their disciplinary body (lean, honed and with fantastic buttocks) will be called in. Or perhaps O'Neill will be able to prove once and for all that Kuddly is nothing more than a poo poo stinky pants. The Fiver shall wait and see.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I had a couple of friends in the stand and they rang my wife Lorraine to say I was alright." Bleeding hero Paul Merson on his moment of terror. Was it just the Fiver, or were you reminded of that scene in Pulp Fiction?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

CLARIDGE CLASS

Imagine you're a striker who's been around a bit, scored a winner in a Worthington Cup final, and not unfamiliar with the term 'journeyman pro'. In fact, imagine you're Steve Claridge. Imagine also that you've placed a highly illegal £250 bet on your team winning at the weekend and, thanks to a hat-trick scored by yourself, you clean up. What would be the first thing you'd do after breaking all the rules in football? That's right, you'd tell the press about it.

After struggling Portsmouth's 3-0 first division win over third placed Barnsley on Saturday, an understandably jubilant Claridge revealed he was "disgusted" at the odds on a Portsmouth victory offered by local bookies Flutters. "When you look at the odds, we were something like 7/2 or 3/1 for a home win, I think that's an insult to us" he said, adding, "We've all had a good bet on it and won a few bob."

Hurrah. But thanks to the immediacy of the media, it wasn't long before those spoilsports at the FA found out, and reliable spokesperson Steve Double was wheeled out to spew some invective. "Nobody connected directly with the game is permitted to bet on football, full-stop. That means players, managers and coaching staff. We will be making enquiries about this later this week and we will be speaking to Steve Claridge."

Speaking today, Steve was less cock-a-hoop. "I didn't know we had done anything wrong - we were all backing ourselves to win the game," said Steve proving that footballers aren't only motivated by a love of the sport. "It was just a bit of fun," he went on, dropping to his knees and hugging the reporter. "We made a bit of money but we're not going to be able to retire on it - let's not turn this into something it's not." Imagine once again that you're Steve Claridge. Would you be appealing to the FA for common sense?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

HUGGER MUGGER

Football's Mr Inclined To Psychological Warfare John Gregory knows a thing or two about showing appreciation where appreciation is due. After mercilessly mocking Gareth Southgate for scoring the goals that saved his job, Gregory yesterday described how the best of Benito Carbone's three FA cup tie-winning efforts yesterday would "usually end up in the Holte End".

What's more Gregory is in no hurry to sign the loveable little Italian up beyond the end of the season. According to Greg discussions on a new contract are like two dogs meeting in a park: "We're just having a look at each other and seeing if we like each other. We're in no rush." Beni however is already on to the arse-sniffing stage, so to speak. While he mainly gave the credit for yesterday's hat-trick to his lucky blue boots ("I was lying in bed the other night thinking about the game coming up with Leeds when I suddenly remembered an old pair of boots I had in the cupboard. I got up and went and found them and they felt good as soon as I touched them. I really love the boots") he was also full of praise for the team ("I really love them").

So are Beni and Gregory ever destined to chase each other's tail? According to Greg, if Beni repeats his dazzling performance against Leeds, he "won't let him out of the ground". And as Stan Collymore can vouch, once you're locked in Gregory's loving embrace at fortress Villa Park, there is no easy escape.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Brazilian striker Jardel has gone on record to declare his interest in playing for Leeds. Porto's record-breaking forward told the press: "Leeds are having a great season, they are going for the Premiership title. I am pleased to know about their interest at Elland Road in my qualities."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Confusion reigns over Muzzy Izzet's international future. According to reports on the Reuters newswire Izzet has decided to play for Turkey in Euro 2000. "I've made up my mind to play for Turkey," the report quotes the Leicester midfielder as saying, "I'm looking forward it it, as long as I get it in writing and confirmed properly." However, the official Foxes website quotes Izzet as saying he will not make a decision until after Wednesday's Worthington Cup semi-final second leg tie with Aston Villa.

Charlton Athletic will not be relocating to the Millennium Dome site. PLC chairman Richard Murray said "The board has fully evaluated the financial aspects of building a new stadium on the Greenwich Peninsula and the projected cost of £42million and the absence of significant grant aid made the project financially unattractive."

Blackpool striker Martin Aldridge has died following a car crash. Aldridge, who was on loan at Rushden and Diamonds, was travelling in a Peugeot which collided with a BMW on the A45 near Wellingborough in Northamptonshire on Saturday evening.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC 1: Match of the Day (10.40pm) Highlights of Blackburn v Newcastle. Why they couldn't wait until Football Focus, we don't know.

ITV: Football extra (12.30 or 12.35am depending on your region thing) More goals per hour than any other programme, and that's guaranteed.

Channel 5: Argentinian football: Boca Juniors v River Plate (4.20am) Didn't we have this one last week. Not that we actually saw it of course.

Sky Sports 1: Western Union football (6.30pm) Tragically not the game as played by cowboys, but a new corporate name for Fut of the Mund.
You're on Sky Sports! (10.15pm) Perhaps McCaff could get a corporate sponsor. Rentokil for example.
Football League review (11pm) Brought to you in association with the Arts Council.

Sky Sports 2: FA Cup football - live (7pm) Blackburn v Newcastle. It's got its own special mOTd so it must be good.

Eurosport: African Nations Cup (8pm) Ghana v Ivory Coast or Cameroon v Togo or Yak-lifting from Zurich.
Eurogoals (10pm) All the goals that matter, apart from those Eurosport don't have the rights for - which is pretty much all of them.

Radio 5 Live: Live football (8pm) But there's a motD to cover this game Alan, why are you bothering?

webTitle: Shipman was sacked for drug abuse

fields.headline: Shipman was sacked for drug abuse
fields.trailText: Harold Shipman was sacked  from a West Yorkshire practice in the 1970s for falsifying more than 70 prescriptions to feed his drug addiction.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman was sacked from a West Yorkshire practice in the 1970s for falsifying more than 70 prescriptions to feed his drug addiction.

Shipman, who had joined a practice at Todmorden health centre, West Yorkshire, injected the pain-killing drug pethidine, which is normally used to help women in labour, into his arms and legs. He said he took to using the drug while suffering from depression caused by opposition to his ideas for improving the practice.

His habit came to light after it became obvious that some patients were being prescribed large amounts of the drug.

Shipman was admitted to hospital. It was realised that the doctor, who had been injecting himself for six months, had a serious medical problem. He saw a psychiatrist and spent time in a treatment centre.

Shipman appeared before Halifax magistrates in February 1976, admitting eight charges of obtaining a drug by deception, and asking for 67 similar offences, and seven of forgery, to be taken into consideration.

He was fined a total of £600 and ordered to pay compensation to the NHS.

Magistrate Dr Maurice Goldin told Shipman, then aged 30: "It is indeed a very sad case - that almost at the beginning of your career you should find yourself in this position."

Shipman told detectives who questioned him after the discrepancies were discovered that he was in the habit of taking 600 to 700 milligrams of pethidine a day, and was taking more and more as he became increasingly depressed.

He would give parts of some prescriptions to the patient and keep some for his own use. On some occasions none of the drug went to the patient for whom it was apparently intended.

The court was told that drug squad officers were satisfied that he had not deprived any patients of drugs they needed, and had not illegally supplied drugs to anyone else.

Shipman's partnership in the clinic was terminated and he obtained a job in Durham in which where there was no need for him to have access to drugs.

fields.headline: 'A tragic and deeply disturbing case'
fields.standfirst: Quotes from the trial
fields.trailText: "The allegations could not be more serious - a doctor accused of murdering 15 patients ... You will have heard evidence which may have aroused feelings of anger, strong disapproval, disgust, profound dismay or deep sympathy." Mr Justice Forbes, summing up
fields.body:
"The allegations could not be more serious - a doctor accused of murdering 15 patients ... You will have heard evidence which may have aroused feelings of anger, strong disapproval, disgust, profound dismay or deep sympathy." Mr Justice Forbes, summing up

Dr Shipman

"He was exercising the ultimate power of controlling life and death and repeated the act so often he must have found the drama of taking life to his taste." Richard Henriques QC, prosecuting.

"No patient had to register with Dr Shipman, but the fact that so many did must mean some inferences can be drawn. With a list size of 3,100, well above the national average, Dr Shipman must have been doing something right." Nicola Davies QC, defending.

His strategy

"As they grieved, this determined man employed every device to make sure no postmortem examination took place. The poisoner, of course, fears the pathologist. He fears ambulances and he fears hospitals." Richard Henriques QC, prosecuting.

The patients

Ivy Lomas, 63: "He said she was a nuisance. He was laughing. He said he considered her such a nuisance he thought about having part of the seating area reserved permanently for Ivy Lomas and mounting a plaque to the effect `Seat reserved permanently for Ivy Lomas'." Detective Sergeant Philip Reade, called to the surgery after Mrs Lomas's death in May 1997.

Joan Melia, 73: "I believe she died from lobar pneumonia. A small percentage of elderly women die very quickly."

Pamela Hillier, 68: "I can remember coming out of the surgery feeling guilty. He was trying to intimate that mum was poorly and we should have expected that she might have died at any time." Jacqueline Gee, daughter.

Muriel Grimshaw, 76: " I don't think I can draw any other reasonable conclusion other than Mrs Grimshaw died from the toxicological affect of morphine." Home office pathologist Dr John Rutherford.

Irene Turner, 67: "Dr Shipman said that due to the number of tablets that she was on, he would not need a post mortem and that he would be able to issue a death certificate the next day." Michael Wodruff, Mrs Turner's son-in-law.

Kathleen Grundy and the £400,000 will

"He came to where Kathleen was lying on the sofa and felt her hand for a pulse. I asked what was the matter and he said 'Cardiac arrest'." - John Green, caretaker of the day centre where Mrs Grundy ran a luncheon club.

"I became very concerned. It was badly typed and my mother was meticulously tidy. The whole thing was just unbelievable, leaving everything to her doctor. It was inconceivable the thought of her signing a document which was badly typed." Angela Woodruff, daughter, on the £400,000 will.

"She thought he was a good doctor. She admired his work. All his patients thought highly of Dr Shipman, not just Mrs Grundy." Her friend, May Clarke, 91.

"Taking the evidence into account my opinion is that the two signatures were not written by Kathleen Grundy. Rather they are poor, crude simulations, forgeries, of her signature, written by some other person." Handwriting expert Michael Allen.

The families

"Their relatives trusted him to tell the truth about the circumstances in which his patients died. The community trusted him to keep records and documentation with insight and knowledge. He did not care at all for these 15 patients he killed." Richard Henriques QC, prosecuting.

fields.headline: The role of toxicology
fields.trailText:
What is toxicology?
Toxicology is the scientific study of poisons and how they affect living tissue. Forensic toxicology is carried out by pathologists to try to establish the cause of death during post-mortems.
fields.body:
What is toxicology?
Toxicology is the scientific study of poisons and how they affect living tissue. Forensic toxicology is carried out by pathologists to try to establish the cause of death during post-mortems.

How is it involved in the Shipman murder trial?
Dr Shipman was alleged to have killed 15 women by injecting them with morphine and diamorphine (heroin). Traces of the substance were found in the bodies of several of these women. The defence barrister, Nicola Davies QC, told the court that the case against Dr Shipman relied on toxicology. 'Without it there would be no case,' she added. Toxicology was a 'new science' which was 'untested by proven scientific methods'.

Julie Evans, the forensic scientist who analysed the levels of morphine found in some of the victims' bodies, submitted evidence to the court. Mrs Evans said that a 'substantial amount' of the drug was found in samples taken from the thigh and liver of Kathleen Grundy. Samples taken from the bodies of other alleged victims Bianka Pomfret, Winifred Mellor, Joan Melia, Ivy Lomas, Marie Quinn, Irene Turner, Jean Lilley and Muriel Grimshaw also revealed morphine. The other bodies were cremated.

Didn't that prove that it was an injection of morphine - which only Dr Shipman could have administered - that killed them?
Not according to the defence. Mrs Evans admitted that the science involved was 'novel'. She also accepted that the levels of morphine found in the bodies might not be an accurate reflection of the levels at the time of death, since decomposition had occurred. Miss Davies described this as a 'crucial and damning concession'. Since it could not be proved that Dr Shipman had administered a fatal dose of diamorphine, it was perfectly possible that his patients had experienced an adverse reaction to the drug or died from some other cause. The doctor himself said that he suspected Mrs Grundy of being addicted to morphine.

The prosecution counsel, Mr Henriques QC, pointed out that Dr Shipman had visited each patient on the day she died. The defence countered that this demonstrated his dedication to his job.

So how reliable is toxicological evidence?
According to Dr Robert Anderson of Glasgow university's forensic toxicology department, where half a dozen pathologists deal with about 1200 bodies each year, 'it depends on what's happened to the body after death. Usually morphine is relatively stable after death, and it wouldn't decompose very quickly.'

However, other factors can come into play. 'Sometimes there is no trace of a poison in the blood because it killed the person too quickly. A heroin addict found dead with a needle sticking out of his arm is an example - sometimes there's no trace of the drug at post-mortem. However, if the person lived long enough [after the morphine was administered] for the blood to get into circulation, it should be present.'

He refuted the accusation that toxicology was a new science. 'A lot of the forensic departments which do toxicology started when scientists came back from France in the early 19th century. Glasgow's department was founded in 1830.' Matthieu Orfila (1787-1853), was the first person to systematise the study and classification of toxic substances when he found traces of poison in the liver of a dead dog.

'Toxicology is not an new science,' said Dr Anderson. What's new is that things are better understood.'

'Toxicology is not an new science,' said Dr Anderson. What's new is that things are better understood.' fields.headline: Inside Preston crown court
fields.standfirst: Helen Carter, who attended the Shipman trial, describes the proceedings
fields.trailText: Harold Shipman, the bearded and bespectacled family doctor, sat through four months of evidence at Preston crown court and spent much of the time listening intently or furiously taking notes.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman, the bearded and bespectacled family doctor, sat through four months of evidence at Preston crown court and spent much of the time listening intently or furiously taking notes.

In the oak-panelled courtroom with its brass-railed dock, the 54-year-old GP from Mottram, near Hyde, Greater Manchester, was accused of being Britain's most prolific serial killer.

He faced 15 charges that he murdered his women patients, aged between 49 and 81, and forged the £386,000 will of one of them, former Hyde mayoress Kathleen Grundy, a wealthy widow who lived alone.

Throughout the trial, Shipman remained convinced of his own innocence, though few agreed with him as the evidence unfolded in court one.

He denied that he knew anything about the deaths of the 15 women, despite a barrage of evidence which suggested otherwise.

No, he did not inject any of the women with morphine. Yes, he had called ambulances, despite grieving relatives' evidence to the contrary. No, he had not forged the will of Kathleen Grundy, but she had occasionally borrowed his battered Brother typewriter from the surgery.

When the time came for him to give evidence, the trial had to be adjourned twice as he broke down.

Once while giving evidence about one of the murders, Shipman was so overcome by emotion that he began to cry. Then, several days later when prosecution counsel Richard Henriques QC rose to cross-examine him, he looked across at the judge, Mr Justice Forbes, and muttered: "I don't feel well." The trial was adjourned once more.

Shipman's voice appeared shaky when he started to give evidence and he apologised for his slurred speech, which he blamed on the tablets he was taking.

A hushed courtroom listened in disbelief as he outlined his suspicion that Kathleen Grundy, 81, had been abusing drugs, although she had denied it.

The public gallery was often filled with Dr Shipman's former patients, friends and family as well as those who were merely curious about how a seemingly unassuming GP could murder 15 patients.

Shipman's wife Primrose was there in the front row every day, loyally supporting her husband. Occasionally their four children were in court next to her.

On several occasions Mrs Shipman smiled wanly at her husband as he was led away from the dock into the cells.

On the first day of the trial, the pensioners and middle-aged men and women in the public gallery remained silent as the charges against the doctor were read out. Throughout the trial they queued to watch Britain's most prolific serial killer deny murdering any of his patients.

But after four months of evidence, nobody seemed any the wiser as to why the apparently normal GP had become a mass murderer.

fields.headline: Denial upon falsehood upon deceit
fields.standfirst: Helen Carter, who was in court during the trial, unpicks the web of lies spun by Harold Shipman
fields.trailText: No real motive ever emerged during the trial of Harold Shipman as to why a respected family doctor, with 3,100 patients, would systematically kill 15 of his patients and then claim they had each died a natural death.
fields.body:
No real motive ever emerged during the trial of Harold Shipman as to why a respected family doctor, with 3,100 patients, would systematically kill 15 of his patients and then claim they had each died a natural death.

In all but one of the cases the murders seemed so pointless. None of the victims was wealthy. Shipman had nothing to gain from killing them. The only exception was when he clumsily forged the will of wealthy former mayoress Kathleen Grundy, making himself the only beneficiary of her £386,000 fortune. In all the other cases, there was no obvious reason why he killed his patients.

The only clue to his murderous behaviour emerged at the opening of the trial, when prosecuting counsel Richard Henriques QC suggested that Shipman killed the 15 women because he enjoyed doing so.

"He was exercising the ultimate power of controlling life and death," he told Preston crown court. "He repeated it so often that he must have found the drama of taking life to his taste."

Shipman, a married father of four, had practised in the Hyde area since 1977 and he had run a solo practice there since 1992.

He had been stockpiling diamorphine for eight years from patients for whom he prescribed the drug. Then he injected lethal doses of diamorphine into the arms of 15 of his patients, killing them almost instantly.

His first victim was Maria West, whom he murdered in 1995. He struck once in 1996, before murdering seven patients in 1997 and six more in the first six months of 1998.

During police interviews, Shipman was consistent in the lies he told. In three cases, he claimed that the women had phoned the surgery in Market Street, Hyde, complaining of chest pains. Telephone records showed that no such calls had been made.

He told relatives that he had called ambulances, but further checks of phone records showed this to be false. Shipman altered his patients' medical records so it would appear that the women had chronic health problems, to support the false cause of death he printed on death certificates.

In police interviews, he denied stockpiling diamorphine and said that he did not keep the drug or carry it. Yet again he was tripped up when a carrier bag full of the drug was found in his house.

Lie after lie was exposed by the prosecution, but in court Shipman continued to protest his innocence.

The court heard how Shipman killed his first victim, Maria West, minutes after she had made a cup of tea for her friend Marion Hadfield. He seemed surprised when he walked into the kitchen and found Mrs Hadfield standing there quietly.

He took another risk when he murdered Ivy Lomas in his surgery and proceeded to treat three more patients before announcing that she had died. He later joked with a police sergeant who was called to the surgery that he considered Mrs Lomas such a nuisance that part of the seating should be reserved for her.

In the end he was exposed by his sheer arrogance. But why he changed from caring doctor to cold-hearted serial killer is an enduring mystery.

webTitle: Irving not anti-semitic, claims US professor

fields.headline: Irving not anti-semitic, claims US professor
fields.standfirst: Kevin MacDonald's homepage
fields.trailText: An American professor today told the high court Holocaust libel trial that he did not consider controversial historian David Irving to be anti-semitic.
fields.body:
An American professor today told the high court Holocaust libel trial that he did not consider controversial historian David Irving to be anti-semitic.

Author Kevin MacDonald, professor of psychology at California State University, was giving evidence on Mr Irving's behalf during his damages action against American academic Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books over a claim that he is a "Holocaust denier".

Mr Irving, the 62-year-old author of Hitler's War, asked Prof MacDonald, who has written books on Judaism and anti-semitism: "Do you consider me to be an anti-semite?"

Prof MacDonald replied: "I do not consider you to be an anti-semite. I have had quite a few discussions with you and you almost never mentioned Jews - never in the general negative way."

Prof MacDonald also said he had never heard Mr Irving express any anti-semitic beliefs.

During the trial in London before Mr Justice Gray, who is hearing the lengthy case without a jury, Mr Irving has been accused by Richard Rampton QC, for Prof Lipstadt and Penguin Books, of making "grossly anti-semitic" statements.

Mr Irving has vehemently denied an allegation by the defendants that he has made statements "designed to feed the virulent anti-semitism" still alive and kicking throughout the world today.

Mr Irving is seeking damages over Prof Lipstadt's 1994 book, Denying The Holocaust: The Growing Assault On Truth And Memory which he says alleges he has distorted statistics and documents to serve his own ideological purposes and reach historically untenable conclusions.

Mr Irving says Prof Lipstadt's book has generated "waves of hatred" against him. The defendants have accused him of being "a liar and a falsifier of history".

Mr Irving rejects the claim that he is a Holocaust denier. He does question the number of Jewish dead and denies the systematic extermination of the Jews in concentration camps.

webTitle: Great name, good ads, plenty hype, flop

fields.headline: Great name, good ads, plenty hype, flop
fields.trailText: It might be paranoia, but I can't seem to get away from these voices telling me to use the internet. They are everywhere - on posters, when I switch on the radio, on TV and in the paper. It is getting too much for me to take in. I believe there is even a medical term for my problem: "dot com-fusion".
fields.body:
It might be paranoia, but I can't seem to get away from these voices telling me to use the internet. They are everywhere - on posters, when I switch on the radio, on TV and in the paper. It is getting too much for me to take in. I believe there is even a medical term for my problem: "dot com-fusion".

The past year has seen a dizzying blur of internet companies desperate to grab our attention. According to Media Monitoring Services in 1999, they spent some £68m trying to do it - not an enormous amount in absolute terms, but impressive nonetheless given that it is all new money.

This year, that £68m is likely to be doubled if not trebled. Dozens of start-ups and new internet operations are now happily spending the money they fought so hard to raise last year, and there is scarcely an internet venture in town that is not planning to spend £2-3m over the next 12 months, with plenty of others planning to spend £10m or more (last year's biggest spender was Freeserve at £9.25m).

A quick scan of this week's media trade press gives a fair reflection of the current dot com advertising frenzy. In Media Week's list of recent advertising account wins, for example, six out of 14 most recent wins are internet companies - representing some £48m spending, and in pretty much every case they are companies that did not exist two years ago.

Now this surge is both good and bad. The good side is that pretty much every bit of advertising for every internet company is good for the medium as a whole. It is as if there is a huge mass of marketing talent currently dedicated to getting the 80% of the population that is not online to make the leap. Even the dot com-fusion caused by the sheer deluge of advertising messages is OK. The overriding impression is that there is plenty of good and useful stuff on the net, relevant to real people.

The bad side is that most of those currently chucking money around are not going to get what they want from it. They want to see surges in traffic and sales that will impress venture capitalists and potential investors. In truth, many will end up squabbling with and sacking their agencies who talk about things like "awareness" and "long-term brand building" - which are nice, but little comfort in the current commercial battlefield. There are two reasons for this. The most obvious is that not every company can succeed, some simply aren't good enough - and we can expect plenty of commercial casualties over the next year.

The other is that with so many people currently shouting so loudly, it is impossible for anyone to make themselves heard. One solution is simply to shout loudest - in other words, just chuck more money at the problem. Competitor spending £5m? Right, let's spend £6m. The other option is obviously to try and spend that money more smartly - invest in creative work and a media strategy that really stands out.

Take two stories in this week's trade press. In one it was reported that the Financial Times had booked one in every five poster sites in Britain for a week as part of a £7.5m blitz to promote FT Your Money, its personal finance site. Elsewhere it was revealed (if that is not too strong a word) that one of FT Your Money's main rivals, Motley Fool, had appointed "the communications consultancy" Michaelides & Bednash to "develop creative and distinctive communication ideas to make the Motley Fool site stand out from the increasing clutter of dotcom advertising."

Motley Fool's US budget is only $6m, so it is unlikely they will ever match FT Your Money. So, does it stand a chance? It would be nice to picture this as a battle between big money and smart money, but in truth, it is going to be a battle between big smart money and small smart money. That, however, does not mean we should dismiss the Fool, because, for all this frenzy, advertising is simply part of the rather complex mix of processes involved in getting people to your site and, most important of all, getting them to come back to you again.

Boo.com, for example, did almost everything right by the marketing handbook. Great name, good ads, plenty of hype. Unfortunately its launch was plagued with technical difficulties, it was slated, and almost certainly lost many of the customers its advertising attracted.

Yahoo on the other hand has yet to produce a half-decent ad. In fact, it has hardly produced any advertising at all. Last year, according to MMS, it spent little more than £91,000. However, I and millions of others use its site and services pretty much every day. How have they done it? Perhaps you should really ask that question to the next ad agency that insists you have to spend £10m on TV in order to build your online business.

Simon Waldman is the head of Guardian Unlimited. simon.waldman@theguardian.com

webTitle: Sorry, but don't papers spin too?

fields.headline: Sorry, but don't papers spin too?
fields.trailText: This is hardly earth-shattering news. But it is that most precious, and increasingly rare, of commodities, generally known as "a fact": Tony Blair doesn't read newspapers. This revelation is most definitely not spin, leaked as part of a Machiavellian plot. It is the unvarnished truth.
fields.body:
This is hardly earth-shattering news. But it is that most precious, and increasingly rare, of commodities, generally known as "a fact": Tony Blair doesn't read newspapers. This revelation is most definitely not spin, leaked as part of a Machiavellian plot. It is the unvarnished truth.

It is not, of course, unusual. Lady Thatcher didn't read the papers when she was at No. 10, depending on her press secretary's selective cuttings. Similarly, Blair does read certain columnists fairly regularly - they include Hugo Young, Phil Stevens, Don MacIntyre, Peter Riddell - but these are photocopied versions snipped from mucky newsprint.

But the fact that this present prime minister, the man who is supposedly "obsessed" with the media, does not read the newspapers is surely of huge significance. We have been confidently told that what the press says about Blair matters so much to him that following a crop of negative stories throughout this month, along with a "slump" in his personal poll rating, his head is down.

Like so much of what the press says about the state of Blair's mind, it is bunkum. It is, in fact, spin. Newspaper spin. The very spin that made necessary the creation of countervailing spin-doctors. The spin that tells readers every day that the government, rather than the media, is guilty of spinning. The spin that is beginning to confuse the public.

It was hard not to be struck by the audience reaction on Question Time on BBC1 when someone asked whether Blair had enjoyed 1,000 days of power or 1,000 days of spin. When the hapless Harriet Harman tried to brush aside the notion of spinning she was loudly jeered.

A myth has caught hold. In spite of the substantial changes wrought by New Labour, many people - not a majority yet, perhaps, but it is growing apace - are convinced that this government is all about presentation. The drip-drip-drip is working.

So why doesn't Blair read the papers? He may be too busy, which is reasonable enough. But the truth - a second fact - is that Blair cannot bear to read the national press because he finds it almost entirely irrelevant. He cannot link the stories and their lurid headlines with reality. Naturally, therefore, he finds the new commentaries and analyses a waste of time.

Ah, say the cynics, that's because his reality and our reality is different. He doesn't know what real life is like. He has to depend on his aides, especially that sinister press secretary of his, Alastair Campbell, to tell him what's happening in the outside world.

This could be said about any past prime minister, but it doesn't ring true in Blair's case. He isn't locked away. He does understand what's going on. More importantly, he has been raised in a media age. While he knows his government must be effective at communicating its message, he has never been naive enough to imagine that doing so is easy. Even so, he has been saddened by the persistently trivial and negative coverage.

Editors and journalists seem obsessed with hidden messages, almost always non-existent, and interpret both long-term policy and spontaneous events as a series of daily crises, often built around a set of (usually non-existent) personality clashes.

In the long run, most don't matter. Who, for instance, can remember what Derek Draper did, or even who Draper is? Part of the reason is journalists' obsession with the next "story", the manufacture of another so-called crisis.

At the heart of Blair's growing disillusionment with the press is a realisation that even the most able of press offices, the most efficient of monitoring units and the most forceful of press secretaries, will never change the situation.

For a variety of reasons, not to mention the dizzying expansion of an electronic media culture itself forged largely in the press's image, journalism in Britain is badly flawed. It is not only, by its nature, empiricist and short-termist, it is dogged by its history (having fought for two centuries to free itself from state control), contaminated by its form of ownership (private capital, which has a vested interest in political and economic decision-making) and mired by the often absurd demands of competition.

Editors have come to equate "independence" from government with knee-jerk opposition, transforming the concept of holding authority to account into one of relentless hostility. The exception, the Thatcher era, is explicable in terms of proprietorial desire to rid itself of organised labour. But even she found much of the press antagonistic towards the end of her reign, and John Major certainly reaped the whirlwind.

Before coming to power, Blair and Campbell recognised what might happen and set out to avoid the obvious pitfalls. But the press message - that government is a spinning machine - has been so insistent there is a danger now of the mantra being taken up by the public.

Even papers which have been supporting Blair have become frightened by the idea that their readers might feel they are being spun. Could that have been the reason Peter Oborne's article in the Spectator two weeks ago, headlined "The Silence of the Sheep", which suggested that Campbell had every paper in his pocket except for the Daily Mail, had such an effect? Suddenly the Mirror went on the warpath about the NHS. The Sun has been more critical too.

That agenda-setting Oborne piece was full of inaccuracies: Campbell played no part in the Observer's political editor, Patrick Wintour, joining the Guardian; there is no evidence that the Daily Telegraph's Rachel Sylvester is "a New Labour writer"; Tony Bevins, the Express political editor, may be a friend of Campbell but he is hardly in his pocket as his embarrassing series of stories on Geoffrey Robinson and BSE prove.

Oborne was spinning, out of thin and holed fabric, one of the many pieces which suggest that New Labour exists only to spin. It is a lie. But the danger is clear: if people believe it will they vote for Blair the next time around?

This could be said about any past prime minister, but it doesn't ring true in Blair's case. He isn't locked away. He does understand what's going on. More importantly, he has been raised in a media age. While he knows his government must be effective at communicating its message, he has never been naive enough to imagine that doing so is easy. Even so, he has been saddened by the persistently trivial and negative coverage. Editors and journalists seem obsessed with hidden messages, almost always non-existent, and interpret both long-term policy and spontaneous events as a series of daily crises, often built around a set of (usually non-existent) personality clashes. In the long run, most don't matter. Who, for instance, can remember what Derek Draper did, or even who Draper is? Part of the reason is journalists' obsession with the next "story", the manufacture of another so-called crisis. At the heart of Blair's growing disillusionment with the press is a realisation that even the most able of press offices, the most efficient of monitoring units and the most forceful of press secretaries, will never change the situation. For a variety of reasons, not to mention the dizzying expansion of an electronic media culture itself forged largely in the press's image, journalism in Britain is badly flawed. It is not only, by its nature, empiricist and short-termist, it is dogged by its history (having fought for two centuries to free itself from state control), contaminated by its form of ownership (private capital, which has a vested interest in political and economic decision-making) and mired by the often absurd demands of competition. Editors have come to equate "independence" from government with knee-jerk opposition, transforming the concept of holding authority to account into one of relentless hostility. The exception, the Thatcher era, is explicable in terms of proprietorial desire to rid itself of organised labour. But even she found much of the press antagonistic towards the end of her reign, and John Major certainly reaped the whirlwind. Before coming to power, Blair and Campbell recognised what might happen and set out to avoid the obvious pitfalls. But the press message - that government is a spinning machine - has been so insistent there is a danger now of the mantra being taken up by the public. Even papers which have been supporting Blair have become frightened by the idea that their readers might feel they are being spun. Could that have been the reason Peter Oborne's article in the Spectator two weeks ago, headlined "The Silence of the Sheep", which suggested that Campbell had every paper in his pocket except for the Daily Mail, had such an effect? Suddenly the Mirror went on the warpath about the NHS. The Sun has been more critical too. That agenda-setting Oborne piece was full of inaccuracies: Campbell played no part in the Observer's political editor, Patrick Wintour, joining the Guardian; there is no evidence that the Daily Telegraph's Rachel Sylvester is "a New Labour writer"; Tony Bevins, the Express political editor, may be a friend of Campbell but he is hardly in his pocket as his embarrassing series of stories on Geoffrey Robinson and BSE prove. Oborne was spinning, out of thin and holed fabric, one of the many pieces which suggest that New Labour exists only to spin. It is a lie. But the danger is clear: if people believe it will they vote for Blair the next time around?

fields.headline: Bad blood
fields.standfirst: The Times faces another high-profile libel action over an article alleging an African president engaged in cannibalism.
fields.trailText: The Times faces another high-profile libel action over an article alleging an African president engaged in cannibalism.
fields.body:
Publishing a newspaper which is viewed abroad as the mouthpiece of the British establishment is not always a good thing. Sometimes, it can have serious drawbacks.

When Charles Taylor, the president of Liberia, saw an article in the Times repeating allegations made in a book accusing him of "indulging in human sacrifice and the ritualistic consumption of human body parts" - otherwise known as cannibalism - he took legal advice. His London-based solicitor has now lodged a claim for substantial damages following the alleged defamation.

As the ever-expanding internet continues to shrink global consciousness, it seems there is no country too remote to worry about its reputation in London. Just as the dust from the Michael Ashcroft affair has settled it looks as if Times editor Peter Stothard now has another high-profile libel case to worry about.

The article, which appeared on the foreign pages on November 2 1999, also mentioned "reports and rumours of Mr Taylor's alleged cannibalism, including drinking the blood of his murdered rivals".

Taylor, who won the 1997 presidential election after leading one of the factions in Liberia's civil war, believes he cannot allow such gruesome allegations to stand unchallenged. And the Times pulls few punches. Taylor's writ also highlights the claims in the article that "specific individuals were selected for human sacrifice and consumption, a practice believed by some Liberians to confer power on the participants. Many of these bloody rituals were allegedly carried out in Charles Taylor's house."

These lurid allegations were based on accounts in The Mask of Anarchy, a scholarly book examining the underlying causes of Liberia's brutal civil war. Written by the Oxford-educated African scholar, Stephen Ellis, the book was praised for its balanced approach. The author and his publishers have also been served with a writ which they will be contesting.

On December 26 the Sunday Telegraph also ran a piece about the book. It appeared on the books pages, clearly labelled as a review. Halfway through his piece, the reviewer wrote: "In the course of the [Liberian civil] war, children were turned into psychopathic fighters and cannibalism was rampant.Mr Ellis deals with this most sensational aspect of the conflict without titillating the reader. He argues that human sacrifice and cannibalism had long been a part of Liberian ritual practice, but under the control of traditional spiritual leaders, who limited it to special occasions.

"The authority of these spiritual leaders was destroyed during the war, and so cannibalism broke its traditional bounds. Young fighters, high on drugs and alcohol, tried to assimilate the power of the slain by eating parts of them."

It seems that because there was no specific mention of Taylor in the Sunday Telegraph account, their reviewer has been spared a writ. It is one thing to mention cannibalism generally and quite another to allege that it actually took place in the current president's house.

The Times has stated it intends to contest the action vigorously. But libel law does not favour defendants and substantiating claims based on allegations made in a book will not be easy.

In Liberia, it is accepted that various factions engaged in atrocities during the civil war. But that does not mean the Times will be able to prove to a libel court that the current president presided over human sacrifice in his own house.

fields.headline: Global disclosure
fields.standfirst:
Today's remarkable revelations about British American Tobacco owe their genesis to a group of investigative reporters whose newsroom is the world. One of their number, David Leigh, explains their motivation
Special report: BAT exposé International Consortium of Investigative Journalism
fields.trailText: Commentators tend to talk interminably about the way the world's politics and economics are being globalised. But investigative journalists, too, are now learning how they must go global.
fields.body:
Commentators tend to talk interminably about the way the world's politics and economics are being globalised. But investigative journalists, too, are now learning how they must go global.

The revelations commencing today in the Guardian about cigarette giant BAT's involvement with smuggled products have emerged from an investigation carried out worldwide, via a novel journalistic organisation. The findings, now complete, are being released more or less simultaneously through sympathetic media outlets in Europe, Australia, North America and South America.

The BAT story is the first fruit from the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists. The ICIJ is a collection of people from around the world, under the aegis of a smallish Washington-based organisation, the Center for Public Integrity.

The ICIJ communicates via the internet and a system of secure emails. Its existence demonstrates that it is possible to use the net not merely as a source of information, but as a means of bringing journalists together to work in a new way. We can do much more complicated things, and do them in more places, with more people, than ever before.

With luck, this is the kind of creative thinking which is going to go a little way towards helping journalism catch up with the activities of mega-corporations and mega power blocs.

I first encountered the ICIJ a little more than a year ago, when I got a letter from Washington inviting me to join a body I'd never heard of. They assured me rapidly that no payment of money was involved, but that it was a means of giving work to experienced investigative journalists. A free plane ticket to Boston followed, with an invitation to spend a weekend at Harvard university helping set the scheme up at its inaugural conference.

Any doubts I had dissolved, when I realised my two fellow founder-members from the UK were extremely distinguished. One was Duncan Campbell - not the Guardian's Los Angeles correspondent, but the veteran Edinburgh-based investigator who has helped expose government intelligence agency eavesdropping over two decades, in the teeth of more injunctions and official secrets act prosecutions than most.

And the other was Australian-born Phillip Knightley, whose fame rests on breaking open the Kim Philby scandal for the old pre-Murdoch Sunday Times, and whose recent autobiography A Hack's Progress is a classic.

At Harvard, the organisers had produced a crowd of around 50 other investigators from all over the world. Some I'd heard of, some I hadn't. A large and powerful woman with flashing eyes proved to be Yevgenia Albats, a take-no-prisoners freelance from Moscow. The small and wiry figure next to her at the buffet table was Yossi Melman, the brilliant security and intelligence specialist from the Hebrew-language Tel Aviv daily Ha'aretz. There was a gentle and polite environmental journalist from Japan and an impressively-bearded bruiser from Panama.

This was a very unlikely collection of people to get together in one room, whose collective history of conflict with the authorities seemed likely to generate a truculence factor way off the scale. How on earth was anyone going to get them to agree about anything?

Righteousness (even perhaps a touch of self-righteousness) is the non-profit ICIJ's keynote. Their mission, it transpired, was "to conduct investigative projects across nation-state borders on the premise that an enlightened populace is an empowered populace".

In the interest of full disclosure they post a list of donors who contributed more than $5,000 on their website (no state or business funds are accepted). They list: The Carnegie Corporation of New York; Edith and Henry Everett; The John and Florence Newman Foundation; The Ford Foundation; Martha P. Newell; The Open Society Institute; The Ruben and Elisabeth Rausing Trust and Rockefeller Financial Services.

Charles Lewis, the group's founder, and a former producer on CBS's well-respected investigative programme 60 Minutes, set out to strike an inspirational note in promoting his aims: "For decades, people around the world have seen or heard news of global events simultaneously, from political and economic scandals to wars and natural disasters. But the commercial demands of the news industry have often meant that such information is brief, disjointed, and confusing." His grand scheme was that "ICIJ and its cadre of international journalists investigate major global issues that affect us all".

The parent organisation, the Center for Public Integrity, is based in an office in Washington and has published dozens of domestic US investigative reports since its inception a decade ago, including The Buying of the President, a study of the intersection of money and politics in the American presidential campaign system. In 1996, the Center broke the Lincoln Bedroom scandal, in which big-money Democratic donors were invited to spend the night in the White House.

Splicing together a heterogenous crowd of cantankerous foreign journalists and finding a way for them to work together was a much more tricky exercise. Some had staff jobs on their own local papers or TV, and wanted scoops for their own organi sations. Others were freelances, who needed sources of income rather than misty protestations of goodwill to the world. Journalistic stances and standards varied wildly.

Nonetheless, by the time of the second ICIJ international conference - at Stanford university last November - a big global investigation had finally got under way rather secretively. Maud Beelman, a veteran foreign correspondent for Associated Press, had taken over as ICIJ director. And she heard via the World Health Organisation and the tight-knit world of anti-tobacco campaigners of an astonishing cache of documents that might be available in England, at a depository in Guildford.

The global tobacco multinational, BAT, had settled a US health suit brought by the state of Minnesota, on condition that they made their internal company files available to researchers for a period of 10 years.

Dismayed, BAT had persuaded a judge to allow access only via an archive near their headquarters in Surrey. And they did not help inquirers understand what their contents might signify. But these files covered their operations in virtually every country on the globe.

With starter funds from a donor foundation, Beelman recruited Duncan Campbell in Britain. "We had to be granted a place at their Guildford archive," Campbell says: "BAT lawyers constantly introduced rules. They would say there were a maxi mum of six places available. Or only one organisation at a time was allowed in. Then, suddenly, all the available places were booked up for weeks ahead. The staff there were clearly told to be polite but everything was as difficult as it could be."

At one point, tobacco campaigners had to enlist the original Minnesota state lawyers to threaten BAT with a return to court, and a revocation of their special dispensation to set up a depository out of US jurisdiction. BAT grudgingly complied. A lengthy process resumed of scanning BAT indexes, ordering up potentially interesting files, and trying to interpret their contents with help from ICIJ members , particularly in Latin America and south-east Asia.

Only last week, BAT's chairman Martin Broughton rather scornfully told a Commons health committee that the Guildford depository had been a waste of time, and health campaigners had failed to discover anything unsavoury.

This was a testament to ICIJ's good security at least. At the time he spoke, finishing touches were being put to a devastating report. The Guardian arranged to publish it first in the UK, ICIJ member Maria Teresa Ronderos put it out simultaneously in Spanish in her magazine La Nota in Colombia, Channel 4 News plan to push the story further on for their forthcoming news bulletins, and ICIJ launched the story on their website in Washington a soon as the Guardian published. All the other ICIJ members round the world got an email tipping them off about a breaking story they could localise for their own purposes.

Investigative journalists are notoriously suspicious types. But Charles Lewis's scheme to set up ICIJ managed to tap into something less obvious - the sense of camaraderie and the love of detective work that it seems bind them together the world over.

The pursuit of the BAT story so far has married investigative skills with global technology in an interesting way. And something less tangible but perhaps even more romantic has been nourished as well - a worldwide optimism about new possibilities for chasing the truth.

David Leigh is Comment editor of the Guardian

webTitle: The internet - making our business smile

fields.headline: The internet - making our business smile
fields.trailText: Nearly every major advertising agency I know, including my own, is working on at least five pitches for dot com companies at the moment. Every day agencies are approached by established clients or by new business start-ups who want to join the internet boom.
fields.body:
Nearly every major advertising agency I know, including my own, is working on at least five pitches for dot com companies at the moment. Every day agencies are approached by established clients or by new business start-ups who want to join the internet boom. How do we sort out the wheat from the chaff? Many of these companies have already had short-term success. But what about their sustainability? And what can we do for them?

Speaking generally, there are three categories of operation. First, what we call the "no brainers" - excellent ideas which are backed by a substantial organisation. They have a carefully thought out business plan, they've got their funds in place and, at least from an agency's point of view, there's very little risk attached. Classic cases are the Co-op's Smile and Egg. These have all the excitement of the new but have the reassurance of the old (ie we reckon we'll get paid). These are the ones you hope come knocking.

Then there's the good ideas from high-calibre people who are in cahoots with a big accountancy firm or a management consultancy. They're seeking venture capital and want a marketing team on board. You do a lot of up-front work for these outfits but if they don't get their venture capital then you don't get paid. But you don't turn these ones away lightly - they may be the Beatles. We have several of these on board, and I'm sure all the other major agencies do as well.

Then there's the rest. Usually run by a 25 year old, with reasonably good ideas but no business plan. And they all want to make £1bn on a float. These are the "timewasters dotcom" (a phrase first coined by Paul Simons of Ogilvy & Mather).

But, whatever the category, all the players involved in launching these companies - bankers, venture capitalists, management consultants, headhunters, lawyers and advertising agencies - seem to be working happily together. The management consultants and the venture capitalists know they're good at the supply side economics. But they understand that, in this virtual world, brands are the only sustainable edifice. And they recognise that it's advertising agencies who know about building brands, attracting people, keeping customers - the demand side. But we have to be much quicker than in the past.

It took a generation to build Heinz and Boots into brands that you could trust. Body Shop and Virgin took between 10 and 15 years to get to the same position. Gap only five. But the dot com companies are reaching maturity within two or three years. The timespan in which to build a brand that people can trust is getting shorter and shorter, and it's getting more and more expensive.

To play seriously in this market now - because of the clutter of companies already operating - costs around £1m a month in media expenditure alone. And in the US they reckon marketing can represent as much as 60% of total costs.

This puts advertising agencies in a great position. The doom merchants said that the growth of internet companies would be the death of advertising and the media as we know it. But, and it's a delicious paradox, these dot com companies have turned out to be the biggest spenders not only with advertising agencies but with "old" media like posters, television and print.

The real issue facing the advertising industry is how we are going to apply our executional skills in the new media. Our strategic skills are as relevant for the new media as for the old. What makes a great brand is identical in both environments. But what has to change is how we execute those strategies. As an industry we're coming to grips with this, but we're by no means there.

Rupert Howell is president of the IPA and chairman of HHCL and Partners. His new On Advertising column will appear every fortnight

fields.headline: My media
fields.standfirst: Steven Norris
fields.trailText: Steven Norris
fields.body:
Newspapers: The Times, Telegraph and Mail I have delivered. My favourite columnists are Matthew Parris in the Times, Boris Johnson in the Telegraph and Keith Waterhouse in the Mail. Sundays is Times, Telegraph, Mail because I think they're such good guides to the audiences I am addressing. There are no newspapers I don't like.

Magazines: The Spectator, New Statesman, the Week - which I think is very good - and Private Eye.

Books: My favourites are political biographies and autobiographies. Inevitably, Alan Clark's diary, but also a very good volume by Hywel Williams called Guilty Men. I like Iain Banks. I love Louis de Bernieres's Captain Correlli's Mandolin. I like Mansfield Park because Mrs Norris is such a gorgon - a family joke. I'll probably take the Derry Irvine biography on holiday.

I love Casablanca, South Pacific, Gentlemen Prefer Blondes. The last film I saw was Notting Hill, which I loved. I'm very much in the Noel Coward mould - moved by cheap music, cheap sentiment.

Ads: I like Peugeot, I hate Renault, I like Boddingtons, I hate John Smiths and Tango.

fields.headline: Not absolutely fabulous
fields.standfirst: Sally O'Sullivan's first mistake was to let a TV crew into the offices of her new publishing company. Her second was to re-lay the carpet tiles before the cameras. Whatever happened to publishing's mystique?
fields.trailText: Sally O'Sullivan's first mistake was to let a TV crew into the offices of her new publishing company. Her second was to re-lay the carpet tiles before the cameras. Whatever happened to publishing's mystique?
fields.body:
It starts like this. An assistant comes into your office - where you are editing a story about the world's biggest bar - and announces, with an air of familiarity, that "Todd" from Burning Owl Television is on the phone wanting to discuss "the treatment" he sent you for the documentary he wants to make. You reach down into the file marked "Television", which is full of crisp white letters from producers hoping to document your daily grind, or turn your magazine into a TV show, and begin to read.

The letter is on good-quality paper with a razor-sharp fold and appears beneath the image of a wise old owl with its arse ablaze. As a logo, it is quite startling and suggests something more anarchic than low-paid voyeurism. Then you notice that just to the owl's side is an embossed camera, slightly raised from the page, capturing the hot-bird action. Todd's "idea" is to follow the editor and his editorial team for a few months to allow the public to see exactly what goes on inside the offices of your "cutting edge" magazine. He has written the request with so much conviction that he might genuinely think that no one has ever suggested such a venture before and that you'll be gagging for him to come in immediately and stick his big lens up your conference table.

Confident and to the point, the missive suggests Channel 4 and BBC2 are both keen to screen, and his talent is certified by the brief mention of the fact that Todd and Burning Owl were the makers of Zoo Keeper. This was the previous week's hilarious look at how men in blue overalls clean up elephant dung, argue about low overtime rates and extract lollipop sticks from the jaws of snakes. You remember smirking at the trailer for Zoo Keeper and then you remind yourself that you thought the programme looked interesting because you would be watching not participating in it.

You think for a moment that you might come across as a TV natural like John Harvey-Jones, Chris Evans, or one of the many Soho chefs. But you are snapped out of your reverie by Todd's telephone inquiry, which you politely turn down.

At least that's the way it's supposed to be. Only no one told Sally O'Sullivan. At one point during last Monday's episode of Trouble Between The Covers - BBC2's documentary annihilation of the launch of her publishing company Cabal Communications - my wife looked at me with what I can only describe as mortgage fear. She wrongly assumed that all magazine companies are like this. Her look was so accusing - as if to say, "Is this what goes on in your industry? Is this what's going to happen to you?" - that I had to reassure her I would do my best to make my own fledgling media company a success without the need to offer it up as entertainment.

And that is what Cabal has become. We had started off thinking the show was funny, became slowly dismayed to see an editor getting his copy checked by a major London gangster, and then were horrified when the head of the company began scrabbling around on the floor changing carpet tiles to impress a potential contract customer.

To the magazine industry, Trouble Between The Covers is enthralling. Rather like seeing something wounded or dying - you don't really want to watch it but you can't quite look away. The words "worst case scenario" and "why?" spring to mind. Whenever I talk to a publisher or an advertiser, a journalist or a distributor, they all pass comment, keen to find out if it will get better or worse, and not too sure which they want.

The stars of the show are Piers Hernu, the editor of junior lads' mag Front, and his boss, the aforementioned Sally O'Sullivan. Bizarrely, their personality traits suggest that each should be doing the other's job. Piers is keen, thoughtful, eager to try things, quick to see the error of his ways and cautious about trying too hard to suck up to advertisers. Sally, meanwhile, is having the time of her life throwing parties and executing daring plans and is frequently to be seen cuddling a wine glass.

To be honest, the things that have been going wrong - interview tapes fail to record, pitches fail - happen every day in a magazine company, but it's all being captured on film and seems all the more spectacular because the series began with grand talk of empires, legends and profit.

The most striking image so far came at the end of the first episode when O'Sullivan was seen shrieking in the street in what sounded like inebriated Italian, insisting that staff members must return to the launch party. Although the two chief executives I have worked for, Mike Matthews at IPC and Jonathan Newhouse at Condé Nast, both have a sense of humour, I cannot envisage either of them ever behaving like that. I admit that I have carried on in far worse fashion, but never as a chief executive.

It is my greatest hope that the series improves matters for the struggling company: indeed O'Sullivan has already pointed out that newsstand sales are up because of the publicity. I'd like to think that Piers, the only man to have been sacked from Loaded for being unpopular (in my time that was the criteria for being hired), will be offered a Channel 5 dating game to host.

He really is a minor-league star waiting to happen. At a time when most of the Loaded staff were getting above their station and refusing to test crisps or ride motorised bar stools around a wet field in Hampshire - preferring to go scuba diving, snowboarding, or raving somewhere luxurious - Piers arrived and gratefully gobbled up all the "shit jobs".

Such keenness - some saw it as toadying - made him unpopular with some staff. But he seemed quite likeable to me. Had the BBC's cameras ever made it into Loaded they might have seen Piers blagging a fridge to house our vodka collection, proudly showing off his terrible dress sense or, strangely, admitting he had once played in a New Romantic pop group on a Noel Edmonds talent contest.To his credit The Gimp became The Godfather and got his own successful magazine on the go with gangsters for contributors. This seems to have annoyed the current Loaded editor, who is apparently seen attacking Piers and camera crew in tonight's episode.

Television cameras should never be allowed into a magazine office. The only genuine portrayal of how good an editor's job can be was in Absolutely Fabulous. In one show, fashion guru Patsy actually went to work and attended a Vogue-style editorial meeting where her editor, played by Kathy Burke, sorted herself a new car, suit and holiday. A role model for us all. In reality any such fly-on-the-wall team approaching the glorious reception at Condé Nast would have been swatted with a pashmina long before it could even reach the revolving doors.

Journalists talk to their readers through their pages; TV catching them at it can only destroy the mystique and preserve on film their unpleasant habits. On one of the few occasions when a camera crew made it into Loaded's office, I was explaining to the Girlie Show's Sara Cox that working on the magazine wasn't all juvenile sex - and they cut to a clip of Reece and Tom, the "fashion assistants", getting a wannabe model to show them her tits.

Perhaps that was for the best. A team of TV journalists making a documentary about magazine journalists is media cannibalism. And fascinating though Trouble Between The Covers may be, as GQ's art director said to me last week: "This is doing our industry no good. I keep telling my friends how glamorous it all is, and then they see this. We all could be in trouble, never mind Cabal." How long will it take the narrator to work out that Sally O'Sullivan's initials are SoS?

James Brown is editor in chief of the I Feel Good media company

fields.headline: Stand-up, be counted
fields.standfirst: It was one of the biggest stories of the week - Whitehall split in an almighty battle over ethical foreign policy. And the man at the centre of it? Mark Thomas, a stand-up from Clapham.  Michael Collins  reports on the blurring line between comedy and journalism
fields.trailText: It was one of the biggest stories of the week - Whitehall split in an almighty battle over ethical foreign policy. And the man at the centre of it? Mark Thomas, a stand-up from Clapham.
fields.body:
The members of parliament who fall prey to the pranks of Mark Thomas have slowly become aware - as his Channel 4 series has evolved over the past four years - that they are not simply dealing with the Chumbawamba of British comedy. This is not a tub-thumping middle-class man in a silly suit dousing the working class John Prescott in the name of direct action. A fact that was confirmed last week when the lines between stand-up comedy and investigative journalism became blurred, with Thomas emerging as the point where a John Pilger-like polemic and Roger Cook-like tactics converge in a Donald MacIntyre-like body.

On Wednesday morning the Guardian sparked one of the biggest stories of the week when it led with a piece headlined "Whitehall leak reveals ethics row". It was a story gained out of collaboration between this newspaper and Channel 4, a missile at the heart of the heated debate about ethical foreign policy. Follow-ups led news bulletins and leader columns.

But for media watchers, the story - about whether environmental considerations should underpin British export agreements - had one fascinating line: "Four departments are at the centre of the Whitehall battle, revealed in documents to be shown on tomorrow night's Mark Thomas Product." Not Panorama, or Dispatches or Newsnight. No, on a show fronted by a comedian who decided that there was a lot more fun to be had confronting people with something to hide than making up jokes. Comic as journalist as entertainer.

Dangerous? Or simply more proof that consumers of news are, increasingly, demanding presentation that is out of the ordinary.

In the offices of Vera Productions - the company behind the Mark Thomas Product - Thomas himself is, of course, joyous that the story made such an impact. However, he is quick to point out that he is not in the business of breaking exclusives, but in working for the good of the story: "You either regard information as a right, or as a commodity. And if you regard it as a commodity, we don't want to play."

This latest development does imply that the guerrilla and Gotcha! tactics he employs to expose absurdities in government legislation, and unveil the more covert uses of taxpayers' money, is granting him access to information that would have previously been pounced on by orthodox current affairs series. But does Thomas do anything more than, as Chris Morris once said, bully receptionists? True, Thomas has sometimes lumbered the girl that works the switchboard for £13,000 a year with the crimes of capitalism, because her boss won't take a call. A case in point being the show on the Millennium Dome.

But for the most part, Thomas's strike-rate has proved impressive, from working to reform a scheme enabling the wealthy to avoid inheritance tax on works of art, to revelations that emerged when Thomas and his team posed as a PR company at an arms fair. The subterfuge resulted in the Indonesian defence attache admitting that equipment made in Britain had been used to squash dissension in East Timor.

"That programme was more effective than the John Pilger one about East Timor," says Jeff Anderson, editor of Tonight with Trevor McDonald, and previously World in Action. "By using humour and pranks, Mark Thomas made a serious subject accessible to a 16- to 30-year-old audience."

"I like the idea of finding a story and not going away," says Thomas. The genesis of last week's disclosures was in a programme in October, revealing how directors advising the government on the underwriting of billions of pounds for arms exports had omitted to mention their own interests.

The missionary zeal that Thomas brings to his efforts to re-enfranchise the Channel 4 viewer could be genetic. His great-grandfather was a Baptist preacher, and his father a lay preacher in his native south London. The style is part fundamentalist, part flypitcher. He can condense complex issues, even though the soundbite on his own political standpoint is simplistic: "Philosophically, I describe myself as an anarchist."

Evangelical is the word he uses to describe his favoured journalists. The kind that, day in, day out, come out fighting in the red corner. But there is "a very strange deal that some journalists make. It is as though they exchange criticism for closeness and accessibility. There are some who have had the Labour party bullying them, attempting to manipulate them. And sometimes the manipulation is wilfully acquiesced in. They will do it to be at the heart of things. Close to the power." In the past, the comedian was contacted by Robin Cook's office, with a view to writing gags. "It doesn't appeal to me. So what if twice a year I'd get invited to drinks at the Foreign Office?"

His series has evolved into a current affairs programme just as the genre has lost weight. It came into being as a Situationist prank. These things happen. Keith Allen's career emerged from a Situationist stunt, as did that of Malcolm McLaren. The aim of the series was to reveal to the public facets of politicians to which they would not usually be privy.

Gradually, it has formed into a genre of its own: factual comedy. The emphasis is now on rigorous research. For the current run, the word "comedy" was ditched from the title, and the stunts have taken a backseat to the reporting.

"We're very happy being this highbrow," says Thomas. "We regard ourselves as dumbing-up while everyone else is accused of dumbing-down."

"I think that Mark's line of investigation is as capable as that of any investigative journalist," says David Lloyd, Channel 4's head of news and current affairs. "This makes him unusual. But I don't think we're about to see a lot of comedy investigators."

And yet there is, elsewhere, a seasoning of politics seeping into the careers of comedians. Dom Joly of Trigger Happy TV was the merry prankster caught on camera during Neil Hamilton's recent court appearance. When BBC2 last year commissioned a fin de siècle series on crime, drugs and class, it was not Jeremy Paxman or Andrew Neil they called, but Mark Lamarr. Thomas's venture has had an impact on other series. "When we were putting together Tonight," recalls Anderson, "I realised we could learn a lot from the style of Mark Thomas and Michael Moore. We decided to attempt to bring an irreverent slant to things."

A charge levelled at Thomas, since the comedy has decreased, is that he has become sanctimonious and tells people what to think. But this is in keeping with a tradition of current affairs television, whereby reports came with the chaser of an opinion - witness the 60s broadcasters such as Alan Whicker, James Cameron and Fyfe Robertson. And in the 70s, anyone with a pad and a biro was looking for a Watergate.

Anderson believes that there was a loss of nerve in current affairs in the 80s. It became too balanced - but "in the last couple of years the committed reporter has begun to reappear". Thomas says there are too few good editors. "Who decides what constitutes a news story? Who decides what the agenda is? There's a rush to this ground where everyone has a consensual opinion on things."

The opinion on The Mark Thomas Product at Channel 4 is unclear. In some ways he fits the bill as the cheeky, punky chappie who thumbs his nose at the TV establishment, like the comic cracking jokes at the expense at those in the royal box. They love it, because, ultimately, it's their finger on the button. For now, the show stays put; in the US, Michael Moore's direct-action mini-documentaries have upset sponsors and been shunned by networks.

As for Thomas himself, a hell of lot of people now have the measure of the man. Members of the police force are reported to be fans of the show. He remains the nemesis of Jack Straw (whom he tricked in a cannabis stunt) and says the Labour party won't talk to him. Recently, he managed to get within five steps of Tony Blair before being whisked away.

"There's a limit to the range of subjects you can cover with comedy in current affairs," says Panorama's editor, Peter Horrocks. "There's a limit to what you can find out. MPs just won't answer the question. They won't demean themselves. When we did a programme last year called The Blair Mayor Project, we unravelled a story that wouldn't have been helped by the kind of tricks Mark Thomas uses. That's not to say that laughs can't be useful."

The Mark Thomas Product is about the pursuit of access, whether to information or to those with access to that information. But what happens once you get beyond the comedy and the thrill of the chase? Some time before embarking on a stand-up career, Thomas, as a student, broke through a police line protecting a bus full of strike-breakers during the miners' dispute.

He stood there, embarrassed, uncertain what to do but shout "Scab!" and run back to the pack. What would happen now if he broke through the police line, or beyond the minders, or reached the minister? What if, when Byers was chased and harangued in last week's show, instead of running, piling into the car and disappearing, he had stopped and said "let's talk". Would he go for the joke or go for the jugular?

"That's fine. That's fine," Thomas says. "Because we know that subject backwards. I know the conditions are bullshit. I know the Turkish authorities have not signed up for the conditions. I know that Blair got a local firm in. I know they have not got an international monitoring agreement. I know the Turkish authorities are fucked off. It's not that we've not got the facts. Once we're through the line - we're armed."

The Mark Thomas Product is on Channel 4 on Thursdays at 11.05pm

The emphasis is now on rigorous research. For the current run, the word "comedy" was ditched from the title, and the stunts have taken a backseat to the reporting. "We're very happy being this highbrow," says Thomas. "We regard ourselves as dumbing-up while everyone else is accused of dumbing-down." "I think that Mark's line of investigation is as capable as that of any investigative journalist," says David Lloyd, Channel 4's head of news and current affairs. "This makes him unusual. But I don't think we're about to see a lot of comedy investigators." And yet there is, elsewhere, a seasoning of politics seeping into the careers of comedians. Dom Joly of Trigger Happy TV was the merry prankster caught on camera during Neil Hamilton's recent court appearance. When BBC2 last year commissioned a fin de siècle series on crime, drugs and class, it was not Jeremy Paxman or Andrew Neil they called, but Mark Lamarr. Thomas's venture has had an impact on other series. "When we were putting together Tonight," recalls Anderson, "I realised we could learn a lot from the style of Mark Thomas and Michael Moore.
