webTitle: Twelve good reasons to worry about the future of the BBC

fields.headline: Twelve good reasons to worry about the future of the BBC
fields.standfirst: Yesterday, among the soft furnishings of Breakfast with Frost, Greg Dyke revealed that none of the BBC governors raised concerns about his personal business affairs. Any surprise, then, that their judgment is being questioned?  Maggie Brown asks whether it's time to sack the board
fields.trailText: Yesterday, among the soft furnishings of Breakfast with Frost, Greg Dyke revealed that none of the BBC governors raised concerns about his personal business affairs. Any surprise, then, that their judgment is being questioned? Maggie Brown asks whether it's time to sack the board
fields.body:
On the comfy sofas of Breakfast with Frost yesterday morning, Greg Dyke gave an account of himself. Yes, the governors did know about all his share dealings before they gave him the job. No, maybe it hadn't been the best idea to try to hold onto £6m of Granada shares even though he was taking over as director general early. And, yes, in fact he would describe it as a "mistake".

But then came the intriguing part. Dyke questioned the veracity of quotes in the press from one governor supposedly angered by the share dealing row. Was that a true quote, Dyke asked. "I doubt it."

Dyke said that no governors had spoken either to him or the chairman of the BBC, Sir Christopher Bland, about their concerns over his private business dealings. The fact that they hadn't says a lot about the way the BBC is governed.

The key task of the BBC's governors is to appoint a director general. So there should be absolutely no surprise that their judgment is now being questioned. Even if you don't share the view of the Daily Mail - which spat "Have there ever been such unimpressive governors of the BBC?" - there is now a consensus that the system is imperfect, and creating an all-too-visible trail of banana skins.

Even as they met for their monthly meeting last Thursday, controversy stirred at their supper table, shared by Will Wyatt, former chief executive of BBC Broadcast, the second most powerful man in the BBC until he retired in December.

He wrote an open letter to Dyke in the London Evening Standard last week which is now reverberating around the BBC's executive suites: "The business of your Granada shares shows that you have not yet quite got the point. The BBC is different."

Wyatt, perhaps unintentionally, also went on in his Standard article to expose the way the BBC trains new governors so that their interests gradually become indistinguishable from the institution.

"Over the years I have watched the arrival from the commercial sector of governors who do know that the BBC is special but begin by coming up with all kinds of bright ideas which are utterly counter to what the BBC is for. Most quickly learn."

The bigger point raised by all this is whether the 12-strong governors - who appointed Dyke despite the furore over his £55,000 Labour donations and who are required to act as custodians of the national interest - have got it as well?

As is well known, Dyke was appointed on a split vote. He was the choice of Sir Christopher Bland right from the start. That is part of the problem. In the current system, the chairman of the BBC wields huge power. Bland's instinct, first over the Granada shares, then over Dyke's money in private property deals revealed last week, was to tough things out. When Dyke finally decided to sell his Granada shares it looked as if media pressure rather than wise counsel from the governors had forced his hand.

Even after Dyke had sold his £6m of shares and then been reminded of his "forgotten" £175,000 Pearson holding, another governor, weary of the huge media interest, insisted to me last week that the whole fuss had been blown up by the Sunday Times. Many would say that shows a fundamental misunderstanding of the situation.

These are not ordinary times. The BBC is being made to sweat, before hearing details of the government decision on an increase in its income either through a digital supplement or an across-the-board increase. Can a rise, paid for by ordinary people, be announced when its governance looks, at best, questionable?

Chris Smith, the secretary of state for culture, media and sport, currently at the centre of a fierce round of inter-departmental politicking over the future funding of the BBC, was horrified at the existence of the Granada share holding.

Smith, who is a firm believer in public service broadcasting and anxious not to undermine the new director general, cannot avoid the question: Are the governors on the ball?

Now this is a key element bubbling through the document that kicked the licence fee debate off last year - the Davies Committee report. It described the governors as "problematic" and said that the future lay with "improved accountability through a modernised system of governance".

The report continues: "On the one hand they are supposed to set the Corporation's general direction under the charter, to be the main instrument by which it is rendered accountable. On the other hand they are often regarded very much as part of the management of the corporation. Governors are serviced by a secretariat which is part of the staff of the BBC and which therefore has to reconcile dual loyalty to its management and the governors.

"This is in sharp contrast to the arrangements that apply in commercial television companies. We do have a sense that the present situation is neither satisfactory nor defensible."

As an interim measure Davies said that the National Audit Office should mount periodic examinations of the BBC's books, as it does with the directly funded World Service, something stoutly resisted by the BBC.

Until now the BBC has been able to rely on a mix of mild reform, inertia, public support, and a respect for years of tradition to protect its constitution, something even Margaret Thatcher did not dare to tackle head on. But with a government finally prepared to square up to even such big vested interests as the hereditary peers it may be different this time.

In 1992 a government consultation paper on the BBC asked: "Should changes be made in the functions of the governors and the BBC board of management? Should there be a public service broadcasting council, either to regulate the BBC or promote public service broadcasting across the board in the BBC and other services?" As ever, nothing of substance happened.

The governors themselves, as the former governor of Northern Ireland, Sir Kenneth Bloomfield, said in a rare paper on the BBC four years ago, have to cope with a huge amount of information, but without an office themselves, unlike the chairman.

And they are 12 individuals with their respective "tastes, interests and prejudices", often with little in common and far removed from popular audiences.

There has been a time-honoured tradition to appoint a trade unionist, a commercial banker, an ex-foreign office mandarin or diplomat, and, most damagingly, a handful of political placemen and women.

Where the rules have been changed, there has been a tendency to concentrate power in the chairman's hands. It really took off with Lord (Marmaduke) Hussey, chairman between 1986-1995, who was deliberately appointed to "sort out" the BBC. He sacked the director general, Alasdair Milne, in 1987 and thus broke the tradition of internally promoted director generals, imbued with the public service ethos. Hussey was the first chairman to be given a second term in office.

This precedent enhanced the chairman's power, and allowed him to bulldoze John Birt with his savage programme of organisational change into the top job - without open competition.

Sir Christopher Bland, his successor and another Conservative appointee, had his chairmanship also extended for a second term, to 2003.

As for the tradition of the governors not being executives, well Hussey and Bland worked and work about four days a week and occupy a large office with a secretary in Broadcasting House. BBC executives point out that that seems pretty full-time.

Charles Wheeler, the distinguished BBC correspondent, pointed out in last week's Radio 4 debate on Birt's legacy that if the BBC is run through a cosy relationship between chairman and director general, there are clear dangers.

In the Bland-Dyke era the combination seems to denote a tolerance for private business deals, all part of both men's multi-millionaire status.

A senior figure in the Royal Television Society believes the problem goes beyond the purely financial transparency driving Davies.

"Bland [over the Dyke share issue] failed to recognise he needed to be scrupulous. No permanent secretary in the civil service would be allowed to hold a large stake in a commercial company like that. "This isn't about not knowing about broadcasting. It's about their moral judgment."

The result of the governor's inability to act, he concludes sadly, is that Dyke is saddled "with the perception that he is greedy".

Of course, it is not all one way traffic. The BBC's deputy chairwoman, Baroness Young, is a tough operator who is thought to have insisted 14 months ago that Jenny Abramsky became the new director of radio. She is a counter to the strength of Bland but again has too low a public profile.

Richard Eyre, the ex-chief executive of the ITV Network and former candidate for the director general's post, says that although ITV's stance in the licence fee debate has been that the BBC is basically ungoverned because of the close relationship between governors and BBC managers, "my brush showed they were no patsies".

Eyre, who was interviewed by the governors for the DG post, said: "They are highly critical of the BBC, pushing it to very high standards. They form a very high calibre board. These are not cosy people."

There have been efforts to change, to inject elements of accountability by dealing direct with the public, but it's not been cutting edge stuff. The BBC's dreadful See For Yourself annual programmes of 1987 to 1989 gave way eventually to the grandiose and often vacuous Statement of Promises of the past four years. Flawed, as the National Consumer Council noted, because the promises are "constructed by the BBC, monitored by the governors".

True, the BBC chairman and director general go before the select committee to account for themselves once a year. There are also more structured meetings with the secretary of state.

But the self-serving nature of so many BBC consultations - typically "licence fee payers say 'yes' to proposals for new BBC services" - have riled everyone outside the BBC, including government ministers.

So, three options remain. In the short term the government could insist that the National Audit Office has a scrutinising role, and amend the charter accordingly.

Longer term, the conservative move would be to strengthen the BBC governors, and bolster their independence with their own secretariat. But in the forthcoming review of regulation ordered by Smith, there could be wider support for an external regulator, which would set standards against agreed criteria for public service broadcasting and key networks - to which the governors would be accountable.

The interesting thing is that a big factor in saving the BBC from big change during the 80s was its popularity, the fact that the audience had not deserted it.

If Dyke manages to inspire programme makers to new heights this might be an escape route yet. But times are changing fast.

fields.headline: Media Diary
fields.trailText: The media diary, the place you first read extracts from Amanda Platell's bonkbuster Scandal, has another publishing scoop: the first extracts from The Spirit Death, David Docherty's rip-roaring account of how a mixture of CJD and ebola terrorises London.
fields.body:
The media diary, the place you first read extracts from Amanda Platell's bonkbuster Scandal, has another publishing scoop: the first extracts from The Spirit Death, David Docherty's rip-roaring account of how a mixture of CJD and ebola terrorises London. "The hypershock thriller about the most terrifying plague since the black death," the front cover says modestly of the book that Docherty, the BBC's deputy director of television, has already had optioned by ITV's drama department.

But before the pulsating extracts, a small thought strikes me. The story's hero is Mike Davenport, the deputy head of the London Centre for Infectious Diseases, who battles against the rampaging virus despite being "frustrated by the bureaucratic obstructions of a boss blind to the dangers of the terrifying situation" - or so the book's jacket says.

Surely, Davenport is Docherty himself, a man who has to push his "resolve and resources to the limit if he is to have any chance of stopping the spread of this nightmare". Obviously a metaphor for television news at BBC White City. And the boss? Well, we can only speculate, but John Birt must be glad he's leaving.

Anyway, on to the text. And what a text it is. "A body was propped between the frame of the door," Docherty tells the reader. "A metal door had been driven through the rib cage and the corpse was wedged upright. A noose around the neck was connected to a hook on the lintel. The face underneath was bashed in and the tongue cut out. Both wrists had been slashed and the blood spilled down the expensively cut cotton trousers and dried hard. The carcass was beginning to smell and the cloud of flies that covered the wounds rose as one when Fernandez moved the body."

I'd like to run the extract about the woman on the top floor of the bus which is equally bloody, but am aware that Media Guardian holds firm family values. Ah well, maybe more next week . . .

 Sir Christopher Bland, beleaguered chairman of the BBC, was looking unusually tense at last Thursday's Royal Television Society dinner in Mayfair, saluting the retirement of Will Wyatt, chief executive of BBC Broadcast.

Wyatt described witnessing a governors' meeting chaired by Bland's predecessor Marmaduke Hussey. He was seeking consensus on a hot policy issue. A governor passed Wyatt a folded note which he thought must pertain to the complicated point under debate. It read: "Do we check when people ring in and say they're vicars? I heard a so-called vicar (on a phone in) standing up for lesbians - I could hardly believe my ears."

And warm applause for Esther Rantzen who, in her 20-minute tribute to Wyatt, managed to mention the man twice before going on to her own achievements in mind-numbingly boring detail.

 Another one somewhat obsessed with herself is Deborah Ross, the Independent's chief interviewer. In the first three paragraphs of her interview with Sarah Lancashire, she uses the word "I" 21 times. Presumably, clever Independent research has discovered the readers are more interested in Ross than they are in the star she is talking to. No wonder their circulation is so robust.

 Robot Wars, the mad Friday night show for boys large and small, is about to spawn a grown-up version. BBC2 has quietly ordered up six episodes of Techno Games, starting in March, in which crazed mechanics, sorry ordinary blokes, compete to make robots which then enter a mad series of competitions, from robot dancing and robot athletics to launching rockets!

Meanwhile, Robot Wars, thrashing TFI Friday's Chris Evans, and about to air on America's PBS channel, is being awarded its own BBC monthly magazine with Sir Killalot, the house robot, as pin-up. As a top children's programme, it's ripe for a transfer to BBC1 in the footsteps of Changing Rooms and Ground Force. Except that's no way to treat a cult.

 Plans have been hastily devised to get BBC1's Castaways on air more regularly. The original proposal was to leave the softies alone with the cameras on Taransay for a year of social experimentation, before screening any more reports. But the wrap-up programme last week, showing the outbreak of flu and misery, beat ITV and gained a 7.7m audience, some 35% of viewers. Controller Peter Salmon is salivating with delight. The BBC has been inundated with calls for more sightings of Tatler picture editor Ben Fogle. It may well produce monthly instalments.

 And of course we couldn't end this week without mentioning that the new home editor of the Times, Michael Gove, was the man who wrote in his biography of Michael Portillo: "While few of Portillo's contemporaries would describe him as a model undergraduate, none recalls anything more embarrassing than drunkenness or a taste for practical jokes." Of course, Portillo later revealed to the, erm, Times that he had had "homosexual experiences" during university. Times hacks are already calling big-brains Gove "the rottweiler".

You can email Maggie Brown at maggiebrown.media@btinternet.com

Except that's no way to treat a cult.  Plans have been hastily devised to get BBC1's Castaways on air more regularly. The original proposal was to leave the softies alone with the cameras on Taransay for a year of social experimentation, before screening any more reports. But the wrap-up programme last week, showing the outbreak of flu and misery, beat ITV and gained a 7.7m audience, some 35% of viewers. Controller Peter Salmon is salivating with delight. The BBC has been inundated with calls for more sightings of Tatler picture editor Ben Fogle. It may well produce monthly instalments.  And of course we couldn't end this week without mentioning that the new home editor of the Times, Michael Gove, was the man who wrote in his biography of Michael Portillo: "While few of Portillo's contemporaries would describe him as a model undergraduate, none recalls anything more embarrassing than drunkenness or a taste for practical jokes." Of course, Portillo later revealed to the, erm, Times that he had had "homosexual experiences" during university. Times hacks are already calling big-brains Gove "the rottweiler". webTitle: Take a deep breath, Oxygen is here

fields.headline: Take a deep breath, Oxygen is here
fields.trailText: This week America sees the launch of what has been called the most audacious entertainment start-up in decades. Oxygen is the new cable channel for women, by women
fields.body:
This week America sees the launch of what has been called the most audacious entertainment start-up in decades. Oxygen is the new cable channel for women, by women, led from the front by Oprah Winfrey. A gigantic publicity campaign hopes that what Oprah has achieved for books, where her endorsement can create a bestseller overnight, she can also do for American women.

As with her book club, Oprah has a cultural as well as a commercial vision. Oxygen aims to empower American women by enhancing their computer skills, so the cable channel is integrated with a string of female-friendly websites. However, the birth of Oxygen highlights a gap in British television.

For years Woman's Hour has been an enduringly successful part of Radio 4. Yet mysteriously television has never created an equivalent. The early years of Channel 4 were littered with brave failures in this genre and the all-woman radio station Viva was also a much publicised unhappy experience.

Of course, Trisha and This Morning and UK Living cater for the Oxygen audience, but primarily in daytime and without "attitude". Oxygen is, as it were, wanting to be a channel with balls. It aims high, "We want to understand women bone-deep and tell the world what we learn . . . we'd like women to rewrite the world's script to reflect their values and goals."

The Oxygen line-up will offer much more than studio chat shows. Edgy animation in the mould of The Simpsons with Break-Up Girl, an interactive teen show called Trackers, and an innovative women's sports programme are promised. The key figure will be one of Oprah's partners - Geraldine Laybourne, a tough executive whose ability to create the kind of street-smart brand she developed with the kids' channel Nickelodeon will be vital. But in the end for an unforgiving, choice-rich audience the programmes just have to be good.

Already, America has a successful women's cable channel in Lifetime, with more than 75m subscribers. Although laughingly dubbed Wifetime because of its soft, middle-aged tone, it dominates the market and has begun to counteract the arrival of Oxygen with younger programmes.

Like all media start-ups, Oxygen will be short of breath. All the programmes will be brand new, without repeats, and inevitably some will fail. Yet at $400m the programme budget will be significantly higher than other new cable channels.

However, much of the cash comes from such usual male media suspects as Microsoft founder Paul Allen and the ubiquitous AOL, as well as from Oprah's own company Harpo. Their most recent investor, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world's leading luxury goods brand, contrasts sharply with the grass-roots, empowering tone of Oxygen's mission statement.

Delegates at the Guardian Edinburgh International Television Festival would also be cautious about how different Oxygen will really be. Comedy producer Caryn Mandabach, an Oxygen partner, gave last year's Worldview lecture and beforehand she said, "Women will love it but perhaps the men ought to leave. . . men will think it's an attack." In fact, her occasionally funny but largely vacuous speech had both sexes in the audience squirming. As one delegate put it, "I was embarrassed to be a woman. I wanted to hide behind my chair." Closer inspection of Oxygen's schedules are not much more encouraging. For all the edgy animation they are also producing Pyjama Party, with viewers coaxed by ads to"Have your bachelorette soirée on TV with us here at Pyjama Party. PJs, snacks, games and the BOD squad."

Despite the recent feminisation of British television, it's still hard not to feel faintly jealous of Oxygen. For all its US plasticity and marketing hype it is trying something different. Original programming, high ambition, cultural as well as commercial aspirations, and at least some promising programmes all add up to a potentially rich mixture.

However, the founders of Oxygen have an enormous responsibility. A team of such creative, well respected and wealthy women will never come together again like this. They need to create a channel and websites that add more value to women's lives than flogging Louis Vuitton luggage or pumping up the subscription levels of AOL. As the cliche goes, they need to make a difference or they will let not only themselves but also women generally down. But if they get it right, male executives will sit up and take notice.

Oprah master class, New Media, page 60. John Willis is chief executive of United Productions

fields.headline: Meriol Trevor
fields.standfirst: Author of enchanting children's books and award-winning biography
fields.trailText: Meriol Trevor, who has died aged 80, wrote enchanting children's books, novels and an award-winning biography of Cardinal Newman. Her Catholicism and understanding of history quietly underlaid all her work.
fields.body:
Meriol Trevor, who has died aged 80, wrote enchanting children's books, novels and an award-winning biography of Cardinal Newman. Her Catholicism and understanding of history quietly underlaid all her work.

She established herself as a children's writer with Sun Faster Sun Slower (1955), Merlin's Ring (1957), The Other Side of the Moon (1957), The Sparrow Child (1958) and The Rose-Round (1963): in these, the theme of redemption, often hidden in mythic or symbolic guise, infuses her narrative. The stories are often more successful in conveying the tenets of Christian faith through a fantasy format than CS Lewis's fiction; they deal squarely with suffering, family conflict and loss of confidence as well as conveying a rich treasury of delight and adventure to the reader.

Trevor's ability to evoke the intense landscape of childhood was fuelled by playing with her brother in the orchards and gardens of Kent, where they grew up. With her lifelong friend Margaret Priestly, Trevor invented Letzenstein, whose chronicles became the subject of many stories; previously unpublished, they have been recently issued by the small American press, Bethlehem Books.

Of Welsh descent, the daughter of an Indian army officer, Trevor was educated at Perse Girls' School, Cambridge and St Hugh's College, Oxford, where she graduated in classics and philosophy. Subsequently she worked in a London nursery, steered canal cargo vessels between London and Birmingham and worked as a cook at a delinquent boys' camp.

After the second world war she volunteered as a relief worker in European reconstruction and was exposed to Catholic culture while in Italy. In 1950 she was received into the church.

Trevor's adult novels explored the meeting of the Romano-British world with the Saxon invasion in The Last of Britain (1956) and The New People (1957); in The Golden Palaces (1986) and The Ring of Constantine (unpublished), she wrote of the frictions of early Christian Europe. These novels reveal Trevor's experience of living through war, becoming reconciled with one's enemies and the inspirations necessary to foster recovery after conflict.

Although she wrote a credible portrait of James II, Shadow of the Crown (1988), Trevor's major biographical triumph, awarded the James Tait Black Memorial Prize for biography in 1963, was her two-volume study of Cardinal Newman, consisting of Newman: The Pillar of Cloud and Newman: Light in Winter. Less well-known are her biographies of St Philip Neri, Apostle of Rome (1966) and Pope John XXIII, Pope John (1967).

From the early 1960s, Trevor lived modestly in a flat in Bath and never married. Her brother survives her.

Meriol Trevor, novelist and biographer, born April 15 1919; died January 12 2000

fields.headline: Jenny, Eric, Martin . . . and me
fields.standfirst: Her book about a girl living with her father and his gay lover fuelled the outcry that led to section 28. As a new row rages over the controversial law,  Susanne Bosche wonders what the fuss is all about
fields.trailText: Her book about a girl living with her father and his gay lover fuelled the outcry that led to section 28. As a new row rages over the controversial law, Susanne Bosche wonders what the fuss is all about
fields.body:
In 1977 I made my first (and only) trip to the UK - five days in London, leaving my one-year-old daughter, Louise, with her father at our home in Copenhagen. Back then I could never have imagined that I would end up embroiled in a British political issue, or that one of my children's books would become a weapon in a war over the teaching of sexuality in schools.

I loved those few days in London. I travelled with a friend, and we saw all the sights. We walked by the Thames, crossed the bridges, went shopping on Carnaby Steet and Kings Road for fancy clothes you could only dream about back in Copenhagen.We went to the theatre, and saw wonderful performances with a humour and an attitude to life that felt very close to the Danish way of thinking. A friend took us to a punk concert and we felt like two old aunties from the country. As we made our way home afterwards we agreed that Britain was miles ahead of Denmark.

But my next encounter with this promised land was very different. It came in 1983 when I was overwhelmed by journalists from different British papers who all hoped to get a story about how badly life had turned out for the little family in my book, Jenny Lives with Eric and Martin. They were very disappointed to discover that it was a fictional story, that the real people who inspired it hadn't fallen victim to any unmentionable disease - and, not least, that I was straight. When they concluded there were no scandals to be found, they lost interest and I didn't have any contact with the British press until recently when my Jenny book was sucked once again into the argument over section 28.

My first book was published in 1977 and I have been writing children's books ever since. The entertainment value has always been important to me, but it seems just as important to give children relevant stories and, in a gentle way, to help them understand themselves and the society they live in. I believe that a good children's book has a built-in tiny bit of wisdom - like the old fairytales. As mother, father, teacher or author we should give our children stories that give them all the time in the world to remain in, and enjoy, their childhood. But we are also responsible for giving them stories that gently open their minds and prepare them for meeting the world as adults - a world in which adults are no longer available to solve the children's problems with a hug and a kiss.

This is the foundation of all my books. I wrote Jenny Lives with Eric and Martin back in 1981 because I became aware of the problems which some children face when meeting family groupings different from the ones they are familiar with, ie mum and dad, possibly mum and dad divorced, maybe a step-parent. It's not possible to go through life without meeting people living in different ways, and they shouldn't come as a shock to anybody.

W hile researching for the book I became aware that there are a lot of children in Denmark living with a homosexual father or mother, and that there was a need for a book for these children to identify with. So I wrote this everyday story about Jenny living with her father - and stepfather. And it was absolutely shocking to see the book vilified as homosexual propaganda in the British press back in 1983 and (to a lesser degree) again now. I feel angry that my intentions in writing this book - namely to give children a little more knowledge about the world - have been twisted by grown-up people who chose to use it as a weapon in a political battle. It has also been depressing to see my own words from interviews misrepresented to fit this or that position.

For what it's worth, I don't personally think homosexuality (or any other subject) should be aggressively promoted in schools, but I do think it should be talked about in an informative, unsensational, way. One way of doing that is by making books like mine available to children in schools and libraries - as is done in Denmark - and by letting teachers and parents be prepared to answer questions without unnecessary drama.

fields.headline: Keep up
fields.standfirst: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future?  Catch up here...
fields.trailText: Missed what the top analysts are saying about our digital future? Catch up here...
fields.body:
* Cynthia Cotts www.villagevoice.com Steve Brill is on a hiring spree. After commissioning Luke Hayman of Ogilvy & Mather to redesign the print version of Brill's Content, Brill signed Hayman to give a unified look to his advertising, print and internet ventures. Another new hire is executive editor Ramsey Flynn. And this spring, Brill says, he's going to hire "30 people in editorial", as he ramps up to launch his new e-commerce venture and online magazine.

Thanks to the redesign and a $1m ad campaign, people are definitely talking about the February issue. But is Brill paying too much attention to packaging content and not enough to those who create it? In November, it lost senior editors Lorne Manly and Nicholas Varchaver. Two more writers left last week. Then last Friday staff writer Ted Rose quit to freelance, making it a certifiable trend.

* Dan Frost www.sfgate.com If building a brand is so important, why are some big publishers tinkering with, or trashing, brands that brought success? TheStreet.com, the New York purveyor of financial news and analysis, is making its flagship site at www.thestreet.com free to all. It will keep a subscription only site, at www.realmoney.com, where people can pay to read columnists like James Cramer, Herb Greenberg and Adam Lashinsky. In other words, even though TheStreet built its brand by promoting those columnists, people who go to the site once the change takes place won't find Cramer or Greenberg's latest musings.

* Michael Wolff www.nymag.com Computer magazines are like girlie magazines. For a long time, they were the only place a man with certain interests could go. PC Magazine was possibly the most profitable magazine since Playboy's dominance of the mag market in the mid-60s. But then a revolution took place and, like sex, technology was everywhere. You didn't have to take a computer magazine up to your bedroom. The irony is that, out of the limelight, computer mags were some of the greatest creators of legal cash of our time; in the limelight, profits dwindled but glamour increased. This trade-off can be good, sort of, because glamour is more valuable than profits these days. But glamour is a different game from evaluating hard drives. I wonder if my "anonymous mogul" knows this. If he is to compete in this suddenly hot publishing space, he will have to take his dullsville computer mags and refit them as hip voices for the new economy. The Industry Standard, which in the 21 months since its launch has become such a voice, recently took a round of investment that values the magazine at $200m. Soon it will go public at, what the hell, a billion.

fields.headline: The greatest job in Britain?
fields.standfirst:
Northern editor Martin Wainwright discusses the regional implications of junior defence minister Peter Kilfoyle's resignation to concentrate his efforts on running for Liverpool mayor
Plus: Bat power
fields.trailText: Before he quit his ministerial post, Peter Kilfoyle will have felt like one of Chris Tarrant's contestants who had just plumped for the 50-50 option in Who Wants to be a Millionaire?   Answer A: spend your life at endless black-tie dinners with military chaps whose only concern is getting more missiles/frigates/tanks. Or answer B: have a crack at putting one of Britain's greatest cities back on the international map.
fields.body:
Before he quit his ministerial post, Peter Kilfoyle will have felt like one of Chris Tarrant's contestants who had just plumped for the 50-50 option in Who Wants to be a Millionaire? Answer A: spend your life at endless black-tie dinners with military chaps whose only concern is getting more missiles/frigates/tanks. Or answer B: have a crack at putting one of Britain's greatest cities back on the international map.

No need to ask the audience for help on that one; Mr Kilfoyle may have lost the chance of greater ministerial glory in the future, but that is not where the chance to do something effective in the UK of the 21st century is exclusively going to lie.

We may be getting carried away with ourselves beyond the M25, but the signs of a real, coherent sense of regionalism really do grow by the day. Not just the spread of grassroots campaigns for elected regional bodies, which now have a real head of steam in the north-east, north-west, Yorkshire and the Humber, but also the new readiness of national institutions to work through a regional structure.

The nine official English regions are becoming the accepted framework for devolving power, in place of a mish-mash of conflicting boundaries which for decades - no, centuries - worked the old centralist ploy of divide and rule.

The lottery's "good causes" are an interesting example, important because they fascinate the public and media far more than anonymous government departments which spend many, many times more public money without anyone paying much attention.

The National Lottery Charities Board, Sport England and the Arts Council all devolve their grant-making to committees in the nine regions. And dozy old Heritage has finally changed the name of its old England committee to the committee of the English regions, at the insistence of a leading regionalista, Sir Ernest Hall of the Dean Clough arts and industrial centre in Halifax.

This new regional coherence is bound to attract more big players like Peter Kilfoyle back home, just as the return of power to London has pulled two former cabinet ministers and a backbench star across the Thames from Westminster.

If Kilfoyle becomes the first mayor of Liverpool (helped by a useful bit of flak against the "southern middle class"), he will also become the de facto leader of the Merseyside region; and it is fascinating to wonder who will follow in his footsteps in Birmingham, Manchester, Bristol and Leeds.

For over 100 years, the trek has been in the opposite direction, with a parliamentary version of the Bermuda Triangle awaiting scores of bright and ambitious local government figures who swapped their mayoral chains for the portcullis notepaper of the House of Commons. Most of them simply vanished. The bizarre public school rituals of parliament were alien to a town hall philosophy of getting ordinary things done.

What we may now see, if regionalism is to meet its full potential, is a parallel to the United States' pool of capable state governors attracted by real, pragmatic power. And remember that, from their ranks, president after president have been drawn.

Useful links
New Labour in power: special report
North-south divide: special report
Liverpool city council
Department of the environment, transport and the regions

Bat power

It is great news, if rather belated, that the powers of the bat are to be harnessed to help blind people, via a glove or a stick with an ultrasound gadget which builds up a "sensory map". Just as bats swoop fearlessly round without hitting trees or buses, so will we be able to avoid pedestrians and cars when our eyes grow dim, rather than them having to avoid us.

The team responsible at Leeds university shouldn't stop there though. The simplest animal encyclopaedia is overflowing with examples of wonderful natural gifts endowed on other species, but not ourselves. Wouldn't it be nice at this time of year if our ears could act (via blood suffusion) as radiators, as happens with the black-tailed jackrabbit; or if we could (when retired) sleep uninterrupted between October and April, like the American black bear?

The animal which really repays study, though, is the leafy plum tree basilisk of central America which has cracked one of mankind's oldest dreams. By dint of running extremely fast and using its fringed toes as flippers, Basiliscus basiliscus has mastered the art of walking on water. With an observed record of over 130 feet, it is full of potential - and has unquestionably earned its vernacular name of the Jesus Christ Lizard.

Answer A: spend your life at endless black-tie dinners with military chaps whose only concern is getting more missiles/frigates/tanks. Or answer B: have a crack at putting one of Britain's greatest cities back on the international map. No need to ask the audience for help on that one; Mr Kilfoyle may have lost the chance of greater ministerial glory in the future, but that is not where the chance to do something effective in the UK of the 21st century is exclusively going to lie. We may be getting carried away with ourselves beyond the M25, but the signs of a real, coherent sense of regionalism really do grow by the day. Not just the spread of grassroots campaigns for elected regional bodies, which now have a real head of steam in the north-east, north-west, Yorkshire and the Humber, but also the new readiness of national institutions to work through a regional structure. webTitle: Britain's conditions for joining the euro

fields.headline: Britain's conditions for joining the euro
fields.standfirst: EMU: special report
fields.trailText:
What does the government think of the euro?
Under the Maastricht Treaty, the UK can choose if and when it wants to join the single currency. The government decided that the economy was not ready to join on 1 January 1999. However, the government supports the principle of joining the single currency, if that is in the national economic interest. It does not expect that to be the case during this parliament. Instead, the government says it is making the necessary preparations so that Britain has the option of joining the single currency early in the next parliament (which will start no later than spring 2002). If the government decided that the UK should join, a referendum will be held.
fields.body:
What does the government think of the euro?
Under the Maastricht Treaty, the UK can choose if and when it wants to join the single currency. The government decided that the economy was not ready to join on 1 January 1999. However, the government supports the principle of joining the single currency, if that is in the national economic interest. It does not expect that to be the case during this parliament. Instead, the government says it is making the necessary preparations so that Britain has the option of joining the single currency early in the next parliament (which will start no later than spring 2002). If the government decided that the UK should join, a referendum will be held.

How does the government define the national interest?
The government has set out its famous five tests for joining the single European currency.

  • Are business cycles and economic structures compatible so that we and others could live comfortably with euro interest rates on a permanent basis?
  • If problems emerge is there sufficient flexibility to deal with them?
  • Would joining EMU create better conditions for firms making long-term decisions to invest in Britain?
  • What impact would entry into EMU have on the competitive position of the UK's financial services industry, particularly the City's wholesale markets?
  • In summary, will joining EMU promote higher growth, stability and a lasting increase in jobs?

    On the issue of convergence, Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank, acknowledged that Britain and Europe were out of synch economically and that it would take years for them to achieve convergence in interest rates, inflation and exchange rates.

    Chancellor Gordon Brown laid out the issues of the single currency in October 1997 and Mr Blair in early 1999.

    How are Britain and Europe out of sync?
    UK interest rates are double those on the continent, and with house price inflation already reaching late 1980s levels in the south-east, cutting rates to European levels would be disastrous. The UK economy is in its eighth year of growth, while the eurozone is still just starting its recovery, but even if the cycles were more in sync, Britain would still need higher rates than Europe to keep price pressures under control.

    Working against the euro is its weakness. Why is it weak?
    As stated above, European economies are just starting to recover, but there is also scepticism about European economies' ability to compete and the burden of unaffordable welfare systems. That is why in late January, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers spoke about Europe's need to reform. As Ottmar Issing , the ECB's chief economist, admitted, reform "is not the dominating characteristic of the euro area".

    Why has Tony Blair not pushed harder on the euro?
    The British public is deeply sceptical of the single currency, as poll after poll shows. The latest ICM poll for the BBC (late January) showed 69% of voters against the euro, the highest level of opposition yet. Besides, the government is divided, with Mr Brown in the eurosceptic camp while foreign secretary Robin Cook champions joining the single currency. If Mr Blair pushes too hard, he risks splitting the party. But if Mr Blair plays it too softly, softly, he risks handing the initiative to William Hague and the Tories, who have coined the slogan, "In Europe, not run by Europe".

webTitle: Pinochet records must stay secret, court rules

fields.headline: Pinochet records must stay secret, court rules
fields.trailText: General Augusto Pinochet is a step closer to flying home to Chile after   Belgium and six human rights groups today lost their high court action to   force a judicial review.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet is a step closer to flying home to Chile after Belgium and six human rights groups today lost their high court action to force a judicial review.

They had challenged home secretary Jack Straw to reveal the contents of the medical tests that left him 'minded' not to extradite the former Chilean dictator to face trial in Spain .

Justice Maurice Kay said the report should not be disclosed and that the application must consequently be refused.

The judge added that Mr Straw had already obtained an impartial medical assessment of Pinochet by an internationally distinguished team of clinicians. The call for a fresh assessment was inappropriate, he said.

Belgium and human rights groups including Amnesty International said the secrecy over the report was depriving them of a chance to make informed and "meaningful" representations to Mr Straw, or possibly challenge him in the courts.

Mr Straw recently announced his wish to end, on compassionate grounds, the costly and long-running extradition proceedings against the 84-year-old general.

A Chilean Air Force Boeing 707 jet is waiting on the tarmac at RAF Brize Norton, Oxon, ready to take Pinochet home.

The general may still have to wait however, as today's application for judicial review could yet be renewed before two or three other judges in the High Court before Mr Straw has a chance to make a final decision. Belgium has said it will appeal.

Later, Amnesty International said the "fairness and transparency" of the procedure followed by Mr Straw to assess Pinochet's mental condition "remain in doubt".

The human rights group said in a statement: "We took action in court in an effort to ensure that all decisions in the extradition proceedings are reached in a fair and transparent manner.

"Throughout the proceedings we have called for justice, not politics."

Amnesty said it was continuing its call on Mr Straw to honour the requests made by the parties, including Belgium, France, Spain and Switzerland, to allow them to nominate experts to carry out another medical examination and for him to make the original medical report available.

"Justice must not only be done but must be seen to be done," said Amnesty.

webTitle: Chile jet arrives in Britain to await ruling on Pinochet home

fields.headline: Chile jet arrives in Britain to await ruling on Pinochet home
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: A Chilean jet was yesterday waiting at a British airbase to take former dictator Augusto Pinochet home if his extradition case is dropped.
fields.body:
A Chilean jet was yesterday waiting at a British airbase to take former dictator Augusto Pinochet home if his extradition case is dropped.

The Chilean air force Boeing 707 touched down at RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire on Saturday night after flying from Bermuda, where its crew had been waiting out the legal battle in London. Groups which oppose allowing the former dictator to return to Chile on health grounds will learn today whether they can go ahead with a last-ditch legal challenge.

Mr Justice Maurice Kay is expected to rule whether Belgium and six human rights groups can seek a judicial review of the home secretary, Jack Straw's refusal to let them see the medical reports which prompted his warning that he was "minded" to drop the extradition proceedings. If the judge rejects the request, the way will be clear for Mr Straw to announce his final decision which could see the 84-year-old former dictator heading back to Chile. The home secretary has undertaken not to make an announcement while the matter is before the courts.

He has also promised to give parties 24 hours notice before delivering his verdict. Belgium, one of four countries seeking to extradite General Pinochet to face charges of human rights abuses, is arguing it has a right to see the medical report drawn up by home office-appointed doctors to enable it to make representations to the home secretary.

Six human rights groups which also took part in last week's high court hearing have complained they cannot make sensible representations without seeing the report.

fields.headline: Life after death
fields.standfirst:
The searing play Death and the Maiden examined the scars left by a brutal dictatorship after the restoration of democracy. As General Pinochet's return to Chile seems ever more likely, Duncan Campbell asks the tortured how they can bear to see their tormentors go unpunished

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The searing play Death and the Maiden examined the scars left by a brutal dictatorship after the restoration of democracy. As General Pinochet's return to Chile seems ever more likely,  Duncan Campbell asks the tortured how they can bear to see their tormentors go unpunished
fields.body:
In the afterword to his play, Death and the Maiden, the story of a torture victim of a dictatorship confronting her torturer after the country had returned to democracy, the Chilean writer Ariel Dorfman poses a number of questions: "How can those who tortured and those who were tortured coexist in the same land? How to heal a country that has been traumatised by repression if the fear to speak out is still omnipresent? And how do you reach the truth if lying has become a habit? How do we keep the past alive without becoming its prisoner?"

While the main question in the minds of Chileans at the moment may be what, if anything, will happen to General Pinochet when, and if, he returns, the underlying questions are those posed by Dorfman. How does a country deal with the legacy of the dictatorship when its victims and its protagonists may, as happens in Dorfman's play, bump into each other by chance? How do Pinochet's prisoners ensure that they do not remain locked in the dungeons of the past?

Coca Rudolphy was one of Chile's leading actresses and a known leftwinger when she was arrested in 1973. Although she was the daughter of an admiral, she was tortured on what was known as the "barbecue", a bed-like contraption on which she was held with electrodes attached to her body, kept in solitary confinement for 40 days, then taken to a concentration camp.

She was eventually released in 1975, after pressure from Amnesty International and Equity. When her father was warned that, if she was detained again, she would be killed, she went into exile in Britain. Her story appeared in the Guardian in 1976 and she returned to Chile in 1984. Three years later, a rightwing terrorist group warned her and 80 other actors and writers that if they did not leave the country within 30 days they would be assassinated. Those threatened, along with the Superman actor Christopher Reeve, who flew in to show his support, put on a show on the day of the deadline. Everyone stayed.

Like the woman in Dorfman's play, Rudolphy had met one of her torturers after her release: "You fantasise what you will do if one day you find them, but when it happened I felt nothing. He took my arm and said, 'I know you. How are you?' I said, 'You certainly know me very well' - because when you are tortured you are naked - 'I'm OK.' I felt nothing. I despised him and we coexist because we have to coexist.

"I don't feel any rancour now. I'm happy to be alive. In personal terms, I don't feel anger but, if it had happened to my brother, maybe I would feel differently. I can cope with it - and I'm glad we are in a democracy now."

When Rudolphy first returned to Chile, Pinochet was still in power and she was blacklisted as an actor. But the most difficult part for her was the national denial of what had happened: "It was worse than being in jail. You felt that all you had been through was for nothing, that nobody cared. People would not talk about it at all. Now everyone, even the rightwing, accepts that torture went on and the most painful thing is their arrogance. When there are people who say it was 'necessary', it is very difficult to accept. But I am at peace with myself."

Psychiatrist Elizabeth Lira has been working with victims of torture for more than 15 years. She has also watched the effect of the detention of Pinochet on the national psyche of Chile. "Hate and fear increase if you don't recognise those emotions," she says. For those reasons she believes it is important that Chile now examines and articulates what has happened to the country. "The normal reaction is that people do not want to know because it means that they have to confront horrible things." Some of her patients, she says, had been able to carry on with their lives, but others lived permanently in the shadow of the torture.

"Sometimes people who had been tortured had to sign a declaration when they were released saying that they had not been mistreated. They would then feel that it was impossible for a judge to believe them when they later said they had signed the statement out of fear." For the victims, she says, it is important to have some sort of acknowledgement, to have a judgment of Pinochet.

For the supporters of Pinochet, too, says Lira, the revelations that have emerged during the 15 months of his detention in Britain have been problematic: "If you recognise that this man has supported torture, it implies that you have supported it too and, for some people, that is not possible." For them, his detention has been educational, because they suddenly find themselves as the supposedly aggrieved party and are furious that he should be detained in this way, while accepting that others could be detained and even killed because it was "necessary".

"While he is still in England it is much easier to discuss everything here," says Lira. "The armed forces were like totems, icons - invulnerable. Now that has ended, and people realise that the only way to have normality is not to have totems."

Diana Duhalde is one of those who were tortured after the coup. She is now a professor of photography in Santiago. She says that while she does not live in fear, she is "prudent" about what she says and to whom. Now she thinks that if Pinochet is not to be tried in Europe it is better that he returns to Chile, "so that he does not become a martyr". (Others have said that they would welcome Pinochet's return to Chile - so they could dance on his grave.)

Since they were usually blindfolded, perhaps only 20% of the surviving victims can identify their torturers (in Dorfman's play, the victim, Paulina, recognises her interrogator only by his voice), but it has been possible to trace some of them. A French television team has been in Santiago confronting torturers with their victims. The results have not been shown in Chile, but the film, shot with a hidden camera, shows that most of the torturers first deny any involvement at all - one says that he was only in the torture centre to take his lunch - then say that they personally did not participate, and finally try to end the interview.

For many Chileans, one of the most disturbing aspects of the torture has been to discover that doctors had assisted, either by patching up victims so they could continue to be interrogated, or by advising on how information could best be obtained. Another speciality of the Dina (secret police) teams was to bring relatives of the victims to watch or listen to the torture.

What has emerged from the testimonies of those interviewed as part of the investigation into Pinochet is the sheer pornographic sadism of his subordinates: a father forced to bugger his son; a dog made to rape a woman; a man dragged along the ground by a rope attached to a helicopter; suspects opened up with carving knives before they were dumped in the sea, so that their bodies would not float.

As the tide turned against Pinochet in the late 80s, details of the torture started to emerge. Following the formation of the Rettig commission, set up by the democratically elected president Patricio Aylwin in 1990, agreements were made to give recompense, in the form of pensions, to the relatives of those who had been killed. In addition, more than 20 people have now been jailed, including Manuel Contreras, the head of Dina.

One of the Rettig commission's members was the human rights lawyer and former deputy director general of Amnesty International, Jose Zalaquett. An old friend of Ariel Dorfman, he, too, has pondered the questions of the torturer and the tortured and of how a nation moves out of the darkness.

"Religions put a premium on forgiveness," he says, "but there is a great confusion here. There can be no absolution if you don't acknowledge what you have done, atone for it and prepare to make recompense." He believes that it will take two generations before the national wounds are healed; there are the victims, and then there are the children who grew up knowing what had happened to their parents. But Zalaquett also believes that, because the source of what happened in Chile was political rather than ethnic or religious, reconciliation will be relatively swift.

For the hardline Pinochet supporters, acknowledgment of systematic torture is not acceptable. At a gathering of people praying for the general's safe return last week, one woman, asked if she accepted that there had been torture, replied: "The only torture was by the Marxists who tortured the police and the soldiers." A 60ft statue commemorating "the police martyrs" erected during the Pinochet era stands in the centre of Santiago. Another woman - most of his more vocal supporters are women, as are most of the organisers of the human rights groups - said: "They say that thousands were tortured but there were no more than 80." Others excuse it with a reference to omelettes - you can't make one without breaking a few eggs.

One of the chief torture centres was the Villa Grimaldi in Penalolen, on the dusty outskirts of Santiago. It has now been turned into a "peace park" with the names of those who were killed or tortured - "physical pressure" was the official word for it - written on a wall. Among the names, reflecting the politics of their parents' generation, are young men called Stalin Aguilera and Washington Cid.

The British surgeon, Sheila Cassidy, was held here while she was questioned about a man she had treated for a bullet wound. She, too, was tied to the "barbecue", had electrodes inserted into her vagina, was gagged and told to lift a finger when she was ready to talk. She, like many others who survived, was made to sign a statement saying that she had not been treated badly while under detention.

The building at the Villa Grimaldi itself has been demolished, but there are signs marking its different functions: one plaque marks the place where cars were driven over prisoners' legs, another where the barbecue was operated. The old main gate to the villa, through which the blindfolded prisoners were driven on what was, for many of them, their last journey, is padlocked now. The sign reads: "This door will remain closed forever."

What many Chileans are now coming to accept is that the doors that have been locked to the past have to be opened again. The old commander-in-chief, the man whose rank gave him the ultimate official responsibility for the deaths and the torture, seems about to return to his homeland and Chileans have to wait to see if truth and reconciliation will follow. There are risks on all sides. As Gerardo, the husband of the tortured Paulina in Death and the Maiden, says: "People can die from an excessive dose of truth."

They would then feel that it was impossible for a judge to believe them when they later said they had signed the statement out of fear." For the victims, she says, it is important to have some sort of acknowledgement, to have a judgment of Pinochet. For the supporters of Pinochet, too, says Lira, the revelations that have emerged during the 15 months of his detention in Britain have been problematic: "If you recognise that this man has supported torture, it implies that you have supported it too and, for some people, that is not possible." For them, his detention has been educational, because they suddenly find themselves as the supposedly aggrieved party and are furious that he should be detained in this way, while accepting that others could be detained and even killed because it was "necessary". "While he is still in England it is much easier to discuss everything here," says Lira. "The armed forces were like totems, icons - invulnerable. Now that has ended, and people realise that the only way to have normality is not to have totems." Diana Duhalde is one of those who were tortured after the coup. She is now a professor of photography in Santiago. She says that while she does not live in fear, she is "prudent" about what she says and to whom. Now she thinks that if Pinochet is not to be tried in Europe it is better that he returns to Chile, "so that he does not become a martyr". (Others have said that they would welcome Pinochet's return to Chile - so they could dance on his grave.) Since they were usually blindfolded, perhaps only 20% of the surviving victims can identify their torturers (in Dorfman's play, the victim, Paulina, recognises her interrogator only by his voice), but it has been possible to trace some of them. A French television team has been in Santiago confronting torturers with their victims. The results have not been shown in Chile, but the film, shot with a hidden camera, shows that most of the torturers first deny any involvement at all - one says that he was only in the torture centre to take his lunch - then say that they personally did not participate, and finally try to end the interview. For many Chileans, one of the most disturbing aspects of the torture has been to discover that doctors had assisted, either by patching up victims so they could continue to be interrogated, or by advising on how information could best be obtained. Another speciality of the Dina (secret police) teams was to bring relatives of the victims to watch or listen to the torture. What has emerged from the testimonies of those interviewed as part of the investigation into Pinochet is the sheer pornographic sadism of his subordinates: a father forced to bugger his son; a dog made to rape a woman; a man dragged along the ground by a rope attached to a helicopter; suspects opened up with carving knives before they were dumped in the sea, so that their bodies would not float. As the tide turned against Pinochet in the late 80s, details of the torture started to emerge. Following the formation of the Rettig commission, set up by the democratically elected president Patricio Aylwin in 1990, agreements were made to give recompense, in the form of pensions, to the relatives of those who had been killed. In addition, more than 20 people have now been jailed, including Manuel Contreras, the head of Dina. One of the Rettig commission's members was the human rights lawyer and former deputy director general of Amnesty International, Jose Zalaquett. An old friend of Ariel Dorfman, he, too, has pondered the questions of the torturer and the tortured and of how a nation moves out of the darkness. "Religions put a premium on forgiveness," he says, "but there is a great confusion here. There can be no absolution if you don't acknowledge what you have done, atone for it and prepare to make recompense." He believes that it will take two generations before the national wounds are healed; there are the victims, and then there are the children who grew up knowing what had happened to their parents. But Zalaquett also believes that, because the source of what happened in Chile was political rather than ethnic or religious, reconciliation will be relatively swift. For the hardline Pinochet supporters, acknowledgment of systematic torture is not acceptable. At a gathering of people praying for the general's safe return last week, one woman, asked if she accepted that there had been torture, replied: "The only torture was by the Marxists who tortured the police and the soldiers." A 60ft statue commemorating "the police martyrs" erected during the Pinochet era stands in the centre of Santiago. Another woman - most of his more vocal supporters are women, as are most of the organisers of the human rights groups - said: "They say that thousands were tortured but there were no more than 80." Others excuse it with a reference to omelettes - you can't make one without breaking a few eggs. One of the chief torture centres was the Villa Grimaldi in Penalolen, on the dusty outskirts of Santiago. It has now been turned into a "peace park" with the names of those who were killed or tortured - "physical pressure" was the official word for it - written on a wall. Among the names, reflecting the politics of their parents' generation, are young men called Stalin Aguilera and Washington Cid. The British surgeon, Sheila Cassidy, was held here while she was questioned about a man she had treated for a bullet wound. She, too, was tied to the "barbecue", had electrodes inserted into her vagina, was gagged and told to lift a finger when she was ready to talk. She, like many others who survived, was made to sign a statement saying that she had not been treated badly while under detention. The building at the Villa Grimaldi itself has been demolished, but there are signs marking its different functions: one plaque marks the place where cars were driven over prisoners' legs, another where the barbecue was operated. The old main gate to the villa, through which the blindfolded prisoners were driven on what was, for many of them, their last journey, is padlocked now. The sign reads: "This door will remain closed forever." What many Chileans are now coming to accept is that the doors that have been locked to the past have to be opened again. The old commander-in-chief, the man whose rank gave him the ultimate official responsibility for the deaths and the torture, seems about to return to his homeland and Chileans have to wait to see if truth and reconciliation will follow. There are risks on all sides. As Gerardo, the husband of the tortured Paulina in Death and the Maiden, says: "People can die from an excessive dose of truth."

fields.headline: email
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Few places are more evocative of the Chilean coup than the National Stadium in Santiago where hundreds of leftists were rounded up and identified as "Soviet spy" or "Marxist" by hooded collaborators before being taken off to be tortured or shot. So it was interesting to hear the thoughts of a group of students larking about at the stadium in one of the boiling hot days that drives many Santiaguinos to the coast at this time of year.
fields.body:
Few places are more evocative of the Chilean coup than the National Stadium in Santiago where hundreds of leftists were rounded up and identified as "Soviet spy" or "Marxist" by hooded collaborators before being taken off to be tortured or shot. So it was interesting to hear the thoughts of a group of students larking about at the stadium in one of the boiling hot days that drives many Santiaguinos to the coast at this time of year.

One 19-year-old said that although she had not been born at the time of the 1973 coup, she knew many artists and actors had died during it and added that this had been the death of Chilean culture. Certainly the imprisonment or execution of writers and artists was followed by the exile of countless others and not all have returned. But the resistance to the coup inspired many books and - abroad - some famous films and plays.

One of the people held at the stadium was the young American writer and film-maker Charles Horman. His death led to the 1982 Costa-Gavras film Missing in which Jack Lemmon starred as Horman's father. Ariel Dorfman's play Death and the Maiden became a film with Sigourney Weaver playing a tortured dissident. Now there is no small excitement that Emma Thompson's film about Victor Jara, the folk singer executed in 1973, is supposedly finally to be made.

The recent events regarding General Pinochet in London have led to a boom in books about the time of the coup. Santiago's largest bookshop has a vast range of literature about the politics of Pinochet which indicate that the country has certainly been getting to know the general while he has been away. They range from Pinochet's own boxed set of writings - mainly reprinted interviews and essays - to glossy books on Salvador Allende, the man whom he overthrew. The complete list of the charges laid against Pinochet by the Spanish judge Baltasar Garzon is also on sale in book form.

Many books show Pinochet in full uniform, a Prussian legacy. One of his daughters lamented in the daily El Mercurio that many people abroad had the wrong impression of him because the only image they saw was of the old boy in dark glasses and those sinister uniforms. If only he had posed in cardigan and cravat, how different everything might have been.

Isabel Allende, the niece of the late president and now a resident of San Rafael in California, is top of the best-sellers and has been in the fiction lists with her latest book, Hija de la Fortuna, for 44 weeks. The best-selling non-fiction book is Women: the Sexual Secret. Its success coincides with moves to make divorce legal in the country, the last in the western hemisphere where it is still against the law although annulments are regularly granted.

The main event of the past week has been the "transparent house", where an actress has been going about her daily business in a glass house in full view of a fascinated public. Some would like to see the actress and the two architects who conceived this performance art prosecuted, so a group of politicians from centre-left and left parties have been going along as a sign of solidarity. How many British politicians would brave the mockery of the press and the wrath of the right to do the same?

Over the past year, of course, the chief objects of the wrath of the Pinochetistas have been the British and Spanish embassy residencies, handily placed close to each other in Providencia. Eggs have been among the main missiles thrown by angry demonstrators, presumably as a statement on the standard explanation (omlettes/eggs) given to foreign journalists for the necessity to torture.

At least two residents of the compound have relished some of the missiles. The British embassy's frisky Airedale terriers gratefully polished off the eggs hurled over the wall. Such diplomatic sangfroid.

fields.headline: False Dawn
fields.standfirst: Morgan Cartwright thinks newspapers have failed in cyberspace.  And he should know, he works in the net-savvy capital - San Francisco
fields.trailText: In 1995 and 1996, newspaper leaders unveiled a bold vision in which cyberspace would release us from the earthly bonds and the enormous costs of newspaper production and distribution, while building a bridge to a vibrant hi-tech journalism of the next century. It hasn't worked out that way.
fields.body:
Five years ago, the newspaper industry appeared well placed to be a leader in the new business of internet publishing. Content-rich papers were in a prime position to take advantage of the text-driven medium. The internet would be a cheap but effective means of circulation; publishers could extend their local brand, influence and advertising reach across the landscape.

In 1995 and 1996, newspaper leaders unveiled a bold vision in which cyberspace would release us from the earthly bonds and the enormous costs of newspaper production and distribution, while building a bridge to a vibrant hi-tech journalism of the next century.

It hasn't worked out that way. There are some darn good online newspapers. But the major newspaper companies have not succeeded in building anything close to a Yahoo, eBay or Amazon.com. Even the most successful online American papers, the Washington Post, Boston Globe and Atlanta Journal-Constitution, reach less than 25% of their local market, while America Online and Yahoo command 40, 50, even 60%.

More typical are the Los Angeles Times, New York Times, Chicago Tribune and Philadelphia Inquirer - all powerhouse newspapers in print, but online they are reaching 10% or fewer of the local web users.

Many in and around the newspaper industry continue to forecast a positive future, predicting a day just ahead when there will be a wireless news device strapped to every wrist. But don't expect your favourite newspaper to play much of a role in making it happen. In America, newspaper executives are too busy trying to boost sliding circulations to take on the millionaire whizz kids and hi-tech deal makers of Silicon Valley.

Several of the larger newspaper companies, including Knight Ridder (Philadelphia Inquirer, Miami Herald, et al), the New York Times, the Chicago Tribune and the Washington Post, have concluded their only hope of making it rich in cyberspace is to pull their new media operations out of the stodgy, slow-moving newspaper world and re-position them as separate dot com start-ups.

It's too soon to say if these efforts will be successful. But they start from a common, and correct, assumption: that newspapers are ill-equipped to win in the internet space. Newspapers have their advantages: longstanding print/advertising relationships, a daily flow of news and information that can be used on the web, and a local, perhaps regional or even national brand. But so far that has not been enough.

Why, when a newspaper company comes along with a keen vision and a plump purse, has success been elusive? There are a number of reasons:

1) A lack of a clear objective and focused product. Many newspapers have tried to build an online version of the newspaper, one that emulates their print mission, which is to be all things to all people, and advertisers.

A typical American newspaper will receive about two thirds of its revenue from advertisers who are trying to reach 30-50% of the readership. Print advertising, from the splashy, full-page display ads of auto dealers to the three-line classifieds, cuts across numerous industries, and includes major accounts with million-dollar schedules as well as mom-and-pops who buy occasionally.

While this diversity seems to work fine in print, it has counted against newspapers on the net, where "category killer" niche websites can do a superior job. To attract advertisers in each of those industries requires a newspaper company to either build a dozen or more top-flight stand-alone websites in such categories as cars, real estate, employment, entertainment, personal finance, travel, health and tech news, or build the same number of "channels" for a portal, or city site. For those who have taken the latter course, the result has often been a dense, difficult to navigate hodgepodge.

Each way, the company's resources and focus are pulled in a dozen directions. And for each site, the competition will be fierce from "pure play" niche internet sites, such as the Monster.com employment site, the Travelocity travel site, and the tech news-and-reviews heavyweight Cnet.com.

2) Failure to market the product. One would think that newspaper companies, which sell ads, would understand the need to promote a product. But even where large newspaper companies have joined to build a single product line, such as Classified Ventures, the promotion has been meagre compared to the ubiquitous national campaigns of Yahoo!, AOL, Cnet and the other pure internet firms. Most papers have restricted promotion to house ads and editorial teasers in the paper, assuming this would drive traffic to their websites. Only a few have spent money advertising in other media.

3) A difficult labour market. Newspapers have low labour costs. Journalists are among the lowest-paid college-educated professionals. A similar advantage is gained on the sales side, with pay mostly commission-based. But in San Francisco, people with just months of web experience are snatched up by non-newspaper companies. If the newspaper attempts to pay web staffers more, unrest among print staff results. For big city papers, the problem can be the opposite: due to union wages, inflexible work rules and bad blood between labour and management, some papers find it difficult or impossible to build a competitive internet business in-house.

4) Failure to raise capital. Newspapers have found it difficult to raise the capital to compete with highly-valued online portals, search engines and city guides trying to home in on the paper's local information franchise. The internet firms have access to large amounts of cash from venture capitalists.

5) Poor management. Poor not because the managers are incompetent, but because they've been asked to do the impossible. The owners have asked management to save the print business while growing an entirely new business from the ground up. They have shown a misunderstanding of what it takes to be successful in such a complicated, fast-changing climate.

These print managers were trained and grew up in the traditional newspaper business, where it has taken decades just to get everyone using coloured ink. The glacial pace of change in the newspaper world is the opposite of what it is in the internet sphere, where whole industry sectors are born and die in a matter of months. That's the main reason companies such as the New York Times are building new businesses, with managers drawn from outside the publishing world. So far, however, neither company has been able to make a major impact, even with the spin-off strategy.

6) Journalism, as defined by highbrow traditionalists and communications school professors, no longer seems to carry the weight it once did. The digital generation appears content to get its news from the margins of Yahoo. Long think-pieces about the World Bank just don't fit anyone's schedule any more.

Whether newspapers can re-invent themselves to be relevant in the new age remains to be seen. New lessons will need to be learned, old habits dropped. Technology will have to play a much bigger role in the planning and strategy of the modern news service. There will need to be more young managers with fresh ideas. Journalists must adjust to the cultural shift by dispensing with some of the old sacred cows and finding a better balance between giving the public what it wants and what it needs.

Perhaps the industry's best strategy is to stay afloat as long as possible, hoping that the armada of internet dreadnoughts blow each other out of the water, or that by some miracle the Wired World finds its way back through some wormhole to a time when real news and real journalism matter. Now that would be a story worth reading.

Morgan Cartwright is online manager for the Contra Costa Times in the San Francisco Bay Area. mcartwright@cctimes.com
