fields.headline: Oprah master class
fields.standfirst: She bought a whole new audience to books. Can she do the same for the net? Jane Martinson on America's big online launch for women
fields.trailText: She bought a whole new audience to books. Can she do the same for the net? Jane Martinson on America's big online launch for women
fields.body:
Oprah Winfrey, a woman who claims never to have visited her own website unaided, will launch Oprah Goes Online this week on a new cable television network targeted at women. The chat-show diva, a multi-billionaire who gets staff to print out the 3,000 emails she receives a day, will invite viewers to join her on a 12-week course in mastering the internet both on air and online. Fans will be able to watch the show on Sunday and then follow an online tutorial any time they like.

The new show will be a flagship for Oxygen Media, a new network which launches tomorrow. It will be the latest attempt to grab hold of one of the most prized markets in the media industry today - online women.

Oxygen Media, which will reach 10m US homes with its first programme tomorrow, is one of several companies in the US which believes that this potential market has gone largely untapped. Under Geraldine Laybourne, its founder and the woman credited with making Nickelodeon the US's most popular station for children, Oxygen aims to link its television diet of chat shows and news with interactive events and information on its websites.

It is hardly the first television company to do so. Viacom, Laybourne's former employer, has launched a popular website on the back of MTV and other channels. But Oxygen has set itself the task of building a cable network offering original programming at the same time as a website for all women aged between 18 and 49. While still embryonic, its plans for interaction between the two media appear ambitious.

Linda Corradina, executive producer of Trackers, the new network's daily programme for teenage girls, says: 'This is different from any kind of traditional job I have ever had. When people pitch a story here, they ask whether it will make a good web story.' She adds that it will be different from most rival television shows in not offering a 'for more information turn to our website' link. Trackers is perhaps the best example of how Oxygen is trying to make the television audience and the web surfer one and the same. Young women (the target audience is between 16 and 20) will be able to email a resident therapist of the show for on air answers to their problems. The two-hour afternoon programme will be linked 24 hours a day to an online chatroom where girls will be encouraged to talk about their interests and desires. The emphasis will be on useful information and entertainment rather than agony aunt. 'We want to give them the tools to navigate their lives and we want them to have fun,' says Corradina.

The 10-year MTV veteran recognises the importance of brand loyalty - or 'stickiness' in the jargon - for new media products. 'If you grab them as young women, they will grow up with us. They will become Oxygen women,' she says.

The value of that 'Oxygen woman' is huge to the fledgling company. Women accounted for half of all internet users in the US for the first time at the end of last year, according to figures released by AdRelevance, a research group in the US. Not only is that an increase from 43% at the beginning of 1998, it also represents a sort of holy grail to e-commerce aficionados. Kurt Barnard, publisher of the Barnard Retail Monitor Report, says that women buy about 75% of all goods sold at American shopping centres. If that figure can be translated to the web - traditionally seen as the home of the (male) cyber-geek who would rather look at porn than buy anything - online companies devoted to women will be as attractive to advertisers as Vogue. Heavy-hitting Oxygen investors, which include Paul Allen, co-founder of Microsoft, as well as America Online, are salivating at the opportunities presented by new women-focused offerings. They see viewers watching a cooking programme, reviewing a demonstration online and then buying the ingredients and pans needed with the click of a mouse.

Oxygen faces tough competition from established media companies and online rivals. Lifetime, the only other US channel exclusively devoted to women, is to relaunch its website at the end of February. The Disney and Hearst-backed company is expected to offer greater connections between the new site and its cable programmes, which already reach more than 75m US homes. Hearst, publisher of several women's magazines, is also behind Women.com Networks, a women-only website launched last year. The site competes directly with iVillage, the four-year industry veteran which attracted 4.2m visitors last month, making it, according to Media Metrix, the most popular website targeted at women in the US.

These sites are general interest portals, which means that they seek to offer everything a woman might be interested in. This largely appears to be cooking, relationships and, of course, shopping. Other soon-to-be-launched websites are expected to focus on particular female groups. Specialist sites targeting new parents or new undergraduates have proved some of the most popular on the web.

In April, Kay Koplovitz, the founder of USA Network, the first advertiser-supported cable network in America, is expected to launch WorkingWomenNetwork. fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: No transfer gossip is too scurrilous for our daily round-up
fields.trailText: Teamtalk Porto striker Jardel has admitted he is interested in a move to Leeds this summer. "Leeds are having a great season, they are going for the Premiership title," said the Brazilian. "I am pleased to know about their interest at Elland Road in my qualities."
fields.body:
Teamtalk Porto striker Jardel has admitted he is interested in a move to Leeds this summer. "Leeds are having a great season, they are going for the Premiership title," said the Brazilian. "I am pleased to know about their interest at Elland Road in my qualities."

The Mirror Don Hutchison is prepared to open negotiations with both Newcastle and Sunderland if his last-ditch contract talks with Everton fail. "I'll give Everton first refusal - what I'm asking for isn't a great deal," revealed Hutchison. "But if not I would listen to offers."

Daily Star Ruud van Nistelrooy could be set to snub Arsenal, Chelsea and Manchester United and stay with Dutch club PSV Eindhoven for another season. Van Nistelrooy's agent, Rodger Linse, said: "PSV have a new team who are capable of winning things and they say they want to keep him one more season after this, and Ruud is happy with that."

Daily Mail Ipswich have not given up on signing Huddersfield's Marcus Stewart, but they may have to part with their own Richard Naylor in an exchange deal if they are to land the 14-goal striker.

webTitle: Lee Clegg cleared on last shooting charge

fields.headline: Lee Clegg cleared on last shooting charge
fields.trailText: Paratrooper Lee Clegg was today cleared of criminal wrong-doing over the killing of two teenage joyriders, bringing an end to a nine-year legal battle that became a potent issue in Northern Ireland's political landscape.
fields.body:
Paratrooper Lee Clegg was today cleared of criminal wrong-doing over the killing of two teenage joyriders, bringing an end to a nine-year legal battle that became a potent issue in Northern Ireland's political landscape.

The Northern Ireland Court of Appeal overturned a conviction against the 31-year-old corporal for wounding 17-year-old Martin Peake, who died along with Karen Reilly in September 1990. It was the last outstanding charge against Clegg, who earlier this year was acquitted in a retrial of murdering Miss Reilly, 18.

While the 36-page ruling referred to "the highly discreditable behaviour of which some soldiers were undoubtedly guilty" on the night of the shooting, it said that could not influence findings of fact which had to be properly based on relevant evidence.

Clegg was originally convicted of murdering Miss Reilly and wounding Mr Peake in June 1993. The two victims were shot dead by an army patrol on the Glen Road, West Belfast, in September 1990 when the stolen Vauxhall Astra they were in raced past the soldiers.

The case has been one of the most politically emotive in Northern Ireland. Clegg's supporters mounted a vigorous campaign on his behalf after he was jailed for life. Subsequently transferred from prison in Northern Ireland to Wakefield Prison, close to his mother's home in Bradford, his release on licence in June 1995 provoked a furious nationalist response and rioting in the province.

Clegg was not in court to hear the judgment but his mother, stepfather and girlfriend were in the public gallery for the 45 minutes it took Lord Chief Justice Sir Robert Carswell to read the 36-page ruling.

Clegg's mother, Wynne Johnson, of Bradford, West Yorkshire, said: "I've spoken to Lee and he just can't believe it. That's it - the ball's finally stopped rolling after more than nine years.

"It has been a long hard struggle. Obviously we have sympathy for the families of the children who died, but it has taken a lot out of our family as well."

Clegg brought his first appeal against the two convictions in 1995 which was turned down by the court in Northern Ireland and then by the House of Lords. His second challenge came after his release and was based on new ballistics evidence.

The court of appeal granted him a re-trial which last year acquitted him of murdering Miss Reilly but again found him guilty of the offence against Mr Peake, which was appealed in November.

Today Lord Chief Justice Sir Robert Carswell said the accuracy and reliability of an RUC constable's recollection of events had been shown to be suspect.

"In these circumstances we consider that the evidence upon which the conviction has to stand is frail and gives rise to an element of doubt in our minds whether it is being sufficiently clearly proved that the appellant did discharge a shot after the car when it had passed his position," the judgment said.

The court also considered the possibility of evidence being further undermined if the defence had had notice that Clegg might be convicted of the wounding charge on the basis of his having fired such a shot.

"Taking these grounds of appeal together, we are unable to regard the conviction as safe. We must accordingly allow the appeal and quash the appellant's conviction."

"Finally, sympathy for the families of Karen Reilly and Martin Peake in their tragic loss cannot be allowed to deflect a court from reaching a decision based on the law and the facts proved in evidence," it concluded.

fields.headline: My daughter is just fine
fields.standfirst: One of my twins has a loving husband, the other a loving gay partner. Both are my family. Both are equal
fields.trailText: One of my twins has a loving husband, the other a loving gay partner. Both are my family. Both are equal.
fields.body:
Tolerance. It's an excellently soothing word; one used almost promiscuously by politicians, leader writers and churchmen intent on spreading a little even-handed balm. For who, pray, seeks an intolerant society? We all need tolerance, oodles of tolerance. But what the hell do we mean by it?

The most relevant text, for the moment, flows fresh from the pen of the Chief Rabbi - and inevitably concerns that great test of sexual tolerance called section 28. So Dr Jonathan Sacks climbs gingerly up on the tightrope already swaying under the weight of Cardinal Winning, Archbishop Carey, the editors of the Sun and the Daily Mail, and the boss of Stagecoach buses.

"I can never forget, as a Jew, that homosexuals were sent to Auschwitz just as Jews were. Therefore, if our society has become more tolerant, that is a good thing," says Dr Sacks. So that's all right, then? It wouldn't be a "good thing" to send gays to the gas chamber.

"However" - there is always a however - "the current proposal (to repeal section 28) is based on a fundamental confusion between tolerance and moral judgment. Tolerance means treating with respect people whose positions are fundamentally different from your own. It does not mean regarding those views as equally valid."

Here, essentially, the Chief Rabbi echoes Cantuar. "I condemn totally prejudice against anyone on the basis of sexual orientation. But I also resist placing homosexual relationships on an equal footing with marriage as the proper context for sexual intimacy," in the Carey version. Sacks does not, to be fair, go the Winning way and talk of "perversion" - let alone about an "active and militant lobby" mustering its forces "all over Europe" to threaten "the Christian family". Tolerance has its boundaries.

But now the phone rings. It's one of our daughters and she's pretty upset. She wants to talk about tolerance, too.

We have two daughters. They are identical twins, born 10 minutes apart. Suckled at the same breast, tended side by side in adjacent cots. They grew up together, played together, made friends together. They went to the same schools and achieved the same spread of results in (mostly) the same subjects. They played the same games and sang the same songs. They are, even today, difficult for strangers to tell apart when they dress alike. Two peas from the same pod. Same genes; same everything. One is gay and one is not.

"How interesting!" the occasional child psychologist will say at the occasional dinner party. It must have been nurture, not nature. Well, perhaps; but don't ask me how that came to pass. They were loved and cherished equally in the most natural sense; brought up without a flicker of difference between them that I can recall. They remain their own best friends.

It is my elder (gay) daughter who calls. She's listening to another radio debate about section 28 and the familiar liberal defences being trotted out there are just so feeble. A "tolerant" society? An excuse for not thinking, for the denial of human identity.

And that, of course, is right when you pause over her distress. Right from where she sits - and right for us, the witnesses who never seem to get called when the tide of purse-lipped toleration starts running again, the parents of gay children we respect and love.

When our twins are home for a family birthday party, what do we say? Do we echo the Chief Rabbi and affirm that one daughter, happily married with a baby, is secure in "moral judgment" because she has not "abandoned a moral code shared by virtually all the world's great religions" - whilst her identical twin, has suffered a "moral confusion" which renders her existence somehow less "valid"? Deserving of "tolerance" but not of equality?

Do we sing along with the Archbishop of Canterbury and "resist placing homosexual relationships on an equal footing with marriage as the proper context for sexual intimacy"? Welcome to the C of E premiership and the depths of its first division. One sister has a loving husband, the other a loving partner. Both are family. What on earth, in the human terms which are the only terms that matter, is George Carey wittering on about? How would he draw his lines in our home at Christmas?

Section 28's language speaks, coldly, for itself. "A local authority shall not (a) intentionally promote homosexuality or publish material with the intention of promoting homosexuality; and (b) promote the teaching in any maintained school of the acceptability of homosexuality as a pretended family relationship."

You can, I'm afraid, hear the likes of Cardinal Winning mouthing such phrases, building them into a bulwark against repeal. "Cast your minds back to the dark days of the second world war," he declaims. "In place of the bombs of 50 years ago, you find yourselves bombarded with images, values and ideas which are utterly alien."

But what is the "promotion" of such values? And what is a "pretended family relationship?" My daughter - troubled and uncertain from the age of 13 on - found nothing to help or to guide her at school: merely an RE teacher the cardinal would have embraced. She did not, to our subsequent chagrin, confide in her parents until her mind was clear. She had damn all in the way of information, let alone the illusion of town hall propaganda. She was left alone to struggle through the most difficult years.

Where is there the least hint of Christianity in that? When did Christ - abandoning any mention of love - inveigh against "pretended family relationships" (which the Daily Mail, for its own reasons, defines as an "equal alternative to marriage")? Why does it sometimes seem that Robert Mugabe must be the natural leader of this panic-stricken crusade?

The repeal of section 28 won't transform society. There will still be vicious playground bullying of the kind copiously documented by teachers themselves. There will still be prejudice and fear. Bits of law do not, in themselves, change our world. But the fight, for all that, has a momentous symbolism attached. It forces every one of us to look into ourselves and decide what's right. It allows no political weaselings. No hiding place.

My daughter isn't some notional stereotype invented to scare elderly cardinals. Nor is she a visitor from an alien place. She is like millions more in the world around - and we, in turn, are like millions of other parents. This is our flesh and blood; part of us, a reflection of us. We don't have to say she's equal. She IS equal. And no drizzle of incomprehension, no fear fostered in ignorance, no puny section, can alter that. It isn't tolerance we need. It is knowing what makes our hearts beat.

fields.headline: The best equine scene
fields.standfirst: Sleepy Hollow
fields.trailText: Twilight. In the fields just outside Sleepy Hollow, Constable Ichabod Crane (Johnny Depp) discovers Magistrate Phillipse (Richard Griffiths) preparing to flee the village.
fields.body:
Twilight. In the fields just outside Sleepy Hollow, Constable Ichabod Crane (Johnny Depp) discovers Magistrate Phillipse (Richard Griffiths) preparing to flee the village.

"What are you running from, Magistrate Phillipse?"

"Damn you, Crane."

"You had a mind to help me."

"Yes, and it's put me in mortal dread of..."

"Of what?"

Phillipse glances nervously around him.

"Of powers against which there is no defence."

Crane regards him coldly.

"How did you know the Widow Winchip was expecting a child?"

"She told me."

"Then I deduce you are the father."

"I am not the father."

Phillipse becomes exasperated.

"She came to me as town magistrate to protect the rights of her child. I was bound by the oath of office to keep the secret."

"Do you believe the father killed her?"

Phillipse almost breaks into a yell.

"The Horseman killed her!"

A flash of lighting; a clap of thunder; a flock of sheep disperses in seeming panic.

"How often do I have to tell you?" Crane erupts. "There is no horseman. There never was a horseman. There never will be a horseman."

Another flash of lightning; more agitation from the sheep. An eerie silence descends.

Crane's jaw hangs open as, from the nearby woods, a headless horseman gallops towards him.

fields.bodyText: Twilight. In the fields just outside Sleepy Hollow, Constable Ichabod Crane (Johnny Depp) discovers Magistrate Phillipse (Richard Griffiths) preparing to flee the village. "What are you running from, Magistrate Phillipse?" "Damn you, Crane." "You had a mind to help me." "Yes, and it's put me in mortal dread of..." "Of what?" Phillipse glances nervously around him. "Of powers against which there is no defence." Crane regards him coldly. "How did you know the Widow Winchip was expecting a child?" "She told me." "Then I deduce you are the father." "I am not the father." Phillipse becomes exasperated. "She came to me as town magistrate to protect the rights of her child. I was bound by the oath of office to keep the secret." "Do you believe the father killed her?" Phillipse almost breaks into a yell. "The Horseman killed her!" A flash of lighting; a clap of thunder; a flock of sheep disperses in seeming panic. "How often do I have to tell you?" Crane erupts. "There is no horseman. There never was a horseman. There never will be a horseman." Another flash of lightning; more agitation from the sheep. An eerie silence descends. Crane's jaw hangs open as, from the nearby woods, a headless horseman gallops towards him. fields.headline: Striker dies after car crash
fields.trailText: Blackpool striker Martin Aldridge has died following a head-on car crash.
fields.body:
Blackpool striker Martin Aldridge has died following a head-on car crash.

Aldridge, who was on loan at Rushden and Diamonds, was travelling in a Peugeot which collided with a BMW on the A45 near Wellingborough in Northamptonshire on Saturday evening.

The 25-year-old former Northampton and Oxford player was taken to Oxford's Radcliffe Infirmary but later died from his injuries.

webTitle: Peasants prey on the gullible with greenback scam

fields.headline: Peasants prey on the gullible with greenback scam
fields.trailText: The shabby-looking peasant approached Mr Xie in the lobby of a south China hotel, clutching a piece of paper.
fields.body:
The shabby-looking peasant approached Mr Xie in the lobby of a south China hotel, clutching a piece of paper.

"Excuse me, sir," he said nervously. "You look like a cultured person: would you mind telling me what this is?"

Mr Xie, a businessman in Nanning, the capital of Guangxi province, recognised it instantly as a US$100 bill. He checked it was genuine at a nearby bank - and saw the opportunity for a quick profit.

"It's American dollars," he told the peasant, who said his name was Li. "But you'll be in big trouble with the police if you cash it. I'll take the risk and give you 200 renminbi."

The sum he offered was worth about £15. They were just about to conclude the deal when Mr Li said casually: "I've got some more notes back home in the village: my grandfather just died and I found them in his chest."

Next morning Mr Xie was on his way to Silong township, 37 miles away. To his amazement, Mr Li's "more notes" amounted to three boxes full - more than $140,000 (£86,400).

The tale ended predictably after Mr Xie had persuaded some friends to help him raise the ready cash and returned to Silong. They gave 54,360 renminbi (£4,100) to Mr Li, who disappeared saying he was going to make an offering to his ancestors. The dollars he had handed over were forged - fake notes at the top of the box and plain paper below.

The most remarkable feature of this scam is that it has been operating successfully since the early 1980s. Hoodwinked "clients" have included businessmen from South Korea and Hong Kong, as well as from across China.

Other cases are unrecorded, since many victims fear they will be accused of illegal currency dealing if they go to the authorities. The police claim this has made it impossible to stamp out the racket, although they did recently stage a roundup of suspects.

Whatever the real reason for their lack of energy, the greenback scam has been developed by the Silong villagers into a fine art.

Their story about a cache of US dollars is built around a historical fact: in 1940 the Chinese nationalist army fought a heroic battle in the area against the Japanese.

The peasant fraudsters tell the clients that the nationalists left behind a hoard of money which their grandparents found and concealed. A photograph of a dead "grandfather" is sometimes produced to back up the story.

To substantiate the story, a genuine $100 note dated 1988 is doctored to look as if it was issued in 1938. The small alteration in the date can easily escape detection.

Variations on the scam include taking the client to a cave in the area, pocketing the money and then disappearing to "fetch the dollars" from a fictitious hiding-place.

The Silong peasants have also forged bank documents from the nationalist era written in old-fashioned Chinese characters. Silong's reputation as a possible source for US dollars persists in spite of the evident frauds. A recent investigation by the popular Guangzhou-based Southern Weekend newspaper found would-be sellers and clients loitering on the roadside in Silong.

It is hard to understand why the victims continue to be so gullible. One theory is that in China, where everyone wants to "get rich first", people are quicker to delude themselves that they have found a magic way.

webTitle: Hollywood woos British glamour at the local women's institute

fields.headline: Hollywood woos British glamour at the local women's institute
fields.standfirst: Also today, fury over BBFC's ruling on End of the Affair | Brosnan's seventh 007 in 007? | Tim Burton joins the Shockwave set | Australian ban on Romance lifted, and Almodovar picks up prizes for All about My Mother
fields.trailText: Also today, fury over BBFC's ruling on End of the Affair | Brosnan's seventh 007 in 007? | Tim Burton joins the Shockwave set | Australian ban on Romance lifted, and Almodovar picks up prizes for All about My Mother
fields.body:
Last April the story of the women's institute members who posed naked behind strategically placed sieves and arranged flowers for a fund-raising calendar caused a flurry of media interest and money for Leukaemia research.

The tale of Rylstone and District Women's Institute's alternative glamour calendar shot across the Atlantic, and nine months later, the New York Times ran an article on the pin-ups. Now it seems that their story has caught the eye of several leading American film companies.

Disney, Telstar and Buena Vista and Julia Roberts' agent have all approached the women, keen to make a film of their story. But the women, as one might expect from the WI, are being straightforward about the whole business.

Says WI member Tricia Stewart, "We've been contacted by Hollywood and it's funny because they're so pushy. But we'd want [a film] done over here. Maureen Lipman invited us down to Women of the Year last year and was so lovely to us that we'd love her to be involved."

Probably not quite what Hollywood has in mind.

Fury over BBFC's End of the Affair ruling

Stephen Woolley, producer of Neil Jordan's The End of the Affair, has hit out at the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) for giving the film an 18 certificate.

Woolley is furious that the adaptation of Graham Greene's novel, which stars Ralph Fiennes as a novelist who has an affair with a married woman (Julianne Moore) has been given such a prohibitive rating. In an interview with the Independent, Woolley said that whilst he never expected a large teenage audience, the 18 certificate would now make the film appear "ugly" to an adult audience. "Any parent with a 16-year-old would love them to see The End of the Affair", he said. "Now, many parents will be put off seeing the film themselves".

Woolley believes the BBFC's decision was based on two scenes: one where "Ralph's bottom was pumping too many times" and another where Fiennes and Moore are seen outstretched on a bed. The ruling comes as a surprise to those who thought the BBFC was adopting a more liberal approach to film censorship, but according to Robin Duval, the BBFC's director, the new guidelines will not come into force until later this year and until then the BBFC is bound by its current ruling which restricts simulated sex scenes to the 18 certificate.

Brosnan's seventh 007 in 007?

Pierce Brosnan wants to equal Roger Moore's record and star in seven Bond films.

Empire Online reveal that the 007 star is in negotiations to appear in four more Bond films, bringing his total to seven. His stunt double Douglas James explains: "He wants to do seven films in all, equalling Roger's record and - if you count Never Say Never Again - matching Sean's total. But his record will be the best - his seventh film will be released in 2007, making it 007 in 007".

Keen to go head to head with Brosnan in one of those films is Eastenders star and former Spandau Ballet singer Martin Kemp. The actor, who made his screen debut as Reggie Kray in The Krays and recently told The Sun that none of Bond's previous villains were as handsome as him, but "that's all about to change", is in preliminary talks with production company EON to play the lead baddie.

Whether Bond will be made in England is another matter: the German city of Cologne has pledged free use of the city to EON and a good rate at their new movie studio complex.

Tim Burton joins the Shockwave set

Tim Burton has signed a deal with Shockwave.com to develop original animation for the web.

The director of Sleepy Hollow will create 26 episodes of a new series based on Stain Boy, a character from his 1997 cartoon book, The Melancholy Death of Oyster Boy and Other Stories. The slightly dubious hero who, according to a poem Burton wrote for the book, "can't fly around tall buildings, or outrun a speeding train, the only talent he seems to have is to leave a nasty stain," will make his debut in the spring.

Burton will join South Park creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone who recently announced that they would develop thirty-nine two and five-minute animated short programs for Shockwave.com. Their efforts will be online in March.

News in brief

The Australian censors have lifted their ban on Catherine Breillat's film, Romance. The Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) said it did not believe that the film's scenes of real sex offended standards generally accepted by reasonable adults and has given the film an 18 certificate.

Girlfight, a film about a woman determined to become a champion boxer, and You Can Count on Me, a drama about a brother and sister who struggle to maintain a sense of family after their parents are killed in a car crash, have split the grand jury prize for best dramatic film at this year's Sundance Film Festival.

Film director Pedro Almodovar has won seven of the Spanish Film Academy's Goya prizes, including the Best Director prize, for All About My Mother. Almodovar, who is in line to win an Oscar for the film, dedicated the award to his mother who died earlier this year.

Gwyneth Paltrow, who provoked worldwide ridicule last year when she broke down in tears after winning an Oscar for Shakespeare in Love, is to present an award at this year's Oscar ceremony.

Casting couch

 Marlon Brando is in talks to join Edward Norton and Robert De Niro in The Score, the Frank Oz film about a young thief (Norton) who persuades a master thief (De Niro) to pull off one last heist. If he agrees - and the producers can stump up his enormous fee - Brando will play De Niro's fence. Filming is scheduled to start in April in Montreal.

webTitle: Our eyes met across a crowded column ...

fields.headline: Our eyes met across a crowded column ...
fields.standfirst:
From small ads to agencies, dating is big business these days - and young women are its keenest customers. Raekha Prasad investigates modern matchmaking

Have you ever used a dating agency? Tell all and debate the issues on the Talk
fields.trailText:
From small ads to agencies, dating is big business these days - and young women are its keenest customers. Raekha Prasad investigates modern matchmaking

Have you ever used a dating agency? Tell all and debate the issues on the Talk
fields.body:
Foreplay has never required the pushing of so few buttons. Step one: switch on your video phone. Step two: press a button to view your possible mate, get his vital statistics and find out how much he earns. Step three is up to you. Call him to find out more or simply hit the reject button which lets him know you're not interested. Welcome to the tiny digital world of video phones, the future of dating. In Japan, 1,000 of these gadgets have been bought by people looking for a mate and the manufacturers expect to sell half a million by next month. At £2,800 to sign up and another couple of hundred pounds for the phone, they are currently only for the rich, but the preference for bespoke, fast-track matchmaking, anonymity ensured, has definitely arrived.

There are now three times more single people in Britain than there were 30 years ago. Working women under 35 make up the biggest growth area in people joining matchmaking agencies, dinner groups and singles parties. The UK dating market is valued at £50m and is growing.

Blame it on longer working hours, a loss of faith in the institution of marriage or a delay in having children, the fact is that fewer of us subscribe to the idea that suitable partners are just "bumped into" and are turning to fast-track compatibility more than ever before. Karen Mooney, director of Sara Eden Introductions, which specialises in thirtysomething matchmaking, has seen a 75% increase in membership in the past year. "Younger women in particular," she says, "have become more discerning in what they want. They're looking for someone who can be a friend but everything else as well. It's become more important to be with a man who is not going to be competitive or jealous of their success. Women are much more specific in their requirements and more likely to ask what guarantees they're going to get. They are in control of their own destiny."

It follows that matchmaking ventures that shun the random in favour of the specific are attractive to younger women. Emotional identification with our working environment has led us to apply goal-oriented office skills to finding a mate: if you're looking for a job, you go to an employment agency; if you want a holiday, you call a travel agent; if you want a partner, why not try a dating agency? "People don't want to waste time," Mooney explains. "It's better to put your cards on the table at the start. That way, you're fishing where the fish are."

It is significant that the generation of women eager to exercise more control over who they see as potential mates is the same generation to have reaped the benefits of feminism from birth. They have witnessed love-by-random-selection ending in tears and worse for older women. The desire to take control is ultimately a bid to limit damage. This fine-tuning of criteria for Mr Right betrays the anxiety women feel about how far they compromise in a relationship and reveals that well-rehearsed concern: some men are relationship-illiterate and will never learn otherwise.

Cate Liston, 26, placed a small ad in a newspaper last year after growing frustrated with "meeting men in my own peer group who were emotionally immature. Apart from my appearance criteria, I was looking for someone who was self-aware."

Liston was tired of trying to second-guess whether men she met through mates or work were interested in being more than just friends. "There's a lot of messing about, wondering what each other is thinking," she says. "On a blind date you don't have to pretend to be friends. It's honest rather than clinical."

Liston got 69 telephone responses in two weeks; she listened to them with her flatmate and then marked them out of 10. After eight dates in a quiet pub, she began seeing number five and they are now living together. "I didn't go into it aiming to meet the love of my life," she insists. "I had control over who I met and became clearer about what I wanted. I was the advertiser and I felt empowered."

Matchmaking ventures require an individual to put a price on how much they are worth - not as a wage-earner, but as a partner. It is only when you have identified what makes you a good mate that you begin to ask who exactly could match it. But placing a small ad, going on to a dating website or joining an agency supplies women only with men on those books and all too often supply does not meet demand. During the 17 years that Lyn Davies, chair of the Association of British Introduction Agencies, has worked in the industry, she says there is one demand, apart from the obligatory GSOH, that has remained constant: men look for women 10 years younger, women look for men the same age.

Mooney, too, notes that men in their late 20s and early 30s may be less concerned about a woman's age, but they are more interested in looks, while women invariably want a man "who can think emotionally. She wants to communicate with her partner."

Rebecca McCrain, now 42, joined a dating agency in her late 30s and a friend then placed a small ad on her behalf. "So many of the guys I've met want to meet loads of women and have a shag," she says. "Or they want to enhance their social life. I'm using the small ads to meet a partner."

Though McCrain's friends knew she was going on blind dates, she felt "uncomfortable" about going public. "I felt as if I were a failure. That I couldn't get my act together, that I wasn't attractive." She says she intends to stop using matchmaking enterprises. "I want my normal life back. Endless nights out with strangers make me feel like a performing seal. It's terribly hard work trying to be up and bouncy."

For all the agencies' talk of the stigma of sad lonely hearts having vanished, a new stigma has replaced it as many young women now feel ashamed to admit they are actively looking for a partner - the fallout, perhaps, of being told that to be single is to be happy. Psychotherapist Susie Orbach says the tension between wanting a relationship and being told being alone is OK makes women anxious about the desire to attach. "Women are hounded by scare stories about the biological clock. They are told if they don't have a partner by a certain age, they never will. But there isn't actually a decrease in people's need for intimacy and attachment."

Perhaps we should view the rise in pro-active dating as a way to achieve attachment now that traditional social stuctures are disintegrating. Dating organisations are being embraced by a generation of women and men raised in a service culture. Kate Fox, director of the Social Issues Research Centre, believes turning to an agency is not a departure from more formalised matchmaking but a return to it. "The idea that matchmaking can happen spontaneously is new. Previously parents or elders helped provide suitable mates. Going to look for one on the internet is more a return to normal mating than some weird aberration."

Psychotherapist Susie Orbach says the tension between wanting a relationship and being told being alone is OK makes women anxious about the desire to attach. "Women are hounded by scare stories about the biological clock. They are told if they don't have a partner by a certain age, they never will. But there isn't actually a decrease in people's need for intimacy and attachment." Perhaps we should view the rise in pro-active dating as a way to achieve attachment now that traditional social stuctures are disintegrating. Dating organisations are being embraced by a generation of women and men raised in a service culture. Kate Fox, director of the Social Issues Research Centre, believes turning to an agency is not a departure from more formalised matchmaking but a return to it. "The idea that matchmaking can happen spontaneously is new. Previously parents or elders helped provide suitable mates. Going to look for one on the internet is more a return to normal mating than some weird aberration."

webTitle: Flaking out with painting and wine

fields.headline: Flaking out with painting and wine
fields.standfirst: Every Monday we talk to a county cricketer about what he's been up to in the close season. This week it's the turn of Durham wicketkeeper Martin Speight
fields.trailText: Martin Speight, 32, is wicketkeeper for Durham, whom he joined in 1997 after 11 years with Sussex. In first-class cricket last season he scored 566 runs at 25.73, took 48 catches and made two stumpings. He and his wife, Lisa, also run an art business, Martin Speight Limited.
fields.body:
Martin Speight, 32, is wicketkeeper for Durham, whom he joined in 1997 after 11 years with Sussex. In first-class cricket last season he scored 566 runs at 25.73, took 48 catches and made two stumpings. He and his wife, Lisa, also run an art business, Martin Speight Limited.

"Painting-wise this winter, I've had various commissions, from Test and county grounds to local grounds and teddy bears. A bit of everything really, including portraiture. I went full-time with the business after I stopped wintering in New Zealand - my last winter over there was 1994-95.

When I started it was very much an ad hoc type arrangement and it went on like that for quite a while. I was just doing it for a bit of fun. I hadn't really promoted my art until the last two winters. It wasn't until the advent of Lisa that I really started looking at it as more than just paying the bills.

I do all sorts of painting - watercolours, pastels, oils. It all depends. Sometimes I wake up in the morning and think I'm just not in the mood for an oil today, so I'll do a watercolour. I did Art A-Level and a little bit at Uni, though mostly I had better things to do there. Lots of people ask me if I paint during a game when I'm waiting to bat, but I actually find I can't focus on it then. I paint to relax, like some people go fishing or play golf. I talk a bit about painting with Jack Russell, but usually only when we play against each other.

Lisa and I got married in September 1997. We've no kids but a Weimaraner dog (a German gun dog) who is 15 months old. It is a lot more trouble than children. It is called Cloudy Bay - as in the wine from New Zealand, which I drank a lot of when I was over there.

I've been doing quite a bit of training - it seems to be my job to run the dog. I've been going to the gym, playing a bit of squash and we've started some training up at Chelmsford with Graham Gooch, who is Durham's batting coach. Other than that, a bit of partying, a bit of reading - it's the Wine Atlas of France at the moment. It is dumbfounding - each region has a wine peculiar to itself. I quite like my wine. We went over to France just before Christmas to stock up, like all the rest of the world.

I live a totally separate life during the winter. I rent up in Durham in the summer, and don't really have the time to socialise. When you're playing four, five, six days a week the last thing you want to do is have people over for dinner. If I do come back to Brighton I tend to just flake out. During the winter I live here. Lisa is a Brighton girl and I'm from mid-Sussex so it is home to us. The North East is very different to the South East - different location, people, climate, attitude. It is colder up there and quite hard work. Hove is a lovely place to play as a batsman. The members there are just happy to see a good day's play. They'll enjoy seeing Hick get a hundred because it is good cricket. Up in Durham, and probably Yorkshire and Lancashire as well, people are more openly passionate about their sport and their local side. If you're doing well then great, but they expect a reasonable degree of success. At Hove you never hear anyone shout out; at Durham they aren't shy of saying what they think.

We don't go back to training proper until the end of March, which is quite late. Durham exceeded expectation last year by coming eighth and I think our top aim is to stay in division one of the Championship, which will be quite a good ask. Also, over the three years that Boon was captain we steadily improved our Championship cricket, but our one-day stuff was pretty poor. With the staff we have, I think we can hope to be challenging for promotion to the top division of the National League.

At New Year about 50 of us went to someone's house in Brighton for a black-tie do. We started about 8pm and finished around 6 in the morning. It was very nice indeed. Christmas was quieter - the usual relatives story. My parents work in Bombay so it was lovely to see them. But I have to say that I prefer December in the sun. I spent five winters in New Zealand, and I know some people say that they could never be abroad for Christmas but give me a barbie, a beach, some tinnies and a few friends any day."

If you're interested in buying a gift (print, jigsaw, card, plate, mug, book) from Martin Speight Limited, please phone 01273 273978 for a catalogue.

Martin Speight was talking to Tanya Aldred

webTitle: Shock for Blair as his 'fixer' quits

fields.headline: Shock for Blair as his 'fixer' quits
fields.trailText:
The popular junior defence minister Peter Kilfoyle last night shook the government by
   announcing his return to the backbenches with a hint that his resignation is a mark of
   disillusion with Tony Blair's New Labour.
fields.body:
The popular junior defence minister Peter Kilfoyle last night shook the government by announcing his return to the backbenches with a hint that his resignation is a mark of disillusion with Tony Blair's New Labour.

The Liverpudlian fixer who helped Mr Blair win the Labour leadership and the 1997 election resigned from the government to rally the party's traditional voters.

"Having reflected long and hard on how I can best use my political energies in the interests of my constituents and the Labour party I have concluded that I should return to the backbenches," Mr Kilfoyle wrote to Mr Blair after news of his intentions was leaked by colleagues. It was the first resignation since 1997 not triggered by personal considerations, scandal or dismissal.

His abrupt departure was being interpreted by fellow backbenchers as a warning that the party was losing support among its traditional bedrock of support.

"I am a serial loyalist as are most Labour MPs," the former political organiser who helped defeat Militant in Liverpool said last night. "I have no wish to embarrass the prime minister or the government. I just want to do what I do best, which is to represent the people who sent me here."

Though he was careful to praise Labour's "tremendous victory" at the polls, it took little reading between the lines to detect disappointment with many of the government's achievements and priorities - which many more traditional Labour MPs see as too far oriented to middle England and a London agenda.

webTitle: Tobacco giant implicated in global smuggling schemes

fields.headline: Tobacco giant implicated in global smuggling schemes
fields.standfirst:
Exposed: How billions of BAT cigarettes end up on black markets
Special report: BAT exposé
fields.trailText: British American Tobacco condoned tax evasion and exploited the smuggling of billions of cigarettes in a global effort to boost sales and lure generations of new smokers, secret company documents reveal.
fields.body:
British American Tobacco condoned tax evasion and exploited the smuggling of billions of cigarettes in a global effort to boost sales and lure generations of new smokers, secret company documents reveal.

The London-based corporation, the world's second-largest international tobacco company with sales of 900bn cigarettes a year, has benefited from black marketeering on a massive scale.

Senior BAT executives arranged to supply huge numbers of "sticks" a year - the industry term for cigarettes - to wholesalers and distributors, expecting that they would find their way into crooked hands and onto black markets after being smuggled across national borders, without duty being paid. In some countries the company also knowingly advertised and promoted smuggled cigarettes to improve its market share.

Facts and figures about the contraband trade are detailed in internal company documents, including memos and faxes marked "restricted" and "secret", found among 8m pages BAT lodged at a depository in Guildford, Surrey, as part of the settlement of a 1998 US court case.

The International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, a group based within the Center for Public Integrity in Washington DC, spent six months analysing 11,000 pages of the papers that BAT agreed to make public.

They suggest that the background to the growth of international cigarette smuggling in the 1990s included rivalry between BAT and its major competitors, as well as the tobacco companies' joint wish to bring down high taxes and increase smoking markets.

The disclosed documents, which span a period up to 1995, do not suggest that BAT employees committed any crime in Britain. They show that the smuggling "channels" which the company's cigarettes travelled along were always operated and managed by others.

But the documents do show how euphemisms - including "duty not paid", "general trade" and "transit" - were often used to describe unorthodox cigarette sales channels, which could be as an alternative to legal "duty paid" deals.

Sometimes the duty paid and duty not paid markets were combined so sales of smuggled goods could benefit from advertising for the legal products under so-called "umbrella operations" which expanded sales.

Marketing strategies and sales drives in Canada, Latin America and Asia were uncovered by the CPI team. Well-know BAT brands involved included Kent, Kool and Lucky Strike as well as regionally popular brands such as State Express 555 and Belmont.

Since the 1997 general election Kenneth Clarke, the former Tory chancellor and health secretary, has been appointed deputy chairman of BAT, a FTSE-100 company that reported profits of more than £1bn for the first nine months of last year.

BAT declined to answer specific questions about its activities and those of individual executives named in the papers, including Ulrich Herter, the managing director, and Keith Dunt, finance director.

The company issued a general statement denying the "allegations of smuggling". It claimed that researchers "have 'cherry picked' a selected number of documents from the 8m pages in the depository, and could be at high risk of drawing and publishing conculsions which are at variance with the facts".

BAT went on: "We do not intend to answer questions or address allegations apparently based on highly selective and out-of-context documents about matters which are more properly addressed - and in many instances are being addressed with our full co-operation - by governments and customs authorities around the world."

Many of the disclosures concern routes that go through the Caribbean island of Aruba and enter Colombia, where they finish up in contraband markets. In an interview on Channel 4 News tonight, Ricardo Ramirez, the Colombian government minister responsible for tax and customs, says BAT recently agreed not to sell to any unauthorised dealers. "We have told them not to sell through the San Andresitos markets but through official channels. If we have evidence that directors or anyone else in the organisation promotes smuggling we will not hesitate to prosecute them."

Today's disclosures, however, could lead to Martin Broughton, BAT's non-smoking chairman, being recalled before the Commons all-party health select committee to explain his company's policy. David Hinchcliffe, the committee's Labour chairman, said last night: "This information is of direct relevance to our current inquiry. I will be suggesting to the committee that we seek further evidence on this matter from the company concerned."

Another member of the committee, the Liberal Democrat MP Peter Brand, said: "It's as clear as a pikestaff that they are deliberately trying to undermine the governments' efforts by, if not in in cahoots with the black marketeers, certainly doing nothing to hinder them."

The UK government alone loses an estimated £2.5bn in duty from smuggled cigarettes.

Clive Bates, director of Action on Smoking and Health, today challenges Mr Clarke to order an internal BAT inquiry and calls for an independent Whitehall inquiry into the corporation.

"The deputy chairman of BAT, former chancellor Kenneth Clarke, should immediately launch an internal inquiry and report back to the BAT AGM on April 27," he says.

"The DTI should begin an in-depth inquiry into BAT's business practices and conduct. It is up to the government to ensure British multinationals do not treat developing countries like some lawless wild frontier."

webTitle: How smuggling helps lure  generations of new smokers

fields.headline: How smuggling helps lure  generations of new smokers
fields.standfirst:
Documents made public through lawsuits in the US reveal how executives of British-based tobacco giant BAT sought to manage cigarette black markets in the drive to increase profits
Special report: BAT exposé
fields.trailText: Documents made public through lawsuits in the US reveal how executives of British-based tobacco giant BAT sought to manage cigarette black markets in the drive to increase profits.
fields.byline: Maud S Beelman, Duncan Campbell, Maria Teresa Ronderos and  Erik J Schelzig
fields.body:
Contrary to tobacco companies' long-standing claims that cigarette smuggling concerns only the work of organised crime or rogue employees beyond their control, internal files of British American Tobacco, the world's second-largest multinational tobacco company, show that smuggling was exploited by senior personnel of the parent company and its subsidiaries as part of a worldwide marketing strategy to increase revenue.

The documents, covering mostly 1990-1995, do not suggest that BAT employees transported contraband cigarettes across customs borders, where taxes would be due. Instead, they show that corporate executives in Britain, the United States and other areas controlled the brands, marketing campaigns and timing and sought to manage volumes and price levels of smuggling markets. Corporate executives worked closely with their local agents and gave incentives to local distributors.

Responding to questions, BAT said it knew that some of its products "are handled other than through official channels", but added: "We cannot control the distribution chain all the way to the final customer." BAT's corporate and regulatory affairs director, Michael Prideaux, admitted recently: "If people wish to draw the inference that we are turning a blind eye to smuggling, they are free to do so."

There is no suggestion that BAT broke the law, but it did more than turn a blind eye. BAT and its subsidiaries used a carefully coded language. Only occasionally did they use such terms as "smuggled" or "contraband". The preferred euphemisms of company correspondence were "DNP" (duty not paid), "transit" or "GT" (general trade), as well as "parallel market", "second channel", and "border trade". The euphemisms were used interchangeably and contrasted repeatedly with references to imports that were legal and "DP" (duty paid).

Three years ago two BAT managers admitted charges related to tobacco smuggling. One had already left the company, the other retired in December 1997, six months after pleading guilty to charges over a scheme that shipped cigarettes marked "Duty Not Paid" and "Not for Sale in Canada" back into Canada from Louisiana, where they had been sent allegedly bound for offshore fishing boats.

Sanguine

Suspicions of tobacco industry involvement in cigarette smuggling have grown since 1997 when researchers demonstrated, by comparing annual global exports with global imports, that about a third of all cigarettes entering international commerce each year could not be accounted for. The industry's sanguine reaction to apparently losing a third of its inventory annually fuelled suspicions of corporate involvement with smuggled products.

But proof remained elusive until last year, when millions of pages of corporate documents, unearthed during health-related lawsuits, became publicly available as part of the tobacco industry's November 1998 settlement with the US states.

The information in those documents could prove far more costly to the companies than the £154bn US settlement, because BAT, like its multinational rival Philip Morris, has focused on expanding business into international and newly emerging markets - the areas where smuggling seems to have flourished.

In Colombia, 21 state governors and the mayor of Bogota have engaged American lawyers to prepare lawsuits in the US against British American Tobacco and Philip Morris, said Jose Manuel Arias Carrizosa, executive director of the federation of Colombian governors. He said they were seeking "an indemnification for damages caused through contraband of cigarettes into the country".

"We think there are two markets, one legitimate that pays its duties and taxes, and the other much bigger, illegal," he said. "That cannot be happening without the knowledge of the producing companies."

Canada filed a lawsuit against RJ Reynolds and its related tobacco companies in New York state in December 1999 for smuggling across the US/Canadian border. Several people, including a former RJR senior sales manager, have been convicted in the US over that smuggling operation. An RJ Reynolds Tobacco Company spokeswoman said the company was "not involved in the day-to-day business operations of any international operations", and that the company had not been implicated in the criminal investigations.

Smuggled cigarettes, by evading import and sales taxes, are usually sold more cheaply than legally imported cigarettes. That makes them affordable to a greater number of people, increases corporate profits, and secures future markets. But because smuggling puts cigarettes in more hands, especially younger ones, it is not just an issue for tax collectors.

The World Bank last year predicted that by 2030 smoking would be the single leading cause of death in the world, killing one in six adults. The Bank warned that smoking deaths would increasingly occur in low- and middle-income countries, least able to afford the costs of treating smoking-related illnesses. It recommended raising taxes on tobacco to reduce consumption.

The BAT documents make two points clear: ranking executives of BAT and its subsidiaries used smuggling by others as part of their overall strategy to increase market share, and they employed a series of euphemisms to plan and mask their activities. The documents, especially as they relate to company operations in Latin America, repeatedly identify legal imports as either "duty paid" (DP) or "duty free" (DF) for traditional duty-free stores. Those phrases are consistently used in opposition to terms such as "DNP", "transit", or "GT", and those contrasting terms appear regularly throughout memos, letters, charts, and graphs of import/export data and sales figures.

A memo from the early 1990s, entitled "Venezuelan market definitions and assumptions", explained that "duty paid" goods owed the government legal excise taxes of 50%. No such requirement was noted for the "duty not paid" goods, which were identified as cigarettes produced in Venezuela, exported mainly to the free-trade zone on the nearby island of Aruba, and then returned to the Venezuelan market as "transit". The memo came from the file of Keith Dunt, then BAT's regional director for Latin America, who is now the company's finance director with a seat on the board.

In a February 16 1993 fax to BAT headquarters in Britain its Venezuelan subsidiary explained: "Since November 1992 the transit (DNP) product into Venezuela have been very low due to tighter border controls."

During a fierce trademark dispute with Philip Morris over which company had the right to use the Belmont brand name in Colombia, a February 22 1995 memo outlined contingency options should BAT lose. One was to "maintain current Belmont GT channel and launch new brand in DP". However, a noted drawback of keeping Belmont in the GT channel was that the company "cannot support Belmont in GT via advertising".

Les Thompson, the RJR senior sales manager who pleaded guilty in 1999 to money-laundering charges stemming from the US/Canadian smuggling operation, said that DNP was also a euphemism his company used to talk about smuggling. "It's an industry-wide term," Thompson said. "It's essentially a long-winded term used by senior folks when they're talking around the topic of smuggling." Other euphemisms for smuggled cigarettes, Thompson said, were "re-entry" goods, the "parallel market" and "transit".

Colombia - a country racked by decades of civil war and cocaine trading, with a long history as a crossroads of contraband - proved to be fertile ground for cigarette smuggling.

Contraband

The BAT records show that millions of cigarettes were shipped from BAT subsidiaries in the US, Venezuela and Brazil to distributors in the free-trade zone of Aruba, an island in the Caribbean just off the coast of Colombia that historically had been a mecca for contraband. The cigarettes could be sold and end up in the hands of smugglers who could take them by boat to to Colombia's La Guajira region, an isolated and lawless haven along the Caribbean coastline. The Guajira peninsula, which straddles the northern border of Colombia and Venezuela, has been a smugglers' paradise since colonial times.

Maicao is a town in La Guajira that was given special customs status in 1991 in order to spur job growth. The law allowed for goods to pass from Maicao into the Colombian interior if they were declared to customs officials and duty paid.

BAT records track how smugglers moved cigarettes outside the Maicao special customs zone "duty not paid" and on to the black market. A "DNP distribution" graph in Mr Dunt's files showed DNP cigarettes travelling from Aruba to Maicao and from there westward to the "consumer" in Barranquilla, outside the tax-free area.

One document in the files showed that officials from BAT and its subsidiaries supplying Colombia - Brown & Williamson, Souza Cruz, Cigarrera Bigott - agreed at a Miami meeting in January 1992 that Souza Cruz would give a 5% "free goods incentive in Maicao and in the San Andresitos to expand distribution in Bogota and Medellin". The term "sanandresitos" - from the Colombian island of San Andres which has been a tax-free port since the early 1950s - refers to the clusters of small stalls found in many Colombian cities.

Asked by ICIJ if a company doing business in Colombia might not know about sandandresitos, Fanny Kertzman, the director of the country's tax and customs office, responded: "This question is ridiculous. It is obvious, so evident most of the merchandise sold there is smuggled."

In 1993 corporate records show that BAT subsidiaries imported a total of 3.98bn cigarettes into Colombia. However, 3.89bn of those cigarettes entered as duty not paid goods.

The BAT documents show that cigarettes also moved from Aruba to Panama's free-trade zone of Colon as a staging point into nearby Turbo, another special customs zone in Colombia, from where they would make their way into the country's black market. In addition, some of the cigarettes shipped from Venezuela to Aruba and on to Maicao went back into Venezuela. Similar smuggling operations went on farther south, too, with cigarettes from BAT's Brazilian subsidiary Souza Cruz being shipped through Paraguay into Argentina. Although BAT was not involved in the smuggling, they marketed the brands to improve sales.

In a June 3 1993 letter to Ulrich Herter, BAT's managing director, the president of Imperial Tobacco Limited, Don Brown, wrote: "As you are aware, smuggled cigarettes (due to exorbitant tax levels) represent nearly 30% of total sales in Canada, and the level is growing. Other documents show that BAT executives were aware of the "sensitivity" of the issue. One of them, Delcio Laux, president of BAT's Venezuelan subsidiary, wrote in an April 21 1992 faxed memo to Mr Dunt that "it is clear that Bigott can't be seen as a clean and ethical company by continuing with DP and DNP in parallel".

Two months later Mr Dunt wrote to Eduardo Grant, president of BAT's Argentine subsidiary, Nobleza-Piccardo, about the "DNP market" there. "We will be consulting here on the ethical side of whether we should encourage or ignore the DNP segment. You know my view is that it is part of your market and to have it exploited by others is just not acceptable," Mr Dunt said.

Notes on a meeting in Colombia in February, which Mr Dunt attended, said it had been agreed that "the Bogota office will be clean by Q3/94 in reference to DNP information. Management of DNP will be in Caracas." Soon after, Mr Dunt was advised that "documents dealing with DNP have been separated and should now be forwarded to Caracas. A good quality safe and shredder are required."

Apart from the euphemisms, what stands out most in the documents is how senior management of BAT and its subsidiaries sought to manage markets in smuggled goods. The full extent of its involvement in Latin America was made clear in a stern note from Mr Dunt to his fellow directors questioning the wisdom of allowing BAT's wholly owned Brazilian subsidiary, Souza Cruz, into Argentina, where it would cannibalise the sales of BAT's majority-owned Argentine subsidiary, Nobleza-Piccardo.

"I am advised by Souza Cruz that [BAT Industries] has endorsed the approach that the Brazilian Operating Group increase its share of the Argentinian market via DNP," Mr Dunt wrote in the May 18 1993 memo. "As the director entrusted with responsibility for the management of Nobleza-Piccardo I need to advise you of the likely volume effect on N-P of this decision and of course the financial impact."

Another memo found in Mr Dunt's file, summarising a February 23-24 1994 visit to Colombia, noted of the Kent Super Lights brand that "DNP product should be launched two weeks after the DP product has been launched". As for the Lucky Strike brand, it was planned "to withdraw from the DNP market the 20s and 10s versions".

Further examples of BAT's awareness of and benefit from DNP markets include a "restricted" note of a chief executive's committee meeting on February 7 1994, which said that a new marketing unit for Latin American countries aimed to achieve annual cigarette sales of 50 billion, "including duty not paid". The meeting was chaired by Barry D Bramley, then chairman of BAT's tobacco operations. And BAT's Latin American "Marketing Guidelines for Company Plan 1995-1999" instructed local managers in Colombia that "your plan should cover the launch of variants on the DP and DNP markets".

The documents also show BAT used the presence of legal imports, however small, as an "umbrella", or cover, to advertise its brand of cigarettes, which would reach the market in far larger quantities via DNP, according to the documents.

Mr Dunt wrote in August 1992 to Mr Bramley: "A small volume of duty paid exports would permit advertising and merchandising support in order to establish the brands for the medium/long term, with the market being supplied initially primarily through the DNP channel."

Competition

Fierce competition for market share drove many of BAT's actions in Latin America, the documents suggest. However, they also show that company executives had discussions with representatives of Philip Morris International about "DNP" and "transit".

At a meeting on February 14 1992 in New York, Philip Morris's then president for the Latin American region, Peter Schreer, and his deputy Fred Hauser met BAT's Keith Dunt and David Etchells. "Transit business from Paraguay into Argentina needs to be watched, particularly bearing in mind industry agreement on quantum level of excise," said a file memo written by Mr Etchells, after the discussions.

In August 1992 the representatives met again, at the smart Pennyhill Park country club near BAT headquarters outside London, according to a "secret" document summarising their talks. "PMI raised the 'contraband from Honduras' issue which was counteracted by BATCo's raising the price gap argument. No ground conceded on either side," the notes said.

"BATCo suggested an aggressive price increase to be negotiated at a local level for DNP to be implemented if possible by the end of August," the notes later said.

The nexus of cigarette smuggling and drug money laundering in Latin America is known as the black market peso exchange, in which "peso brokers" convert US dollars from drug lords into clean pesos. Their sources of clean pesos are smugglers who need US dollars to purchase international goods. James Johnson of the US treasury department has called the system "primarily an exchange of currencies" but one that is "perhaps the most dangerous and damaging form of money laundering that we have ever encountered".

With access to US dollars regulated by Colombian law and administered by banks, requiring proof of legal import, the peso broker "offers a businessman a choice and the drug trafficker an opportunity", Bonni Tischler, US customs service assistant commissioner for investigations, told the June 1999 congressional hearing. She said the cigarette industry was one of the "most affected" by the black market peso exchange.

"Some American companies, and I would give Philip Morris as an example, have been accused of implicitly supporting the black market peso exchange in order to increase their market share in Colombia and avoid paying hefty Colombian taxes," noted the hearing's chairman, Senator Charles Grassley.

The BAT documents suggest that company officials were aware of the linkage between cigarette smuggling and money laundering, and they discussed how black market money flows in Aruba affected their business.

The BAT documents end, for the most part, in 1995. Since the mid-1990s legal imports of cigarettes have risen exponentially in Colombia. Official figures show that while only $4.6m in cigarette imports were registered in 1994, that number had leapt to $39.9m by November 1999.

In August 1999, BAT signed a letter of commitment with the customs and tax department promising, according to its director, Fanny Kertzman, "that if they have any evidence that distributors to whom they sell their products are, in turn, selling to smugglers, they will stop selling to these distributors".

In a final desperate attempt to crack down on its contraband problem, two weeks ago Colombia announced a new ban on bringing cigarettes, liquor, or home appliances - the three most common types of contraband goods - from Maicao and Turbo into the rest of the country, effective from July 1. Despite street protests, President Andres Pastrana vowed: "The government has already bit into contraband and is not going to let go until this scourge is eradicated."

Canada filed a lawsuit against RJ Reynolds and its related tobacco companies in New York state in December 1999 for smuggling across the US/Canadian border. An adviser to the Prince of Wales Youth Business Trust is one of many BAT executives whose name repeatedly crops up in the internal memos. Keith Dunt, was the company's regional director for Latin America in the early 90s and has since been promoted to finance director with a seat on the London board. Mr Dunt, 52, an accountant, has spent a quarter of a century with BAT since joining as an international auditor.

Ulrich Herter joined the BAT board in 1990 and was made managing director in charge of its tobacco interests two years later. A German economist, 57-year-old Mr Herter has a reputation for toughness and has spent his working life in the tobacco industry.

Nick Brookes, 49, was director of new business development in the early 90s until being appointed chairman and chief executive officer of BAT's US subsidiary Brown & Williamson five years ago. He is the regional director for America-Pacific and is on BAT's management board.

Barry Bramley was chairman of BAT's tobacco operations and was a reasonably prominent member of the Confederation of British Industry, serving on the business body's European committee.

Mark Waterfield was an executive of BAT's Venezuelan subsidiary, Bigott.

Martin Broughton , BAT's £1m-a-year chairman, will be under pressure to investigate what his senior executives were up to.

webTitle: BAT says smuggling is beyond its control

fields.headline: BAT says smuggling is beyond its control
fields.standfirst: Special report: BAT exposé
fields.trailText: BAT said the "allegations of smuggling" were based on the "cherry picking" of documents from among the 8m which the company was required to make public at its Guildford depository.
fields.body:
BAT said the "allegations of smuggling" were based on the "cherry picking" of documents from among the 8m which the company was required to make public at its Guildford depository.

The company refused to answer specific questions put to it at the end of last week by the Washington-based Center for Public Integrity and the Guardian.

BAT instead issued a statement running to one A4 page which included the following passage: "Along with many other companies in the tobacco industry, and in other industry sectors, we are aware that some of our products are handled other than through official channels.

"Smuggling is a matter of considerable concern to us, not least because it undermines our substantial investment over decades in building proper and well managed distribution networks. "We are acting, with others, to seek to eradicate a significant global problem, but we cannot control the distribution chain all the way to the final customer."

The Center for Public Integrity, BAT went on, was a "special interest group to whom the Guildford document depository in the UK has been made openly available and who claim to be preparing a report based on documents which they have selected".

"We have not seen this report. They appear to have 'cherry picked' a selected number of documents from the 8m pages in the depository, and could be at high risk of drawing and publishing conclusions which are at variance with the facts."

BAT said the documents were old."Allegations such as these are not new. We have frequently encountered inaccurate claims. We do not intend to answer questions or address allegations apparently based on highly selective and out-of-context documents, about matters which are more properly addressed - and in many instances are being addressed with our full cooperation - by governments and customs authorities around the world."

webTitle: A tobacco giant and its global reach

fields.headline: A tobacco giant and its global reach
fields.standfirst: Special report: BAT exposé
fields.trailText: •British American Tobacco sells 900bn cigarettes a year in 180 countries to make it the second largest international tobacco company
fields.body:
British American Tobacco sells 900bn cigarettes a year in 180 countries to make it the second largest international tobacco company

The London-based giant boasts that every minute of every day some 90,000 smokers back the business by buying a pack of 20

The anti-smoking group Ash estimates that the grim flipside of the firm's success is more than 1m premature deaths every year

BAT was founded in 1902 as a joint venture between American Tobacco of the United States and Imperial Tobacco of Britain. From 1911 it was listed on the London stock exchange

The company diversified during the 1960s into activities ranging from financial services to shopping centres before deciding in 1996 to concentrate on tobacco. In 1998 it got rid of the last two non-tobacco elements, financial services companies Allied Dunbar and Eagle Star

BAT completed a £13bn merger last year with Rothmans International, putting it close to overtaking Philip Morris as the world's biggest international tobacco firm

One in every six cigarettes puffed around the world is from one of the 240 BAT brands, which include Lucky Strike, State Express 555, Rothmans, Dunhill, Peter Stuyvesant, John Player Gold Leaf, Kent, Pall Mall and Benson & Hedges

Its £6.5bn stock market value makes BAT Britain's 52nd biggest firm. For the nine months to last September it reported a 26% jump in profits

Non-smoking chairman Martin Broughton declares: "Big tobacco is responsible tobacco"

There are 50,000 employees around the world. The former Tory chancellor Kenneth Clarke is on the board. Though the head office is on the Embankment in London, BAT's global operations are run from Staines, Middlesex

Most of the billions of cigarettes made in BAT's British factories are exported. The company sold few lines at home until its link-up with Rothmans

British rivals Imperial and Gallaher are tiny compared with BAT and risk being taken over unless they merge with other companies

 The chancellor pockets £12bn a year for the exchequer in tobacco taxes but complains that he loses £2.5bn to smuggling

The China National Tobacco Corporation is the world's largest cigarette maker, but does not trade around the world

webTitle: Opposition to euro reaches new high

fields.headline: Opposition to euro reaches new high
fields.trailText: Labour's support for the single European currency is running into a mounting tide of opposition, with an opinion poll showing a record 69% of voters are now against joining the euro.
fields.body:
Labour's support for the single European currency is running into a mounting tide of opposition, with an opinion poll showing a record 69% of voters are now against joining the euro.

Only 22% were in favour of the euro, according to the ICM poll carried out for the BBC, indicating that Mr Blair's softly-softly approach to the euro is not working. In another blow to Mr Blair, the Confederation of British Industry is to stop trying to promote British membership of the single European currency until he gives a lead by calling a referendum.

Meanwhile, Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank, last night admitted that it would take Britain years to be ready for membership. In a BBC television interview, Mr Duisenberg said he thought it would be in Britain's interests to join the single currency area.

But Mr Duisenberg acknowledged that the UK was out of synch economically with its European partners. One prerequisite for joining the euro is a convergence of inflation, interest rates and the exchange rate towards euro area levels - something, Mr Duisenberg said, that "will take some time, to say the least".

In comments designed to clarify the government's policy towards the euro, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers last week said that the government had not fixed the timetable for a referendum on joining the euro. He added that Europe's economy needed to be reformed as it remained old-fashioned and lacked innovation.

Joining the euro is proving to be as difficult an issue for Labour as it was for the Tories. Labour has its own eurosceptics, not least chancellor Gordon Brown, while foreign secretary Robin Cook has emerged as a champion for the single currency. Part of Mr Blair's reluctance for mounting an all-out campaign for the euro lies in the fear that it will split his party just as it tore the Tories apart.

British enthusiasm for the euro has not been helped by the currency's feeble standing. Last week it dipped below parity with the dollar for the first time. If the US Federal Reserve raises rates as it is expected to this week, the euro could sink further.

The ICM poll for the BBC also indicated little support for the EU as a whole, with 34% favouring withdrawal from the EU and only 53% wishing the UK to remain as a member of the union.
