webTitle: European unity could flounder on regional neglect

fields.headline: European unity could flounder on regional neglect
fields.standfirst:
Monetary Union: special report
KPMG's report
fields.trailText: In the debate on the euro very little attention is paid to differences in the levels of income and unemployment across the regions of Europe, and whether a single currency is likely to narrow or exacerbate these differences.
fields.body:
In the debate on the euro very little attention is paid to differences in the levels of income and unemployment across the regions of Europe, and whether a single currency is likely to narrow or exacerbate these differences.

This is an important issue because existing regional inequalities already pose a threat to the cohesion of the European Union. There is a very real possibility that the single currency, without an effective regional policy, will worsen these disparities.

At present the gap is huge. Income per head in the richest cities of Europe is five times higher than in some of the poorest rural areas, and the rate of unemployment in some of the worst affected regions is 10 times higher than in those least affected. There is some evidence that regional incomes and productivity have been converging slowly (although much more slowly in the 80s and 90s than in earlier decades), but at the expense of unemployment.

The trend in the regional dispersion of unemployment is upwards. Unemployment in the 25 poorest regions of the EU averages 25%, compared with 10% in the EU as a whole. These differences are not simply a temporary phenomenon. Contrary to neo-classical orthodoxy there is little evidence that migration of the unemployed reduces regional unemployment rate differences. If anything, labour mobility from depressed to prosperous regions tends to make the poor regions poorer and the rich regions richer; witness the continued north-south divide in Italy and the UK.

The case for regional policies should be self-evident. High unemployment represents a massive social waste; it generates substantial social costs and regional imbalances in economic activity worsen the macroeconomic climate. But most serious of all for the grand design of European integration, regional inequalities provide the basis for serious social and political unrest.

Research on regional disparities across Europe indicates that what happens to regional differences in living standards and unemployment depends mainly on what happens to the relative performance of individual countries.

In considering what is likely to happen to regional disparities in Euroland, the two basic questions are first, is there likely to be real convergence between the countries of Eu roland? And second, will regional policies be strong enough to offset divergent tendencies if countries adversely affected by shocks find difficulty in adjusting because they have lost sovereignty over monetary and exchange rate policy?

The answer to both questions is almost certainly "no". I know of no reputable economist who believes that the 11 countries of Euroland constitute an optimum currency area in the sense that they comprise a sufficiently homogeneous entity so that, if shocks occur, a single economic policy applied to all countries will make no difference to their relative performance.

On regional policy, the structural funds available are simply inadequate. A new allocation of funds for the period 2000-2006 was agreed at the Berlin summit in March 1999. The objectives are broadly the same as in the past - to help poor regions and those with high unemployment - but there is to be greater concentration on the regions most in need of assistance. The total allocation of funds is €213bn, which, spread over seven years, is a smaller annual allocation in real terms than the amount allocated in 1999 of €28bn.

If the EU is serious about regional convergence and cohesion, it needs to increase substantially the size of the budget, particularly to tackle unemployment.

The scourge of unemployment is the greatest economic challenge facing Europe and the consequences of regional neglect could threaten the future of both economic and political union.

Tony Thirlwall is Professor of Applied Economics at the University of Kent at Canterbury, and author of a forthcoming pamphlet, The Euro and "Regional" Divergence in Europe, The New Europe Research Trust. Copies are available on 0171 582 1001 or email researchtrust@new-europe. co.uk

fields.headline: Woodhead brushed aside on clause 28
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Education secretary David Blunkett yesterday brushed aside an embarrassing intervention by the chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, in the controversy over the repeal of section 28, insisting it would not lead to schools promoting homosexuality.
fields.body:
Education secretary David Blunkett yesterday brushed aside an embarrassing intervention by the chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead, in the controversy over the repeal of section 28, insisting it would not lead to schools promoting homosexuality.

Mr Woodhead appeared to put himself on collision course with the government by saying in a Sunday newspaper interview that he had no evidence from any schools that the rule was doing any harm.

Ministers decided to repeal the legislation after concluding that it was stopping teachers from teaching sex education properly and dealing with homophobic behaviour.

Speaking on GMTV's the Sunday Programme, Mr Blunkett said that proposals to repeal the clause would not lead to the promotion of homosexuality in schools, and that he still wanted teachers to emphasise the importance of marriage.

It was down to those responsible for the welfare of children to help them make logical and sensible decisions.

Mr Blunkett said: "All the evidence is that marriage and stable relationships are the best contexts to bring up children. They need stability, they need security".

But he added: "The clause makes a wrong presumption in that there was a tendency to promote a particular sexuality or orientation.

"We are not talking about that. The guidance will indicate that it isn't the job of teachers or youth workers to promote, as though it is a cause, a particular form or orientation. So they will not be promoting homosexual relationships, they will be helping young people to discover their sexuality, to be able to cope with it as they move from adolescence into adulthood in a sensible and sensitive way."

Earlier, Mr Woodhead said he believed the law did not prevent staff in schools from dealing with homosexuality or anti-gay bullying.

He told the Sunday Telegraph: "My own experience is that there is no evidence that clause 28 has had a negative influence on teachers' ability to deal with homophobic bullying. No headteacher has raised with me, in all the many school visits I have made, clause 28 as a cause of concern." He added that inspections around the country had given no indication that children were not getting appropriate information or help about homosexuality.

An Ofsted spokesman said that Mr Woodhead was not criticising the government's decision to repeal the clause, but that he was commenting on his own experience of how schools tackled section 28 on a day-to-day basis.

 A video that encourages children to experiment with gay sex will "help save lives", Avon health authority insisted yesterday.

In the film Beyond a Phase: A Practical Guide to Challenging Homophobia, one boy tells pupils that to obtain sexual satisfaction, they should "try experimenting with both boys and girls to see who you feel most comfortable with".

Pupils are asked whether he should have unprotected gay sex with his boyfriend.

The health authority said that teenage homosexuality is part of "the real world" and the video, which is being distributed to schools across Britain, aims to reduce suicides and sexually transmitted diseases.

However it has caused controversy among family campaigners and MPs.

Liam Fox MP, Tory health spokesman, told the Sunday Times that he planned to urge the department of health to investigate as few parents would want their children "exposed".

fields.headline: Tube bond plan will save £1bn
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott's part-privatisation plan to modernise the London Underground will cost at least £1bn more than the bond scheme favoured by Labour mayoral frontrunner Ken Livingstone, according to the first comprehensive academic study of the controversy, published today.
fields.body:
John Prescott's part-privatisation plan to modernise the London Underground will cost at least £1bn more than the bond scheme favoured by Labour mayoral frontrunner Ken Livingstone, according to the first comprehensive academic study of the controversy, published today.

But whoever is elected mayor, the study's authors also warn, will face a tube funding gap of up to £175m a year whatever method of finance is used - and that shortfall can only be met either by higher fares or increased government subsidy.

The report by the public policy unit at University College London dismisses as unrealistic the government's claims for its public-private partnership proposal, which would hand over the tube infrastructure to private operators for 30 years.

Campaign workers for Frank Dobson, the candidate backed by Tony Blair and Mr Livingstone's main rival, estimated last night that as many as 70% of London's nearly 50,000 paid-up Labour members have already voted in the tightly fought ballot to pick the party's mayoral nominee.

Today's UCL study was commissioned by the three rail unions - the train drivers' union Aslef, the Rail Maritime and Transport union and the Transport Salaried Staffs Association - but one of the report's authors, senior fellow Declan Gaffney, insisted yesterday that the unions had not influenced the content.

"We would have said exactly the same if it had been commissioned by the government," Mr Gaffney said.

Last month, the government's advisers PricewaterhouseCoopers suggested that the public-private partnership scheme would end up £4.5bn cheaper over 15 years than the bond scheme backed by Mr Livingstone and the Liberal Democrat mayoral candidate, Susan Kramer.

But the UCL unit suggests this is because PricewaterhouseCoopers made unwarranted assumptions about improved efficiencies offsetting the higher cost of capital under the government's scheme. UCL's own estimate is that interest payments on tube bonds would cost £991m over the same period, compared with around £1,970m under the public-private partnership.

But the authors say the argument has obscured the fact that, under either financing plan, there will be a funding gap demanding either higher fares or subsidy. In the second year, they estimate the shortfall at about £110m under the government's scheme and £30m under the bond plan.

A spokeswoman for Mr Dobson said yesterday: "The debate over the public-private partnership is a purely rhetorical one, as the government's policy has already been decided and the mayor will have no power to change that. But it's just not practical to propose a fares freeze and radical improvements to the tube infrastructure, as Ken Livingstone has done."

Mr Livingstone countered that part of the income from his proposed congestion charge should help meet the shortfall, combined with increased public subsidy. Labour's third candidate, Glenda Jackson, backs the government's plan.

A spokesman for the RMT said the UCL report threw into question the government's policy for the tube and called for a full inquiry by the transport select committee.

webTitle: Hopes fade for deal over IRA arms but talks go on

fields.headline: Hopes fade for deal over IRA arms but talks go on
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The government was last night locked in intensive discussions with Northern Ireland's political leaders in a last-ditch attempt to broker a deal over IRA disarmament.
fields.body:
The government was last night locked in intensive discussions with Northern Ireland's political leaders in a last-ditch attempt to broker a deal over IRA disarmament.

Amid fears that the peace process could unravel in days, senior officials "hit the telephones" in the hope of finding some common ground between Ulster Unionists and Sinn Fein.

Hopes of reaching a compromise began to fade when sources close to the international decommissioning body indicated it was unlikely to report any breakthrough today.

John de Chastelain, the Canadian general who heads the body, is expected to report that the IRA has not even agreed a timetable on disarmament during a series of meetings in recent weeks.

However, he is planning to delay his long-awaited report until later today in the hope of a change of heart by the IRA. He will then pass his findings to the British and Irish goverments which are expected to publish his report tomorrow.

Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern have been briefed on intense behind-the-scenes discussions, and British sources last night insisted they had not lost hope of a late breakthrough.

"We are not at the suspension stage yet. We have to see the general's report and he doesn't have to hand it over until 11.59 and 59 seconds tomorrow night. We are not suggesting a rabbit will be pulled out of the hat, but these things in Northern Ireland have a tendency to go right down to the wire," the sources said.

The frantic preparations for the publication of the de Chastelain report came as Sinn Fein and the Ulster Unionists clashed once again over disarmament.

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, made clear that the IRA was not yet prepared to disarm, while the Ulster Unionist party leader, David Trimble, hinted that he would resign if the IRA failed to deliver.

Speaking on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost, Mr Adams dismissed Mr Trimble's demand as a "unilateral deadline" which was outside the terms of the Good Friday agreement. "It just is not within my grasp to deliver it on their terms and neither is it my responsibility," he said.

Mr Trimble hit back on BBC1's On the Record. In an uncharacteristically calm performance, Mr Trimble said that he had gone out on a limb to implement every aspect of the Good Friday agreement and it was time for republicans to deliver.

fields.headline: Arms impasse haunts peace process
fields.standfirst:
When De Chastelain reports, the issue of decommissioning can no longer be fudged

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: From the moment it was launched seven years ago, the Northern Ireland peace process has come within inches of being derailed on many occasions. After each crisis Ulster's political leaders have dusted themselves down and moved on to produce an extraordinary political settlement which would have been unthinkable just a few years ago.
fields.body:
From the moment it was launched seven years ago, the Northern Ireland peace process has come within inches of being derailed on many occasions. After each crisis Ulster's political leaders have dusted themselves down and moved on to produce an extraordinary political settlement which would have been unthinkable just a few years ago.

Within the next 24 hours, however, the peace process will face its severest crisis when decommissioning takes centre stage with the publication of John de Chastelain's report on his dialogue with the IRA.

Successive governments on both sides of the Irish Sea have fudged the issue on numerous occasions since the issue of decommissioning started to haunt the province in 1995.

Now there appears to be barely any room for manoeuvre, after David Trimble, the first minister, issued a stark warning yesterday that he cannot remain in office if the IRA refuses to disarm.

Running out of road
"Our capacity to sustain the administration with people in it who have not demonstrated a commitment to peaceful means is extremely limited, and we expected to run out of road after only a month or two," Mr Trimble told BBC1's On the Record.

His insistence that decommissioning must begin now was dismissed by Gerry Adams. Speaking on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost, the Sinn Fein president said that decommissioning could only take place in line with the Good Friday agreement, which set May as a deadline.

"I understand why unionists want decommissioning now," Mr Adams said. "It is just not within my grasp to deliver it on their terms and neither is it my responsibility."

The first step of the week will be taken today when General de Chastelain, a Canadian, passes copies of his decommissioning report to the British and Irish governments.

The general, who has won widespread respect from both sides for his even-handed approach, has held meetings in recent weeks with a leading provisional who is understood to have discussed the IRA's arsenal.

It is understood that by last night the general still had not finalised his report as he held out hope of an eleventh-hour commitment from his IRA contact that the provisionals would begin to disarm.

If, as seems likely, the IRA makes no move, the general is expected to outline in what sources described as a "factual way" his discussions with the paramilitaries.

The very fact that the IRA decided to meet him - after insisting that it would not decommission "through the back door or the front door" - will be seen as an encouraging sign. But with less than four months to go before the deadline for decommissioning, there will be disappointment that there appears to be no agreement even on a timetable for disarming.

Hard grind
The British government is expected to digest the report overnight before publishing it tomorrow, accompanied by a commentary. Government sources refused to say last night what would be in the commentary.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, was said to be working flat out trying to broker a deal with the province's political leaders.

Sources are making no secret of their disappointment that the IRA has failed to begin disarming. "We have endeavoured to ensure that Sinn Fein have no excuse for the IRA's failure to disarm," a government source said. "We have done what we said we would do, and the unionists have done what they said they would do."

At the same time as the government publishes its report tomorrow, the Ulster Unionists will up the ante with a debate in the Northern Ireland assembly on decommissioning. This will provide a high-profile opportunity for anti-agreement unionists to vent their fury at Mr Trimble, putting pressure on him to withdraw from the executive if General de Chastelain's report is gloomy.

There was speculation last week that Mr Mandelson could suspend the executive tomorrow or Wednesday to prevent it from being destroyed altogether by a unionist walk out.

However, he is not expected to act immediately, for fear of precipitating a nationalist walk out. Instead, he is expected to hold intensive talks with political leaders in the hope of finding an agreement.

If the deadlock over decommissioning is not broken by next Monday, February 7, Mr Trimble is unlikely to remain in office. On that day his party's executive meets, ostensibly to discuss the RUC, and his position will be unsustainable if there is no progress.

In addition, his opponents in the party have his post-dated resignation letter, which would be triggered - if decommissioning has not started - when the Ulster Unionist council meets the following Saturday, February 12.

Only the foolhardy would predict what could happen beyond then. But if the peace process does remain on track, there are two key dates. General de Chastelain is believed to have pencilled in March 14 as the date by which decommissioning must start if it is to be completed by May 22, the day laid down in the Good Friday agreement.

webTitle: Green lobby fears move to approve GM crop trials

fields.headline: Green lobby fears move to approve GM crop trials
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Campaigners against genetically modified crops yesterday claimed that the government was pressing ahead with legal procedures to approve commercial planting long before completion of farm trials in 2003.
fields.body:
Campaigners against genetically modified crops yesterday claimed that the government was pressing ahead with legal procedures to approve commercial planting long before completion of farm trials in 2003.

Technical committees reporting to the ministry of agriculture will this week start considering an application for a GM maize to be grown for animal fodder, and Friends of the Earth said commercial plans for another 23 GM crops were in preparation.

FoE, which praised the government's part in a ground-breaking international agreement to allow countries to ban GM imports on a safety-first principle, called on ministers to adopt a similar approach here.

But Michael Meacher, the environment minister, insisted that Britain already had rules to ensure that any risk was evaluated before GM organisms were introduced, and the farm trials were part of that process.

The government has a voluntary agreement with the biotech industry that it will not plant crops commercially here until the trials are over. But companies are still seeking EU marketing consents, approvals for novel foods and addition to the national seed list. A number of crops are said to have achieved the first two of these.

Peter Riley, biotechnology campaigner for FoE, said: "Ministers must keep their clear promise to the public. They must prevent these GM crops getting commercial approval before the threat they pose to the environment is known. If these crops do get approval the farm scale trials will lose whatever credibility they have left."

Liana Stupples, FoE campaigns driector, said Mr Meacher "had done a grand job" last week in helping developing countries to defeat entrenched opposition to a new agreement from the US and the multinational GM companies. "He took a tough stance on the precautionary principle. We want to see if he is allowed to exercise it back at home."

The new biosafety protocol says that companies wishing to export GM seeds and crops would have to notify governments in advance. These would have the right to refuse entry if they believed, after risk assessments, that imports would threaten the environment or the health of their people.

Mr Meacher said that the agreement was "a tremedous step forward" which would enable developing countries to protect their biodiversity.

"In Europe we already have directives which ensure that any risk to the environment is evaluated before the introduction of GMOs."

fields.headline: Concorde in landing scares
fields.trailText:
A Concorde plane was forced to execute two emergency landings over the weekend at Heathrow,
   British Airways admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
A Concorde plane was forced to execute two emergency landings over the weekend at Heathrow, British Airways admitted yesterday.

The supersonic jet carrying 100 passengers made an emergency landing on Sunday, less than 24 hours after engine failure on the same aircraft forced it to make an unscheduled landing at the same airport.

A spokeswoman for BA, which owns seven Concordes, said it was "pure coincidence" that the same plane had experienced problems on consecutive days.

Fire crews were put on full alert yesterday after the flight crew on a BA charter flight to the Bay of Biscay reported that a cockpit warning light indicated a fire in the rear hold 20 minutes into the flight.

The captain turned the plane around and performed an emergency landing at 1.23pm, the BA spokeswoman said. "The captain decided to turn around and come back to Heathrow and automatically it is called an emergency. The plane was checked out and it was a false alarm.

There was nothing wrong with the plane. It was just a precautionary measure," she said.

Passengers had to leave the plane for 30 minutes while it was checked, before taking off again and completing the three-and-a-half hour trip.

BA denied there was any link with an incident on Saturday, when the same aircraft, on flight BA272 from Barbados to Heathrow was forced to land seven minutes early after an engine shut down in mid-air.

Emergency services were put on stand-by after the aircraft, with 92 passengers on board, developed engine trouble seven miles from Heathrow and landed with three engines working. The spokeswoman said: "The Concorde has four engines but it can fly perfectly safely on three and even on two. It is standard procedure to declare an emergency when you have an engine shutdown."

She added that an inquiry would be carried out into the cause of the engine shutdown.

webTitle: Over 100 feared dead after Kenyan jet crash

fields.headline: Over 100 feared dead after Kenyan jet crash
fields.standfirst: Nine survivors plucked from the sea so far
fields.trailText: A handful of survivors were found clinging to wreckage in the Atlantic today after a Kenya Airways jet carrying 179 people crashed off the west African coast yesterday evening.
fields.body:
A handful of survivors were found clinging to wreckage in the Atlantic today after a Kenya Airways jet carrying 179 people crashed off the west African coast yesterday evening.

The plane, an Airbus 310, took off from Abidjan, Ivory Coast, at 9:08pm yesterday eveningand crashed just one minute later, according to George Dapre Yao, the head of air traffic at Abidjan's Felix Houphouet-Boigny Airport.

Emergency officials - fireman, police officers, soldiers and divers - combed the beach near the crash scene late immediately after the crash to search for survivors.

At least nine people are though to have survived, including one man who swam to shore. Rescuers said 14 bodies had been brought to shore and at least 49 more were coming in by boat Monday morning, leaving over a hundred passengers and crew unaccounted for.

Witnesses said the plane never appeared to get sufficient altitude as it crossed over the airport's wall and headed out over the ocean, just a few hundred yards away.

"Just after takeoff the plane started having problems," said Samuel Ogbada Adje, a Nigerian survivor, wrapped in a blanket at an Abidjan port after being plucked from the water by rescuers. "It wasn't quite balanced and the next thing we knew we were in the water."

Mr Adje said he was propelled into the water by the force of the crash, and managed to swim from the wreckage.

He said the rescue was a disaster. "If they had come sooner, a lot of us would have been saved. We waited two hours for people to rescue us," he said angrily before being pushed into an ambulance and driven away.

The plane's final destination was Nairobi, Kenya - a popular route among Nigerians heading to Dubai for duty-free shopping.

It was supposed to have landed in Lagos, Nigeria, on Sunday afternoon but was diverted to Abidjan because of bad weather.

The route is popular is Anne Yeze was worshiping at the Celestial Christian Church, a concrete-walled, metal-roofed building just off the beach, when the plane crashed into the water nearby.

"We were praying and we heard a noise, like something hitting the water," she said. The parishioners rushed outside, but couldn't see the crash. They then called the airport.

An official at the airport's control tower, speaking on condition of anonymity, said French military firefighters, who are stationed at the military base next to the airport, were dispatched to the scene.

The control tower official said that wreckage of the plane could not be seen, but the area where the plane had crashed was visible from the tower.

Kenya Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, working together, have daily flights from Amsterdam to Nairobi. Sunday's crash was the first such disaster for Kenya Airways, which has been operating since 1977.

The Kenyan government retains a significant interest in its national carrier while KLM Royal Dutch Airlines is the largest individual shareholder with a 26 percent stake in the company.

fields.headline: £5,000 to visit UK, Asians told
fields.trailText: Visitors from the Indian subcontinent are to be asked to provide a £5,000 bond guarantee if they are suspected of planning to settle illegally in Britain.
fields.body:
Visitors from the Indian subcontinent are to be asked to provide a £5,000 bond guarantee if they are suspected of planning to settle illegally in Britain.

In a pilot scheme expected to begin this autumn, British visa offices in India, Pakistan or Bangladesh will require a financial guarantee before granting entry permission to visitors regarded as "borderline" cases.

The money, which could be provided by family members, would be returned if visitors left the country on or before the date they were due to go.

If judged successful, the scheme will be extended to other countries. The home office minister Barbara Roche said the plan would help visitors who might otherwise be refused entry.

"We are talking about people who satisfy the entry requirements in every single respect, apart from whether they will go back at the end of the visit," she said.

"If an entry clearance officer says no, and it turns out to have been a perfectly legitimate application, somebody could miss a family wedding, or perhaps a very important event, perhaps a naming ceremony in a child's life."

But MPs and immigrant pressure groups condemned the plan as flawed and discriminatory. They said poor visitors would in effect be prevented from visiting Britain. The Labour MP Jeremy Corbyn warned that the measure could be illegal under existing race relations legislation.

On the latest figures, which exclude EU countries, visitors from the subcontinent account for about 5% of foreign entries into Britain.

webTitle: Mitterrand did not give me money, says Helmut Kohl

fields.headline: Mitterrand did not give me money, says Helmut Kohl
fields.standfirst: German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: Helmut Kohl yesterday flatly denied a report that he had taken a huge donation from his friend and ally François Mitterrand to finance his re-election as German chancellor six years ago.
fields.body:
Helmut Kohl yesterday flatly denied a report that he had taken a huge donation from his friend and ally François Mitterrand to finance his re-election as German chancellor six years ago.

Responding personally to the claims for the first time, Mr Kohl said in an interview with a Sunday newspaper that the claim was "absurd and a lie".

French and German television journalists last week reported claims that the late French president Mitterrand had kicked back £10m into the coffers of Mr Kohl's Christian Democratic Union (CDU) to help fund its 1994 re-election campaign.

The money was said to have arisen from commission generated from the sale of an east German refinery to the French oil firm Elf Acquitaine. It is the largest single amount to figure in the scandal over illegal financing that is surrounding Mr Kohl and his party.

But the former chancellor told Welt am Sonntag: "Mitterrand and I at no time talked about money in the context of elections or parties."

He called the report a "repulsive concoction of unproven claims, slander and anonymous 'tips', but possibly also machinations by intelligence services".

His denial came as the mood surrounding the affair took on an air of farce. In a report on the methods used by regional party officials in Hesse to cover the source of the funds, the news magazine Der Spiegel said they had resorted to putting false nameplates on burial niches in a Paraguayan cemetery.

The magazine said their aim was to provide evidence of the death of non-existent German exiles from whom the CDU in Hesse claimed to have received bequests. In fact, the money came from secret accounts in Switzerland and Liechtenstein, where it had been deposited by the CDU to be invested and laundered. Its true origin is one of the central mysteries of the whole affair.

Der Spiegel quoted a German businessman in Paraguay as saying he had forged more than 200 death certificates, charging £3,000 for each.

A key figure linking the scandal in Hesse with the federal party's accounts is Horst Weyrauch, who last week stepped down as CDU head of audit. On Saturday he submitted a report to the Hesse CDU, which is likely to be the focus of further investigation.

webTitle: Those other bug killers that could rescue the world from disaster

fields.headline: Those other bug killers that could rescue the world from disaster
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Amid all the talk of using the internet to change the way we do business, there is another - potentially more important - development lurking in the background at this year's World Economic Forum taking place in the Swiss ski resort of Davos.
fields.body:
Amid all the talk of using the internet to change the way we do business, there is another - potentially more important - development lurking in the background at this year's World Economic Forum taking place in the Swiss ski resort of Davos.

The genetic revolution, which will pass an important milestone later this year when the project to map the human genome is expected to be completed, has the potential to change not just the way we live our lives but life itself.

Yet the debate about the profound economic, ethical, regulatory and personal issues which it raises has barely begun, getting bogged down as it has in the crude caricatures of "Frankenstein foods" and Dolly the sheep. Davos is trying to move it forward.

The technology of genomics is already four years ahead of schedule and is doubling every 18 months, according to George Church, director of the Lipper Centre for Computational Genetics at Harvard medical school.

Its scope in the field of human health is enormous.

William Haseltine, chairman and chief executive officer of Human Genome Science, said that within three to five years drugs made from human genes and proteins would be used to help the body regenerate itself. Applied internally, they could, for example, help to heal the lesions caused by cancer.

Ecological impact

In the longer term, it ought to be possible to replace human organs with new ones manufactured out of human materials and ultimately to control the ageing process, Mr Haseltine said.

Organisers of another discussion claimed that, presuming continuing genetic advances, a child born today will have an average life expectancy of 120 years.

To sceptics such as Vandana Shiva, director of the Research Foundation for Science Technology and Natural Resources Policy in India, this is hype, inspired by the money-making potential of such technological advances, and it is at the same time failing to give proper consideration to the ecological impact.

She pointed out that in the region she comes from, in the Himalayas, indigenous people have been living to well over 100 years for a long time, aided not by wonder drugs but through simple living.

Natural alternatives to genomics are available and should not be excluded from the debate, she said.

The divide between the two sides in the row over genetically modified foods is equally wide.

On the one hand, people such as Thilo Bode, international executive officer of Greenpeace International in the Netherlands, argued that genetically modified organisms have no role whatsoever to play in agriculture. Once released into nature they cannot be recalled if they prove harmful.

For Mr Bode, the risks outweigh the potential benefits; but for Gordon Conway, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, the opposite is true.

While acknowledging the ecological risks, Mr Bode pointed out at Davos that GMOs are already in widespread use around the world, especially in America, where they account for half of the cotton crop and one-third of the maize production, and that they are achieving positive results.

For example, the Alabama cotton crop, which supports thousands of jobs, was saved from destruction by pesticides through the application of bug-resistant GMOs.

The greatest potential of GMOs, however, is probably in the developing world, which is the source of 90% of the planet's store of biological resources at present being exploited by the biotech industry.

Reverse the tide

There are 800m undernourished people in the developing world, including 400m women of childbearing age with anaemia and 100m vitamin A-deficient youngsters, all of whom could benefit from using GMOs to reverse the tide of sharply falling crop yields from traditional farming methods. Should they be denied the chance of a better diet in order to appease the sensitivities of western consumers spoilt for choice over what they eat?

Critics of GMOs hit back by saying that there is already more than enough food in the world to feed everyone and that the answer to hunger and poor diets in the developing world is better global agricultural policies.

It is certainly the case that the European Union would do the world a favour if it dismantled the Common Agricultural Policy instead of continuing to dump surplus produce on countries at price levels at which local farmers cannot compete.

But does that also mean that GMOs should be abandoned? If so, why not also abandon chemical farming? It has done enormous amounts of damage to the natural environment, polluting rivers and destroying species. Will GMOs be any more harmful? Are they any more unnatural?

New strain of rice

The big issue with GMOs is not so much whether they are a good or a bad thing but the way in which they are being handled by the business community.

Anxious to wrest back control of the debate from increasingly hostile consumers, the biotech industry is busy promoting the benefits of a new strain of GM rice packed full of vitamin A which it says has the potential to transform the lives of millions of people in the developing countries.

What it is not so keen to tell people is that its use is governed by 24 different patents, all designed to ensure that the financial gains are maximised.

No one expects companies with shareholders breathing down their necks to do something for nothing but governments have a role in ensuring the licences to use such products are not too restrictive.

The way to win people over is to give them the information they need to make up their own minds.

The information revolution has grabbed all the headlines at Davos with a cast list of New Economy heroes headed by Bill Gates, Michael Dell and AOL's Stephen Case taking the podium to talk about the benefits of technology, and no conversation is complete without a reference to the internet. What use the technology is put to is another matter.

Amid all the coming and goings of e-entrepreneurs and world leaders here in Davos, including Bill Clinton and Tony Blair, there has been lots of talk about using the internet to respond to public hostility which surrounds the activities of multi-national companies.

fields.headline: Price of backing a loser
fields.standfirst:
Neil Hamilton's funders may be counting the cost of their generosity after the ruling that names must be disclosed. Marcel Berlins reports. Adrian Zuckerman says there's a wider cause for concern about who pays for court cases : Where mortals fear to tread
Hamilton, Al Fayed libel trial
fields.trailText: 'I completely fail to understand a culture which provides state funding if you lose a finger, but not if you are deprived of your reputation. And I profoundly reject the idea that defending your reputation should be the preserve of the rich." That attack on the lack of legal aid for libel came, surprisingly, from the late Sir James Goldsmith, a man not usually known for his adhesion to fashionably liberal legal causes.
fields.body:
'I completely fail to understand a culture which provides state funding if you lose a finger, but not if you are deprived of your reputation. And I profoundly reject the idea that defending your reputation should be the preserve of the rich." That attack on the lack of legal aid for libel came, surprisingly, from the late Sir James Goldsmith, a man not usually known for his adhesion to fashionably liberal legal causes.

It was 1987. Goldsmith had set up a fund to help individuals bring or defend libel actions which they could not afford. Ironically, the first beneficiary was one Neil Hamilton, who, with his fellow Conservative MP Gerald Howarth, successfully sued the BBC over a Panorama programme branding them as extremists with links to fascist and racist groups. The BBC retracted and paid them each £20,000 compensation plus costs. Had they lost, the Goldsmith fund - administered by libel solicitor Peter Carter-Ruck - would have uncomplainingly borne all the legal costs.

Hamilton wasn't able to call on the Goldsmith millions to fund his libel case against Mohamed Fayed. With little money of his own, he relied on his friends and supporters to pass the hat round. Under a court order made last Friday by the trial judge, details of the larger contributors to Hamilton's fighting fund have to be disclosed to the court. Their belief in him might prove expensive - they may have to pay up far more than their original donation.

The problem lies in the rule that the loser of a court case normally has to pay not only his own lawyers, but also the legal costs of his winning opponent. It is common for campaigning groups, trade unions or professional organisations to back litigation brought (or defended) by their members or sympathisers. They know that if their sponsored litigant loses, they'll have to pick up the legal tab. The Police Federation, for example, has backed hundreds of libel cases involving its members, the vast majority successful. When five policemen lost a libel suit against the Guardian in 1998, the federation had to pay the newspaper a six-figure sum in legal costs. But where the unsuccessful claimant is an impecunious individual, the winner can get his legal costs reimbursed only from the loser's backers. Fine if it's James Goldsmith; not so easy if it's a rag-bag collection of donors who'd given sums from a fiver to tens of thousands.

It used to be a crime, called maintenance, for someone to finance someone else's lawsuit, unless there was some close link - such as family - or a "community of interest" between giver and litigant. If the backer stood to get a slice of any winnings, it was known as champerty, and was treated as even more serious. The crimes of maintenance and champerty were abolished in 1967, and a new set of legal principles was developed (especially in the 1995 case of the Symphony Group v Hodgson) to deal with examples of "strangers" who fund litigation. What's clear from that, and from new 1999 rules, is that the trial judge has a wide discretion to order backers of the losing party to pay towards the costs of the winner (although it's unlikely that any judge would order a close relative to stump up). He also has power to order the disclosure of the names of anyone contributing to a fighting fund.

Mr Justice Morland demanded to know details of who had paid in more than £5,000. Presumably he felt there was no point in pursuing smaller donors. But, so far, only one person has publicly admitted giving a substantial sum. It's not the first time the 10th earl of Portsmouth has played Lord Bountiful to a libel claimant. In 1989 he contributed to Count Nikolai Tolstoy's failed defence to a claim by Lord Aldington, which resulted in the biggest-ever jury award - £1.5 million - over allegations of war crimes in Yugoslavia. The winner never got a penny of the money; Tolstoy had nothing.

Portsmouth wasn't called on to pay any extra legal costs. It turned out that Aldington himself had been bankrolled, by the insurance company of which he'd been head.

The columnist Taki, another backer of Hamilton's, has written: "I shall not be revealing my contribution unless forced to, in which case it was £4,999."

He may not want to disclose how much he gave, but under the court order Lord Harris of High Cross, the fund's organiser, will have to reveal the information. Harris himself has admitted being a donor and Norris McWhirter of the Freedom Association is also known to be one.

It would be a contempt of court, for which they could go to jail, for Lord Harris and Hamilton not to reveal what the judge has demanded. It is no excuse to claim that contributors to the fund were promised that their identities would be kept secret. Nor would backers be able to say: "No one told me that I might have to pay more than my original contribution."

Whatever the final result, this quibble about legal costs will send a message to anyone (other than a close family member) who, because of kind-heartedness or belief in a cause, is thinking of backing someone else's litigation. Don't.

The Hamilton-Fayed litigation produced much indignation at Hamilton's fighting fund. A better cause for outrage should have been the fact that (except in small claims) litigants in England are exposed to extravagant, disproportionate and unpredictable costs. Even modest disputes can absorb large legal fees.

Recently, a couple had to sell their house to pay £19,000 costs to their opponents, in a dispute over a narrow parking space. In a divorce battle over the family home the lawyers' fees can swallow its value. In about a third of high court claims of under £12,500, the costs to one side alone have been between £10,000 and £20,000.

The English system exposes litigants to maximum risk and offers lawyers maximum profit. The system exalts the principle of justice which holds that the function of the courts is to decide cases on their true merits and not on procedural technicalities. If litigants are late in performing procedural tasks, such as providing an adequate statement of the case, they must be given more time.

If their performance is defective, they must have a chance to rectify it. But requests for extensions or to remedy defects are often hotly contested, involving appeals and generating great expense. Paradoxically, the principle of justice-on-the-merits produces much litigation which has nothing to do with merits.

The rule that the loser in a court case has to pay the winner's costs tends to erode resistance to cost. Given that success brings with it not only a favourable judgment but also reimbursement of legal fees and expenses, a litigant who believes that spending more will increase the chances of success has good reason for progressively raising the stakes. So both litigants become locked in an investment competition.

Lawyers' economic interests are served by the system of hourly fees. The more complex and protracted the litigation becomes, the more they earn. Lawyers don't have to inflate procedural activity because the system does it for them. The courts have allowed litigants to engage in sterile procedural disputes. Clients' resistance to spending more and more is undermined by the hope of winning and thereby recovering all their outlay. And the system preys on their hopes and goads them into ever greater investment.

Reforms initiated by Lord Woolf, master of the rolls, seek to establish a sensible balance between the value and complexity of disputes and their cost. Unfortunately, the new system does not radically alter the combustible mixture fuelling costs. Both the hourly fee system and the rule that the winner recovers costs from the loser have been retained. With limited exceptions, the idea of fixed-cost litigation has been abandoned in the face of resistance by the legal profession, which has found plenty of scope for hourly fees in the new procedures. And conditional fees - no-win, no-fee arrangements - which are now replacing legal aid, will in some types of claims provide lawyers with even greater opportunities for high fees.

High and unpredictable costs deter most citizens from seeking the courts' help. Those who do are trapped in a vortex of expense which is hard to control. There are better ways of providing access to justice, if only our government could face down the vested interests involved.

webTitle: MPs attack bond plan for Asian visitors

fields.headline: MPs attack bond plan for Asian visitors
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Government plans to require financial guarantees against illegal settlement by visitors from the Indian sub-continent were criticised last night by MPs and pressure groups.
fields.body:
Government plans to require financial guarantees against illegal settlement by visitors from the Indian sub-continent were criticised last night by MPs and pressure groups.

Simon Hughes, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, condemned as "inept and discriminatory" the pilot plan to force visa applicants regarded as borderline cases to pay a bond of about £5,000 before being allowed into Britain.

He accused ministers of trying to "look tough" in advance of a Tory-initiated Commons debate on asylum and immigration this week.

"There may well be a case for a system to prevent those families with a history of abuse [from entering Britain]. But most people who apply and are turned down have never broken the rules before. Families where there is no history of breach of any conditions should always be given the benefit of the doubt."

Other restrictions could be demanded, he said, such as making visitors re-register every month or so or requiring a family member to give up their British passport until the visitor had left. But the bond plan discriminated against poorer visitors; it took some families years to save up to travel to Britain.

Jeremy Corbyn, Labour MP for Islington North, said the plan was discriminatory and because of race relations laws "possibly illegal". The Liberal Democrat peer Lord Russell, a professor of history at King's College, London, said it would hit the finances of a lot of universities by discouraging overseas students.

"When the Malaysian ringit collapsed in 1998 the London School of Economics was badly hit. Overseas students will simply go elsewhere," he said.

Ashika Thanki, project manager for the Newham monitoring project, which campaigns for ethnic minorities in London, said visitors from the Americas and Europe would not face the same demands.

"Clearly the British state wants to restrict entry for people from the third world. It seems to think it's fine to have people from anywhere except the third world. How are they supposed to put the money together to make the bond requirements?"

Claude Moraes, the loyalist Labour MEP for London and a former director of the joint council for the welfare of immigrants, said: "Pilot projects are all very well. But there are concerns that they need to be monitored very carefully, because there are genuine concerns about indirect discrimination, and fairness."

William Hague, the Conservative leader, said at the weekend that the government's policy on asylum seekers would become a key battlegrounds in the next election.

The number of asylum seekers awaiting a decision topped 100,000 for the first time last year, figures released last week showed.

fields.headline: Shipman jurors in hotel heartbreak
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: I really feel sorry for the jury in the Shipman trial. Not because they had to listen to, and then consider, several weeks of distasteful evidence about 15 deaths, but because the poor things were denied what used to be a fundamental perk of jury service - the inalienable right of juries to be put up overnight at a posh hotel if they weren't able to reach a decision during the day.
fields.body:
I really feel sorry for the jury in the Shipman trial. Not because they had to listen to, and then consider, several weeks of distasteful evidence about 15 deaths, but because the poor things were denied what used to be a fundamental perk of jury service - the inalienable right of juries to be put up overnight at a posh hotel if they weren't able to reach a decision during the day.

I believe it was enshrined in one of the lesser-known clauses of Magna Carta. How well I remember the days when a typical London jury, having agreed on the verdict long before noon, would brilliantly spin out its deliberations until five, so as to ensure for every member a luxury meal and kip at the elegant Brown's Hotel in the west end. On occasions, it is said, every room in the place was occupied by such bogusly indecisive jurors. Later, the Howard Hotel, nearer the Old Bailey, was used, but it didn't have the same cachet.

Jurors who had overnighted at Brown's felt superior to mere Howarders. Alas, the whole jury hotel scene is no more. A vicious law passed a few years ago allows judges to send jurors back to their own homes for the night, with firm instructions not to discuss their case with anyone. I'm sure they're all keeping to that ban. Just as the spouses and lovers on conjugal visits to the hotel-bound jurors in the OJ Simpson trial never ever mentioned a word about the case. Still, it's good to know that the Shipman jury deliberated for so long because they were considering the evidence, not dreaming of a night between silken sheets.

Genocide is a word much misused these days, too often applied to very nasty behaviour against some ethnic, racial, religious or national group. To use it so cavalierly serves only to diminish the impact of true genocide - conduct or policies aimed at human extermination. The ethnic cleansing perpetrated in the Balkans during the 1990s was appalling and awful, but not genocide. What I hadn't realised, until informed the other day by Michael Ignatieff in an stimulating lecture at the Royal Society of Arts, was quite how recent the word is. It was invented only in 1943, by a Polish-Jewish lawyer, Raphael Lemkin. Just two years later it was one of the charges faced by the main defendants in the Nuremberg trials. A few years after that, there was a United Nations Genocide Convention, its existence largely the result of the obsessive Lemkin's incessant pressure.

Lemkin died, forgotten and alone, in 1959. In the nearly 60 years since his invention, the number of defendants found guilty of genocide in the courts is precisely one, arising from the Rwandan massacres.

Solicitors, as you've seen from their brass plates, are usually also "commissioners for oaths". If you need to swear to some official document, you wander over to a solicitor, who signs the thing in question and pockets a small fee. What I didn't know is that a few years ago, behind my back, barristers were also allowed to be commissioners for oaths. At a time when their earnings are under such savage attack, this could become an important money-spinner. They charge £4 an oath, and it only takes a minute of their time. In an eight-hour day, if they don't go to lunch and have an adequate queueing system, they can do 480 signings, for a daily income approaching £2,000. Barristers claim that oaths taken in front of them are more truthful, and last longer, than those done by solicitors. The only problem is that very few documents need to be sworn in this way. Still, every little bit helps.

Those of you lucky enough to have penetrated the portals of the Law Society in London's Chancery Lane will have noticed, on the walls, many large oil portraits of serious-looking men in suits.They are the past presidents of the Law Society, and, I've thought, how generous of the society to honour their past leaders in this way. Wrong. Martin Mears, a recent past president, reveals the truth in the New Law Journal. The men in question (no women yet) commissioned their own paintings and paid for them out of their own pockets. They've then kindly donated them to the Law Society, which graciously accepted them. Skint presidents get no wall space. Perhaps it's the same with portraits of the Queen. It must cost her a fortune.

I believe it was enshrined in one of the lesser-known clauses of Magna Carta. How well I remember the days when a typical London jury, having agreed on the verdict long before noon, would brilliantly spin out its deliberations until five, so as to ensure for every member a luxury meal and kip at the elegant Brown's Hotel in the west end. On occasions, it is said, every room in the place was occupied by such bogusly indecisive jurors. Later, the Howard Hotel, nearer the Old Bailey, was used, but it didn't have the same cachet. Jurors who had overnighted at Brown's felt superior to mere Howarders. Alas, the whole jury hotel scene is no more. A vicious law passed a few years ago allows judges to send jurors back to their own homes for the night, with firm instructions not to discuss their case with anyone. I'm sure they're all keeping to that ban. Just as the spouses and lovers on conjugal visits to the hotel-bound jurors in the OJ Simpson trial never ever mentioned a word about the case. Still, it's good to know that the Shipman jury deliberated for so long because they were considering the evidence, not dreaming of a night between silken sheets. Genocide is a word much misused these days, too often applied to very nasty behaviour against some ethnic, racial, religious or national group. To use it so cavalierly serves only to diminish the impact of true genocide - conduct or policies aimed at human extermination. The ethnic cleansing perpetrated in the Balkans during the 1990s was appalling and awful, but not genocide. What I hadn't realised, until informed the other day by Michael Ignatieff in an stimulating lecture at the Royal Society of Arts, was quite how recent the word is. It was invented only in 1943, by a Polish-Jewish lawyer, Raphael Lemkin. Just two years later it was one of the charges faced by the main defendants in the Nuremberg trials. A few years after that, there was a United Nations Genocide Convention, its existence largely the result of the obsessive Lemkin's incessant pressure. Lemkin died, forgotten and alone, in 1959. In the nearly 60 years since his invention, the number of defendants found guilty of genocide in the courts is precisely one, arising from the Rwandan massacres. Solicitors, as you've seen from their brass plates, are usually also "commissioners for oaths". If you need to swear to some official document, you wander over to a solicitor, who signs the thing in question and pockets a small fee. What I didn't know is that a few years ago, behind my back, barristers were also allowed to be commissioners for oaths. At a time when their earnings are under such savage attack, this could become an important money-spinner. They charge £4 an oath, and it only takes a minute of their time. In an eight-hour day, if they don't go to lunch and have an adequate queueing system, they can do 480 signings, for a daily income approaching £2,000. Barristers claim that oaths taken in front of them are more truthful, and last longer, than those done by solicitors. The only problem is that very few documents need to be sworn in this way. Still, every little bit helps. Those of you lucky enough to have penetrated the portals of the Law Society in London's Chancery Lane will have noticed, on the walls, many large oil portraits of serious-looking men in suits.They are the past presidents of the Law Society, and, I've thought, how generous of the society to honour their past leaders in this way. Wrong. Martin Mears, a recent past president, reveals the truth in the New Law Journal. The men in question (no women yet) commissioned their own paintings and paid for them out of their own pockets. They've then kindly donated them to the Law Society, which graciously accepted them. Skint presidents get no wall space. Perhaps it's the same with portraits of the Queen. It must cost her a fortune.

fields.headline: Up in arms over exports
fields.trailText: After Gordon Brown's much applauded pledge to cancel third world debt, coupled with his insistence that any resources released should be prioritised for poverty reduction and economic recovery, how does the government justify the role of its export credit guarantee department (ECGD) in financing corrupt tyrants and warlords with massive arms loans and fuelling the flames of conflict in the third world (Leader, January 26)?
fields.body:
After Gordon Brown's much applauded pledge to cancel third world debt, coupled with his insistence that any resources released should be prioritised for poverty reduction and economic recovery, how does the government justify the role of its export credit guarantee department (ECGD) in financing corrupt tyrants and warlords with massive arms loans and fuelling the flames of conflict in the third world (Leader, January 26)?

Zimbabwe's President Mugabe, who was recently supplied with jet spare parts for his intervention in the Congo, is spending £1m a day to keep his army there, at a time when Zimbabwe's foreign reserves are all but exhausted and the economy is on the brink of collapse.

Twenty per cent of Africa's debt is attributed to arms procurements. This makes it morally unjustifiable for Britain to insist that resources released from debt cancellation are prioritised for poverty reduction whilst it allows the ECGD to increase the debt burden by fuelling the flames of conflict.
Kwesi Owusu
Jubilee 2000 Africa Initiative
kowusu@jubilee2000.org.uk

 Your list of countries benefiting from the venture capital of export guarantees (Doing the business, January 26) shows the most favoured nation status conferred in the following order: China, Saudi Arabia, Indonesia, Quatar, Brazil, Russian Federation, Turkey, all with over £500m guaranteed.

I doubt that these are the regimes that the electorate would wish to see benefiting most from the investment of taxpayer's money. If Britain was really to be run as a forward thinking business corporation (which is the style the Blair government seem to wish to emulate) they would be putting most of this £4,823m venture capital into research and development, where there is a clearly predictable future demand, which would result in reliable exports, such as technologies for harnessing renewable energy and conserving water supplies. Instead they drive British firms such as BP, which want to invest in the development of Photovoltaics, to shift their operations to the United States for lack of any financial incentives.

It has been demonstrated that there is no overall financial benefit to the UK economy from our arms trade and that in some years it produces a net deficit. Setting ethical questions to one side for the moment (rather than at all times, like the DTI) any intelligent corporation executive would be seeking to diversify out of the areas where both trade and returns were erratic and caused PR problems.
Kate Macintosh
Winchester, Hampshire

 While it is proper to consider whole-country bans where there is gross abuse of human rights, it is equally important to use the powers of government to help combat the sad record of abuses by British and European companies themselves. Our first responsibility should be to ensure that public money only goes to support companies which can demonstrate compliance with international labour, environmental and human rights.
Richard Howitt MEP

 You allege (Whitehall leaks reveal ethics row, January 26) that the foreign office was lukewarm about including environmental and human rights factors in the ECGD review. In fact, in contributing to the review, the foreign office wrote: "As you know the foreign secretary has put respect for human rights and the protection of the environment at the heart of foreign policy. ECGD's mission and statement need to reflect his approach". I do not think many of your readers would disagree.
Robin Cook MP
Foreign secretary

fields.headline: No closer to harmony
fields.trailText: I am struck by the procession of Scottish Labour party people who feel the need to tell London members who to vote for. What if London members were to try to tell Scots how to vote in their internal selections?
fields.body:
I am struck by the procession of Scottish Labour party people who feel the need to tell London members who to vote for. Ian McCartney, Gordon Brown, and now Baronness Smith (Letters, January 29) have all felt the need to intervene. What if London members were to try to tell Scots how to vote in their internal selections? I think I can guess how they would react to such prize impertinence.
Dorothy Macedo
London
d.macedo@unisonfree.net

 Baroness Smith's encomium of Frank Dobson stops conveniently short when invoking her late husband's views. Does she think John Smith would also have approved of blatant vote-rigging on behalf of one favoured candidate?
Victor Hunt
Ilkley, West Yorks

 New Labour's next campaign song (Letters, January 29)? It has to be Money's Too Tight To Mention (NHS mix).
Judi Hodgkin
Bristol

fields.headline: Mothers and children first
fields.trailText: In defence of her Panorama programme, Sarah Powell (Letters, January 27), has still to address two issues. First, why, when the research team were provided with quotes and references, were two recent studies contradicting the programme's view not mentioned?
fields.body:
In defence of her Panorama programme, Sarah Powell (Letters, January 27), has still to address two issues. First, why, when the research team were provided with quotes and references, were two recent studies contradicting the programme's view not mentioned?

Second, the quality of Professor Joshi's work is not at issue. It is Ms Powell's interpretation of the findings that lacks rigour. Professor Joshi has not made the same claims. For example, the programme did not tell us that out of all the tests given to children, only one showed any significant difference. That was a reading test. Children whose mothers went out to work when they were very young scored 2% worse. Hardly proof of lasting damage.

The programme also failed to tell us that Professor Joshi reported children of working mums were less likely to turn into worried and unhappy adolescents. Similarly, the study did not ask working mothers what kind of care they used for their children. If the mums in the study were at all typical, most would have left their children with close relatives, invariably grandparents.
Dr Tony Munton
Institute of Education

 It's a laugh, isn't it, that in the 60s such a deal of concern was expressed about what people would do with the excessive leisure time available at the end of the century? Most people know that long hours are worked to show commitment to the job, rather than as a necessity to get the work done. We should excoriate any company that does not demand at least a 15 hour interval between one day's work and the next. Amazingly, the work would still get done and life would be more worth living.
John Hole
London

fields.headline: Race victory
fields.trailText: We also, as employers, welcome the home secretary's announcement on legislation to tackle indirect/institutional racism in public bodies. However, Jon Rogers of Unison (Letters, January 28) is wrong to criticise London's councils. They have taken a lead in identifying a problem around indirect racism in the disciplinary process and commissioned research via GLEA well before the publication of the Lawrence inquiry.
fields.body:
We also, as employers, welcome the home secretary's announcement on legislation to tackle indirect/institutional racism in public bodies. However, Jon Rogers of Unison (Letters, January 28) is wrong to criticise London's councils. They have taken a lead in identifying a problem around indirect racism in the disciplinary process and commissioned research via GLEA well before the publication of the Lawrence inquiry.

Examples of the initiatives being taken by the boroughs to tackle indirect discrimination are now being incorporated into the document we are publishing. We will be publishing the summary report within the next month. The full report will be in the public domain and readily available to anybody who wants a copy.
Huw Jones Owen
Greater London Employers' Association

 I am particularly pleased that the amended bill will deal with direct and indirect racism in the "implementation of central and local government's regulatory, economic and social policies". This is very welcome at a time when the effects of modernising local government has indirectly nipped the political aspirations of nearly 500 black, Asian and minority ethnic councillors. There is hardly any space or provision for them in the concentrated power structures of a leadership or a mayoral cabinet. I live in a borough where 24% of the population are of black, Asian and minority origin but I am the only councillor of minority ethnic origin out of the total of 59.
Cllr Nirmal Roy
Camden, London

webTitle: Counting the cost of bailing out the dome

fields.headline: Counting the cost of bailing out the dome
fields.trailText: Have I missed something? If attendance figures for the dome have fallen to 5,000 a day but the attraction needs 20,000 visitors a day to break even, how can takings be "only just sufficient to cover running costs" (Extra £60m to bail out dome, January 29)?
fields.body:
Have I missed something? If attendance figures for the dome have fallen to 5,000 a day but the attraction needs 20,000 visitors a day to break even, how can takings be "only just sufficient to cover running costs" (Extra £60m to bail out dome, January 29)?

The dome's budget is said to have been £758m and its projected life is one year - this equates to around £2m a day. Ignoring "running costs", each of the anticipated 20,000 daily visitors would have to pay a ticket price of £100 simply to cover the capital repayments.

The figures just don't add up. Can Peter Mandelson now admit to having overseen a gigantic white elephant?
John Brownlow
Bolton

 It seems that around a quarter of the UK population would have to visit it in the first year to obviate the bail-out loan. But these putative visitors do not live within walking distance of the dome. Your claim, therefore, that £56 per family is reasonable (Leader, 29 Jan) is vacuous: we have to get there first!

Ten years ago, cultural day outings from Manchester to London were possible. Now Virgin's pricing policy (£150 standard return before 9.30) has placed such trips out of the reach of most. Watching Bradford City play is a whole lot cheaper if you happen to live in Bradford.
Clare Gallaway
Manchester
clare_gallaway@ compuserve.com

 You quote from Coleridge's Kubla Khan (Leader, January 29) to illustrate the inflated aspirations of the dome, but surely The Rime of the Ancient Mariner would now be more appropriate. New Labour could easily have cancelled the project when they came to power. Now this albatross will hang round Tony Blair's neck for years, as the dome itself drifts against the Greenwich sky "as idle as a painted ship upon a painted ocean".
Stephen Plaice
Brighton

 The government is to bail out the dome with a loan of £60m, which will not be repayable if its financial crisis continues. Thousands of poverty-stricken Income Support recipients get Social Fund loans (not grants) for essential items like cookers, with repayments deducted weekly. These can mean they then have £30 a week less than even the miserly levels of social security.

If the poor suffer further financial crises, will the government agree that these loans do not have to be repaid? Or does New Labour only bestow financial privileges on the wealthy while continuing to treat welfare recipients as the unworthy poor?
Bob Holman
Easterhouse, Glasgow

 At £750m for 12m visitors, it would have been cheaper simply to have handed out free tickets to Alton Towers.
Frank Roper
London

 One last use for the Dome (Letters, January 27): see how many skips it will fill.
Tony Green
Hebden Bridge, West Yorks

fields.headline: Diamonds from granite
fields.standfirst:
New Hampshire can show its mettle
The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The voters of New Hampshire, the state where the first primary election in this year's US presidential contest will take place tomorrow, are routinely characterised as contrary, perverse, and "upset-minded". By reputation at least, these level-headed, hard-nosed, square-jawed Yankee pragmatists favour outsiders and underdogs.
fields.body:
The voters of New Hampshire, the state where the first primary election in this year's US presidential contest will take place tomorrow, are routinely characterised as contrary, perverse, and "upset-minded". By reputation at least, these level-headed, hard-nosed, square-jawed Yankee pragmatists favour outsiders and underdogs. They are not swayed by bombast or blather; are not fooled by down-south carpetbagger politicians. These are people who can sit for hours over a hole cut in the winter ice which covers the state's many beautiful lakes without ever a word, let alone a fish, to interrupt their solitary vigil. In New Hampshire, as a matter of pride, they don't do the expected thing: they do the right thing.

While beguiling, this enduring image, routinely re-conjured at election time, is largely illusory. New Hampshire is a state like any other where jobs, taxes, healthcare, trustworthy leadership and values (broadly-defined) matter most. And even in strictly political terms, New Hampshire is not the exception to the rule that it is commonly held to be. In every primary bar one in the past 48 years, the state has picked the Republican or Democratic candidate who went on to win the presidency. The odd man out is Bill Clinton, who lost there in 1992 to the late Paul Tsongas. For all its supposed cussedness, New Hampshire is actually terribly conventional in its tastes. All the same, at a moment of great American prosperity, the state may just feel comfortable enough this time around to indulge its myths. George W Bush, the Republican frontrunner and Iowa caucus victor, is being squeezed hard from the right by two long-shot candidates, Steve Forbes and Alan Keyes. This defection of conservative support could let in Senator John McCain. On the Democratic side, Bill Bradley, who stumbled in Iowa, is fighting with the desperation borne of the prospect of imminent obliteration to overtake Vice President Al Gore. Since 37% of New Hampshire's voters are independents who may participate in either ballot, both Mr McCain and Mr Bradley hope to forge one-off cross-party coalitions. If New Hampshire gives them the nod, they will try to build on the bounce, as it is called, in the big state primaries which follow. But even if their rivals take the granite state, Mr Bush and Mr Gore are determined to outspend, outgun, and outlast them in the long run, New Hampshire's querulous quirkinesses notwithstanding.

fields.headline: Hizbullah kills SLA commander
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The second-in-command of the Israeli-backed South Lebanese Army died yesterday in a bomb attack mounted by Hizbullah guerillas.
fields.body:
The second-in-command of the Israeli-backed South Lebanese Army died yesterday in a bomb attack mounted by Hizbullah guerillas.

A major coup for the Iranian-backed militia, the bombing marks a general escalation in its attacks on Israeli-occupied South Lebanon, giving rise to fears that Israeli-Syrian peace negotiations, already in abeyance since both sides postponed the despatch of negotiating teams to the US, could be jeopardised.

Colonel Akef Hashim, com mander of the "central sector" in the Israeli "security zone", was working in an orchard near his house in Dibel village, 19 miles south-west of Marjayoun, when the bomb went off. He was killed instantly. The SLA said in a statement the bomb exploded outside his home.

On hearing the news, residents in the nearby towns of Tyre and Nabatiyah poured on to the streets, distributing sweetmeats in the traditional expression of joy.

A former sergeant in the Lebanese army, Hashim was the second most powerful man in the Israeli security zone. Though officially the deputy of General Antoine Lahd, the SLA commander, he acted like an independent warlord, with his own loyalist following and territorial hegemony. He lived in a palatial villa, said to be have been largely financed by locally imposed "taxes" and "donations" from businessmen.

Recently, there had been a reversal in the pattern of steadily growing Hizbullah successes. This was apparently the result of "severely limited troop movement on the ground combined with a heavy reliance on air power" which the Israelis adopted after Prime Minister Ehud Barak announced that he would pull troops out of South Lebanon by next July. Israeli fatalities fell to 12 last year, half the previous year's toll.

But since the beginning of this year, Hizbullah has again stepped up the number, variety and effectiveness of its attacks. Last week it killed the first Israeli soldier in several months.

Hizbullah probably has its own internal reasons for the escalation. But, more importantly, it clearly has Syria's backing. President Hafez As sad has long used the war of attrition in South Lebanon as a means of diplomatic pressure, and he is now making no secret of the link between the escalation and his dissatisfaction with Syrian-Israeli peace negotiations.

Mr Assad's son and presumed successor, Bashar, last week received Hizbullah secretary-general Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, informing him that the negotiations were "stumbling seriously" and paying tribute to Hizbullah's "honourable role".

Damascus radio reported that "Israel's repeated attacks on South Lebanon are hampering the achievement of peace in the Middle East". This has forced the Lebanese national resistance to respond to Israeli fire.

The Israeli deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh, has warned that "if the Syrians are serious about peace negotiations they will have to stop Iran from encouraging Hizbullah and other terrorist factions". The Damascus newspaper Tishreen retorted that "whoever wants peace doesn't send his war planes to destroy [Lebanese] homes".

The renewed Hizbullah mil itancy poses a headache for the Israelis. With its pledge to withdraw from South Lebanon, with or without an agreement over the Golan heights, it has caused alarm and despondency in the 2,000-strong SLA.

Gen Lahd has almost openly threatened to turn SLA guns on the Israelis if they don't live up to their promise to look after his men. The SLA rank and file are increasingly tempted to ensure their future by collaborating with the Hizbullah. Colonel Hashim's death will have dealt another heavy blow to their morale.
