A major coup for the Iranian-backed militia, the bombing marks a general escalation in its attacks on Israeli-occupied South Lebanon, giving rise to fears that Israeli-Syrian peace negotiations, already in abeyance since both sides postponed the despatch of negotiating teams to the US, could be jeopardised. Colonel Akef Hashim, com mander of the "central sector" in the Israeli "security zone", was working in an orchard near his house in Dibel village, 19 miles south-west of Marjayoun, when the bomb went off. He was killed instantly. The SLA said in a statement the bomb exploded outside his home. On hearing the news, residents in the nearby towns of Tyre and Nabatiyah poured on to the streets, distributing sweetmeats in the traditional expression of joy. A former sergeant in the Lebanese army, Hashim was the second most powerful man in the Israeli security zone. Though officially the deputy of General Antoine Lahd, the SLA commander, he acted like an independent warlord, with his own loyalist following and territorial hegemony. He lived in a palatial villa, said to be have been largely financed by locally imposed "taxes" and "donations" from businessmen. Recently, there had been a reversal in the pattern of steadily growing Hizbullah successes. This was apparently the result of "severely limited troop movement on the ground combined with a heavy reliance on air power" which the Israelis adopted after Prime Minister Ehud Barak announced that he would pull troops out of South Lebanon by next July. Israeli fatalities fell to 12 last year, half the previous year's toll. But since the beginning of this year, Hizbullah has again stepped up the number, variety and effectiveness of its attacks. Last week it killed the first Israeli soldier in several months. Hizbullah probably has its own internal reasons for the escalation. But, more importantly, it clearly has Syria's backing. President Hafez As sad has long used the war of attrition in South Lebanon as a means of diplomatic pressure, and he is now making no secret of the link between the escalation and his dissatisfaction with Syrian-Israeli peace negotiations. Mr Assad's son and presumed successor, Bashar, last week received Hizbullah secretary-general Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, informing him that the negotiations were "stumbling seriously" and paying tribute to Hizbullah's "honourable role". Damascus radio reported that "Israel's repeated attacks on South Lebanon are hampering the achievement of peace in the Middle East". This has forced the Lebanese national resistance to respond to Israeli fire. The Israeli deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh, has warned that "if the Syrians are serious about peace negotiations they will have to stop Iran from encouraging Hizbullah and other terrorist factions". The Damascus newspaper Tishreen retorted that "whoever wants peace doesn't send his war planes to destroy [Lebanese] homes". The renewed Hizbullah mil itancy poses a headache for the Israelis. With its pledge to withdraw from South Lebanon, with or without an agreement over the Golan heights, it has caused alarm and despondency in the 2,000-strong SLA. Gen Lahd has almost openly threatened to turn SLA guns on the Israelis if they don't live up to their promise to look after his men. fields.headline: Scandalum magnatum
fields.trailText: A Cheshire businessman faces jail this week for accusing judges of being bent, corrupt, members of the mafia and a variety of other nastinesses. Geoffrey Scriven was taken to court by the then attorney general, Sir Nicholas Lyell, in 1997 for the heinous offence of "scandalising the court" - also known as "scandalising the judges" - an archaic type of contempt of court last used in Britain in 1931. Scriven, a disgruntled litigant who believes he has had a raw deal from the legal system, gave an undertaking not to repeat his accusations, which he insists was extracted from him under duress. Since then, his broadsides against the bench and the Lord Chancellor.
fields.body:
A Cheshire businessman faces jail this week for accusing judges of being bent, corrupt, members of the mafia and a variety of other nastinesses. Geoffrey Scriven was taken to court by the then attorney general, Sir Nicholas Lyell, in 1997 for the heinous offence of "scandalising the court" - also known as "scandalising the judges" - an archaic type of contempt of court last used in Britain in 1931. Scriven, a disgruntled litigant who believes he has had a raw deal from the legal system, gave an undertaking not to repeat his accusations, which he insists was extracted from him under duress. Since then, his broadsides against the bench and the Lord Chancellor.

Scandalum magnatum - scandalising magnates or speaking ill of dignities - (criticising royalty, judges, peers and other nobs) was made an offence in the reign of Richard II. In 1344 a lawyer was found guilty of scandalising the court for writing a letter casting aspersions on the judges of the king's bench. In 1899 the judicial committee of the privy council declared: "Committals for contempt of court by scandalising the court itself have become obsolete in this country. Courts are satisfied to leave to public opinion attacks or comments derogatory or scandalous to them." But it was revived in 1900 to punish a newspaper editor who described an unpopular judge as "a microcosm of conceit and empty-headedness", and in 1931 to deal with an editor who suggested a judge "could hardly be altogether unbiased" about legislation he had helped to steer through parliament as solicitor general.

Next Friday the current attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, will take Scriven back to the high court not for scandalising the court - that has been dropped - but for breaching his undertaking not to scandalise the court. Is this a distinction with a difference?

The rationale for punishing judges' critics is that the criticisms threaten public confidence in the administration of justice. But Scriven's allegations have reached a wide audience largely as a result of action taken against him, which made them newsworthy.

As Geoffrey Robertson QC has said: "Scandalising the court is an obnoxious law which offends against the principle that the courts should not be judges in their own cause. The government should be abolishing it, not reviving it."

fields.headline: Old age angst
fields.standfirst: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: On Sunday, Rosemary visited her elderly Auntie Mary in hospital. Auntie was cleaning her teeth. She spat into the tooth mug because there was no alternative.
fields.body:
On Sunday, Rosemary visited her elderly Auntie Mary in hospital. Auntie was cleaning her teeth. She spat into the tooth mug because there was no alternative.

"Naughty Mary," said the nurse strictly, tapping her on the hand.

"I'm so sorry," said Auntie, "but I wanted to say thank you to my niece for so kindly visiting." But the nurse had gone, off to the other side of the ward, too busy for a long polite sentence, and never heard the explanation. Rosemary found this very depressing. There was her Aunt, former head of the Royal College of ****, being ticked off like a witless baby.

"I'm haunted by the helplessness of old age," said Rosemary, looking desolate. No wonder. Last night, at home alone, her children all away, Rosemary bleached the sink in an efficient way and went up to bed. She awoke this morning to find the kitchen awash, floating slippers and a paddling cat. She had left a tap on all night.

"I can't live alone!" cried Rosemary, thinking of her future and her Auntie. And then there was another red alert. My mother had left a desperate gabbled message on her answerphone. "Where are you?" wailed my mother's voice. "I don't know where Michele is! The AA man can't find her." Home alone, my mother naturally assumed I was dead, crashed en route to my broken-down car.

Hot on the heels of my mother's message came another from Arthur, another elderly chum of Rosemary's. His wife had disappeared. Where could she be? She'd been gone all day and he was too poorly to cook his own dinner. So was my mother. Rosemary was surrounded by helpless elderly persons asking for assistance. Meanwhile, her cork tiles had all come loose and were curling up at the edges and Rosemary had tripped over several and broken bits off. Her kitchen looked like a slum and she had been hoping to sell her house. Who would buy it now? Left alone for one night, Rosemary had wrecked her kitchen. And she was only 60.

I find Rosemary standing on the pavement looking rather pale. "Your mother's been phoning, Arthur's been phoning, everybody's worried about everybody." And now I am worried about Rosemary. So we have a worriers' support network. In an odd way, this has rather cheered us up.

fields.headline: Mayor and the martyrs
fields.standfirst: Digging up town hall treasure
fields.trailText: When Graham Mayhew became mayor of Lewes he discovered buried treasure under the town hall: a vast cellar including the medieval steps up which the Lewes Martyrs are said to have walked in 1557, to their dreadful deaths at the stake in the street outside.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
When Graham Mayhew became mayor of Lewes he discovered buried treasure under the town hall: a vast cellar including the medieval steps up which the Lewes Martyrs are said to have walked in 1557, to their dreadful deaths at the stake in the street outside.

Part of the cellar was converted into a second world war bomb shelter, and in the 1980s another part into a secret home office shelter in case of a more modern war. To a certain amount of muttering - in a town with a rich history of dissent, from Simon de Montfort's rebellion to Tom Paine's revolutionary pamphlets - the mayor has launched a project to transform the entire space into a cafe and art gallery.

The least certain bit of the building's history, Mr Mayhew admits, is the association with the 17 men and women who became the Lewes Martyrs in the reign of Queen Mary. Their deaths are commemorated every year in the East Sussex town's notorious bonfire night celebrations.

The stairs to the street, and the now blocked spiral staircase to the cellar, were already ancient when the martyrs died. But despite the confident assertion of a plaque, it is more likely they were imprisoned in the cellars under the castle, a few hundred yards away. "There's certainly no proof that they were actually imprisoned here, or that they ever walked up these steps," said Mr Mayhew.

According to Fox's Martyrs, the most famous of the 17, a brewer from Brighton called Derrick Carver, who was greeted as a hero by the crowds at the execution, carried a Bible to his death. The executioner was ordered to throw it into the flames. Instead Carver threw it into the crowd.

The cellar houses a century of stored municipal junk. "It's ludicrous. Just look at this stuff", said Mr Mayhew. "This wonderful space, in an absolutely prime area of some of the most expensive real estate in England, and it is full of ballot boxes and old papers that could all go into a shed on an industrial estate. We have got to bring it back into use."

The council's collection of paintings includes an early 17th century panel of Protestant Reformers, showing Luther, Calvin, and other worthies. The building also has one of the finest Renaissance staircases in England. It was brought by the 18th century owner, Thomas Sergison, from a demolished mansion.

webTitle: Race to be first to vote grips New Hampshire

fields.headline: Race to be first to vote grips New Hampshire
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: When the next president of the US is elected 10 months from now he might be able to trace his route to the White House back to 27 voters who live in a snow-white world at the foot of swooping mountains.
fields.byline: Michael Ellison  in Hart's Location, New Hampshire
fields.body:
When the next president of the US is elected 10 months from now he might be able to trace his route to the White House back to 27 voters who live in a snow-white world at the foot of swooping mountains.

They are much too dignified to describe it as a race but the people of Hart's Location - a town where everyone knows everyone else but all are so scattered that they rarely meet - will acknowledge that it is a contest.

Tomorrow they aim to be the first people in the first state to declare the result of the first direct vote to select this year's presidential candidates. And only Dixville Notch, a community of 30 voters about 50 miles north, in the White Mountains, can stop them.

"They were trying to outdo us," said Marilyn Dowler, 62, one of three people who counts the ballots in Hart's Location. She moved to the town 10 years ago and speaks with the devotion of the outsider who has become an insider. "We're not getting into shouting matches, we're just bringing back a tradition."

That tradition means gathering at the Notchland Inn -the social centre of the town (population 38) - just before midnight for a natter over hot drinks, cakes and cookies, getting into the makeshift voting booths with their shower curtains for screens just after the clock strikes twelve, and then out again as quickly as possible.

New Hampshire state law says that the polls must stay open until 7pm unless all those eligible to vote have done so. Hart's Location intends to be finished within minutes, and certainly before Dixville Notch.

"We're not fancy people here," said Mrs Dowler, sitting in the kitchen of her wood-built home, a "Welcome, friends" sign on the wall and a bowl of fruit on a lace table-cloth in front of her.

"We're not out to impress the world, we just come as we are. They have a ballroom, dress in gowns and have a full dinner beforehand."

The former bakery manager from Rhode Island is referring to the people of Dixville Notch, who caught the early-voting bug in 1964 after Hart's Loca tion's voters tired of the attention they were attracting and abandoned voting at midnight.

But, when the matter was raised by Ed Butler, one of the owners of Notchland Inn, it was decided to resurrect the custom.

"We got tired of the media so we didn't do it any more," she said. "So Dixville Notch snapped it up instantly. They're only a precinct; we're a town. Now we're doing it again, this brings the people back and it brings our history back."

Aside from the civic pride that goes along with being first, the importance of securing a good result in the first primary requires that the candidates make themselves available to the voters. Not that this necessarily has the desired effect at the grassroots level.

"George W? I was all for him until I saw him," said Mrs Dowler of the Republican frontrunner, George W Bush. "He acts like a spoilt child, which is what he was. And I absolutely loved his mom and dad. He wouldn't be where he is today without them. But John McCain [the Republican challenger], he's seen a lot of war, more than you or I would ever care to. He's like the average American, that's why I like him."

Before Mrs Dowler enjoys the luxury of casting her early vote, other matters require attention. There are pies to be baked, ballot box pencils to be sharpened, less devoted adherents to democracy to be cajoled to the poll and an over-eager Japanese television crew to be held in check.

But the town's rivals have not abandoned their claim. "It's a ribbon-cutting ceremony that begins here in Dixville and continues across the country," said Michael Pearson, a prominent member of that community.

"Maybe we'll be first, maybe we won't," said Mrs Dowler. "It's not a race, it's a tradition."

Then she rubs her eyes and remembers just what is at stake. "Hart's Location is first in the nation - forget about Dixville."

fields.headline: Look! Look at that!
fields.standfirst: No, no, not him. Her. Or, to be more precise, her legs. Last week the tabloids had a field day over Monica Tyson's unshaved appendages.  Dea Birkett asks what is it with women and bodily hair
fields.trailText: No, no, not him. Her. Or, to be more precise, her legs. Last week the tabloids had a field day over Monica Tyson's unshaved appendages.  Dea Birkett asks what is it with women and bodily hair
fields.body:
Pluck it, wax it, zap it, or get nicks from a Bic. However you remove your hair, it hurts. Nevertheless, the majority of women still strip their bodies of stubble. In America, 92% of women shave their legs, 58% pluck their eyebrows, 2% even depilate their toes. The agony may be awesome, but it's far easier to bear than the public humiliation of being hairy.

Monica Tyson, the paediatrician and boxer's wife, is the latest to find that, even today, there are tight boundaries on feminine appearance. Last week, national newspaper columnists were moved to condemn her after she took a step that was considered shocking: she went shopping before shaving her legs. To be hairy is to be, by definition, unfeminine. When Julia Roberts waved her underarm hair at the Notting Hill premiere, fashion columnists condemned her unflattering dress, comparing it unfavourably with the slinky number shaven Liz Hurley wore.

I, too, have suffered for being unshorn. The only time I've been fired was for my body hair. I was working as a cocktail waitress, lifting a small round tray above my head and wearing very little below my neck. Nothing could hide the hair in my armpits. I was told it put the customers off their stuffed olives. Either it went, or I did. This was the 80s and I felt it a matter of principle. I chucked in my cocktail tray and took a job in a steakhouse, where the cowgirl uniform was more concealing. Clandestinely, the hairy armpits remained.

In the 80s, refusing to shave was a rallying cry of feminism. The Joy Of Sex celebrated hairiness, arguing that lovers should regard pubic hair as a "resource". On the armpit, it waxed lyrical: "Classical site for kisses. Should on no account be shaved."

Yet, almost 20 years later, we are berating a beautiful, powerful, professional woman for not packing her ladyshave in her luggage. And on Channel 4's film Private Parts last week, one participant suggested that women were becoming hairier because they were moving into traditionally male areas of employment, as if beards were compulsory for being on the board.

But it is one of the best-kept secrets: women have always been hairy. Ten years ago, two American artists, Hannah Bonner and Mary-Charlotte Domandi, sent a hundred women two silhouettes. On one, they were asked to fill in the body hair they have naturally; on the other, where hair is left after removal. The results were hair-raising. Most women respondents had patches of fur all over their bodies (chin, chest, neck, calves, thighs); 35% had moustaches and 30% chin or neck hair. "I've had a handsome red beard since the age of 18," confessed one respondent. But the most shocking discovery was about nipples: over half the respondents said they had hair on their chests.

The British "Ladies Hair Removal Market" is worth an estimated £30m. More means have been developed for hair removal than for contraception: waxing, shaving, tweezing, bleaching, plucking, electrolysis and depilatory cream. But The Joy Of Sex was right: you don't need to be shorn to be sexy. Madonna was the first, flaunting her hairy armpits in Desperately Seeking Susan, blow-drying them in a public toilet. Frida Kahlo, the celebrated Mexican artist, was considered stunning. In her self-portraits, she boldly painted her thick, dark moustache.

After such displays of animalistic passion, it is shocking that women are still slaves to the shave. But, as we battle for more major equalities, are these few follicles really so important? Yes, because while masculinity is still seen as God-given, femininity is formed. And to be regarded as fully female, you have to have a body that resembles a four-year-old's. The only naturally hairless human beings are the very young.

But we aren't children and we can make our own decisions. Now I'm sometimes shaven and sometimes not. I don't regard it as a matter of principle but of preference, rather like body piercing. And, like piercing, it can easily be changed. Hair one day, gone another.

"I've had a handsome red beard since the age of 18," confessed one respondent. But the most shocking discovery was about nipples: over half the respondents said they had hair on their chests. The British "Ladies Hair Removal Market" is worth an estimated £30m. More means have been developed for hair removal than for contraception: waxing, shaving, tweezing, bleaching, plucking, electrolysis and depilatory cream. But The Joy Of Sex was right: you don't need to be shorn to be sexy. Madonna was the first, flaunting her hairy armpits in Desperately Seeking Susan, blow-drying them in a public toilet. Frida Kahlo, the celebrated Mexican artist, was considered stunning. In her self-portraits, she boldly painted her thick, dark moustache. After such displays of animalistic passion, it is shocking that women are still slaves to the shave. But, as we battle for more major equalities, are these few follicles really so important? Yes, because while masculinity is still seen as God-given, femininity is formed. And to be regarded as fully female, you have to have a body that resembles a four-year-old's. The only naturally hairless human beings are the very young. But we aren't children and we can make our own decisions. Now I'm sometimes shaven and sometimes not. I don't regard it as a matter of principle but of preference, rather like body piercing. And, like piercing, it can easily be changed. Hair one day, gone another.

webTitle: The ultimate escape plan: a glider flight from Colditz

fields.headline: The ultimate escape plan: a glider flight from Colditz
fields.standfirst: Winds thwart attempt to find out if derring-do would have worked
fields.trailText: It was an amazing feat of derring-do and would have been the ultimate break-out from the maximum security Colditz prison in the second world war.
fields.body:
It was an amazing feat of derring-do and would have been the ultimate break-out from the maximum security Colditz prison in the second world war.

The construction of the Colditz Cock, a glider with a 32-ft wingspan in which prisoners of war dreamed of drifting out of their jail and off to freedom, defied belief.

More than 50 years ago, PoWs built a secret workshop in the attic of the 11th-century Saxony castle used by the Nazis to imprison what they considered to be the "bad boys" of the allied prisoners.

Every day for eight months, a team of builders worked quietly on the plane for short spells in order not to be caught by their guards.

The Boys Own bravado saw the daring plans for the plane being drafted on a small sheet of paper and led to its construction from the most unlikely of materials.

The prisoners pulled up floorboards, slipped out bed slats and made control wires from electrical wire found in unused areas of the prison. Tools to build the Cock were fashioned from the handles of bed boards, the frames and iron bars from windows, blades were made from gramophone springs and needles were used to drill holes.

The skin of the aircraft was sewn together from the officers' sleeping bags. And a concrete-filled bathtub plunging five storeys and then crashing into the floor was to have provided a catapult needed for the launch.

The plane was completed but the escape officer decided lift-off should be delayed in case the SS ordered the massacre of the remaining prisoners in the castle. The glider's existence was only revealed after the allied victory in 1945 when the camp was peacefully turned over by its kommandant. While they embraced their freedom, the prisoners wished that they had been able to see their dream glider in flight.

Yesterday, that flying dream was thwarted again. Plans to fly a copy of the Colditz Cock were confounded, not by Nazis or cautious escape officers, but by the boring old weather.

The tools and the materials used to build the replica glider were not the same, but builders followed the original plans drawn up by a navy lieutenant, Tony Rolt.

Yesterday's flight, to have been watched by the plane's designer and some of its builders, was postponed because of winds of up to 30 knots. The veterans had gathered at RAF Odiham in Hampshire to see if their brainchild could ever have flown, as part of the Channel 4 series Escape from Colditz.

One of those present was Bill Goldfinch whose idea it was to try to fly out of Colditz. Mr Goldfinch, who now lives in Salisbury, Wiltshire, and was imprisoned for two and a half years, said: "It is a huge disappointment not to see the plane airborne after all these years, but we have been promised we will get another chance.

"Although it is a magnificent effort by those who built this plane, what cannot be recreated are the conditions in which we built the original and the need we had to finish it. My one regret is that the original never flew. If we had been in Colditz a bit longer then maybe she would've got up."

The new glider was built by Southdown Aero Services based in nearby Lasham, after being commissioned by the makers of the three part documentary which begins tonight. Neil Fripp, who helped build the new plane, said: "It is very frustrating but the high wind will just not let us do it. It could flip over on take-off and we do not want to take the risk."

Flight Lieutenant Jack Best, 87, who helped build the original glider, said: "I was perfectly certain that it would fly, and the meticulous job they have done in reconstructing it from the original plans is very impressive. Obviously they had tools that we could only dream about at the time, and the standard of materials is far higher because we had to use what was available."

Officer Skelley Ginn said: "We smuggled all kinds of bits and pieces to and from the workshop. We used metal hinges and replaced them with bits of webbing. We used lots of people to do different things so we wouldn't get caught."

Between 1941 and 1945, 1,500 allied prisoners were held in 700 rooms at Colditz, 176 attempted to escape and 31 succeeded. Colditz castle has been immortalised as a sinister, impenetrable fortress where the "bad boys" of the British officer class plotted their escapes and carried out their extraordinary feats.

webTitle: Watchdog condemns sugar in baby snacks

fields.headline: Watchdog condemns sugar in baby snacks
fields.trailText: An independent food watchdog has accused "irresponsible" food manufacturers of creating a "health hazard" by selling snack foods for babies containing more sugar than jam tarts and doughnuts.
fields.body:
An independent food watchdog has accused "irresponsible" food manufacturers of creating a "health hazard" by selling snack foods for babies containing more sugar than jam tarts and doughnuts.

Health and nutrition experts called on the government to tighten food regulations after a report published by the food commission today revealed that biscuits and snacks designed for babies and toddlers have a higher sugar content than many comparable adult snack foods.

Despite health warnings to parents, sugary biscuits are the biggest cause of tooth decay in infants aged between one and two years.

The survey by the consumer group, titled Good for Sales, Bad for Babies, found that biscuits aimed at infants had a higher sugar content than some well known adult biscuit brands.

Two manufacturers, Nestlé and Boots the Chemist, were singled out for criticism. Nestlé's Fruit Sticks were found to contain 50% sugar while Boots' Teddy Bear biscuits are 37% sugar, compared with the 36% sugar content in a jam tart. A traditional Farley's Rusk had 29% sugar, against 27% in a chocolate digestive.

The commission also found that snacks claiming to have "reduced sugar" content, including Farley's Rusks and Hipp's First Bites, which are both 21% sugar, were sweeter than a jam doughnut with 19% sugar.

Only five out of the 22 products examined were virtually sugar free.

Tim Lobstein, a co-director of the commission and author of the report, described the snacks as "health hazards", adding: "The baby food regulations are very weak. Manufacturers exploit this in order to label highly sweetened products as specially suitable for infants.

"Parents expect baby foods to be nutritious and safe for their children. Our survey found the majority of baby biscuits to be dangerous for an infant's newly emerging teeth."

New food regulations governing baby foods came into force last year but health experts called for the maximum sugar content to be drastically reduced from the present level of 40% of weight - which can mean up to two teaspoons of sugar in each biscuit.

Biscuits are strongly linked to an increased risk of tooth damage, with 11% of frequent biscuit eaters getting damaged teeth before they are 30 months old, compared with 1% of infants who eat biscuits less than once a day.

Tim Lang, professor of food policy at Thames Valley university, called for the new food standards agency to investigate the "irresponsible" levels of sugar in infant snacks and cereals. He said: "The food industry is actually encouraging the long term problems of high sugar consumption, like tooth decay, diabetes and obesity, which is a key risk factor in coronary heart disease."

Both Nestlé and Boots issued statements defending the sugar content in their products and Sarah Jacobs, spokeswoman for the Infant Dietetic Foods Association, which represents manufacturers, said: "All baby foods are strictly controlled by law and sugar content is kept to a minimum but babies have a very high requirement for carbohydrates and sugars."

The ministry of agriculture, fisheries and food said that although there were concerns over clear labelling, there were no plans to intervene over the content of infant foods.

webTitle: Staffing crisis hits child protection plan

fields.headline: Staffing crisis hits child protection plan
fields.standfirst: Social services struggle to fill new care posts
fields.trailText: Two-thirds of social services authorities have warned the department of health that they are struggling to recruit the staff they need to implement measures to tighten safeguards for children in care.
fields.body:
Two-thirds of social services authorities have warned the department of health that they are struggling to recruit the staff they need to implement measures to tighten safeguards for children in care.

The problem threatens to undermine confidence in the government's response to the Waterhouse inquiry report on abuse in north Wales children's homes, expected to be published shortly.

Of 150 authorities in England, 105 have told the department that implementation of the measures, known as Quality Protects, is being held up because 40% of designated posts remain unfilled.

The figures, in a mid-year performance assessment report by the government's social services inspectorate, reflect an acute skills shortage in the social care sector. Essex social services is recruiting social workers in South Africa.

Although the government has instructed authorities to make Quality Protects their top priority, the inspectorate's report revealed that many were finding it hard to fill their allocation of the 2,241 extra posts for the programme.

Sixty per cent of authorities are said to have made "significant" progress in implementing action plans, and most others have made "some" progress, the report said. Often, however, this has been achieved only by using temporary or agency staff.

All authorities expect by the end of March to be meeting their statutory duties to inspect children's homes - one in 20 went uninspected last year - but 20 authorities said they would not have the inspectors in post to check on child day-care facilities.

Ministers had hoped to respond to the Waterhouse inquiry by pointing to the £375m Quality Protects programme, and its equivalent in Wales, as evidence that tough new procedures were in place to ensure that abuse on such a scale could never happen again.

Social services leaders today say that it "extremely unlikely" that organised abuse of the kind practised in some Welsh and English children's homes in the 1970s and 1980s could be easily repeated.

The Association of Directors of Social Services says authorities are now far more vigilant. Twenty-five years ago, in an "age of innocence", it was barely conceivable that people with an apparent vocation to care for youngsters might secretly aim to abuse them.

It is calling for prompt settlement of "proper" compensation claims from proven victims of abuse, after the inquiry report is published. But it warns that establishing clear liabilities will not be easy.

Jo Williams, the association's president, said financial compensation would "at least help some people in some circumstances begin to rebuild their shattered lives"

fields.headline: Irish coffee 'can help stroke victims'
fields.trailText: A glass of Irish coffee may help stroke victims because the two-fold effect of alcohol and caffeine might jolt the brain into a recovery.
fields.body:
A glass of Irish coffee may help stroke victims because the two-fold effect of alcohol and caffeine might jolt the brain into a recovery.

The news comes as another piece of medical praise for alcohol. Red wine has been shown to lessen heart disease.

Scientists at the university of Texas, in Houston, discovered the benefits of Irish coffee after testing dozens of drugs to treat strokes. One of the scientists tried out a mixture of caffeine and alcohol on his laboratory rats. Together, caffeine and alcohol reduced the areas of brain damage by 80%.

The dose was roughly the equivalent to one short of hard alcohol and three or four cups of coffee.

Researcher James Grotta and his colleagues are not entirely sure why Irish coffee works but Dr Grotta said: "Both substances have a strong effect on neurotransmitters. It may be that the combination tweaks the balance to a point that is somehow beneficial."

David Mendelow, of the department of neurosurgery at Newcastle university suggested: "The alcohol would dilate the blood vessels and ease the flow of blood, while the coffee would elevate the blood pressure.

"Using Irish coffee to speed recovery from strokes would certainly go down well with many patients."

According to a report in the scientific journal Discover, drinking dampens the response of the brain to a stroke and caffeine jazzes it up.

A stroke usually happens when either a tiny piece of atheroma tissue breaks off an artery wall or a blood clot gets lodged in a vessel in the brain, stopping blood flow.

No blood flow means no or little oxygen to that part of the brain and the cells start dying without it. Strokes are difficult to treat because many neurons in the brain die of oxygen starvation before doctors can re-establish the blood flow.

The knock-on effect is that damage is made worse because injured cells set off a cascade of biochemical chain reactions that damage healthy neighbouring cells.

fields.headline: Change of tune
fields.standfirst: Carmen gets an adult twist
fields.trailText: First their male dying swan ruffled feathers in the ballet world, now Adventures In Motion Pictures, whose Swan Lake has become a worldwide sensation, are giving one of opera's holy of holies a cheeky tweak.
fields.body:
First their male dying swan ruffled feathers in the ballet world, now Adventures In Motion Pictures, whose Swan Lake has become a worldwide sensation, are giving one of opera's holy of holies a cheeky tweak.

The company is taking Bizet's Carmen, one of the most beloved operas in the repertoire, and turning it into The Car Man, "an auto-erotic thriller" about a love-lorn mechanic.

Choreographer Matthew Bourne, whose playful version of Swan Lake first horrified traditionalists before Tony awards and Broadway acclaim put it on the A-level syllabus, wants to marry Bizet's score with a film noir story of "murder, passion and betrayal" not dissimilar to The Postman Always Rings Twice.

"This isn't some kind of transvestite Carmen," said Katherine Doré, who founded AMP with Bourne 12 years ago when they did their first tour out of a battered Transit van.

"It's the same essential emotional ingredients as the opera, but it is not the Carmen people will recognise.

"It's about the same passion and lust and being trapped in an explosive situation because of your past, but we have given it a contemporary spin.

"We are not sending it up. We proved with Swan Lake, which if anything was a holier grail, that we are out not to trivialise. We justified everything we set out to do."

She said sex was the driving force behind The Car Man, which will open in London in the autumn after previewing at the Theatre Royal, Plymouth, in May.

"It is unashamedly adult in what it does. I don't think it is going to be on any school syllabus for a while."

AMP is also working with cult Hollywood director Tim Burton on a stage version of his Edward Scissorhands, she revealed.

With Swan Lake now about to open in London for the last time, another world tour beckoning, and talks going on with a big studio about an as yet undisclosed project, the company is now second only to the Royal Ballet in the number of dancers it employs.

But Doré warned that such international successes will only be sustained if the government gets involved in dance training.

"If British dance is really going to be a world force, and it already is a big export earner, we need government help with apprenticeships.

"If this was the steel industry, the schemes would already be there, but for some obscure reason we don't have these public-private partnerships in the theatre, and particularly not in dance where we really need them," she said.

webTitle: Slimming prize for woman who shed eight stones

fields.headline: Slimming prize for woman who shed eight stones
fields.trailText: A woman who was so fat she had difficulty squeezing into aircraft seats has shed more than eight stone to land the title Slimmer of The Year.
fields.body:
A woman who was so fat she had difficulty squeezing into aircraft seats has shed more than eight stone to land the title Slimmer of The Year.

Jacqui Buck, 30, from London, weighed in at 17st 4lb and was in agony when she went on holiday. "I couldn't put the tray down because of the size of my bust and stomach and the arm rests dug into my thighs," she recalled yesterday. "It was agony, but the pain of seeing the other passengers stare at me was worse."

Jacqui's problems began when she started comfort eating as a child during a brief hospital stay. By the time she was 10, she had a 36B bust.

At the age of 17 she married her first husband because she thought no one else would ever find her attractive. But the marriage ended within weeks.

Jacqui, who works as a postwoman, joined the Slimming Magazine Club and started her dieting and exercise when her second marriage failed.

fields.headline: Incontinence drug advert misled GPs
fields.trailText: The pharmaceutical company which funded a TV advertising campaign urging people suffering from incontinence to seek treatment has been reprimanded for misleading doctors about the drug it sells for the condition.
fields.body:
The pharmaceutical company which funded a TV advertising campaign urging people suffering from incontinence to seek treatment has been reprimanded for misleading doctors about the drug it sells for the condition.

Pharmacia and Upjohn has been found in breach of the industry's code of practice over the advert for the drug Detrusitol in the pages of the British Medical Journal. The advert, aimed at doctors, shows a picture of a smiling older woman in a swimsuit with the caption "Freed from incontinence".

But Social Audit, the consumer watchdog body which brought the complaint, said the advert was misleading and that it inaccurately implied the drug was a universal panacea. It does not work for everybody - in fact, the manufacturer's data show that fewer than two in 10 patients in trials of the drug experienced "no or minimal bladder problems after treatment". That was only slightly better than the numbers who were given a placebo (dummy pill) without their knowledge and recovered of their own accord.

The prescription medicines code of practice authority has upheld the complaint, ruling that the advert is not "accurate, balanced, fair, objective and unambiguous" as required under the code. Pharmacia and Upjohn has undertaken to drop the misleading claims.

The television advertising campaign urged people with incontinence to see their doctor for treatment. It did not name a drug - advertising medicines direct to the public is illegal in Britain - and Pharmacia and Upjohn point out that there are several drugs on the market and other forms of treatment, such as exercise, that could be recommended, although Detrutisol is the market leader.

The Royal College of Nursing and the Patients Association lent their support on the grounds that incontinence is a taboo subject and many men and women hide themselves away in distress without realising anything can be done.

But others saw the commercials as a stalking horse for the sort of advertising of prescription medicines to the public which is permitted in the United States.

Disease awareness campaigns paved the way there for a loosening of the regulations and the eventual explicit promotion of branded drugs. Vast sums of money are now spent in the US on medicines advertising. Charles Medawar of Social Audit said the breach of the rules in an advert intended for doctors showed the dangers of advertising to the public, who are even less able to see through misleading claims.

"Given that we have here a fairly ineffective drug, you are going to get into trouble with advertising it as soon as you put pen to paper. You can't say buy this product that may help one in 10. You're going to start using phrases like "can help" and "can be treated". You will get these people along to the surgery to disappoint eight out of 10 at considerable cost to the health service."

Roy Sutherwood, spokesman for Pharmacia and Upjohn, said the breach of the code was simply a dispute over whether "the data is capable of supporting this kind of language. In any system of regu lation you are going to find cases where people say 'not on this occasion'."

The disease awareness campaign, he said, was to fulfill an unmet need for information. "Neither government nor the health eduaction authority could afford to do it," he said.

It is possible, he said, that advertising medicines direct to the consumer as in the USA might not be appropriate in a context where the NHS has a monopoly. But "we certainly want to take forward the idea that we think pharmaceutical companies together with health care professionals and patient groups and regulatory contractors should be treating the consumer like an adult and providing information that the patient wants about their treatment."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Air traffic record
Britain's air traffic controllers handled a record 1.9m flights last year, 7% up on the 1998 total, National Air Traffic Services - Nats - revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Air traffic record
Britain's air traffic controllers handled a record 1.9m flights last year, 7% up on the 1998 total, National Air Traffic Services - Nats - revealed yesterday.

On July 9, 1999, some 6,389 flights - the highest-ever daily figure - were handled. The government is seeking a controversial part-privatisation of Nats.

Girl, 12, has baby
A 12-year-old girl has given birth at Torbay hospital in Devon after her family were given financial support by the Roman Catholic church so she could keep her baby.

The girl, who has learning difficulties, sparked controversy last year after it emerged she was being backed by the church in her decision not to have an abortion. The father is believed to be a 15-year-old schoolfriend.

Drug tsar's challenge
Drugs tsar Keith Hellawell yesterday challenged his critics at Westminster to "put up or shut up".

The former chief constable, who heads the government's drive to combat drug abuse, said he feared that "negative spinning" directed at him was undermining the drugs strategy.

Kidney man 'improving'
Pensioner Graham Reeves, whose healthy kidney was removed in a surgical blunder, was said to be improving yesterday.

Mr Reeves, 69, was meant to have had a diseased kidney removed. A friend, the Rev Walford Roberts, said: "There has been a slight improvement."

A spokesman for Morriston hospital, Swansea, said Mr Reeves remained critical but stable.

Veteran Tory MP to quit
Veteran Tory MP Sir Peter Emery, 73, has announced his retirement from parliament at the next election after 40 years in the Commons. The former junior minister had a 7,489 majority in his Devon East constituency.

webTitle: Lego is toy of the century

fields.headline: Lego is toy of the century
fields.trailText: Lego has beaten the teddy bear, Action Man and Barbie to become the official toy of the century.
fields.body:
Lego has beaten the teddy bear, Action Man and Barbie to become the official toy of the century.

Monopoly was named game of century by the British Association of Toy Retailers, which chose the humble yo-yo as the craze of the century. The awards were presented last night at the Royal Lancaster hotel in London.

Lego - which in Latin means "to put together" - was voted top toy of the past 100 years by 12 BATR members after considering polls conducted on the internet and in newspapers.

The classic building tool for young architectural enthusiasts was introduced in Denmark in 1932 by Ole Kirk Christiansen. Lego bricks first went on sale in Britain in 1955 and its success continues today with the latest hi-tech bricks embedded with microchips to create robots, controlled over the internet.

Gerry Masters, spokesman for BATR, said: "Lego uses a classic building brick which must go back to ancient times.

"The brick has been developed for each generation and the toy has never stood still, but fundamentally the classic building brick still remains."

He said that Monopoly "is the classic family game and still one of the top selling board games".

Devised in the US in 1933 by Charles Darrow, the Monopoly concept was originally rejected by game companies for being too complicated. But it proved a success when, in 1936, it was made in the UK under licence by Waddingtons.

The yo-yo can be traced to ancient Greece but took off as a craze in Britain in 1930.

Other winners included the Furby Babies for 1999 toy of the year, the Who Wants to Be a Millionaire board game for game of the year, and Alien Eggs for craze of the year. Boys' toy of the year went to the WWF Wrestlers while Baby Annabell was voted girls' toy of the year.

The UK toy industry is worth more than £1.6bn a year, according to the BATR, which represents more than 75% of the toy retail sector.

webTitle: Artists rage over 'fiasco' of Scottish Oscars

fields.headline: Artists rage over 'fiasco' of Scottish Oscars
fields.trailText: It is nearly 20 times bigger than the Booker or Whitbread prizes, but if you hadn't heard of last week's Scottish Oscars you were not alone. Neither had most Scottish writers.
fields.body:
It is nearly 20 times bigger than the Booker or Whitbread prizes, but if you hadn't heard of last week's Scottish Oscars you were not alone. Neither had most Scottish writers.

The first inkling most had about the £350,000 lottery-funded Creative Scotland awards was when they got invitations from the Scottish arts council to the big bash afterwards.

The awards were meant to support the much-trumpeted "Scottish renaissance", which has been built on the reputation of writers like Irvine Welsh, Alan Warner, AL Kennedy, Andrew O'Hagan and Don Paterson. Unfortunately, none of these was told anything about them.

Kennedy branded the fiasco a "monumental embarrassment", Paterson called it a "dog's dinner" and a "disgrace". Welsh's thoughts on the subject are unprintable.

With almost killing irony, the 14 £25,000 awards were dispensed on Burns Night, when Scotland celebrates another writer it deprived of a decent living.

"It makes my blood boil," said Robin Robertson of Jonathan Cape, who publishes a spray of Scotland's leading writers. "Scotland has more good writers per square mile than anywhere, and even the so-called successful ones are pretty much skint."

Kennedy said alarm bells should have gone off at the SAC when only 12 writers applied. She insisted that publishers, agents and writers' organisations she had contacted were unaware of the awards.

Paterson, a poet, who like O'Hagan was recently shortlisted for the Whitbread prize, said the SAC appeared to have run with the awards "with the insouciance of the tombola stand at a kirk fete".

The SAC which recently responded to mounting criticism of its alleged secrecy by holding meetings in public, insisted that the response to the Scottish Oscars was so good that they would be offered again next year.

The timing of the awards, in the same week that the council slashed its grant to Edinburgh's influential Talbot Rice gallery, has also been attacked.

But the SAC's chairman, Magnus Linklater, said he was "amazed by the criticism" from writers. "It was covered on television and radio and in the newspapers. I really do not know how much more we could have done."

Its literature director, Jenny Brown, said she was sorry if any artist had missed the chance to apply. Publishing associations, writers' groups and several umbrella bodies had been notified, but lottery rules prevented them from telling individuals.

An SAC spokeswoman said £3,000 had been spent on a professional advertising campaign, and "dozens and dozens" of articles about the awards had been in the press.

The criteria on which the council decided the awards, which seemed to favour artists who dipped into other areas, have also been attacked.

Only two of the 11 awards went to writers - Alice Thompson and Janet Paisley - the rest mostly going to visual artists and musicians.

"We have no problems with the awards in other disciplines," said Robertson. "Surely it is now time for the arts council to acknowledge its mistake and rethink the whole thing. The idea is good in principle; good individual artists and writers need support."

Paterson said it was time the arts council looked to the Irish Aosdana system, which supports many writers with tax breaks and small stipends.

"It's a measure of the rude health of our culture that despite this dog's dinner, there are still first-rate artists among the prizewinners."

webTitle: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Kirstie Alley
fields.body:
Kirstie Alley in Star Trek: The Wrath of Khan

(Nicholas Meyer, 1982)

Who? Ex-cheerleader and one-time prodigious drinker/drug user who found fame as Rebecca Howe in alco-sitcom Cheers. Latterly a prominent Scientologist - she's also the spokeswoman for Narcanon, the Church's in-house rehab programme - Alley currently divides her time between lingerie-themed TV show Veronica's Closet and fighting the good fight for L Ron Hubbard: "I don't like it when journalists mention the 'controversial Church of Scientology' in an article about me", she remarked in 1998. "It's like me saying 'the controversial Jew who interviewed me'."

The role: Lieutenant Saavik, Vulcan protégé of Captain Spock, aboard the now somewhat delapidated USS Enterprise, battling to save the universe from the sadistic Khan (played by Richard Montalban, otherwise known as Mr Roarke, custodian of TV's Fantasy Island). And, yes, that means she's sporting comically raised eyebrows and pointy ears (albeit tucked under her hair).

Best Line: "Girshon marlon ich vanu. Ich veni... cormay" (phonetic translation of the Vulcan for "He's not what I expected. He's so... human."

Cringe factor: Depends on how you feel about pointy ears.

Other wannabes: Young blood being thin on the ground here, the best you'll find is Nicholas Guest - brother of Spinal Tap's Christopher - as a "Star Fleet Cadet".

Critical judgement: "A bit hokey and pretentious at times," remarked Leonard Maltin, "but likeable overall, with nice touches of warmth and humour."

Also not starring in: Champions - the 1983 biopic of jockey Bob Champion - and two episodes of sci-fi TV series The Hitchhiker the same year.

Star Trek: The Wrath of Khan, Sky Cinema, Saturday February 5, 8pm

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Down To Earth (3.45pm, Radio 4)
fields.body:
Ray Brown has been on the trail of one of the odder hobbies to evolve from 20th-century technology - the assiduous search for the wreckage of aircraft which crashed long ago. Throughout the week Down To Earth (3.45pm, Radio 4) reports daily on the efforts of highly expert amateur archaeologists who track down fallen machines. Their finds range from the R38 airship (which plunged into the Humber in 1921) to the remarkable number of crippled wartime planes still buried where they fell.

Having chronicled the often stroppy atmosphere of the initial selection course for prospective chief constables in The Right Stuff (8.0pm, Radio 4), Gerry Northam (pic tured) now follows the high-flyers through their six-month training at Bramshill Police College. The programmes were recorded at the height of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry. Inevitably, much of the Strategic Command course focuses on various police chiefs' failure to translate their declared acceptance of racial equality into reality on the streets.

fields.headline: Slippery polls
fields.standfirst:
The evidence is there. New Labour can't take the outcome of the 2001 general election for granted

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The evidence is there. New Labour can't take the outcome of the 2001 general election for granted.
fields.body:
For the past two years the quickest way to lose money at great odds has been to bet on any outcome in the next general election other than a convincing Labour victory: the bookies have been falling over themselves to accept that bet. And the political classes share their view, with virtually all columnists assuming a two-term Labour government. David Blunkett broods aloud about a five-term Labour hegemony, and the Tories struggle to find anyone to stand for key target seats.

Recent Labour travails haven't dented this picture at all. The parties' support in the polls has stayed stable with Labour at 48% or more, the Conservatives 32% or less, Liberal Democrats 13% and others 7% for two years now. The polls did well in getting the 1997 result right, so that seems to be that.

And yet something funny is going on. In the few Westminster byelections, numerous council byelections, in the annual local government elections of 1998 and 1999, and the three critically important mid-term elections in May/June 1999 for Scotland, Wales and the European parliament, there has been virtually no collateral evidence that the opinion polls have the government vote right. Only one Westminster byelection, at Eddisbury, gave anything like the result we would expect from the polls' configuration.

Don't get me wrong - the polls have got Conservative support right to a tee in all these elections, and they've got Liberal Democrat support more right than at any time in recent history. But compare their rating of Labour on 48% with what the party actually got in the three 1999 elections - just 36% in Scot land and 34% in Wales, both Labour heartland areas, and 26% nationwide in the European parliament elections. These figures are a world away from the hegemony which the polls are painting.

Many people who haven't really got a settled view think quickly and say Labour. But in a real election, right in front of them sits a ballot paper with other options, options they don't have when a pollster pops up on the phone.

People are voting for fourth parties, for the Scottish National party who got 27% in 1999, for Plaid Cymru who racked up 31% from nowhere in reaction to the imposition of Alun Michael on the Welsh Labour party by Downing Street, and for the "others" - the Greens, the UK Independence party, left-of-Labour parties, and so on who along with the nationalists gained an astonishing 26% support nationwide in the European parliament elections.

Most mass media estimates of the 1999 elections have underestimated how badly Labour did. If we do like-for-like comparisons of the party's 1999 votes with 1997 intentions, then Labour's vote was down 12% in Scotland, down 19% in Wales and down 18% in the Euro parliament vote nationwide. A slump of between 12 and 19% is dramatic stuff - even John Major only lost 11% between 1992 and 1997.

Political scientists poring over the runes of 1997 have been shocked to discover how different it was from the rest of our post-war elections. Labour did better in terms of its seats share divided by its votes share than at any other time in this period. And so did the Liberal Democrats, who doubled their tally of MPs even while their unspectacular 1992 vote declined a further 1% nationwide. And the Conservatives were under-represented in 1997 by more than ever before in their history this century.

Labour and Liberal Democrat leaders signed a joint pact on constitutional reform just weeks before the 1997 election, giving their supporters an unmistakeable cue how to vote tactically, and as we now know Blair considered appointing Liberal Democrats to his cabinet right up until election night. As a result the two parties' voters effectively acted as a single bloc commanding 61% of the national vote to the Tories 31%, an imbalance which under the first-past-the-post system was bound to deliver a commanding result, just as the 1931 National government coalition trashed the then isolated Labour party.

But these conditions will not repeat. The government has reneged on its manifesto pledge of a referendum on voting reform; encouraged the Wakeham commission to propose a massively unpopular and undemocratic scheme for changing the Lords; allowed Jack Straw to explore the outermost limits of illiberalism for a Labour home secretary; cut welfare payments for the disabled; and done little to promote an effective European policy. The alienation of Lib Dem voters seems assured.

The consequences will be enormous. If all parties keep their 1997 vote shares, but Labour's seats over votes ratio goes back to its average for post-war elections it could lose 60 constituencies to the Tories, especially in south-east England. What's more the Lib Dems could drop 15 seats to the Tories too. Hague should have 75 more MPs behind him in the Commons in 2001 even if he gets not a single more vote.

Work the arithmetic and a 2001 election suddenly looks much more open. The underlying real starting position, is an overall Labour majority of just 60. To keep that majority, Labour must poll 44.4%, safe enough compared with the polls' 48%, but a hurdle compared with any recent real elections. The next general election is not a shoo-in.

 Patrick Dunleavy is professor of government at LSE

As a result the two parties' voters effectively acted as a single bloc commanding 61% of the national vote to the Tories 31%, an imbalance which under the first-past-the-post system was bound to deliver a commanding result, just as the 1931 National government coalition trashed the then isolated Labour party. But these conditions will not repeat. The government has reneged on its manifesto pledge of a referendum on voting reform; encouraged the Wakeham commission to propose a massively unpopular and undemocratic scheme for changing the Lords; allowed Jack Straw to explore the outermost limits of illiberalism for a Labour home secretary; cut welfare payments for the disabled; and done little to promote an effective European policy. The alienation of Lib Dem voters seems assured. The consequences will be enormous. If all parties keep their 1997 vote shares, but Labour's seats over votes ratio goes back to its average for post-war elections it could lose 60 constituencies to the Tories, especially in south-east England. What's more the Lib Dems could drop 15 seats to the Tories too. Hague should have 75 more MPs behind him in the Commons in 2001 even if he gets not a single more vote. Work the arithmetic and a 2001 election suddenly looks much more open. The underlying real starting position, is an overall Labour majority of just 60. To keep that majority, Labour must poll 44.4%, safe enough compared with the polls' 48%, but a hurdle compared with any recent real elections. The next general election is not a shoo-in.  Patrick Dunleavy is professor of government at LSE

fields.headline: Everyone's gone to the sun
fields.trailText: Scheduling is a serious business, so we must assume that a good deal of research went into the decision to put Sunburn on Saturday evening and Clocking Off on Sunday. The message to BBC1's weekend audience couldn't be clearer: Saturday night is about action and fun, while Sunday should find you in the mood for more reflective drama.
fields.body:
Scheduling is a serious business, so we must assume that a good deal of research went into the decision to put Sunburn on Saturday evening and Clocking Off on Sunday. The message to BBC1's weekend audience couldn't be clearer: Saturday night is about action and fun, while Sunday should find you in the mood for more reflective drama.

Sunburn is very much like Casualty, which it follows, except that we find ourselves in the Algarve rather than A&E. Other than that, the format's the same: a bunch of regular characters, about whom we find out little bits each week, and a series of guest cameos who live out their individual dramas and then disappear. Visitors to Casualty get a few days' work in Bristol and bleed a lot, whereas the casting directors on Sunburn can offer a spell in sunny Portugal and the chance to sport leisure wear.

Saturday's show was stuffed with stars: within a few seconds Frank Windsor, Windsor Davies and Brian Murphy had all got off a coach, while Robin "Confessions" Askwith looked fruity and modelled a heinous floppy hairdo. While the guest turns busied themselves with sub-plots about a dominoes tournament and a nudist beach, the regulars got on with the serious business of being Janus Holiday reps, which involves a lot of trotting around with a clipboard. Michelle Collins was alternately brisk and smouldering, peering out from under her fringe with huge, pale grey eyes, fending off the solicitous Askwith and dealing smartly with moping holidaymakers. Sean Maguire, another EastEnders alumnus, charged around in a state of permanent sexual arousal. Sunburn is so full of familiar faces from long-running TV shows that it would have come as no surprise if Brookside's Trevor Jordache had burst out from beneath the patio to join the fun.

As the dominoes tournament reached its climax, several characters realised that there are moments in life when you have to make a choice, and one of them sang a song ("This is the moment...") to underline the fact. Frank Windsor lost at dominoes but won back his estranged wife, so the holiday wasn't entirely wasted.

Twenty-four hours later, Paul Abbott's factory drama Clocking Off delved into the murky private life of widowed, divorced mother of three Yvonne, who burnt down her own house without realising her children were still inside. Sarah Lancashire played the bungling arsonist as an appealing hybrid of Marilyn Monroe and Mike Tyson - she wiggled her rear and used her fists to equal effect. Chris Eccleston, whose very presence in a drama ensures a leavening of grit, was the neighbour who rescued the kids from the fire, allowed the entire family to move into his house, fell in love with Yvonne, allowed her to beat him up in an Indian restaurant and still came back for more. "You must be wrong in the head", claimed Yvonne, but agreed to "play it by ear".

Clocking Off alternates between hard-hitting mode and mushy mode, rather like its heroine, who was magnificent when angry or snapping out a hard-boiled one-liner ("You wouldn't rear dogs in a skip like that"). The "will-they-won't-they" romantic tension worked well for once, and it was a relief that none of the characters were maverick policemen or in any way connected with the medical profession. The next-week trailers suggest that we've done with these characters now, which is a blow, as Eccleston and Lancashire make a handsome couple.

Channel 4 provided more sobering fare in Gypsies, Tramps and Thieves (Saturday), a shocking story of the plight of Romany people in the Czech Republic. "They rob pensioners", claimed one street interviewee; "we should eliminate them", said another, casually munching an ice-cream cone. To the gypsies themselves, this has alarming echoes of the rhetoric of the Third Reich, who disposed of 90% of Romanies in the death camps. One holocaust survivor returned to the camp at Lety, where she'd seen her sisters raped and murdered by a camp commander who lived on, unpunished, until a couple of years ago. There is no memorial at Lety; the site is now an industrial pig farm. Another woman watched the skinheads who had murdered her husband walk free from a courtroom; she was afraid that they would follow her home and kill her as well. Thousands of Romanies have turned up in the UK seeking asylum, but have so far been denied refugee status; at least we now know what they are seeking refuge from.

fields.headline: No more heroes
fields.standfirst: Ex-Father Ted star, Ardal O'Hanlon, is about to embark on that tricky second sit-com. Occasional self-reinvention is something every star has to face, and it is full of potential pitfalls.
fields.trailText: Ex-Father Ted star, Ardal O'Hanlon, is about to embark on that tricky second sit-com. Occasional self-reinvention is something every star has to face, and it is full of potential pitfalls.
fields.body:
The actor Harrison Ford recently announced that - for the first time in his career - he is retaining an agent. After a series of flops, he wants help in choosing scripts. This development reminds us that the stardom of a performer is something which needs to be renegotiated with each project. A brilliant footballer - given freedom from injuries, junkies and showbiz hangers-on - should be guaranteed a decade or so of adoring Saturdays. But a movie actor needs to find a new team and stadium each year. Make the wrong choice and a star can soon look like a reserve.

In television, an actor can wear the same shirt for years or (in soap) even decades, but the problem of making your fame work in a new place will still eventually arise. After the success of Father Ted - brought to an end by the death of its star, Dermot Morgan - co-star Ardal O'Hanlan could have done pretty much anything he wanted. What he chose to do is My Hero (BBC1, 8.30pm, Friday). Perhaps he should put in an urgent call to Harrison Ford's new agent.

There has long been an expression in Hollywood about stars who can "open films big", meaning that their movies will produce huge takings on the first weekend, creating the momentum which builds publicity and word of mouth. As British television has become more competitive, the concept of the big openers has spread here.

Executives believe that David Jason - who successfully transported a large audience from Only Fools And Horses to A Touch Of Frost - will always empty pubs and crease settees, and this has encouraged the belief that any celebrity can change address. A frequent device now is to use proven comedy and soap stars to open new peak-time shows. Michelle Collins left EastEnders to lead the creaky holiday series Sunburn. Ross Kemp hung up Grant Mitchell's razor in the same show to make various ITV dramas due soon on the screen.

But the case of Ardal O'Hanlon and My Hero is the most audacious example of an attempted star-transfer. Father Ted, though loved and garlanded, was a show on a minority network (Channel 4) and O'Hanlon played a supporting character, Father Dougal. Yet My Hero plays in BBC1 peak-time. Even if O'Hanlon's Father Ted audience proved entirely transportable, it would not be enough. In this case, the star-transplant is also an attempt at star-enhancement.

Although David Jason, the inspiration behind all such attempts at reinvention, often travels some distance between scripts - Del Boy and DCI Jack Frost are at most cracked-mirror images - leading television actors are in general lucky if they're permitted even a haircut when they move from one show to another. Recognition and familiarity are the point.

It would frankly have been no surprise if the BBC had simply asked O'Hanlon to play an Irish monk or, if really stretching him, a Church of England curate. At least My Hero frees him from his dog collar, but he inevitably plays another slow-witted Dubliner, though this time George, the owner of a health-food shop who is in love with a nurse in Northolt. George, though, has a secret. He has a fly-by-night job as Thermoman, a comic-book hero who saves the lives of those in danger and has indeed intervened to rescue the Northolt nurse during her American holiday.

You can see how the thinking went. A central element in the success of Father Ted was its surreal sequences and therefore this new O'Hanlon project is designed to have two levels. But Father Ted created an intricate world - Craggy Island, a slightly skewed Ireland - through which recognisably human characters moved. The surrealism was rooted in the superstitions of rural Ireland and the bold leaps of logic asked by the religion which was the central character's job.

The problem with My Hero is that the premise is not obviously comic. Imagine being pitched the idea: "There's this rather dull guy but, in private, he's a superhero who saves the world." Well, yes, but that's precisely the plot of Superman and Batman and all the other cartoon strips about the wimp with the hidden heroism. All the possible gags - your girlfriend thinking you're dull, the sudden disappearances, the curious convention that these guys always wear tights - have been done in those programmes and movies. My Hero attempts a humorous spin on a genre which has already seen the joke.

The sit-com does have one novelty but it is regrettably another mistake. George has an American cousin, Arnie, a cafe owner. Although British sit-coms have had American characters before (there was a Yank in Lenny Henry's Chef), My Hero attempts whole scenes of pastiche American sit-com featuring Arnie. The writers weren't to know that the viewer would be able to switch directly from this show to see Friends and Frasier on Channel 4, but the proximity leaves the sit-com needing a superhero to save it.

All producers and performers attempting star transplants remember the example of A Year In Provence, the series to which John Thaw moved when Inspector Morse was the nation's favourite programme. It stank like French cheese. For Ardal O'Hanlon, My Hero also seems likely to prove that you can't take it with you.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Hardware, 12.05am, Sky Cinema
fields.body:
Hardware

(Richard Stanley, 1994)

12.05am, Sky Cinema

Messy, disjointed, violent (but at least British) sci-fi from the ex-video director, that doesn't really hold a candle to its Terminator/DarioArgento/2000AD influences, but has a knockabout irreverence that's quite endearing. It's that post-apocalyptic-nightmare-world kind of scenario again; The Scavenger (a metal-armed Dylan McDermott) finds an old robot head which his girlfriend incorporates into one of her junk sculptures, and guess what? It's still alive and itching to wreak havoc!

Steve Rose

The Boxer

(Jim Sheridan, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

This third teaming of Sheridan and Daniel Day-Lewis (pictured) doesn't pack quite the punch of In The Name of The Father and My Left Foot, but it's a strong, earthy human drama nevertheless. Day-Lewis plays the boxer, a former IRA man picking up the gloves back in Belfast after serving 14 years in prison, trying to set up a non-sectarian club and gettinginvolved with onetime girlfriend Emily Watson: a bleak, hard, ultimately affirmative tale.

Things To Do In Denver When You're Dead

(Gary Fleder, 1995)

10.0pm, UK Arena

The problem with such a great title is living up to it, but Fleder largely succeeds with a refreshing, Runyonesque take on familiar gangster fare. Andy Garcia's Jimmy the Saint is going straight until Christopher Walken's sick, dessicated villain draws him and his old buddies back in, with deadly consequences. Jimmy moves from smooth-talking charmer to heroic, in the old-school Chandler mode.

Trust

(Hal Hartley, 1990)

2am, FilmFour

Hartley's darkly funny follow up to his debut feature, The Unbelievable Truth. Adrienne Shelly is again the star, playing teenage brat Maria, who induces a fatal heart attack in her father when she tells him she is pregnant. Wandering the smalltown streets, she meets Martin Donovan's suicidally inclined misfit. Offbeat and moving.

webTitle: Boost for Mowlam after double indignity

fields.headline: Boost for Mowlam after double indignity
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night rallied in support of Mo Mowlam after the cabinet office minister suffered the double indignity of losing the security protection she had in Northern Ireland amid renewed speculation about her career and health.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night rallied in support of Mo Mowlam after the cabinet office minister suffered the double indignity of losing the security protection she had in Northern Ireland amid renewed speculation about her career and health.

Friends of the former Northern Ireland secretary are close to despair over a succession of reports about her alleged reluctance to embrace her new job as the policy "enforcer" across Whitehall departments.

No 10 is still said to be keen to "bind her in and use her immense popularity". The loss of protection - on the day of the Cheltenham sword attack on Nigel Jones MP - may reflect a security service assessment of that popularity as a form of protection in itself.

Ms Mowlam and her staff are surprised and unhappy about the decision, it emerged yesterday. And it comes in contrast to protection still provided to more confrontational Nothern Ireland secretaries such as Lord Roy Mason 20 years after he left office - though attempts have been made to cut his trained driver and armed police support.

As for Ms Mowlam's career prospects, Mr Blair's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, has been consistently supportive, though her allies are adamant that someone "further down the food chain" in No 10 is trying to damage her.

Far from being denied the health secretary's post when Frank Dobson decided in September to stand for mayor of London - a punishment, it was said, for her refusal to leave Belfast in July - she was offered the post by Mr Blair, authoritative sources confirmed yesterday.

Instead she opted for the wide-ranging cabinet office brief to re-aquaint herself with the centre of government after years on the Belfast beat. "She is a huge asset to the government and is already making a difference where she is," a senior Blair aide said last night.

That contrasts with anonymous whispers that Ms Mowlam is uninterested in her new brief with its absence of a large "hands-on" department or high profile political agenda. There has been speculation that her £350,000 book contract is the first step to a decision to leave politics - though both Barbara Castle and Richard Crossman signed book contracts in cabinet in the 1960s.

More worrying are murmurs - dismissed as "nasty and insidious" - that Ms Mowlam has never fully recovered from the brain tumour that robbed her of her hair during treatment after 1996. Some officials claim she is a loose cannon who refuses to be briefed properly on the kind of issues her job needs her to understand.

One ally said last night: "She may be being slagged off for ruffling a few feathers and trying to get departments to agree."

Ms Mowlam's name has been touted as potential minister for rural affairs and for promoting social inclusion, a topic which - like the drugs problem - does appeal strongly to the former comprehensive pupil who admits to modest experimentation with soft drugs in her youth.

If they persist, Ms Mowlam's problems reinforce what may be a long-term problem for Mr Blair whose cabinet contains five women members but only one who runs a department - the formidable Clare Short at international development, which is important, but not central to the Blair agenda.

Coincidentally yesterday the chief whip in the Commons, Ann Taylor, was in hot water with some Labour MPs over her handling of the section 28 issue. They claimed she had backed the idea, hastily withdrawn, of a free vote because she is privately unenthusiastic about repeal of the section.

It is noticeable that she, Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, and Baroness Jay, leader in the Lords, run parliament but not the big departments of state.

All are women of an older pre-Blair generation. Blairite men of the class of '92 like Stephen Byers, Alan Milburn and Geoff Hoon have now got into cabinet, but none of the tipped women like Tessa Jowell and Patricia Hewitt.

Since there are worries that the record number of women Labour MPs elected in 1997 will not get back next time, Mr Blair's laddish administration may yet face a backlash.
