webTitle: Robinson may face police fraud inquiry

fields.headline: Robinson may face police fraud inquiry
fields.standfirst: Tory MP steps up pressure in TransTec grant affair
fields.trailText: Fraud squad officers were last night deciding whether to launch an investigation into the collapsed engineering company founded by the former treasury minister, Geoffrey Robinson.
fields.body:
Fraud squad officers were last night deciding whether to launch an investigation into the collapsed engineering company founded by the former treasury minister, Geoffrey Robinson.

Allegations that government grants totalling hundreds of thousands of pounds were improperly obtained by TransTec have been passed to West Midlands police by Conservative MP John Taylor.

The Solihull MP has requested Edward Crew, the chief constable, to launch a full investigation into the alleged abuse of a government funding project.

Yesterday the force stressed that no decision had been taken about an investigation, although it said it would liaise with the department of trade and industry.

But a Labour MP not known as a Robinson ally said: "Anyone can complain to the police." And one minister played down the significance of Mr Taylor's request: "It's inconceivable that any police force would begin any investigation until the report of the DTI inspectors who, unlike the police, will have complete and ready access to all the documents."

News of possible police action came at the end of a weekend during which the former paymaster general's difficulties deepened further, with a string of new allegations about both TransTec and his offshore financial interests.

Yesterday Mr Robinson's former business partner Fawzey El-Menshawy, a Birmingham engineer, said he understood that government inspectors had on occasion been hoodwinked when visiting TransTec during the late 1980s to ensure grants for technical innovation had been spent as required. "They were presented with old machinery and parts dressed up as new," he reportedly stated.

Elsewhere it was reported that the Belgian tax service, investigating the affairs of Mr Robinson's late benefactor, entrepreneur Joska Bourgeois, had come up against a wall of non-cooperation from the British authorities when requesting information about the Channel Islands trust settled by Mrs Bourgeois on the Robinson family.

If true, this would be particularly embarrassing for the government, given that one of Mr Robinson's ministerial duties had been to spearhead a crackdown on tax dodging.

Yesterday Mr Taylor said: "I am very concerned about the effect of the TransTec collapse upon component suppliers in my constituency and the surrounding area. I know others in the local business community are equally alarmed."

Were the police to take up the case, Mr Robinson - MP for Coventry Northwest - would be facing three separate investigations. DTI inspectors have been appointed to examine the collapse of TransTec and an internal DTI team is investigating claims by TransTec's former accountant Max Ayriss that claims for government grants were inflated in the 1980s.

These are the claims Mr Taylor made to Mr Crew: "If true, I believe these allegations amount to criminal offences," the MP said. He called for them to be "thoroughly investigated by a competent police team, skilled in matters of alleged fraud".

In a statement last night, West Midlands police said: "We can confirm that we have received a written allegation in relation to the activities of TransTec. We will be liaising with the DTI, before we decide what action to take."

webTitle: Tories seek in vain the knockout blow that links Blair to Maxwell

fields.headline: Tories seek in vain the knockout blow that links Blair to Maxwell
fields.trailText: One fact in the TransTec affair, perhaps only one fact, is undeniable.
fields.body:
One fact in the TransTec affair, perhaps only one fact, is undeniable.

Geoffrey Robinson is still standing, despite a pounding from opponents and the media that, suffered by a more sensitive soul, would have had the referee clearing the ring on compassionate grounds.

It is ironic that the former paymaster general actually enjoyed (if that be the word) a brief chat with Mike Tyson last week.

He would have been better employed giving Tyson's hapless British opponent a crash course in true grit.

But the secret of Mr Robinson's stamina is simple. While his accusers may have made hay this month in the aftermath of TransTec's bankruptcy, they have failed to make a single serious allegation stick.

This alone does wonders for a chap's morale.

The weekend brought a slew of new or reheated reports, some making serious allegations. But the knock-out blow keenly anticipated in Conservative central office was not delivered.

That said, the stakes are high; were just one count on the lengthening indictment to stand up, a by-election would loom in Coventry North West. Take the £12m claim from Ford, the car group, lodged against TransTec and concealed from shareholders. Mr Robinson left the board just as the Ford issue was surfacing. He denies any knowledge of the claim or its treatment in the accounts.

There would be no room for "clarification" should that punch be landed.

More serious are claims that Mr Robinson knowingly submitted falsified invoices for government grants in the late 1980s in which routine business costs were relabelled as "technical innovation".

Again, a denial from Mr Robinson and no room for future ducking.

Beyond these two solid accusations, the charge sheet starts to ramble. There are reports he skipped (and later paid) TransTec pension fund contributions a decade ago (quite legal at the time). There is a suggestion his former colleagues at the treasury have been less than helpful in cooperating with a Belgian inquiry into the tax affairs of the late Joska Bourgeois, Mr Robinson's benefactor.

All very cloudy stuff but the big game being hunted here is anything but and goes by the name of Robert Maxwell.

The Tories and others believe Mr Robinson and TransTec link Tony Blair's Labour party to the disgraced tycoon. TransTec, they say, was a Maxwell creation, as indeed was the bulk of Mr Robinson's recent business career.

There was no doubt that Mr Robinson's generosity to the party - estimated by one newspaper yesterday as little short of £5m - is an embarrassment when the MP is under investigation on at least two fronts. In many ways, his brief ministerial career was the least important aspect of his role in the "project" when set alongside generous funding for research, large donations to the party proper and, of course, those Blair holidays in Italy.

But the view among many in the party was summed up by one minister yesterday: "I don't think Geoffrey's corrupt, but like a lot of businessmen he's cut corners and sailed close to the wind."

Others wish to prove something quite different - that New Labour was Captain Bob's parting gift to his adopted country.

A punch like that would knock out more than Mr Robinson.

webTitle: MP hurt in sword attack calls for bodyguards

fields.headline: MP hurt in sword attack calls for bodyguards
fields.trailText: Nigel Jones, the Liberal Democrat MP for Cheltenham who survived a sword attack in which his friend was killed, yesterday called for all politicians to be given bodyguards.
fields.body:
Nigel Jones, the Liberal Democrat MP for Cheltenham who survived a sword attack in which his friend was killed, yesterday called for all politicians to be given bodyguards.

Speaking about the attack in which Andrew Pennington, a school governor and local councillor, was killed, Mr Jones called for a review of security measures for those in public service.

The two were attacked by a man wielding a 2ft-long sword who burst into the party's offices in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire. Mr Pennington died after being stabbed 10 times in the chest and stomach.

Mr Jones, who needed surgery on his right hand to repair a severed tendon, said the tip of one finger was chopped off and found on the floor of his constituency office. He had 50-60 stitches in his hands.

He was visited by Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, before being allowed home.

"Every MP ought to have a big minder," Mr Jones said. "We do take a lot of risks, and we need to look closely at the security of all public servants. What we must not do, though, is make it impossible for the public to come and see MPs or councillors."

Mr Kennedy said the attack was "grotesque and appalling", but MPs and councillors could not shut themselves away if they were to continue doing their job."

Mr Jones last night issued a statement which said: "Words cannot convey the deep hurt I feel for the loss of my friend Andy. He was totally dedicated and committed to the people of Cheltenham. Although Andy worked as my assistant, he had been a friend and confidant for many years and I will miss him greatly."

A man aged 49 is to appear before the Cheltenham magistrates today charged with the murder of Mr Pennington and the attempted murder of Mr Jones.

fields.headline: Margarete Schütte-Lihotsky
fields.standfirst: Socialist beliefs were central to the life of Austria's first female architect, from designing mass-production kitchens to defying the Nazis
fields.trailText: Margarete Schütte-Lihotsky, who has died just before her 103rd birthday, was Austria's first female architect. A communist from an early age, she devoted her life to improving the living conditions of working women throughout Europe, and her invention of the "Frankfurt Kitchen" revolutionised the way living space was perceived to relate to housework.
fields.body:
Margarete Schütte-Lihotsky, who has died just before her 103rd birthday, was Austria's first female architect. A communist from an early age, she devoted her life to improving the living conditions of working women throughout Europe, and her invention of the "Frankfurt Kitchen" revolutionised the way living space was perceived to relate to housework.

Born in Vienna, she defied her parents' wishes to become the country's first female architecture student, studying at the Imperial and Royal Arts and Crafts School (1915-19), where Oskar Kokoschka was one of her teachers, and later at the High School for Applied Arts. "They thought I would go hungry," she later said. "In 1916 no one could possibly imagine anyone allowing a woman to build a house - not even me."

The artistic, structural and, above all, the social dimension of architecture persuaded her to stick it out. Small and red-headed, she began winning prizes for her designs even as a student. It was an award in 1920 for an allotment design that first brought her into contact with Vienna's Housing movement and the pioneer of modern architecture, Adolf Loos. The collaboration was to have a profound effect on her entire career, and led to significant developments in the design of homes, kindergartens, children's furniture and self-assemble furniture. The influences are still keenly felt; the Swedish furniture store Ikea presented her with an award in the 1990s.

The Vienna Housing movement was established because of the huge demand for living space that existed in the Austrian capital at that time. "Between 1914 and 1918, nothing was built," the architect recalled. "The soldiers came back from the war to find they had no roofs over their heads." She joined forces with Loos; the two were convinced of the importance of their task after witnessing angry demonstra tions on Vienna's Ring Road, where thousands of smallholders demanded construction subsidies, land and building materials so they could steer themselves out of poverty.

From 1922, Schütte-Lihotsky worked with Loos on the first public housing scheme for Austria's war disabled, and their close friendship was to endure until his death in 1933.

German architect Ernst May had had his eye on the young Austrian's work for some time, and in 1926 he invited her to join the Frankfurt structural engineering department. Here she was able to concentrate on improving, through simplification, the way household tasks were carried out. Around this time she wrote her first essay: How can we make housework easier by building appropriate apartments? She drew up plans for kindergartens, laundries and apartments, focusing on the needs of single working women. This culminated in the design for the Frankfurt Kitchen, the creation for which she will be most remembered.

Ten thousand apartments on a Frankfurt housing estate were kitted out with this design, which had been thought out down to the very last detail. It was the most functional kitchen space that had ever been created on a mass scale - the precursor of the modern fitted version. "I built the prototype of a 1.9 by 3.4 metre kitchen and I measured with a stop-watch how long it took me to do certain tasks. It has been helping women to save time for years," Schütte-Lihotsky said.

In Frankfurt she met and married her colleague, architect Wilhelm Schütte. The couple accepted an invitation, along with Ernst May, to go to the Soviet Union in 1930, where Schütte-Lihotsky spent seven years developing standardised designs for kindergartens, nurseries and children's furniture for the newly developed heavy industry cities. She was often based thousands of miles from Moscow in the middle of the steppes, where travel was only possible in horse-drawn carts and sleighs.

With the growing strength of Nazi Germany, she decided to demonstrate against the Nazi regime in her homeland. At the end of December 1940 she travelled via Paris and Berlin to Istanbul, where she also worked, before returning to Vienna. There, she linked up with the resistance wing of the Communist party.

After only a few weeks she was arrested by the Gestapo. The Berlin national court commuted a recommended death sentence to 15 years in a Bavarian prison, where she stayed until the end of the war. "During the four years, three months and one week that I served, 16 of around 100 Austrian women who fought for the resistance and who I got to know during this period were murdered - the political prisoners were executed." She wrote in detail about the experience in her only book, published in 1985, Memories from the Resistance: the Aggressive Life of an Architect between 1938 and 1945. Returning to post-war Austria, the self-professed Marxist found herself to be virtually persona non grata.

For years she found success only abroad. She was particularly popular in the Soviet Union, but it was not until 1980 that Austria began to start recognising her talents, awarding her the Vienna City Prize for Architecture; whole-hearted acceptance of her achievements only arrived after the end of Kurt Waldheim's presidency in 1992, when her country started to come to terms with its past.

In 1988, Schütte-Lihotsky refused to accept the Austrian Honorary Medal for Science and Art from Waldheim; she finally received the prize some years later. More recently, she criticised Austria's acceptance of far-right leader Jörg Haider, saying that people forgot their past too easily; she predicted correctly that "in the next election, his party will make great gains."

In 1993, Vienna's Museum of Applied Arts held an exhibition exploring her life and career - the first and only such celebration of her work in a mainstream forum. Five years later, in what was to be one of her last undertakings, Schütte-Lihotsky oversaw a project for a housing estate in north-east Vienna designed for women by women - the largest project of its kind in Europe. On her 100th birthday Vienna authorities announced that the estate would be renamed after her in recognition of an outstanding contribution to the city spanning more than a century. In the last few years of her life Schütte-Lihotsky lived alone, a stone's throw from her birthplace, in a small Vienna apartment with her cat, walking 700 steps every day to the local delicatessen. "I measure all distances in steps," she said. "I can't help it - I'll be an architect until my dying day."

fields.headline: Frances Drake
fields.standfirst: Beauty who quit movies for her aristocrat husband
fields.trailText: Although Frances Drake, who has died aged 91, appeared in 20 movies in the 1930s, she will be remembered almost solely as the beauty to Peter Lorre's beast in Mad Love (1935), a classic of the horror genre. The lovely brown-eyed brunette is the object of obsession for the bald-domed Lorre - in his first Hollywood film - as Dr Gogol, a crazed surgeon who grafts the hands of a murderer on to those of Drake's husband, Orloff, a concert pianist. Gogol is so infatuated by Mrs Orloff that he buys a wax figure of her and stares at it in a mirror while playing his pipe organ. When she rejects him, he tries to strangle her with her own long tresses. Drake's beauty and poise were enough to convince audiences that she could drive a man mad.
fields.body:
Although Frances Drake, who has died aged 91, appeared in 20 movies in the 1930s, she will be remembered almost solely as the beauty to Peter Lorre's beast in Mad Love (1935), a classic of the horror genre. The lovely brown-eyed brunette is the object of obsession for the bald-domed Lorre - in his first Hollywood film - as Dr Gogol, a crazed surgeon who grafts the hands of a murderer on to those of Drake's husband, Orloff, a concert pianist. Gogol is so infatuated by Mrs Orloff that he buys a wax figure of her and stares at it in a mirror while playing his pipe organ. When she rejects him, he tries to strangle her with her own long tresses. Drake's beauty and poise were enough to convince audiences that she could drive a man mad.

Mad Love was the last of eight films directed by cinematographer Karl Freund, who ended up directing I Love Lucy episodes on television. It was the highlight of Drake's film career, which consisted mainly of small roles in big films, and big roles in small films. Yet she got to star opposite Cary Grant in Ladies Should Listen (in which she was a switchboard operator who falls for him over the telephone) and George Raft as a Mexican bandit to her señorita in The Trumpet Blows, both minor Paramount pictures of 1934.

Born in New York and educated in Canada and England, she started out as a nightclub dancer in London, where she made her screen debut in Meet My Sister (1933) under her real name of Frances Dean. She went to Hollywood in 1934, having gained a Paramount contract, starting with a dancing role in Bolero, which starred George Raft and Carole Lombard.

Paramount failed to use her well, and it was while she was on loan to MGM that she made Mad Love. Also at MGM, she played Joan Crawford's witty rival for Robert Montgomery in Forsaking All Others (1935). In the same year, she was touching as Eponine in the oft-filmed Les Misérables, with Fredric March as Jean Valjean. This was followed by another role as a beauty in The Invisible Ray (1936) at Universal. This time Boris Karloff is the mad scientist - he learns that, as a result of an experiment with radium X, he can kill with a touch and Drake, as his wife, almost falls victim.

Then it was back to starring in second-feature films such as I'd Give My Life (1936), as the mother of a young hood; and The Lone Wolf in Paris (1938), as a princess who employs the gentleman thief hero (Francis Lederer) to steal back her stolen jewels.

In 1939, Drake married Cecil John Howard, the second son of the 19th Earl of Suffolk and, after small parts in two more films, I Take This Woman and The Affairs of Martha, she retired because "my husband hated the movie business", although they continued to live in Beverly Hills. In 1992, seven years after Howard's death, she married David Brown, who survives her.

This time Boris Karloff is the mad scientist - he learns that, as a result of an experiment with radium X, he can kill with a touch and Drake, as his wife, almost falls victim. Then it was back to starring in second-feature films such as I'd Give My Life (1936), as the mother of a young hood; and The Lone Wolf in Paris (1938), as a princess who employs the gentleman thief hero (Francis Lederer) to steal back her stolen jewels. In 1939, Drake married Cecil John Howard, the second son of the 19th Earl of Suffolk and, after small parts in two more films, I Take This Woman and The Affairs of Martha, she retired because "my husband hated the movie business", although they continued to live in Beverly Hills. In 1992, seven years after Howard's death, she married David Brown, who survives her. Frances Drake, film actress, born October 22 1908; died January 17 2000

fields.headline: System crash exposes US
fields.trailText: Computer systems at the world's most powerful intelligence gathering agency crashed for four days last week, leaving a blackout at the US government's National Security Agency, officials said.
fields.body:
Computer systems at the world's most powerful intelligence gathering agency crashed for four days last week, leaving a blackout at the US government's National Security Agency, officials said.

The collapse at the NSA headquarters began on Monday and was partially restored on Friday. The computer system was "still not 100%" at the weekend, a spokesman said.

Sources said there was no indication that it was caused by sabotage or by the Y2K computer glitch, but a spokesman said the loss was serious. The crash was said to have been caused by a system overload.

"As of now, there is no evidence other than this was a system stressed to meet day-to-day operational pressures," the spokesman said.

The NSA in Fort Meade, north of Washington, is responsible for protecting US government information systems and for supplying international intelligence information to the US and its allies.

webTitle: The Fugitive Case that inspired Hollywood resurrected as doctor's son tries to clear father's name

fields.headline: The Fugitive Case that inspired Hollywood resurrected as doctor's son tries to clear father's name
fields.trailText: The US murder case which inspired a long-running television series and the Hollywood film The Fugitive, will be heard for a third time today, when a court in Cleveland will decide whether a wealthy surgeon, Dr Sam Sheppard, murdered his wife 46 years ago.
fields.body:
The US murder case which inspired a long-running television series and the Hollywood film The Fugitive, will be heard for a third time today, when a court in Cleveland will decide whether a wealthy surgeon, Dr Sam Sheppard, murdered his wife 46 years ago.

A case of wrongful imprisonment is being brought by Dr Sheppard's son, Sam Reese Sheppard, who has spent four years trying to clear his father's name.

Dr Sheppard claimed that his wife, Marilyn, had been bludgeoned to death by a "bushy-haired" intruder, who had knocked him unconscious.

The Cleveland court which first tried the case in 1954 rejected his claims and sentenced him to life in prison. But a subsequent supreme court decision ruled that his case had been prejudiced by pre-trial publicity, and he was acquitted in a retrial in 1966.

By then the case had provided the inspiration for television's The Fugitive, which had the wrongfully accused doctor escaping from prison and pursuing his wife's true murderer. The 1993 film, starring Harrison Ford, followed the same plot.

But the real Dr Sheppard never recovered his reputation or his career. He had difficulty getting a job as a doctor, and at one point even became a wrestler, going by the name of Killer Sheppard. He died in 1970, an impoverished alcoholic.

Now his son wants the state of Ohio to pay damages for what he calls the "destruction of an American family". He claims that advances in forensic science and DNA analysis prove his father's innocence.

The intruder, his lawyers will argue, was a thief called Richard Eberling, who was working as the Sheppards' window cleaner at the time of the murder, and who was later convicted of beating another woman to death.

At the time of the investigation, Eberling denied killing Marilyn Sheppard and passed a lie detector test on the murder. However, Reese Sheppard says that before Eberling's death in 1998, he confessed to the murder to a fellow inmate. A ring belonging to Marilyn Sheppard had been found among his possessions when he was arrested for an unrelated theft.

Recent DNA analysis of scrapings from the crime scene has identified blood which did not belong to either Dr Sheppard or his wife, but which came from a third person. That third person was Eberling, Mr Sheppard's lawyers will argue.

The county prosecutors who will be defending their predecessors' integrity, maintain the new evidence is insignificant, and that the original 1954 verdict was correct.

"The police didn't get lost in 1954 when they accused Sam Sheppard of the murder. It was a garden-variety case of domestic violence," Bill Mason, the prosecutor who will argue the case for the state, said. "When we look at what evidence may connect Richard Eberling to the murder, we get a little pile. When we look at the evidence against Sam Sheppard, we've got a mountain."

Reese Sheppard, a 52-year-old dentist, said he will wear black to today's trial. "I'm still in mourning," he told People magazine. "And I will be until my father's name is cleared and I am allowed to fully grieve."

webTitle: Briton sought over illegal Aids treatment

fields.headline: Briton sought over illegal Aids treatment
fields.trailText: Kenyan police were last night searching for a British man who is accused of peddling an illegal treatment for Aids, which is ravaging the country. He is also wanted for probation violations in the United States.
fields.body:
Kenyan police were last night searching for a British man who is accused of peddling an illegal treatment for Aids, which is ravaging the country. He is also wanted for probation violations in the United States.

Basil Wainwright, who has served prison terms for fraud in the US and Britain - where he was convicted of defrauding the television presenter Noel Edmonds - has been charging terminally ill patients in Kenya thousands of pounds.

Mr Wainwright claims to have cured 371 HIV-positive patients since 1996.

But Richard Muga, Kenya's director of medical services, said: "This man is a conman of the highest order."

Mr Wainwright, also known as Roderick E Stone, came to Kenya in July 1996. Claiming that he could cure Aids, and that he enjoyed patronage from the highest echelons of the Kenyan government, he set up clinics and began administering his treatment, which he calls "polyatomic apheresis". It involves injecting ozone into a patient's bloodstream.

According to the country's ministry of health, more than 750,000 Kenyans out of a population of 30m have died of Aids, and a further 1.9m are infected with the HIV virus.

Mr Wainwright was given a temporary licence to practise on condition that he was providing his services freely and on a charitable basis. But in December 1996, when it emerged that he was charging huge sums of money for the treatment, this permission was rescinded.

A detailed investigation into Mr Wainwright's practices led the ministry of health to impose a comprehensive ban on the treatment in July 1998.

"Wainwright is a fraud who preys on the desperation of the terminally ill," said JW Nyikal, who led the medical authority's investigation.

"Wainwright is charming, and undoubtedly very reassuring to the sick - but the man has a criminal record, his method is suspect and he has no medical qualifications. What does he think he is doing practising medicine in Kenya?"

But Mr Wainwright continued administering his treatment. Last week medical officers raided a house in the coastal town of Mombasa after receiving information that Mr Wainwright was operating a clinic there.

Peter Kimuu, the district medical officer who led the raid, claimed Mr Wainwright and his associates had been tipped off and had removed records and equipment from the premises in advance.

"When we entered the house we found a room with 10 beds and oxygen equipment which was clearly a ward. There is no doubt in my mind that Wainwright and his associates were administering the outlawed ozone treatment there."

The authorities questioned a nurse, Elizabeth Karanja, who was in the house at the time of the raid and who admitted she was an employee of Mr Wainwright's.

Ms Karanja confirmed that they had been treating Aids patients in the house and that equipment and records had indeed been recently removed.

She said that most of the patients had been foreigners, including some Europeans.

Some of Mr Wainwright's former patients have revealed that he charges up to £23,470 for treatment. Patients are also required to sign a waiver absolving Mr Wainwright and his team of any liability.

It emerged yesterday that Mr Wainwright is heavily in debt, and one creditor, a Nairobi restaurant owner, said he had initiated legal proceedings against him.

A spokesman for the British high commission in Nairobi said: "We are aware of the case and are following it closely. We are particularly concerned at allegations of two different passports held in different names."

He said British authorities had informed Kenyan medical authorities in 1997 that Interpol had a file on the man.

Mr Wainwright was convicted and sentenced to a three-year prison term in Britain in 1983 on 22 charges of theft, forgery and false accounting. He swindled Edmonds out of £70,000.

After his release from prison he heard of the alleged medical properties of ozone - an activated form of oxygen that its proponents claim is capable of cleansing the blood of viruses.

Although variants of ozone therapy have been in use since the late 19th century its effectiveness in treating viruses has never been established.

In the late 1980s Mr Wainwright moved to Florida, where he sold his homemade ozone delivery systems. In 1990 he was sentenced to four years in prison for running an unlicensed medical practice.

The US embassy in Nairobi said he was wanted for alleged probation violations.

webTitle: Los Angeles police mired in corruption scandal

fields.headline: Los Angeles police mired in corruption scandal
fields.trailText: The corruption scandal within the Los Angeles Police Department threatens to cost tens of millions of dollars, throw the criminal justice system into confusion and darken the city's reputation at a time when it was emerging from the shadow of the Rodney King and OJ Simpson cases.
fields.body:
The corruption scandal within the Los Angeles Police Department threatens to cost tens of millions of dollars, throw the criminal justice system into confusion and darken the city's reputation at a time when it was emerging from the shadow of the Rodney King and OJ Simpson cases.

The scandal came to light in 1998 when Rafael Perez, an officer from the Rampart division of the city, was caught stealing 8lbs of cocaine from a locker storing police evidence. On February 25 he is due for sentencing in a plea bargain in which he hopes to receive a five-year term in exchange for testifying against corrupt former colleagues.

Among the worst cases in which he was involved was one in which a gang member was shot and paralysed, and framed for attempted murder.

Perez has admitted to framing 99 people whom his team arrested. More than a dozen have been freed and those with the most serious grievances are suing for millions of dollars. So far, 20 officers have been sacked or suspended.

Last week, another officer backed up Perez's claims that police routinely planted evidence on suspects - mainly gang members. Even more seriously, Perez's lawyer described shootings in which some police had been involved as "hunting" expeditions.

The LAPD's handling of the city's 409 gangs comprising 61,000 members is at the centre of the inquiry. In 1980 a special unit Crash (Community Resources Against Street Hoodlums) was formed to combat the gang problem.

In one report a police officer described its work thus: "The only way to stop the gangs is to make it so dangerous for them to do their shit that they'll be forced to stay home and watch cartoons."

The Rampart division, west of downtown LA, has around 60 gangs and 8,000 members. Currently there are about two gang killings a week.

The city is braced for an avalanche of claims for wrongful arrest and assault. The paralysed gang member has already filed a claim for $20m (£12.5) and lawyers say he is likely to receive at least $2m.

The chief of police, Bernard Parks, who was not in his post during the worst excesses, has a team of 30 officers investigating the claims. He insists that what Perez and his team did represents a small percentage of the officers and that the scandal is under control.

In turn, the police claim that gang members are using the scandal to settle scores with clean officers, and say its beneficiaries will be gang members who falsely claim that evidence was planted on them.

webTitle: Students without hope strike for a future

fields.headline: Students without hope strike for a future
fields.standfirst: Protests at plans to end free tuition have become part of a greater cause at Mexico's biggest university
fields.trailText: Behind the barricaded entrances to the National Autonomous University of Mexico campus, the striking students who have kept the country's oldest and biggest university shut since last April reveal the unease beneath their bravado.
fields.body:
Behind the barricaded entrances to the National Autonomous University of Mexico campus, the striking students who have kept the country's oldest and biggest university shut since last April reveal the unease beneath their bravado.

"After nine months we are surer than ever that we have right on our side, but outside people just don't understand," says Fernando Camacho, one of the strikers occupying Unam, a university that, with its 270,000 students, is the symbol of state-run higher education in Mexico.

Within minutes, the point is proven as the radicals speed off to the psychology faculty "to defend the struggle" against students opposed to the occupation. A false alarm, but in the past week the anti-strike movement has retaken several university buildings outside the main campus, and the "ultras" know their strike is close to breaking point.

"We are all aware that this is the most critical moment so far," says Roberto Bermudez, a sociology student.

This latest and longest strike in the history of the tradition ally rebellious Unam was triggered by plans to increase fees from a symbolic equivalent of about two US cents to about $70 (£43).

"That was the straw that broke the camel's back," says Mr Bermudez, who views the movement as a stand against globalisation that is comparable with the battle in Seattle.

The Unam strike was widely supported at first, until the student leadership ignored promises by the university authorities to suspend the proposed fee and open up the debate over modernisation.

The strikers poured scorn on the results of an official referendum on January 20 that showed overwhelming support for a return to the classroom. Now some students, quietly supported by the authorities, are trying to take back the university piecemeal by changing the balance of power in student assemblies.

"Referendum ha! ha! ha!", a student in a Che Guevara beret mocked into a microphone during a march of the radicals through central Mexico City. "We will not lift the strike until we win. Forward to victory always," she said, echoing her hero.

"They don't think they are striking. They think they are provoking a crisis in the system; they think they are making history," says Alfonso Zarate, a political analyst, explaining why the radicals did not end the strike when it had apparently achieved its main aims.

Not that Unam is a stranger to history. In October 1968 the massacre of hundreds of students leading a pro-democracy movement marked a watershed in Mexican politics. It is the fear of rekindling those memories that Mr Zarate says has prevented the Mexican president, Ernesto Zedillo, from storming the campus. Sending in the police or army remains the least likely option.

"This occupation would never have been allowed to survive so long in many European countries or in the United States," says Mr Zarate, who as a student in 1968 left Tlatelolco square just minutes before the soldiers opened fire.

Despite Mexico's reputation for violence, and constant warnings that the strike could degenerate, the nine-month standoff has produced remarkably few violent incidents.

But while the past may help to account for the passivity of the authorities and the sparseness of firebombs, it fails to explain the sudden explosion in student radicalism.

Gone are the dreamers of 1968. Mr Zarate says today's movement belongs to a new class of those without hope, created by recent economic transformations and crises that have hit the middle classes hard and the working classes even harder.

Educated in a swollen state system suffering from deteriorating academic standards, the "ultras" have little stake in the future, he says.

Back behind the barricades, Mr Camacho, 20, says he thinks of the student movement "less as the vanguard of a revolution, more as an example of conscious rebellion".

"Democracy does not always produce the right choice," he says of the referendum.

"What makes us sure we are right is the experience of knowing that we are screwed. The experience of thinking, 'what is going to happen to me?'."

fields.headline: Germany caught in far-right controversy
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: Austria's far right
fields.trailText: The issue of how much freedom should be given to the extreme right is high on the political agenda throughout the German-speaking world today after a weekend in which there were dramatic moves in opposing directions.
fields.body:
The issue of how much freedom should be given to the extreme right is high on the political agenda throughout the German-speaking world today after a weekend in which there were dramatic moves in opposing directions.

The publicly-funded German television network, ARD, yesterday unexpectedly withdrew an invitation to the far right Austrian leader Jörg Haider to appear on a leading talk show.

The move came after hundreds of neo-Nazis were allowed to march through the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin - the first such display since the fall of the Third Reich.

Mr Haider had been scheduled to appear in a debate with Daniel Cohn-Bendit - "Danny the Red" of the 1968 Paris students' revolt - Germany's interior minister, Otto Schily, and the deputy leader of the Jewish community, Michel Friedman.

But, in a statement faxed to news organisations, ARD indicated that the other participants had threatened to withdraw if Mr Haider, whose party is negotiating to enter the government in Austria, was among the guests.

The statement added: "We still believe that it is better that rightwing populists like Haider should be engaged in discussion rather than ignored or isolated.

"But our conditions have always been that leading representatives of Jewish organisations and German government should sit opposite him. After this proved unrealistic, despite promises, the editors of the show came to their decision."

It was not clear whether the channel or its guests had come under pressure from the authorities. But the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, said in remarks published yesterday: "Developments in Austria fill me with concern."

His views, in an interview with the rightwing tabloid Bild am Sonntag, were clearly aimed at the section of the population in which sympathy for Mr Haider's anti-immigrant views is strongest. Mr Schröder's government has been moving in the opposite direction, taking steps to naturalise a large part of Germany's immigrant community.

All concerned with the Haider interview seem to have been wrong-footed by the decision late on Friday to let the neo-Nazis stage their demonstration. A court in Berlin overruled a ban imposed by the police, saying that freedom of speech should take priority.

The protest was the most extreme expression so far of the backlash in several parts of Europe against recent events to commemorate the Holo caust. It was called to protest against a national monument honouring Jews who were murdered under the Third Reich.

On Thursday, German Jewish leaders and politicians, including Mr Schröder, dedicated a tract of land in the centre of Berlin on which a maze of concrete pillars resembling a huge graveyard is to be built. About 600 neo-Nazis gathered at the site on Saturday to hear Udo Voigt, the chairman of the fringe National Democratic party (NPD), describe the project as "an undesirable stain on the Reich capital".

Around 500 Germans shouting "Nazis out" staged a counter protest nearby. Police briefly detained about 25 neo-Nazis when they started singing SS songs, but riot police kept the two groups well apart and only one scuffle occurred.

The publicly-funded German television network, ARD, yesterday unexpectedly withdrew an invitation to the far right Austrian leader Jörg Haider to appear on a leading talk show. The move came after hundreds of neo-Nazis were allowed to march through the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin - the first such display since the fall of the Third Reich. Mr Haider had been scheduled to appear in a debate with Daniel Cohn-Bendit - "Danny the Red" of the 1968 Paris students' revolt - Germany's interior minister, Otto Schily, and the deputy leader of the Jewish community, Michel Friedman. But, in a statement faxed to news organisations, ARD indicated that the other participants had threatened to withdraw if Mr Haider, whose party is negotiating to enter the government in Austria, was among the guests. The statement added: "We still believe that it is better that rightwing populists like Haider should be engaged in discussion rather than ignored or isolated. "But our conditions have always been that leading representatives of Jewish organisations and German government should sit opposite him. After this proved unrealistic, despite promises, the editors of the show came to their decision." It was not clear whether the channel or its guests had come under pressure from the authorities. webTitle: Birthday party adulation fest for Haider

fields.headline: Birthday party adulation fest for Haider
fields.standfirst:
As Austria's extreme rightwing Freedom party prepares for power, its leader stages an Alpine love-in.

The issue explained: Austria's far right
fields.trailText: As the sun began setting in the mountains and weary skiers sipped their last schnapps of the day, a colourful parade suddenly whooshed out of the dusk.
fields.byline: Kate Connolly  in the Gerlitzen mountains near Villach, Austria
fields.body:
As the sun began setting in the mountains and weary skiers sipped their last schnapps of the day, a colourful parade suddenly whooshed out of the dusk.

Jörg Haider, the leader of Austria's far-right Freedom party, gripped the bar of the bobsleigh with one hand and waved at his fans with the other. Either side of him, lines of pretty ski instructors holding pink lanterns led the tanned populist into the specially constructed snow arena.

"It's like a triumphal procession," said one young female onlooker holding a bouquet of flowers to present to him. "He deserves such respect and we're going to lay it on thick."

The man whose recent electoral success has shattered postwar consensus politics in Austria and set the European Union on edge was celebrating his 50th birthday, which fell on Wednesday.

To mark the occasion, the governor of the southern province of Carinthia handed out 5,000 ski passes to party members, friends and journalists, proving once again his ability to tap into Austria's psyche by milking its obsession with snow sports.

The invitations had billed Saturday's £500,000 celebration, held on the summit of the Gerlitzen mountain range, as "the biggest party the region has ever experienced".

Mr Haider, whose party has edged ever closer to power in the past couple of weeks, was taking a day off from coalition talks with the conservative People's party. But the occasion was as much about his political success as his reaching half a century.

Mr Haider admitted on Friday that last week's collapse of socialist-conservative coalition talks, which have paved the way for him to take the chancellorship, had been "the best birthday present ever". It marked the fulfilment of his lifelong ambition to crush the traditional party system.

He spent the day attempting to woo journalists, skiing with them from one mountain hut to another where different surprises had been laid on, in what one critic who had managed to slip into the ski-lift queue unnoticed said was "a pure adulation fest".

As Mr Haider donned a leather apron and "tapped open" a new beer barrel - an honour usually reserved for dignitaries - one party official remarked: "The 50th birthday of Haider, although an important occasion in its own right, also marks the beginning of a new era for Austria."

The keen mountaineer sported a colourful ski suit and rucksack and was accompanied by his wife, Claudia. The first stop for the party saw Mr Haider being serenaded by a choir dressed in hunting uniforms as children ran around clad in fir tree branches in celebration of the region's bear-hunting past.

Mr Haider joined in the singing of traditional folk songs and even took the microphone himself to sing a ballad about a shepherd leaving his alpine pasture for warmer climes as winter sets in.

But he was interrupted as four sunshine-yellow Austrian air force planes made a fly-past in tribute to him.

The head pilot, a friend of Mr Haider's, later told the crowds: "I hope we symbolise a new wind sweeping through our country."

Blue, the Freedom party's official colour, dominated the day - blue balloons marked with his trademark signature "Jörg" hung in the bare trees; the snowmobile that transported non-skiers was Freedom party-blue; blue sashes were attached to the beams of the huts, and the predominantly young crowd ate a barbecued mix of scrambled egg and pork from blue frying pans.

The similarly hued flag of the EU was stuck in the snow tucked away behind the mountain hut. "It doesn't have a place here at all," one Haider supporter said.

The partygoers withstood a sharp wind and temperatures of -10C (14F) by stoking up on the so-called "Jörg menu" - pale blue schnapps miniatures called "Stand Up Little Fellow" and "Jörg Bear Beer" (blue of course), which had been specially brewed for the occasion.

After skiing in at the third pitstop through a specially constructed "victory gate" adorned with all the regional flags of Austria, Mr Haider was presented with gifts of mountaineering equipment, an exercise bike and a two-week holiday in the province of Styria, along with baskets of Austrian cheeses, wines, pretzels, numerous portraits and figurines of himself and paintings of Austrian mountain scenes. One group of fans announced that they had named a star after him.

The weekly magazine News commented that Mr Haider was "no longer the suitor but the desired bride".

As he signed autographs and joked with party members, many of whom he recruited by searching them out in Carinthia's discos, Mr Haider again proved his ability to woo the public.His next challenge is to use these talents to win over Vienna's political and intellectual establishment.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Italy told to shut 'cruel' hostels
fields.body:
Italy told to shut 'cruel' hostels

The Italian government came under increasing pressure yesterday to close down immigration centres condemned by critics as inhumane and illegal.

Protests were held in several cities on Saturday and police fired tear gas at thousands of demonstrators in Milan. Interior Minister Enzo Bianco vowed that sub-standard centres would be closed. Reuters, Rome

Cuba hails grandmothers

Cuba is planning a huge welcome for the grandmothers of Elian Gonzalez when they return from the US - without the six-year-old boy.

"The heroic behaviour of these humble and kind grandmothers has won the respect and admiration of the people," said a statement in state newspapers.

The grandmothers flew to the US nine days ago to lobby for the return of Elian, who is at the centre of an international custody battle. Reuters, Havana

Casino bites the dust in Reno

One of the oldest hotel-casinos in the US was dyna mited yesterday in what is seen as a major defeat for historic preservationists.

Thousands gathered in central Reno, Nevada, to pay their last respects to the art deco Mapes Hotel. City leaders had battled for years with the National Trust for Historic Preservation which listed the Mapes in 1998 as one of the 11 most endangered places in North America. AP, Reno

French truckers plan blockades

French truckers protesting a reduction in their working week from 39 hours to 35 were preparing road blockades across the country yesterday. Coinciding with public transport strikes on Tuesday, they were expected to cause traffic chaos. Reuters, Paris

fields.headline: No: 1567 Wuvvie
fields.trailText: What on earth is it? Something to do with Roy Jenkins? Or Jonathan Ross? Glad we got the speech impediment joke over early. No - it's a toy.
fields.body:
What on earth is it? Something to do with Roy Jenkins? Or Jonathan Ross? Glad we got the speech impediment joke over early. No - it's a toy.

A toy? You mean you give that to children? Terrifying isn't it? They may scare the bejaysus out of anyone over 11, but these little blindingly neon furballs are about to conquer the world. Think Furbies. Think Teletubbies. Think Gremlins.

Gremlins? Those psychotic little pets that reproduced when you poured water on them? Thank God they died with puffball skirts. Dust off your legwarmers. Gremlins by any other name are back. Except these ones don't even need water.

You don't mean... Yes I do. Parents beware - if you thought a randy hamster was bad, these beasties are blessed with a frightening fecundity. A little pat on the back has them making little babby-wabby wuvvies. One in 12 even has twins.

Well at least it's a useful lesson in cell division in the reproductive cycle. Well yes, if you want your kids to believe that babies pop from the belly after half an hour's back rubbing and a few bleebs.

Always worked for me... Easy. There are children present. Although to be fair, they may have other educational qualities. Wuvvies, according to the PR guff, are "more intelligent than any other toy currently available".

Let me guess, they burble quantum physics while in labour. Not quite, but your kids' vocabulary will certainly be enhanced. Wuvvies have a range of 2,000 words - getting on for Shakespearean. And immediately the sprog is dropped, they pick their own moniker for the little monster. It's beautiful.

What, like Big Ted? Little Ted? Jemima? Humpty? Hamble? Enough of the legwarmers already. No, Wuvvies prefer the onomatopoeic school of nomenclature. "Is it Bingle or Bongle? Tumtum or Bleeps? Wonky or Lonk? Moo Moo or Yeep?"

Not to be confused with: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Cabbage Patch Dolls, Tinky-Winky, Pokemon, Frank Dobson.

fields.headline: 'I can't read the future'
fields.standfirst: When the Mail's astrologer resigned, they offered him £2m to stay. He explains how he made a fortune from forecasts that stretch his 'belief system'.
fields.trailText: When the Mail's astrologer resigned, they offered him £2m to stay. He explains how he made a fortune from forecasts that stretch his 'belief system'.
fields.body:
Jonathan Cainer (Sagittarius) Britain's highest earning astrologer, usually smokes a pipe. "But the truth is," he says, drawing sharply on a Camel Light, "you cannot smoke a pipe in crisis. Normally it fits perfectly well - getting into a meditative state, looking at what the planets are doing, you light your pipe and you think" - he closes his eyes and nods his head back and forth - "Hmm, what shall I say for Aries today?" He opens them again and bangs the packet on the table. "But dealing with lawyers and on the phone and crisis meetings, I haven't got time for a pipe. It's, ' Find me some fags, quick .' "

Cainer, 42, is having a mad time at the moment. He's a chain-smoking newspaper man these days, not a mystic. Though hopefully things will settle down now. Today he finally joins the Express after a month of legal wrangling with his former employers the Daily Mail. He decided to leave in December after a scrap relating to his highly lucrative phone lines. He was on a 50-50 deal with them, which added an extra £500,000 to his annual £80,000 basic. He needed a bit of leeway on this. "I wanted to say, 'Guys, freeze your current income levels and let me expand things, tarot lines, that sort of stuff. And they just demonstrated an attitude to me. I could almost hear the pat on the head, 'Look, run along little astrologer, we're busy.' "

So he ran along to Rosie Boycott (Taurean - "typically stubborn") at the Express, who was just off to deliver a bread oven to Bosnia. "And I thought: 'Oh damn, I was going to try really hard to drive a big financial deal and now she's got me. I'm going to have to work for her now.'" He's always been a Guardian man anyway and working for the Mail had been seven years of "sticking up a voice for reason", of trying to "counterbalance" the prejudices of the rest of the paper. "There was a classic occasion when the Mail went rabid over Redwood. You didn't have to be an astrologer to see he was a long shot. There was one glorious day when the whole Mail was dedicated to Redwood this, Redwood that and finally you get to the horoscope page, right at the back of the book, and there tucked away next to the cartoon was a little lone voice saying the man hasn't got a chance. After that I got a bit more respect from them."

The Mail didn't want him to go - "Horoscopes sell papers," says Cainer - and when the offer of a £1m salary plus another £1m bonus didn't wash, they threatened to sue him for breach of contract. He'd have gone to prison he says, but luckily he hasn't had to. He's writing in the Express for free. "Though I get to keep my phone lines. Basically Jonathan Cainer can set up his stall. I'm coming but I keep my licensing and marketing rights." He gives a broad Cheshire-cat grin, in which his very white replacement top teeth seem to glint in the light. "If all this attention translates into hard cash, I've cracked it."

To visit Jonathan Cainer, a stocky man in a crumpled suit with a bald head and a steady, dark-eyed stare, at his headquarters (25 employees, mainly women, mainly long-haired) in the centre of York, is to enter a world in which the sky is ecliptic, the house system is porphyry and the lunar node is mean. You can't be sensitive here without being "extraordinarily intuitive", you can't have a temper without it "erupting into a supernova". There is a shop front where you can get a quickie horoscope printout (£3.99) and a bag of powdered myrrh and there is "out the back" from where the internet site (worth £50m) is run and the phone lines are organised and the mail order business is managed and the personal profiles (£22) are sent out. My heavy-bound, 35-page astrological report takes four minutes to produce. "Er... normally we try and conceal how quickly these are done," says Cainer.

He gives you a lot of blurb about planetary positions, but he's the first to admit that he's got Mercury in Capricorn which "blesses you with the ability to sound like you know what you're talking about even when you're spouting rubbish". He is also likeably frank about his profession. "Let's be clear about this. I believe in astrology. Astrology is a belief system, not an art or a science, though there is a bit of art and science chucked in, and I am a true subscriber to that belief. But my belief system gets a bit stretched when I find myself in the game of forecasting for a 12th of the population."

Star signs, he says, are not what it's about, but if you are involved in the "commercial side of things", if you have "sold out and are standing there naked doing ridiculous things", you might as well do it properly. "I have a formula that I never deviate from. If you work on the basis that life is tough but never mind, one of these days it will take a turn for the better, you can't go wrong. If you turn to most people and acknowledge the fact that they're having a crap time, you'll find very few people who'll say, 'No, I'm not.' You read your horoscope when your partner's splitting up from you, when your domestic life is crap. You look at your horoscope because you're desperate, you'll look anywhere. So to that extent it makes no difference what sign you are, or where the planets are. My job is to be philosophical and to offer encouragement, to say, 'Look, when you're in a rough period, learn through it.' Lucy the five cents psychoanalyst from Peanuts. I am that Lucy, yes."

As for the lucrative phone lines, he says: "Look, what are they? Glorified answering machines. Twelve. One for Aries, Taurus... With lots of lines going in. That's all they blooming well are. The overheads are bugger all. The costs are bugger all. And you can buy the equipment for less than 25 grand. That's a hell of a big profit margin..."

Cainer hasn't always been an astrologer. He was born in Surbiton but when his parents split up when he was 13, he went to live in Leeds with his mother (once a medical secretary, now a spiritual healer) and twin brothers, and soon dropped out of school to become a petrol attendant. He was in a band called Strange Cloud before, "fancying myself a bit of an entrepreneur", he fetched up in LA. Here he touted his brother around as a singer, managed a nightclub and met a pyschic poet called Charles John Quatro. Back in England, he lived on "this glorious thing called social security" and studied at the Faculty of Astrological Studies in London. His first astrological job was at Today - which he also left in a phone line dispute. "I've been making money from them for a long time. I don't know if people know that. Well, the tax man certainly knows." At that point a small object whizzes past my ear and makes me jump. It's a 50p piece that had been balancing on the top of the sofa. Cainer laughs, "That's what happens if you sit around here. Money falls on to you."

Horoscopes and money. Money and horoscopes. It is hard, in conversation with Cainer, to disentangle the two. Until you start talking personally. In 1992, Cainer's wife, Melanie, died in surgery after a car crash. "She popped out to the shops and had an altercation with a lorry," he says in an attempt at frivolity. He didn't get to see her in hospital after the accident because he was at home looking after the seven children they had between them, including two still breast-fed seven-month twins. "My favourite song," he says: "You picked a fine time to leave me, Lucille." You realise when he talks about this how bluff he tends to be even on subjects that are close to him.

And then suddenly he reports a conversation he had with Melanie, after the accident. I look puzzled. And he says, "Oh yeah, I was serving tea to the kids and suddenly - sound and vision in the corner of the room. It was Mel in a strange blue light, looking serene. She said: 'Jon I think I'm going...' I said: 'No you're not, I need you here.' She said: 'No, no I think I am...' So I wasn't too surprised when the doctor later told me she'd died in surgery. I said I thought as much."

Did you really say that? "Maybe I didn't. I've learnt you have to be careful how much you tell people about the communications with the dead. Everyone assumes you're a bit of a nutter, but sorry, I have. I've had innumerable conversations with her since." He's got a locked room at his house with all her things in it. He made a housing for the bins where she wanted it. He painted the bathroom the colour blue she chose. He looks down at his hands. "She only really moved further away when I got help with childcare," he adds sadly.

He's had "light relationships - plural" since, but nothing serious. "I'm quite sure I'll never get married again." Has he looked at his chart to check? "Absolutely not, I hate having my fortune told. I loathe and detest being told by anybody what the stars have in store for me. Anyway," he leans forward and shouts into the microphone, "Astrologers can't read the future. Astrologers can't read the future. Astrologers can't read the future."

He sits back and says again quietly, in a normal voice, "No I'm quite sure I'll never get married again." He says it with no bluster, no mysticism. Typical Sagittarius.

I'm coming but I keep my licensing and marketing rights." He gives a broad Cheshire-cat grin, in which his very white replacement top teeth seem to glint in the light. "If all this attention translates into hard cash, I've cracked it." To visit Jonathan Cainer, a stocky man in a crumpled suit with a bald head and a steady, dark-eyed stare, at his headquarters (25 employees, mainly women, mainly long-haired) in the centre of York, is to enter a world in which the sky is ecliptic, the house system is porphyry and the lunar node is mean. You can't be sensitive here without being "extraordinarily intuitive", you can't have a temper without it "erupting into a supernova". There is a shop front where you can get a quickie horoscope printout (£3.99) and a bag of powdered myrrh and there is "out the back" from where the internet site (worth £50m) is run and the phone lines are organised and the mail order business is managed and the personal profiles (£22) are sent out. My heavy-bound, 35-page astrological report takes four minutes to produce. "Er... normally we try and conceal how quickly these are done," says Cainer. He gives you a lot of blurb about planetary positions, but he's the first to admit that he's got Mercury in Capricorn which "blesses you with the ability to sound like you know what you're talking about even when you're spouting rubbish". He is also likeably frank about his profession. "Let's be clear about this. I believe in astrology. Astrology is a belief system, not an art or a science, though there is a bit of art and science chucked in, and I am a true subscriber to that belief. But my belief system gets a bit stretched when I find myself in the game of forecasting for a 12th of the population." Star signs, he says, are not what it's about, but if you are involved in the "commercial side of things", if you have "sold out and are standing there naked doing ridiculous things", you might as well do it properly. "I have a formula that I never deviate from. If you work on the basis that life is tough but never mind, one of these days it will take a turn for the better, you can't go wrong. If you turn to most people and acknowledge the fact that they're having a crap time, you'll find very few people who'll say, 'No, I'm not.' You read your horoscope when your partner's splitting up from you, when your domestic life is crap. You look at your horoscope because you're desperate, you'll look anywhere. So to that extent it makes no difference what sign you are, or where the planets are. My job is to be philosophical and to offer encouragement, to say, 'Look, when you're in a rough period, learn through it.' Lucy the five cents psychoanalyst from Peanuts. I am that Lucy, yes." As for the lucrative phone lines, he says: "Look, what are they? Glorified answering machines. Twelve. One for Aries, Taurus... With lots of lines going in. That's all they blooming well are. The overheads are bugger all. The costs are bugger all. And you can buy the equipment for less than 25 grand. That's a hell of a big profit margin..." Cainer hasn't always been an astrologer. He was born in Surbiton but when his parents split up when he was 13, he went to live in Leeds with his mother (once a medical secretary, now a spiritual healer) and twin brothers, and soon dropped out of school to become a petrol attendant. He was in a band called Strange Cloud before, "fancying myself a bit of an entrepreneur", he fetched up in LA. Here he touted his brother around as a singer, managed a nightclub and met a pyschic poet called Charles John Quatro. Back in England, he lived on "this glorious thing called social security" and studied at the Faculty of Astrological Studies in London. His first astrological job was at Today - which he also left in a phone line dispute. "I've been making money from them for a long time. I don't know if people know that. Well, the tax man certainly knows." At that point a small object whizzes past my ear and makes me jump. It's a 50p piece that had been balancing on the top of the sofa. Cainer laughs, "That's what happens if you sit around here. Money falls on to you." Horoscopes and money. Money and horoscopes. It is hard, in conversation with Cainer, to disentangle the two. Until you start talking personally. In 1992, Cainer's wife, Melanie, died in surgery after a car crash. "She popped out to the shops and had an altercation with a lorry," he says in an attempt at frivolity. He didn't get to see her in hospital after the accident because he was at home looking after the seven children they had between them, including two still breast-fed seven-month twins. "My favourite song," he says: "You picked a fine time to leave me, Lucille." You realise when he talks about this how bluff he tends to be even on subjects that are close to him. And then suddenly he reports a conversation he had with Melanie, after the accident. I look puzzled. And he says, "Oh yeah, I was serving tea to the kids and suddenly - sound and vision in the corner of the room. It was Mel in a strange blue light, looking serene. She said: 'Jon I think I'm going...' I said: 'No you're not, I need you here.' She said: 'No, no I think I am...' So I wasn't too surprised when the doctor later told me she'd died in surgery. I said I thought as much." Did you really say that? "Maybe I didn't. I've learnt you have to be careful how much you tell people about the communications with the dead. Everyone assumes you're a bit of a nutter, but sorry, I have. I've had innumerable conversations with her since." He's got a locked room at his house with all her things in it. He made a housing for the bins where she wanted it. He painted the bathroom the colour blue she chose. He looks down at his hands. "She only really moved further away when I got help with childcare," he adds sadly. He's had "light relationships - plural" since, but nothing serious. "I'm quite sure I'll never get married again." Has he looked at his chart to check? "Absolutely not, I hate having my fortune told. I loathe and detest being told by anybody what the stars have in store for me. Anyway," he leans forward and shouts into the microphone, "Astrologers can't read the future. Astrologers can't read the future. Astrologers can't read the future." He sits back and says again quietly, in a normal voice, "No I'm quite sure I'll never get married again." He says it with no bluster, no mysticism. Typical Sagittarius.

fields.headline: Me and my motor
fields.standfirst: Leslie Phillips
fields.trailText: Leslie Phillips
fields.body:
What vehicles do you own?

I have a Jag for motorway bashing but my chariot is a beautiful Mercedes Cabriolet, a 220 SE made in 1965 - the last of the line. I call it "the drop head".

How much would it be worth now?

I don't know - probably around £50,000. I paid £5,000 for it back in the 60s.

What does the Merc say about you?

30 years ago it said I was a bit of a devil.

Why did you buy it?

At the time I was car mad, especially for Bentleys. One day a car salesman said he had something that would suit me. I wasn't interested at first but he turned up out of the blue with the car and as soon as I saw it I was in love.

What do you like about it?

It's a joy to put the hood down and when I do everyone says "Wow!". But I don't pick up girls any more. There are always little notes left on the windscreen asking if I want to sell it (all offers considered!).

Have you ever had your car vandalised?

I can't take it out because people want to kick or scratch it. Dogs want to pee on it. It's not taxed but I'm putting it on the road next year.

What kind of driver are you?

Good. I took, and passed, my advanced driving test in a 1924 Bentley which I drove in the film The Fast Lady. The examiner was impressed - he said he'd never been in a Bentley before.

Any bad habits?

No - or at least no one dares tell me. I'm courteous.

Have you ever crashed/got a speeding ticket/any points etc?

I had one serious crash about three months ago in the Jag. I spun off the road on a difficult corner and went round and round in circles, ending up near a burial ground! I didn't injure myself nor anyone else but it cost a lot to put the car right.

Have you experienced road rage?

I was once chased by a big bloke who didn't like a turning I made, but when he recognised my face he instantly forgot all his hatred. He went from being a road-rager to a sweetie and even wanted his picture taken with me.

Have you ever had sex in a car?

Oh I think so! I've enjoyed myself. You can in a Bentley.

What do you listen to on the road?

Recently I've not wanted to have the radio on because I find it distracting. You've got to be a damn good driver these days. In the past I've enjoyed Radio 3.

Who would be your dream passenger? Why?

Anyone who's not a bloody nuisance or a bore.

Do you ever get recognised?

All the time. Usually if someone sees a nice car they shout something aggressive but when they see it's me they change. It's not a penalty - they seem to like me.

 Leslie Phillips appears in On the Whole It's Been Jolly Good which opens tonight at Hampstead Theatre in London

fields.headline: Road test
fields.standfirst: VW Polo
fields.trailText: VW Polo
fields.body:
It might be a bad time for new car sales but one segment is doing OK - the cheery hatchbacks we're told are bought as second cars for spouses, nannies or spoilt students. In truth, the supermini has grown up and now deserves centre stage on your drive. The latest Clio is roomier and smoother, the Vauxhall Corsa's acquired slick undersprings and the Y2K Fiat Punto shows an Italian knockabout doesn't have to be a bit of rough.

So it's no surprise that Volkswagen has been rethinking the ubiquitous Polo. The current generation of the car is now five years down the line, so if VW is to match pace with the freshest rivals it needs to administer some sprucing-up.

Not that you'll see any such words from VW. This car, officially, is 80% new. True, the front now has a big grown-up grille, and the rear end is tidier because the number plate is tucked underneath. But apart from that, Polos old and new are as indistinguishable as mints in a packet.

Amid the engines and trim, however, lurks the promise of hot news: VW is to unleash a new design of diesel technology, badged 1.4TDI. This car - not the new GTI - is the one to bag. It's got a respectable-sounding 75bhp, all of which comes from a three-cylinder diesel engine. At idle speed, it's an unmistakeable diesel. Yet as soon as you shift the throttle, it quietens down; from here on, it's wonderfully smooth and quiet and - with maximum clout delivered at just 2,200rpm - the car's a true firework.

Though not quite a disgrace, the GTI(shown below) falls short of its badge heritage. It's far noisier and less dramatic than a GTI should be and it suffers an endemic VW problem: having put on weight for the sake of safety, it feels ponderous to drive and out of touch with the road. Against the dashing and more nimble likes of Peugeot's 206 GTI, VW's avowed rival, this Polo's on tricky ground.

Other petrol options are a 1.0 litre, 1.3, 1.4 and, as an extra diesel, a 1.9. Prices will kick off at £8,500 and peter out somewhere near £15,000. Rod McLeod, VW's Mr Polo, estimates only 2% of his sales will be the TDI, which will be available in luxury spec only and will cost about £12,700. Given its performance and an average fuel figure of 64.2mpg, I reckon he'd best order a few more.

fields.headline: Mad, bad and dangerous
fields.standfirst: It's colonised America, now it's taking over here. Run for the hills, says  Lesley Hazleton, the 'sports utility vehicle' is one evil lump of metal
fields.trailText: It's colonised America, now it's taking over here. Run for the hills, says  Lesley Hazleton, the 'sports utility vehicle' is one evil lump of metal
fields.body:
Time was, I'd joke about sport-utes - that army of descendants of the once-modest military jeep, gone upscale and urban chic. At least, I thought I was joking. "It's a conspiracy," I'd say. "It's all a plot to get us to spend more on new metal. Make us turn in our cars and buy something bigger and more expensive. Use more petrol and pay more insurance and spend more on repairs."

That was 10 years ago. Since then, sport-utes (aka sport-utility vehicles, SUVs, or "utes" for short) have spawned at so alarming a rate that many people here in the US are buying them in self-defence. It's either get into one yourself, or be condemned to drive surrounded by them on the road, feeling more and more ant-like by the minute. The next thing you know, you're paying $40,000 (£25,000) for a $20,000 pickup truck with at most $1,000 of extra metal, seating, and carpeting.

Now I hear that the invasion has reached across the Atlantic, where you don't even have the excuse that petrol is only a fifth the price of Evian water. So allow me to offer a few words of gentle warning before you write your annual cheque to Greenpeace and then drive to the supermarket in a three-ton, four-wheel-drive vehicle that does 10 miles to the gallon and handles like a tank.

Consider, first, the little question of image. 10 years ago, at the start of the ute invasion, pre-Daimler Chrysler hired a team of anthropologists to determine the appeal of its Jeep division. They fingered a capitalized cultural artifact known as "Nature". Sport-ute owners apparently want to consume nature as well as metal. Or more precisely, the image of nature as drummed home in endless commercials: utes by deep-woods waterfalls, utes atop mountain ranges, utes by pristine lakes.

Successful marketing could be defined as the victory of fantasy over reality, and sport-ute marketing is a classic example. How else can you sell something that endangers the environment in the name of worshipping it?

Not that ute owners actually do go in much for the wilderness. That's the good news. Even in the furthest wilds of the American west - Seattle and San Francisco and Los Angeles - they spend their lives as urban and suburban cruisers.

This makes sense. Unless the vehicles in question are OPC (other people's cars, driven mainly by testosterone-happy soldiers and members of the automotive press), what fool is going to take a $40,000 vehicle off-road and risk getting the paintwork scratched or the suspension banged up? Even manufacturers admit that only 3% of their customers ever take their utes off-road. Discount gravel driveways, and it's under 1%.

In fact, there's little either sporty or utilitarian about sport-utes. True, watching a driver trying to manoeuvre one into a supermarket parking spot is a new form of spectator sport. And I suppose using a ute to drop the kids off at school could be considered a tad more utilitarian than using a Ferrari. But the only thing that really makes them sporty is the element of risk.

No rugged outdoorsman or incipient wildwoman would want to forgo risk, of course, and sport-utes oblige extravagantly. Watch the news coverage of the next snow or ice storm, and see the utes doing 360s in the middle of the road.

Or take one onto a slalom course to test its maker's claim of "car-like handling," as I did once, and find out what it's like to try to induce an elephant to tango. The ute wallowed spectacularly through every turn, listing alarmingly. I'm not sure whether it was physics or fear that made me feel sick.

Seduced by the joy of riding high in what car salesmen call "the master driving position," ute owners tend to enter whole hog into the big-bad-and-dangerous-to-know thing. "Anyone else had better keep out of my way and not mess with me," crowed one Land Cruiser-wielding lawyer in my mild hometown of Seattle, "because I'm bigger than they are." She's five-foot-four. And suffering from the illusion of ute-conferred invulnerability.

That higher seating comes by way of a higher centre of gravity. Which means it's far easier to tip utes than cars. And tip they do, quite reliably.

Single vehicle crashes - mainly rollovers - account for nearly half of all fatal crashes in the States. Most of them involve sport-utes or pickup trucks. And of those, 92% happen because of that high centre of gravity. The ute gets "tripped" by a curb or a guard rail, loses balance, and rolls. Still, if you manage to stay upright, there is something to the invulnerability thing. Because now comes the clincher to my conspiracy theory: in a crash, the heavier vehicle tends to inflict the damage, the lighter vehicle to suffer it - especially when the heavier vehicle has bumpers that ride high over the lighter one's, thus ramming straight into the passenger compartment. Two or three tons of ute colliding with one ton of mini is what's called an uneven contest. If you're in the mini, you'll pay the price for the ute-owner's addiction to size. Statistics show that when cars and utes collide, 80% of the fatalities are in the cars.

This may make the sport-ute the most psychopathic vehicle yet invented for civilian use. Fearful that someone might say just that, manufacturers recently announced that they would add low bumper-bars, depriving them of some of their battering-ram ability. But as though to make up for this munificent consideration of public health, they've also intensified the size war. The current leader is the Ford Excursion. Nearly 20ft long and seven feet high, it weighs in at well over four tons. I hear it's selling big in Texas.

Most auto-biz analysts, seduced by soaring dividends, see no end to ute mania. But there are a few sharp-eyed doubters. "The auto business is a fashion business," says Chris Cedergren of Nextrend, a forecasting and consulting firm, "especially with a product like the upscale sport-ute. As with all fashion, the moment it gets so hot that everyone has to have it, the image begins to cool down. I think that's beginning to happen now."

Sales stay high but have started to level off. And there are signs of incipient resistance. Luxo-utes are getting keyed in parking lots. Their owners risk clambering down to ground level to face sneers of derision. Some have found their vehicles plastered overnight with bumper stickers saying "I pollute" - not exactly the height of wit, but sometimes even the bluntly obvious can reach its target.

And Jeep-ready rugged individualist though I am - well, individualist at any rate - with more than my share of daring, I now find myself acutely self-conscious when test- driving a luxo-ute on any road narrower than a highway. I look down from my master driving position at the latest station wagons and think "Hey, they look really stylish." I watch nifty little roadsters cut in front of me, tails waggling, and think: "I could buy two of those for one of these." I glance at the gauges and wonder where the petrol went. And when I get home, I write another cheque to Greenpeace.

Lesley Hazleton's book Driving to Detroit is published by Scribner UK. She is the motoring columnist for the Detroit Free Press
