fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Graham Brady is the Conservative MP for Altrincham and Sale West, Leader, page 21, January 27. Wythenshawe and Sale East has a Labour MP, Paul Goggins.
fields.body:

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Utilities bill a wildlife threat
fields.body:
Utilities bill a wildlife threat

The government's utilities bill, envisaging electricity cuts of at least 10%, would have a negative impact on Britain's wildlife, the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds said last night.

The legislation, due to receive its second reading in the commons today, should bring substantial reductions in domestic and commercial bills.

The RSPB said the price cuts would encourage further over-abstraction of water from rivers and important wetland sites

US appeals for belt tightening

In a speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, US Treasury Secretary Larry Summers appealed to debt laden American consumers to tighten their belts. He said the economy was in good shape but it was a mistake to over interpret the relationship between strong growth and new technology.

"The laws of economics have not been repealed, much less those of human psychology," said Mr Summers.

WH Smith buys Hazlewood

WH Smith, the UK's biggest book retailer, said it had paid £11.7m for the US book chain Hazlewood.

The acquisition of Hazlewood's 70 shops which are mainly in hotels, fits with WH Smith's strategy of positioning outlets near large numbers of customers. In the US 300 of WH Smith's 450 existing shops are in hotels and airports.

fields.headline: SFO in racehorse chase
fields.standfirst: Sentencing of City fraudster delayed as investigators follow £32m trail
fields.trailText: A self confessed fraudster who lost his City firm £32m may be trying to hide from the crown a large chunk of the money that disappeared, the Guardian has been told.
fields.body:
A self confessed fraudster who lost his City firm £32m may be trying to hide from the crown a large chunk of the money that disappeared, the Guardian has been told.

Peter Leonard, a former commodities broker at investment firm Muirpace is thought to have more than 90 racehorses, based mainly in France, as part of a haul of fraudulently acquired possessions.

Leonard, of Chislehurst, Kent, took the unusual step of pleading guilty to magistrates when he was arraigned before City of London JPs on November 26. He was aged 49 at the time. His sentencing at the Old Bailey had been expected sometime this month, but has been put off.

It now emerges that the reason for this is the Serious Fraud Office's need for more time to investigate allegations that Leonard has hidden way millions of pounds of the Muirpace "losses" in property and bloodstock. The Guardian understands the SFO will ask for another adjournment tomorrow for a further two months.

Authorities in France and the Isle of Man have been asked to help the inquiry, but such requests are time consuming. It is thought the crown fears that Leonard may be sentenced by a crown court judge not in possession of all the facts.

Leonard's solicitor Stephen Pollard said his client "denies having any interest today in any racehorses". He added that Leonard had in the past traded horses on behalf of Muirpace's owners, the Thompson family, who owned the 1992 Grand National winner Party Politics.

At the magistrates' hearing in November, Mr Pollard described his client as a "sad case". He added that Leonard was trying to come to terms with the "enormity of what happened".

The extent to which Leonard had been acting for his own benefit or was merely trying to cover up mistakes will be critical to the length of what will certainly be a prison sentence.

He has pleaded guilty to a £32m fraud stretching back to 1985, the principal victim of which is the private business empire of the Thompson family, whose interests range from Party Politics to Queen's Park Rangers football club.

The 15 charges to which he confessed were largely concerned with fraudulent use of grain warrants and the forgery of warrants. Another 300 or so offences relating to the fraud will be taken into consideration when Leonard is sentenced.

His guilty pleas marked the end of Operation Leo, a long-running SFO inquiry that began in early 1997 when Leonard - no longer able to carry the burden of his fraud and aware that no amount of successful trading could make up the losses - turned himself in to his employer, the Thompson family, and to the authorities.

At the time of the hearing, there was no suggestion that Leonard sought to make money for himself, although the SFO said at the time that there were inquiries into the possibility of personal benefit. This belief was reflected in Leonard's bail conditions; he was ordered to surrender his passport and live at home.

Now it is thought the SFO's inquiries may bear some fruit but will need more work.

Leonard confessed that, from June 1 1985, he had been running the affairs of Muirpace for a fraudulent purpose, with the intent to deceive customers, investors and auditors by concealing the true state of the company.

webTitle: Howells favourite for DTI business ethics job

fields.headline: Howells favourite for DTI business ethics job
fields.trailText: The government plans to create a new ministerial post for corporate social responsibility to reflect the growing importance of business ethics.
fields.body:
The government plans to create a new ministerial post for corporate social responsibility to reflect the growing importance of business ethics.

The new job within the department of trade and industry would deal with policy issues ranging from the treatment by business of disadvantaged groups to companies' environmental performance.

Industry minister Kim Howells is seen as the most likely candidate for the post, as he has responsibility for consumer protection as well as company law.

Plans for the post are being held up because of uncertainty over international aspects of the job. Both the foreign office and the department for international development are involved in ethical trade issues and the post would have to take this into account.

Policy action teams set up by the exclusion unit have argued that businesses could help reduce poverty if they had a more responsible approach to poor areas.

Meanwhile the DTI is struggling to deal with fundamental issues about company responsibility which have been raised by the review of company law.

The review, which began in spring of 1998, will not make its final report until next year. But its interim report next month will reflect a fierce battle over companies' responsibilities to shareholders and other interest groups.

It will advocate sticking to the legal position, based on Victorian company law, which gives shareholders ultimate power, but will accept that business also has responsibilities to workers, suppliers, customers and society at large.

webTitle: Greens blue as Prescott gets back on the road

fields.headline: Greens blue as Prescott gets back on the road
fields.trailText: John Prescott will today underline the triumphal return of the road lobby over green issues as the government prepares its campaign to attract middle England in the lead up to the election.
fields.body:
John Prescott will today underline the triumphal return of the road lobby over green issues as the government prepares its campaign to attract middle England in the lead up to the election.

Mr Prescott and his deputy, Lord MacDonald are due to launch the Motorists' Forum, a new national body set up to consult with government on the interests of road users.

The forum, chaired by Sir Trevor Chinn, chairman of the Lex Service car dealership, will help address "the adverse problems of congestion and pollution" while ensuring that the views of the motorist are properly represented.

The move marks a distinct change in the government's attitude to the motorist and roads. Mr Prescott has promised a review of the roads programme and is being encouraged by his close ally, Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the shadow Strategic Rail Authority, to build more roads.

As leader of an organisation which is supposed to promote the use of rail, Sir Alastair has stunned people in the industry by saying that not enough trunk roads are being constructed.

Mr Prescott's move comes as he is trying to separate two warring ministers - Lord MacDonald, and the environment minister, Michael Meacher, who is angry at a toning down of the government's attitude towards green issues.

The two are at loggerheads over a proposal by the treasury to introduce four new tax bands for motorists in the budget which would replace the current annual £155 excise duty on cars. It is to be replaced with a system reflecting more fairly the size of the car.

Lord MacDonald wants nar rower tax bands than Mr Meacher, who believes that "gas guzzlers" should be made to pay premiums of at least £300 a year.

Mr Meacher is also incensed that Lord MacDonald has moved into his territory by backing a government sponsored report on pollution, which says that London is the least polluted "mega" city in the world. Mr Meacher was taken aback by the report which he thought was based on inadequate research. It compared London mainly with third world cities and conveniently left out European cities.

Critics of the government's green policies on transport say that Mr Prescott has already gone cold on the idea of introducing congestion and workplace car parking charges in the near future.

Legislation is going through the Commons at present, but the onus is on individual cities to act on the plans and the first schemes are unlikely to be running for another four years.

webTitle: This courtyard used to be a car park

fields.headline: This courtyard used to be a car park
fields.standfirst: Somerset House is being transformed from a dreary office block for civil servants into an ambitious cultural centre.  Jonathan Glancey is delighted
fields.trailText: Somerset House is being transformed from a dreary office block for civil servants into an ambitious cultural centre.
fields.body:
Away from the brouhaha surrounding the dome and the noisy fluster of a public relations industry working its socks off to promote the gaggle of new cultural venues opening this year, the restoration of London's magnificent Somerset House has been developing apace in quiet, stately fashion. Facing the Strand to the north and the Thames to the south, this grand Palladian civic palace will surprise and delight the millions of locals and tourists who will pass it on the way to work, the West End and well known monuments when it opens to the public in May. It will be one of Britain's finest cultural venues and an example of how, across the country, we might begin to rethink the way we use public buildings, public space and the public realm.

Designed by Sir William Chambers (1723-96), architectural advisor and tutor to King George III, Somerset House was built between 1776 and 1801 to house various government offices and learned societies. Among these were the Navy, Stamp and Salt offices alongside the newly founded Royal Academy of Arts (since removed to Burlington House, Piccadilly). The vast courtyard building was, in effect, the first government office block in London and probably the first purpose-built office in Britain.

For too many years it has been a home to civil servants - the Inland Revenue in particular - who seem to have been heedless of its Classical charms. The corridors and individual offices within were things of Men-from-the-Ministry austerity, if not squalor; the grand central courtyard was made over as no more than a car park, while the breathtaking riverside terrace was inaccessible to the public and largely unused.

The Somerset House Trust, a committee of the grand and architecturally minded under the chairmanship of Sir Timothy Sainsbury, was formed in June 1997. Its aim was to turn this warren of civil servant burrows, this mammoth exhibition of filing cabinets and memoranda in triplicate, this palace of more than 1,000 rooms, into a "major new visitor attraction for London, and a new centre for culture and the arts". The government granted the trust a 128-year lease that autumn, and work began. The necessary works were expected to take 10 years; in fact they will have taken just three and cost £48m - £12m less than the subsidy apparently needed to keep the £758m Greenwich dome all at sea.

The results are very likely to please everyone who steps into the great courtyard this spring. To their further delight, visitors will find that they can keep walking across the courtyard, under arches, on to the riverside terrace, across the Thames to Sir Giles Gilbert Scott's supremely elegant Waterloo, and so to the South Bank Centre, which will soon be improved considerably by the architect-planner Rick Mather. More than a new cultural centre and visitor attraction, here is an inspirational walk through the centre of London, connecting Covent Garden to Waterloo through Neo-Classical architectural splendour.

The trust sees the vast courtyard (40,000 sq ft) as an area of repose during the day from the hurly-burly of the major streets that flank Somerset House and, by night, as a place of intelligent entertainment (capacity 3,500 people). A new 55-jet fountain designed by Dixon Jones, architects of the revamped Royal Opera House, will play at the centre of this great space. The jets can be choreographed and would make a superb backdrop to, say, a performance of Handel's Water Music, a Thames-side piece composed not long before Chambers began work on Somerset House. Concerts, music festivals, opera, theatre, dance and open air films will oust the blare of car engines and exhaust pipes that has been the staple sound of the courtyard for many years.

The transformation of Somerset House is a model for both urban conservation programmes and new city development, a judgment that can be made from the treatment of the great courtyard alone. There are several such spaces the length and breadth of Britain that have been given over to uncategorisable detritus and the car over the past 50 years and could be similarly improved.

Beyond the courtyard are the Embankment and South Buildings, restored and converted by the meticulous Peter Inskip and Peter Jenkins, and now housing the Gilbert collection of historic decorative arts. From the autumn, selections from the State Hermitage Museum, St Petersburg, will also be displayed in part of the South Building. This makes impressive sense. Somerset House is built on a heroic scale to compete with that of the bombastic Russian palace, while cultural links forged with the Russian government are more than valuable at a time when diplomacy and good will are needed to keep relations between Moscow and the west on something like an even keel.

The River Terrace, aside from eye-boggling views of the Thames and the architecture - good, bad and ugly - that lines its banks, offers a cafe designed by Dixon Jones. Oliver Peyton, the fashionable Irish restaurateur, is further providing a restaurant, cafe and delicatessen, so catering promises to be of a high standard. Commuters beetling back to Waterloo in the evening can pick up civilised food to take home, and might even be tempted to listen to a concert or take in an exhibition instead of rushing headlong to all points suburban.

It sounds almost exhausting to say that these are only the highlights of what for many first-time visitors to Somerset House will be something of a magical mystery tour of this noble Palladian architecture. There are so many other pleasures: just wait until you see the Nelson Stair (blitzed in 1940, reconstructed by Sir Albert Richardson, one of the last convincing British classicists), or the Courtauld's collection of Impressionist and Post- Impressionist paintings that now adorn this former government ghetto.

Somerset House offers many lessons in how we might transform our city centres at the outset of the 21st century. Most importantly, it demonstrates how a major civic building not only needs to be well looked after and generally available (there is something odd in the fact that so many public buildings are closed to the public), but can connect beneficially to the streets and wider city beyond. Our towns and cities are notorious for being disjointed; think how many famous and grand buildings have been all but cut off by roads and traffic, or used as dumping grounds and, of course, car parks. From the spring, Somerset House will be not just an attraction in its own right, but a kind of urban junction box, routing pedestrians through its architectural glories to city quarters north and south of the Thames.

More than this, the transformation of Somerset House is a good example of how urban thinking can be "joined up": people walking through its courtyard to other parts of central London will find themselves wanting to stop for a coffee or part of an open-air performance, or dropping in on exhibitions that they must otherwise make a special trip to see.

To make great cultural venues a real part of city life is an intelligent step towards making high art truly accessible. Because people will be able to spin through the heart of Somerset House as well as to stop and browse, they will become familiar, over a long time, with the arts and events it promises to put on show from May.

This redevelopment is, in short, a triumph. The fact that such a triumph should have come into being quietly, subtly and without the bombastic force of overweening PR hype or government spin is almost a miracle. Now it's time to see the Somerset House effect spreading to the rest of our town and city centres.

fields.headline: Insecurity measures
fields.standfirst: In the past decade, the arms build-up has accelerated throughout east Asia. Cooperation, not aggression, needs to be encouraged by the west
fields.trailText: In the past decade, the arms build-up has accelerated throughout east Asia. Cooperation, not aggression, needs to be encouraged by the west
fields.body:
Despite tensions on the Korean peninsula, across the Taiwan straits and in the South China sea, East Asia was more peaceful during the 90s than at any time during the past 100 years. (The region comprises China, Taiwan, Japan, the two Koreas, Thailand, Malaysia and eight other south-east Asian states.) Yet during the past decade those east Asian governments have been spending substantially on weapons and military modernisation. Prosperity has grown but so, it appears, has insecurity.

The 1997 recession forced some (Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, and to a lesser extent South Korea and Japan) to cut spending. But like China, Taiwan and Singapore, all little affected by the economic downturn, other countries in the region - especially Japan and South Korea - went on boosting their military capabilities.

Recent deals include a large consignment of Su-27 fighters for China from Russia at a cost of $2.5bn, Japan's purchase of four American Awacs aircraft with a price tag of $1bn, 13 British naval helicopters for South Korea ($337m), 60 French Mirage 2000 fighters for Taiwan ($2.6bn), a new Thai aircraft carrier from Spain ($257m), four Swedish subs for Singapore ($400m), and two British frigates for Malaysia ($600m).

The governments claim they have just used their new wealth to modernise their forces, implying mere upgrading of existing equipment. Closer analysis shows them going far beyond simple updating. Generally, the money has gone on conventional weapons, but in China and North Korea programmes involve nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles.

East Asia became an important market for American and European defence suppliers (and Russia and Israel) after the end of the cold war. Americans are pre-eminent though competitors have won contracts on the back of Washington's restrictions on arms sales to Taiwan and China and American reluctance to share advanced defence technology.

Europeans (Britain and France especially) have often supplied equipment the Americans cannot or will not. Western governments are likely to outlaw arms only for states which commit gross human rights violations. Russia has no such qualms. Russia has regained its role as an exporter mainly because of its willingness to arm China, largely under embargo by the west since 1989.

To operate successfully in the region, suppliers have had to agree to transfer technology. But the region has not depended entirely on imports. Home-grown defence industries have benefited from the technology transfer and other offset arrangements which international suppliers must usually provide in order to secure contracts. Yet this dependence also reflects limited capabilities. Even the region's more advanced defence industries in Japan, China, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore remain weak in critical areas.

Despite the new equipment, it is not clear that Asian armies and navies are any more capable of fighting effectively. Some are halfway there. The most militarily advanced states, in terms of conventional capabilities, are Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore. However, these are all "status quo powers": none looks likely to use its growing military means aggressively. Indeed, recent developments in these states' conventional capabilities may stabilise the local military balance, particularly if it helps to deter China from attacking Taiwan or North Korea from launching an offensive against the South Koreans.

The key regional player remains the United States through its alliances with Japan and South Korea and its special relationship with Taiwan. It has a substantial lead in what experts call the "revolution in military affairs", which revolves around integrating hi-tech command, control, communications and intelligence systems with precision-guided weapons. American conventional forces will continue to outclass any likely east Asian adversaries for at least the next decade.

Yet two things threaten to undermine the military advantages of the US and regional powers supporting the status quo. One is the Chinese and North Korean missile and nuclear programmes. Washington might, in the not-too-distant future, find the American homeland as well as its forces overseas held hostage by Chinese and Korean missiles. Anti-missile defences may not provide a timely, affordable, effective or politically acceptable solution to this problem. If recent tests are any guide, they may not work either.

Beijing is arming the People's Liberation army with hi-tech systems and may eventually challenge not just neighbours but threaten American aircraft carriers with potentially highly accurate and destructive but relatively cheap weapons, such as state-of-the-art anti-ship missiles and high-speed torpedoes.

These threats to regional stability suggest more intense cooperation between the central players is vital. Cooperation will have to be based on "security with" rather than "security against". Continued engagement between the US and China is critical: while Washington needs to deal firmly with Beijing where vital interests are concerned, gratuitous confrontation (for example, deploying missile defence systems or over-arming Taiwan) could prove counterproductive. Washington remains the key to the region's future security; so much depends on who succeeds Clinton.

Tim Huxley directs the Institute of Pacific Asia Studies at Hull university

fields.headline: Are you busy this evening?
fields.standfirst: If not, can you conduct our orchestra?  Jessica Duchen on the musical careers boosted by a star's failure to show
fields.trailText: It's the stuff of musicians' dreams. The great X breaks his leg and the youthful Y appears in his place, promptly to be hailed as a bright new star. And it can really happen - just ask the Bulgarian mezzo-soprano Vesselina Kasarova or Sakari Oramo, Simon Rattle's successor at the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra. Kasarova, currently starring in La Clemenza di Tito at the Royal Opera House, made her mark by replacing Marilyn Horne at short notice in Salzburg in 1991; Oramo, then a Finnish orchestra leader, picked up the baton to cover for a sick maestro in 1993 to find himself transformed permanently from violinist to conductor.
fields.body:
It's the stuff of musicians' dreams. The great X breaks his leg and the youthful Y appears in his place, promptly to be hailed as a bright new star. And it can really happen - just ask the Bulgarian mezzo-soprano Vesselina Kasarova or Sakari Oramo, Simon Rattle's successor at the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra. Kasarova, currently starring in La Clemenza di Tito at the Royal Opera House, made her mark by replacing Marilyn Horne at short notice in Salzburg in 1991; Oramo, then a Finnish orchestra leader, picked up the baton to cover for a sick maestro in 1993 to find himself transformed permanently from violinist to conductor.

On Saturday the Swiss-born pianist Andreas Haefliger will get his chance to raise his profile when he performs Mozart's Concerto in A major K488 with the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra and conductor Riccardo Chailly at the Royal Festival Hall in London. He is replacing Maria Joao Pires, one of the most sought-after pianists on the international circuit.

Haefliger, 37, has less to prove than many of his peers. He is a serious, strong-minded musician with an established international career and has worked successfully with the Concertgebouw before. The repertoire suits him well, and he says that he had enough notice of the event to regard it as just another date in the diary.

"Chailly and the Concertgebouw were something I was hoping to fit into my schedule anyway," Haefliger says, "though the opportunity has arisen a little sooner than I thought." For all that, he could still gain much glory if he proves himself a worthy replacement for Pires.

Today's concert promoters are increasingly reluctant to take a chance on newcomers, however. The more dramatic and high-profile the cancellation, the harder their task becomes and the greater the danger of damaging the precious relationship with their audience.

A couple of years ago, Cecilia Bartoli, probably the world's best-loved mezzo-soprano, suddenly pulled out of a London Philharmonic fundraising gala concert at Glyndebourne, and the LPO's chief executive, Serge Dorny, had just 48 hours to sort out a replacement and inform 1,000 audience members. The singers Thomas Allen and Susan Graham were drafted in; meanwhile, the LPO office telephoned every single ticket holder. "People were disappointed, but they were grateful to have been personally contacted," says Dorny, "and only one person asked to exchange the ticket."

He emphasises that cancellations are usually made with good reason. "Nobody cancels a concert with pleasure - it's inconvenient for everyone."

That's something of an understatement. Last Friday the Alban Berg Quartet, one of the world's top string ensembles, had to cancel Saturday's sold-out concert at the Queen Elizabeth Hall because one of the violinists had caught pneumonia. No quartet of the same calibre was available, and box-office staff were left with less than 36 hours to contact the holders of 1,000 tickets.

But there is a small number of top-notch musicians who have earned themselves reputations as notorious cancellers. The pianists Sviatoslav Richter and Arturo Benedetti Michel-angeli, both of whom died in the 90s, achieved the status of legends primarily for their artistry but also partly because of the mystique surrounding their frequent non-appearances on stage. No one who bought a ticket for their concerts could be sure that they would actually hear them play.

Pianist Martha Argerich has long-term health problems that have made her an irregular recitalist. When she did give a concert in London in March 1999, she had been absent from the stage for a year - and got rave reviews. But only the greatest musicians can cancel frequently and get away with it. "It's quite courageous of Maria [Joao Pires] to cancel," says Haefliger. "I think it's a wonderful thing that she can decide to give herself some time to replenish the batteries." According to Pires's agent, she is taking a year's break from performing.

Younger musicians setting out to increase their mystique with a few cancellations are asking for trouble, however. "In the case of Argerich, people will take the risk because she's such a brilliant pianist and everyone loves her," says Jilly Clarke, an artist manager with the musical agency Askonas Holt. "But if a younger artist who isn't well known starts messing promoters around, it can take years for them to recover from the bad reputation that results. They get dropped like hot bricks."

In 1997, a young Russian competition winner was booked for a UK tour. He refused to commit himself totally. The agents rang up British pianist Lucy Parham and asked her to be on standby for six months in case he pulled out, which he finally did, with one month's notice. Parham did the tour; the Russian hasn't been asked back.

"Up to a point you are totally dispensable," says Parham wryly. "Unless you are an Argerich or a Richter, there are innumerable pianists who can replace you. There's less work around now than 10 years ago, so people are very loath to give up a date and pass it on to a colleague, who may then do better with the orchestra and be invited back instead of you. "I have played with horrible flu," Parham continues. "Another time I'd hurt my foot and could hardly move. I went on to the platform wearing a long evening dress, one shoe and one trainer."

As for agreeing to step into another musician's shoes, the young British pianist Leon McCawley says, "It's all about decision making and risk taking." A popular figure with British audiences after coming second in the 1993 Leeds piano competition, aged only 19, McCawley has been offered opportunities that could well have put him on the fast track to stardom. "I've had some nice experiences taking over cancellations. But once I was asked to step in for Richard Goode at the Proms at one week's notice with a Mozart concerto I'd never done and I decided it was too much of a risk."

About five years ago, a television broadcast of Beethoven's Fourth Piano Concerto in Coventry cathedral came McCawley's way at the last moment. He turned it down. A lost opportunity? Perhaps.

Clarke says she and fellow agents have to be very careful about offering young artists replacement dates. "We have a huge responsibility to put them up for things if we think they're up to it; but, if they're not ready, or a particular audience is too demanding, we shouldn't suggest them. Doing the wrong thing at the wrong time can destroy someone."

For most young musicians, last-minute dates present an impossible dilemma. Play well and you can kick-start your career; accept something too risky and you may well end up playing Russian roulette with your future.

Andreas Haefliger plays the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (0171-960 4242), on Saturday, with the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra and conductor Riccardo Chailly.

fields.headline: Crucial week for flagging euro
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
KPMG's report
fields.trailText: The euro's slide against the dollar is expected to worsen this week with the prospect of a rise in US interest rates striking a further blow to the single currency's poor fortunes.
fields.body:
The euro's slide against the dollar is expected to worsen this week with the prospect of a rise in US interest rates striking a further blow to the single currency's poor fortunes.

The US Federal Reserve Bank meets this week to consider its position on interest rates.

However, a strong hint by European Central Bank president Wim Duisenberg yesterday that the European Central Bank may also raise rates could put a support under the euro's slump.

He said if wage pressures emerge across the continent in the coming months then "we might have to react with our monetary policy".

The euro plummeted below the parity barrier with the US dollar last week and was recently at $0.9753.

In an interview with the BBC's The Money Programme, Mr Duisenberg also said it would be "years from today" before Britain would qualify to join the European monetary union.

"One of the pre-requisites for joining monetary union is to have demonstrated that your economic performances in inflation, long-term interest rates and the exchange rate have converged towards the base of economic developments in all those aspects in the euro area.

"It will take Britain some time, to say the least," he added.

Trade secretary Stephen Byers said yesterday that the government had not fixed the timetable for a referendum on joining the euro and added that Europe's economy needed to be reformed as it remained old-fashion and lacked innovation.

"He [Mr Duisenberg] has raised some important questions about the fit between our economy in the UK and the economies in continental Europe," Mr Byers said on Sky News.

Asked about the prospect of the euro's devaluation on inflation, Mr Duisenberg said: "We might have to react with our monetary policy," but only if inflation caused wages to rise "at a pace higher than the rate of productivity would warrant".

He said the euro would eventually strengthen in tandem with the European economy's recovery.

fields.headline: Freeserve eyes publisher
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Freeserve has begun takeover talks with the troubled children's book publisher Dorling Kindersley which would significantly boost the content offering of the UK's largest internet access provider.
fields.body:
Freeserve has begun takeover talks with the troubled children's book publisher Dorling Kindersley which would significantly boost the content offering of the UK's largest internet access provider.

Sources from both companies confirmed discussions had been held for "some time" and were accelerated after Dorling Kindersley's profits warning last week when it said it would report a £25m pre-tax loss for the December half-year and announced the resignation of its chief executive, James Middlehurst.

Insiders close to Freeserve said: "They have been having discussions and it does make a sensible addition to online content."

DK shares were on a roller coaster last week, falling sharply on the profits warning and then adding almost £1 to to Friday's close of 372.5p, valuing the company at £267m.

The price of a bid has been put as high as £360m. Any offer would be likely to be in shares, given Freeserve's strong performance since it floated last July at 150p. The shares closed at 622.25p on Friday.

Talks are going ahead despite job cuts at online fashion retailer Boo.com and bookseller Amazon which have caused concern about the future of online businesses.

DK's losses were caused by a "seriously misjudged over-investment" in Star Wars books and the promotion associated with it.

An alternative to takeover might be Freeserve acquiring exclusive rights to the British content of DK.

Freeserve's content includes travel, insurance, books, electrical goods and an auction site.

fields.headline: Knowing when to quit
fields.standfirst: Reader reply: How to have a happy appraisal
fields.trailText: Many thanks to Office Angels for this week's illuminating insight into office life. According to the recruitment firm, as many as 25% of us will start looking for a new job within a fortnight of a bad appraisal and 40% within a month.
fields.body:
Many thanks to Office Angels for this week's illuminating insight into office life. According to the recruitment firm, as many as 25% of us will start looking for a new job within a fortnight of a bad appraisal and 40% within a month.

I thought I was the only one who threw monumental wobblies if anyone mislaid words like 'phenomenal', 'unsurpassable' and 'better than perfect' when criticising my efforts, but evidently the adage 'Never complain, never explain' cuts no ice in the modern corporate environment.

With around a third of staff flouncing off in a rage at the merest whiff of a bad review it could be high time those of us with easily-deflatable egos took a few skin-thickening steps prior to the next appraisal meeting:

1. Rehearse your facial expressions. If criticism acts like a blow to your solar plexus the odds are your face resembles something from The Exorcist and you will all but spurt green bile when told you need to try harder. Two weeks spent rehearsing a thankful smile prior to the appraisal will pay dividends on the day, making you look like a model employee who can take it on the chin.

2. Don't get into conflict. An appraisal is supposed to be an illuminating experience, not a trading ground for insults. Listen to everything that is said, don't interrupt and avoid disagreeing with every point made.

3. Ask for any criticism to be made specific. No one needs to sit and listen to a load of vague tosh about attitudes and standards. If there is something wrong with your work you need to know exact details if you are going to improve.

4. Take a notebook and write everything down. Once outside the office you may find yourself suffering from selective memory loss, recalling only the negative comments and getting increasingly stroppy about them.

5. If you feel the need to challenge points made try to do so assertively. Avoid phrases like 'Who said that?', 'That's not my fault', 'Everyone does that, it's just others seem better at getting away with it than me' and 'You are totally wrong.' You will sound more positive if you try lines like: 'I wonder how I came to create that impression?', 'Could you possibly go into details on that point?', or 'So can I just clarify that...'.

6. Never get emotional. Keep calm and look relaxed. Appraisals are difficult on both sides and neither you nor your superior will want to say or do something you may regret later. Your feelings are valid but describe them without acting them out. It is far more powerful to say: 'I feel very angry about that' in a calm tone than to start shouting or slamming doors.

7. An appraisal should be a two-way communication. Plan some points you want to make before you go in. Sound professional by sticking to positives. If you need to talk about a problem try to take a solution in with you.

8. Never whinge. Appraisals should not turn into a moan-fest with no effective action plans as a result. It's easy to react to a criticism with an excuse or attack but that's ultimately counter-productive. Don't complain about colleagues by name unless their behaviour is intolerable.

9. Receive compliments about your work gracefully. A genuine-sounding 'thank you' is best. Never go down the self-effacing trail, telling your manager it was no big deal and you were just lucky because you didn't really know what you were doing at the time.

10. Never make threats. Hotheads among us may well find themselves offering ultimatums along the lines of: 'Well if you're so unhappy with my work then I may as well go to a firm that does appreciate my talents'. This may be met with a curt 'okay' rather than the scene of pleading, snivelling knee-hugging and hem-wresting you had envisaged. Rehearse a dignified exit line for all outcomes. Don't change the script at the last minute or you could end up hurling insults, or worse, resigning on the spot.

If criticism acts like a blow to your solar plexus the odds are your face resembles something from The Exorcist and you will all but spurt green bile when told you need to try harder. Two weeks spent rehearsing a thankful smile prior to the appraisal will pay dividends on the day, making you look like a model employee who can take it on the chin. 2. Don't get into conflict. An appraisal is supposed to be an illuminating experience, not a trading ground for insults. Listen to everything that is said, don't interrupt and avoid disagreeing with every point made. 3. Ask for any criticism to be made specific. No one needs to sit and listen to a load of vague tosh about attitudes and standards. If there is something wrong with your work you need to know exact details if you are going to improve. 4. Take a notebook and write everything down. Once outside the office you may find yourself suffering from selective memory loss, recalling only the negative comments and getting increasingly stroppy about them. 5. If you feel the need to challenge points made try to do so assertively. Avoid phrases like 'Who said that?', 'That's not my fault', 'Everyone does that, it's just others seem better at getting away with it than me' and 'You are totally wrong.' You will sound more positive if you try lines like: 'I wonder how I came to create that impression?', 'Could you possibly go into details on that point?', or 'So can I just clarify that...'. 6. Never get emotional. Keep calm and look relaxed. Appraisals are difficult on both sides and neither you nor your superior will want to say or do something you may regret later. Your feelings are valid but describe them without acting them out. It is far more powerful to say: 'I feel very angry about that' in a calm tone than to start shouting or slamming doors. 7. An appraisal should be a two-way communication. Plan some points you want to make before you go in. Sound professional by sticking to positives. If you need to talk about a problem try to take a solution in with you. 8. Never whinge. Appraisals should not turn into a moan-fest with no effective action plans as a result. It's easy to react to a criticism with an excuse or attack but that's ultimately counter-productive. Don't complain about colleagues by name unless their behaviour is intolerable. 9. Receive compliments about your work gracefully. A genuine-sounding 'thank you' is best. Never go down the self-effacing trail, telling your manager it was no big deal and you were just lucky because you didn't really know what you were doing at the time. 10. Never make threats. Hotheads among us may well find themselves offering ultimatums along the lines of: 'Well if you're so unhappy with my work then I may as well go to a firm that does appreciate my talents'. This may be met with a curt 'okay' rather than the scene of pleading, snivelling knee-hugging and hem-wresting you had envisaged. Rehearse a dignified exit line for all outcomes. Don't change the script at the last minute or you could end up hurling insults, or worse, resigning on the spot.

fields.headline: Only the good die young...
fields.standfirst:
The rest of us should ensure we have a good pension, says Alexandra Watson
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Most people find it easier to get excited about the company's free healthclub membership than its pension scheme. But despite its unsexy image, a good company pension could be your most important financial benefit after your salary.
fields.body:
Most people find it easier to get excited about the company's free healthclub membership than its pension scheme. But despite its unsexy image, a good company pension could be your most important financial benefit after your salary.

Although they often have a lower status, and less pay, than other employees, secretarial and support staff generally have the same pension rights as the rest of the workforce. Some companies do give better pension provision to senior management, but it is increasingly common to have one set of rules for the whole company.

Almost two-thirds of companies offer pensions to their support staff and the strongest factor in determining whether they do so is their size. The administrative, secretarial and support staff survey produced by recruitment consultants Gordon Yates and the Guardian found that 87% of all large companies (those with more than 1,000 employees) offer support staff some form of pension provision, but only a third of small firms (less than 10 employees) do. This disparity may increase following the government's announcement this month that businesses with fewer than five staff will be exempt from having to provide staff with the new stakeholder pensions when they come into effect next year.

Stakeholder pensions are aimed at workers with low earnings - those on a salary of between £9,000 and £18,000 a year - who do not have a private pension. Ministers hope the new scheme will encourage those without pension provision to start making plans for their future.

But even if your package does include a pension, secretarial staff may still be losing out, according to Richard Grace, Gordon Yates' managing director. "A lot of company pensions are linked to salary packages, so if the company contributes 5% of your salary as a PA, it is much less than a high earner is getting," he says. It's a case of the higher the salary, the larger the benefit, so low- paid employees suffer."

The survey found secretarial staff attached a high value to jobs that had pension provision, the favourite being non-contributory schemes, where employers make the payments. But pension plans only really become important when secretaries are slightly more senior, says Emma Rance, who runs the secretarial division at recruitment consultants Judy Farquharson. "Most younger people looking for secretarial work are desperate to get experience, and for them pensions are something to think about in the future," she says. "Those further on in their career think more about what they want from a company, what sort of pension it will provide them with, and so on."

Julia Sampson is PA to the director at charity Water-Aid, which has no company pension, but encourages employees to set up their own. Sampson set up hers through a financial adviser recommended by her employer. She puts in 5% of her salary and her employers contribute the equivalent of 10%.

She admits it is a good deal, but it wasn't her priority: "I'd decided I wanted a career in development so when this job came up I grabbed it - the pension wasn't a big incentive. Salaries here are not huge, so I don't think people are really on the lookout for competitive benefits packages." She admits it would be different if she were to work for a big City firm. "Because it would be that type of environment, I'd ask a lot more questions about what sort of pension I'd get and look at those details carefully."

A good company pension is important to Sarah Macintosh, a secretary at accountants KPMG. She explains: "There is not as much career development potential in secretarial work and the pay is never going to be great, so the benefits that a company provides, such as a pension, really make a difference to the deal I'm getting."

Macintosh has changed jobs regularly in the past but is reluctant to do so now because she knows she will lose out. "It's not just because of losing out financially if I move, although that would probably happen. But I like working for a company which provides a good pension because it sends out signals that it values its employees. I might not find that in another company."

The Occupational Pensions Advisory Service has a national helpline offering advice on any subject to do with occupational or personal pensions. Tel: 0207 233 8080

fields.headline: Read your way to success
fields.standfirst: If you hope to get on at work, the message is that you will have to make your own way. Esther Addley on the growing UK market for self-help manuals for the career-minded Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: If you hope to get on at work, the message is that you will have to make your own way. Esther Addley on the growing UK market for self-help manuals for the career-minded
fields.body:
The Roman philosopher Seneca didn't know a great deal about office politics or corporate networking, but he had a neat line in motivational epigrams."When a man does not know what harbour he is making for, no wind is the right wind," he wrote in his Epistolae ad Lucilium.

It's a sentiment endorsed (and reprinted) in Anthony Weldon's book Breakthrough: Your Guide to Handling Career Opportunities and Changes. The book will, suggests the epigram, help to guide you to your own personal harbour, filling your sails with positive winds of change as you embark on the great career journey.

Stephanie Myers, author of I Want More: Straight-talking Advice on How to Get What You Want, prefers to quote Voltaire. In a chapter entitled "I want more respect" she cites his maxim: "We owe respect to the living. To the dead we owe only truth."

It's deliciously easy to mock workplace self-help books. All that touchy-feely stuff about Knowing Your Inner Work Self! and Finding Power In The Office! - exclamation marks and excessive capitalisation in the title, gung-ho motivational exhortations in the text. It all feels a bit embarrassing and, well, American, in a nation where we are more comfortable apologising when someone walks into us on the Tube.

But cheesy or not, it seems we can't get enough of personal development books. The market in the UK for motivational manuals has seen phenomenal growth in the past decade, and all indications are that the curve will continue steeply upwards. High street bookshops set increasingly substantial chunks of their floorspace aside for pop psychology guides, and tempt us at the checkout with bitesize versions of the same. Men and women may be from different planets, but it seems the road less travelled has been well trod by all of us. And I'm OK if you are.

While many of the well-known bestsellers deal with general personal and spiritual development, our increasing enthusiasm for emotional self-motivation and Oprah-style sharing has also spilled into the workplace. Help is available for every type of office dilemma, offering to increase your confidence, improve your powers of influence, and get you the job of your dreams. After all, You Deserve It!

But if the emotional gushiness of the career self-help market is easily parodied, the reasons behind the genre's extraordinary popularity are less lighthearted. The workplace is less secure, and if we want to get on, we suspect we'll have to make it happen ourselves. Managers are under pressure to squeeze ever more from their staff, and so are more receptive to "alternative" management strategies. The flexible market demands flexible skills. If in doubt, buy a book.

"I suppose if you look at it from a cynical point of view, you could say that we are fitting into people's insecurities," says Pauline Goodwin, publishing director at specialist business publisher Kogan Page. "Every organisation has a hierarchy, and trying to understand that, and the systems and processes of the organisation, is important. I think people want to know how to behave and present themselves. Who are the people you should be looking to impress?"

She thinks wider changes in society have also contributed to the boom in career motivation books. "There are increasing numbers of women returners and women in the workplace generally. The former group in particular need their confidence boosted, having been out of the workplace for some time, and the latter group, particularly the new generation of women entering the job market, are determined to compete on an even footing with men, and keen to progress their careers."

A third important factor, crucially, is the growing emphasis on so-called "soft skills". Flexibility, initiative and "common sense" are repeatedly mentioned by employers and recruiters as skills in short supply, not abilities one can easily set out to acquire on a course or through application alone. The easy self-knowledge, confidence and powers of influence promised by many books in the genre are tempting prizes indeed.

But publishers admit that the self-help genre has something of an image problem in the UK, despite its phenomenal growth. "British people want more pragmatic advice, rather than the vacuous razzmatazz you often get in American books in this field," says Goodwin. "We don't want to learn how to 'Transform Ourselves In The Workplace!' if it's not giving practical advice."

Similarly, Judith Dennett, head of publishing at the Institute of Personnel and Development, is eager to stress that the career help books published by the IPD are the "respectable face" of self-help publishing. "I don't think there's anything wrong with talking about human things at work," she says, "but it's the sentimentalising of that which is wrong. Much of it would stick in your throat. We don't want to be seen as a comedy act."

In fact many of the British books published in the field seem to take pains to distance themselves from the most emotive excesses of the genre. "Forget the 'power of positive thinking' and 'fake it to make it': these are very good strategies, but put them in storage for now," writes chartered psychologist Jim Mackay in Breakthrough. Ros Taylor, author of Transform Yourself! says her book discusses "a number of different ways of thinking, not just an adjuration to think more positively, as I have always thought that so insulting."

Despite making her own contribution to the genre, Lucy Kellaway retains a healthy scepticism about the popularity of career advice books. "What happens to all those management books that are published in greater number each year?," she asks in Sense and Nonsense in the Office. "Who has the time (or the inclination) to sit down and read them? The answer seems to be practically nobody. Managers buy the books, only to leave them on their shelves for show-off value or, at best, to dip into them briefly."

In contrast to the relentless optimism of personal development-speak, Kellaway articulates the one great secret about our jobs that we all hate to admit - "all work is tedious for much of the time. If everyone accepts this, then so much the better."

It's a sentiment with which Seneca would probably agree. A member of the Stoic school, he held that happiness was achievable only by putting aside passion and submitting to one's duty.

Word power

Want a change of career, a new job, a new you? These books all promise the chance to open a revised chapter in your life

Breakthrough: Your Guide to Handling Career Opportunities and Changes. Edited by Anthony Weldon.

(Bene Factum, £10.99)

Blurb: "Job change - whether by force or by choice - is disturbing. It poses many questions. Questions that Breakthrough will help you answer. Only you can get the job you want, but Breakthrough will help you every step of the way."

Sample: "Perhaps you should get your act together, hold back any emotion you might feel and launch yourself on to the job market. After all, that really good job that you feel is right for you could be difficult to come by. So if you're busy at home reading and analysing, perhaps somebody else might be getting the very job that was made for you."

By Ros Taylor.

(Kogan Page, £8.99)

Blurb: "This proven programme will help you to develop clarity of vision and renewed confidence in your own judgement and abilities. Transform Yourself! will inspire you to become more positive, productive and relaxed."

Sample: "We need from birth to be hugged and stroked, not only to provide us with a sense of security, but also to give us an awareness of the boundaries of our bodies. As we grow older, hugs and strokes are confined to intimate relationships, but we still desire metaphorical stroking, socially and at work. If these 'strokes' are absent then behavioural withdrawal or attention-seeking results."

By John Courtis.

(Institute of Personnel and Development, £5.95)

Blurb: "Armed with Getting a Better Job by one of the UK's top recruitment experts, you can be confident that a persuasive application and polished interview will secure success."

Sample: "How to spot the warning signs [in potential employers]. Danger signals identified by leading industry specialists include: lavish HQ buildings (beware especially those with flagpoles, fountains and statues), key directors who wear bow ties, gold medallions, toupees or very dark glasses (except for medical reasons), those where the chief executive was a salesman or Young Businessman of the Year, or is also chairman."

(Institute of Personnel and Development, £9.95)

Blurb: "Learn how to cope with dull meetings, live down your indiscretions, deal with difficult colleagues - and much, much more!"

Sample: "How to shake hands or kiss people. Stick to handshaking unless you are confident the other person wants to be kissed. Many people - such as husband and wife politicians Peter and Virginia Bottomley - would never kiss their nearest or dearest in public.

fields.headline: Catharsis combo
fields.standfirst:
Rage Against the Machine
Wembley Arena, London
Rating: * * * * *
fields.trailText: Rage Against the Machine are the last true rock'n'roll band left on earth, and boy are they pissed off. Melting down the sound of an amplified four-piece, they forge it anew with apocalyptic passion, wrathfully denouncing American racism and corporate evil. RATM have come to Wembley with a spray-painted banner declaring "The Battle of London". Tom Morello's freshly wound guitar strings wave shinily from his headstock like multiple fuses on an incendiary device, and rapper Zack de la Rocha screams as though screaming has just been invented.
fields.body:
Rage Against the Machine are the last true rock'n'roll band left on earth, and boy are they pissed off. Melting down the sound of an amplified four-piece, they forge it anew with apocalyptic passion, wrathfully denouncing American racism and corporate evil. RATM have come to Wembley with a spray-painted banner declaring "The Battle of London". Tom Morello's freshly wound guitar strings wave shinily from his headstock like multiple fuses on an incendiary device, and rapper Zack de la Rocha screams as though screaming has just been invented.

Imagine an enormous wall of television static come to reptilian life: an explosion of noise, then an obscenely lithe and melodic riff. One moment epic bass fuzz is doubled by guitar, the next Morello is playing astonishing staccato feedback solos with his pick-up switch (Know Your Enemy), or emulating a police siren.

To hear RATM's first and third albums played almost in their entirety (with a couple from the dodgy second thrown in) is to marvel at how much fresh musical variation they squeeze from the electric-four-piece formula. Storming riffs are intercut by a jazz-bass intro (Calm Like a Bomb), or chilled-out, deliciously slowed-down swing (Wake Up, with its spectacular cowbells). They sound even better live than on record. And, after an apoplectic final rendition of Killing In The Name, the crowd emerges beaming in sweat-soaked catharsis. It's simple: RATM are the best band in the world.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Byers rules out increase in minimum wage

fields.headline: Byers rules out increase in minimum wage
fields.trailText: The government has ruled out an increase to the minimum wage for fear of jeopardising the booming economy, the trade secretary, Stephen Byers said yesterday.
fields.body:
The government has ruled out an increase to the minimum wage for fear of jeopardising the booming economy, the trade secretary, Stephen Byers said yesterday.

Speaking on GMTV's Sunday programme, he said the minimum wage had been implemented more successfully than expected but that increasing the rate from the current level of £3.60 an hour for adults could mean a heavy price.

"The minimum wage being introduced is a huge change, with 1.5m people benefiting from it," he said. "It would be easy to get the plaudits for today if we had a big increase in the level, but we would probably pay a big price in a few years time."

He added that much of Britain's current economic success was due to Labour having implemented European regulations in a way sensitive to business.

The social chapter, for example, had been introduced in a manner which had not damaged the economy, Mr Byers said.
fields.bodyText: The government has ruled out an increase to the minimum wage for fear of jeopardising the booming economy, the trade secretary, Stephen Byers said yesterday. Speaking on GMTV's Sunday programme, he said the minimum wage had been implemented more successfully than expected but that increasing the rate from the current level of £3.60 an hour for adults could mean a heavy price. "The minimum wage being introduced is a huge change, with 1.5m people benefiting from it," he said. "It would be easy to get the plaudits for today if we had a big increase in the level, but we would probably pay a big price in a few years time." The social chapter, for example, had been introduced in a manner which had not damaged the economy, Mr Byers said.

fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: • TIPS ON TRIPS
fields.body:
 TIPS ON TRIPS

PAs who book travel may want to take a trip to the Business Travel 2000 exhibition, on 8-10 February at the Business Design Centre in London. More than 200 exhibitors will be taking part, from hotels and travel agents to airlines and training organisations. Seminars cost £30 each and the programme has been designed to give insider tips on saving time and money, and includes a masterclass for top PAs. For more details, call 0208 710 2185, or visit the website at www.businesstravelshow.com

· RACISM AT WORK

Racism is still widespread in UK workplaces, according to a salutary new report from the Trades Union Congress. The report, Qualifying for Racism, argues that although 21% of black and Asian employees are educated to degree level compared to 16% of their white counterparts, there is a growing "management gap" between black and white workers. The report coincides with the launch of the TUC's action plan to reduce racism at work, which includes guidelines for employers and a course to help combat the problem.

· GET TO GRIPS WITH THE BOSS

Is your boss a nightmare to work with? Or is a problem with a colleague threatening to spoil the way you feel about your job? Managing Your Boss and Colleagues, by Steve Gravett, offers practical advice on improving your working relationships, and shows you how to change a negative position into a positive one. Price £9.99, from Plymbridge Distributors on 01752 202301.

· PHOTO FIT

Fed up with rummaging through files for a loose photograph, only to find it creased and damaged? Invest in some sturdy, punched pockets designed for the job. Kept in a ringbinder or lever-arch file, the clear A4 sheets have pockets of varying sizes to store photos, transparencies, negatives, and other less common formats. The first 2,000 people to call Avery Consumer Centre on 0800 805020, quoting "photosp, will receive a free sample pack.

· SENIOR SERVICE

Looking for high-level training and development, and the chance to network with colleagues? The two-day Executive PA in Business conference, designed specifically for senior secretaries, offers advanced training on issues including building good working relationships, assertiveness, identifying career opportunities, and creating the secretary of the future. Top PAs will be also chairing sessions and sharing insider knowledge. The event will take place in central London on 11 and 12 April 2000. For details call IIR on 0207 915 5055.

fields.headline: Vodafone delivers knockout blow
fields.trailText: Telecoms group Vodafone AirTouch dealt a knockout blow yesterday in its bid to take over Mannesman with the announcement of a deal with the German company's hoped-for saviour, Vivendi.
fields.body:
Telecoms group Vodafone AirTouch dealt a knockout blow yesterday in its bid to take over Mannesman with the announcement of a deal with the German company's hoped-for saviour, Vivendi.

Vodafone and Vivendi will pool their fixed-line networks and establish a European web portal, scuttling Mannesmann's hopes of an alliance with the French media group.

Mannesmann was said to have been in discussions with Vivendi about a possible merger to save the German firm from falling to Vodafone's record £95bn bid. That bid closes on February 7.

The joint venture between Vodafone and Vivendi will see a powerful combination of their telecom and internet assets, potentially creating a pan-European fixed-line operation and web portal with up to 70m subscribers.

The agreement is conditional on Vodafone winning 50% of Mannesmann.

Under the terms of the pact, Vodafone would have management control of the joint venture company, which would run the web portal.

A flotation of a minority stake in the web portal could be considered with 18 months, and a minority stake in the combined fixed-line networks might be floated.

Vodafone has also agreed to sell 7.5% of France's second-largest telecoms group, Cégétel, to Vivendi for an undisclosed sum. Mannesmann owns a 15% stake in Cégétel, while Vivendi owns about 44%.

Mannesmann hit back last night at Vodafone's plans claiming it was trying to sell off the "family silver".

"Vodafone's sell-off of Mannnesmann's premium assets continues," Klaus Esser, Mannesmann chairman, said. "This would destroy Mannesmann's superior growth prospects and destroy the opportunity for significantly greater value for our shareholders."

If Vodafone wins it will sell or float mobile phone group Orange, bought by Mannesmann last year. Chris Gent, Vodafone chief executive, said there was no intention to sell Orange to Vivendi.

He said he had not spoken to Mr Esser about the alliance with Vivendi. "The ball is now very much in his court."

Mr Gent said talks with Vivendi had begun in earnest in the past three months and denied it was to prevent a deal between the French group and Mannesmann.

Vivendi chairman Jean-Marie Messier said of the deal: "It is an ideal alliance between two partners with highly complementary profiles and it comes at just the right moment."

webTitle: NatWest will aim final salvo against both predators

fields.headline: NatWest will aim final salvo against both predators
fields.trailText: NatWest will tell its big shareholders this week that if they back either of the bids by its two Scottish assailants they could be left holding shares that underperform the banking sector by up to 40%.
fields.body:
NatWest will tell its big shareholders this week that if they back either of the bids by its two Scottish assailants they could be left holding shares that underperform the banking sector by up to 40%.

The besieged bank has two weeks to try to win the backing of its shareholders who today are expected to receive higher offers from Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland.

Sir David Rowland, NatWest chairman, stressed that bank mergers rarely work and said he would provide shareholders with figures from the US showing how stocks in merged groups fail to match the growth of independent rivals.

BoS, which raised its offer earlier in the four-month tussle, is offering to pay more for NatWest than Royal Bank which will disclose today that it has secured the backing from strategic partners to provide it with the extra ammunition to raise its £22.5bn bid.

Both banks are using their own shares to pay for NatWest as well as offering some cash. The cash component is expected to prove crucial in any decision made by investors. The bidders have until midnight tonight to make their best offers to NatWest and are expected to play a tactical game with neither wanting to show its hand first.

Royal Bank's strategic partners include the insurer CGU, which might entice French bank Société Générale to step in. CGU helped SocGen survive a hostile bid last year.

BoS, which is expected to raise its offer after an announcement by Royal Bank, will question how its rival's strategic partners will control any combined entity.

However, NatWest is expected to continue to warn shareholders of the risks associated with hostile takeovers.

fields.headline: Obsession gone dotty
fields.standfirst:
Yayoi Kusama
Serpentine Gallery, London
Rating: * * * *
fields.trailText: Now in her 70s, the Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama is a legend. This exhibition spans her career, yet somehow fails to give the full measure. It is still a terrific, troubling show. Her work is a conundrum.
fields.body:
Now in her 70s, the Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama is a legend. This exhibition spans her career, yet somehow fails to give the full measure. It is still a terrific, troubling show. Her work is a conundrum.

In the 50s she moved from Japan to New York, had an affair with Donald Judd and a relationship with an adoring Joseph Cornell. She filled vast canvases with thousands of white-on-white whorls, canvases which, though extremely beautiful, are frightening, when one considers the obsessiveness of their manufacture. Kusama covered canvases in the dots she had begun to see in hallucinations, and which spilled from her paintings onto shop mannequins, her own naked body and the garments she designed.

Part of her paradox is that she could make works so delicate as the white paintings (Judd called them "solid lace"), and go on to perform quaintly exhibitionistic naked street Happenings, to make inflatable vinyl environments, to replace the dot with dry pasta, and to exhibit shoes stuffed with phalluses. It is her forms, rather than the nature of her obsessions, which mutate. This is wonderful, vulgar, an art that overcomes difficulty by its accommodation.

 Until March 19. Information: 0171-402 6075

fields.headline: Boss from heaven
fields.standfirst:
Diane Glynn rated her employer so highly that she nominated her for an award. Hilary Whitney on a winning working relationship
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Diane Glynn rated her employer so highly that she nominated her for an award. Hilary Whitney on a winning working relationship
fields.body:
When Amanda Berry landed her first job in the media, as a junior assistant with a talent agency, it was through Pathfinders recruitment consultancy. Now the deputy chief executive of Bafta (the British Academy of Film and Television Arts), in November Berry was named the media boss of the year, an award coincidentally sponsored by Pathfinders.

During her time at Bafta, Berry has been assisted by Diane Glynn, who was originally her PA before being promoted - with Berry's encouragement and support - to events officer. It was Glynn who nominated Berry for the award. "My job changed very much because of the way Amanda works. I think if somebody else had had Amanda's role, my job would have been very different and I wouldn't have had the same opportunities," she says.

The media boss of the year award was set up to acknowledge and reward managers who have encouraged their staff to develop their careers. This seems to be second nature to Berry, who, since winning the award has been contacted by several former colleagues, eager to acknowledge her support over the years.

"I'm always keen to encourage people," she says. "I'm not the sort of person who thinks 'Oh God, if they move up the ladder then there's less room for me.' It's a terrible waste if people don't get the chance to fulfil their potential."

Berry has been a high achiever since her early career. She was a company director by the age of 23, representing some of the most illustrious names in the entertainment industry, including David Bowie and Paul McCartney. After four years she switched to a career in television, first as a researcher and then as a producer working on a range of programmes from current affairs to fashion. During a stint at Scottish Television she learned Gaelic so that she could produce television programmes in the language. She joined Bafta in 1998 as director of development and events, moving to her current post last year, when she was also honoured as one of the "women of the year".

But even the highest of flyers needs helpers. Soon after joining Bafta Berry assumed responsibility for organising its film and TV award ceremonies. "She already had a very heavy workload and when it increased, naturally mine did too," says Glynn.

"We spent the most frantic five months working on the awards. We would be working until 11pm and over the weekend on a regular basis. We had to organise everything from what knives and forks we were going to use to policing the area outside and arranging for a one-way traffic system. There were endless meetings, but luckily I went along too to take notes and I ended up learning an awful lot."

Initially, most of her time had been spent dealing with straightforward administrative duties such as dealing with correspondence, arranging meetings and looking after her boss's diary. But Glynn, who is an English graduate with an MA in text and performance studies, had never intended to be a career PA and was delighted when her boss began to give her more responsibility. "Diane picks things up terribly quickly," Berry points out. "She's terrific with people and I can trust her to do anything - which is so important. There are a huge amount of people involved with arranging these awards and they know that if they talk to Diane it's the same as talking to me - we're almost interchangeable." In her new role as events officer, Glynn organises events specifically for Bafta's members, although she still works alongside Berry on the awards, much to the deputy chief executive's relief.

The winner at the media boss of the year was announced at a party hosted for the four pairs of finalists. "Amanda was in the States on business so I had to accept the award on her behalf," says Glynn. "Luckily she had prepared a speech - 'just in case' - so I read that and said a few words of my own. It was quite nerve-wracking but exciting at the same time. Now I know how Bafta award-winners feel!"
